photochromic molecules is a very reasonable approach to control the structure of monomer units at will [7–10]. When a reversible transformation between two photoisomers having different absorption bands is induced by light of a specific wavelength region, fully regulated two‐state photoswitch of the monomer structure can be achieved. Furthermore, in comparison with other chemical reactions using chemical substance, photochromic reactions generally produce no chemical wastes, and their repeatability is a very intriguing property that is reminiscent of biochemical transformations and photoregulation systems omnipresent in living systems. Accordingly, many supramolecular chemists have designed a variety of photochromic monomer units and noncovalently polymerized them to establish diverse photoresponsive supramolecular polymers showing a photocontrollable degree of aggregation and/or supramolecular architectures. However, it has not been overviewed yet how photoinduced structure changes in monomer units can induce a variety of changes in the structures and properties of supramolecular polymers.
This chapter highlights how we can utilize photochromic molecules to control (i) the degree of supramolecular polymerization, (ii) the supramolecular polymerization process, and (iii) topologies of one‐dimensional chains. The first topic will be illustrated by focusing on photoresponsive supramolecular polymers based on host–guest and  metal-ligand  complexation (Section  2.2), complementary hydrogen‐bonding interactions (Section  2.3), and π–π stacking interactions between photochromic moieties (Section 2.4). For the second topic, supramolecular polymers based on π–π stacking interactions play important roles to discuss the underpinning principles (Section  2.4). The third topic will address specific design of supramolecular monomers inducing topological changes of one‐dimensional supramolecular chains, along with maintaining the degree of polymerization during photoisomerization (Section 2.5). The application of photochromic molecules for other functional materials, such as vesicles, micelles, gels, organic nanotubes, biomolecular systems, and molecular machines, are summarized in other important reviews [11–17], and hence we do not address these issues in this chapter. Photoresponsive liquid crystals, which are one of the important smart soft materials, can also be studied in the other chapters of this book.

sections.heading: 2.2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Host–Guest and Coordination Systems
sections.text:
The manipulation of association and dissociation events in supramolecular host– guest complexes by light has been attempted already in the late 1980s by Shinkai et al. [18]. A self‐complementary azobenzene derivative 1 bearing an ω‐ammoniumalkyl moiety on one end and a crown ether moiety on the other end was designed to  form crown–ammonium complexes either intermolecularly or intramole cularly (tail‐biting), depending on the isomeric form of the azobenzene core (Figure 2.1a). Although the polymerizable trans‐isomer affords only cyclic oligomers by the intermolecular complexation, upon trans‐to‐cis photoisomerization it transforms into a “dormant” monomer by the intramolecular complexation of the bent cis‐isomer. They have also developed photocontrollable polymeric
48 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
supramolecular complexes consisting of a ditopic azobis(benzocrown ether)  2 and an oligomethylene‐α,ω‐diammonium cation 3 (Figure  2.1b) [19]. This binary system also shows a similar result with that of 1. Accordingly, these systems already demonstrated a basic idea for creating photoresponsive supramolecular polymers based on host–guest supramolecular chemistry.
Cyclodextrin is one of the most important macrocyclic host molecules applied to numerous research fields [20–25]. Harada and coworkers developed a photoresponsive host–guest supramolecular polymer by using a stilbene‐ bridged bis(β‐cyclodextrin) 4 as a macrocyclic host and a ditopic adamantane guest 5 (Figure 2.2). The trans‐to‐cis and cis‐to‐trans isomerization of the stilbene‐bis(β‐cyclodextrin) 4 are reversibly controllable in aqueous solution with UV‐light irradiation at 365 and 254 nm, respectively. Rotating frame nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy (ROESY) analysis revealed that adamantane guest 5 can complex with both the trans‐ and cis‐isomers of 4 (trans‐ and cis‐4). The trans‐4 formed 1  : 1 supramolecular dimers or small assemblies with 5, which was suggested from concentration‐independent hydrodynamic radius (Dh) observed by pulse field gradient nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). Upon UV‐light irradiation with 365 nm, the Dh value became smaller with increasing concentration of the mixtures, which demonstrated  that  the photogenerated cis‐4 formed linear supramolecular polymers upon complexing with 5. AFM measurements showed that the mixture of trans‐4 and 5 produced only small objects with the overall lengths of c. 30 nm. Conversely, for the mixture of cis‐4 and 5, supramolecular wires with the overall lengths of c. 350 nm were visualized [26].
From the standpoint of versatile macrocyclic host molecules, pillar[n]arenes have attracted increasing interest owing to an outstanding applicability to various supramolecular systems based on host–guest chemistry [27, 28]. As the inventor of pillar[n]arenes, Ogoshi et al. established photoreversible supramolecular copolymerization of an azobenzene‐bridged bis(pillar[5]arene) 6 as a ditopic host with hexamethylenebis(pyridinium) 7 as a ditopic guest (Figure 2.3) [29]. Diffusion-ordered  NMR  spectroscopy  (DOSY) and 1H NMR analyses in dichloromethane‐d2 (CD2Cl2) revealed that the host–guest mixture of the trans‐ isomer of 6 (trans‐6) and 7 affords supramolecular copolymers in high concentration. Upon irradiation of the mixture with UV light (λ = 365 nm), a significant increase of the diffusion constant (D) was observed, indicating a disassociation of the supramolecular copolymers into relatively low molecular weight oligomers composed of cis‐6 and 7. The photoresponsive assembly and disassembly processes have been shown reversibly by alternating irradiation of the mixture with UV and visible (λ = 436 nm) light. Other host–guest supramolecular polymers including calix[n]arenes [30–32] and cucurbit[n]urils [33] have also been applied to photoresponsive polymerization/depolymerization systems. These photoswitchable host–guest supramolecular polymers can find a wide range of applications, for instance, self‐healable supramolecular gels and vesicles, controllable aggregation of particles, and others [34–37].
Metal–ligand interactions are also useful to construct well‐defined supramolecular architectures [38–40]. Huang and coworkers successfully prepared
a  photoresponsive metallosupramolecular polymer using a stiff stilbene functionalized with pyridine ligands [41]. They designed a stiff stilbene derivative 8 bearing two pyridyl groups as a ligand and a bis(trans‐Pt(II))benzene complex 9 as a precursor of the metal center (Figure 2.4a). Multinuclear NMR and ESI‐MS measurements showed that equimolar mixing of the cis‐isomer of 8 (cis‐8) with  bis‐Pt(II) complex 9 in CH2Cl2 yielded a discrete metallocyclic tetramer (cis‐82·92) with high efficiency. Upon UV‐light irradiation (λ = 387 nm) of the solution of the metallacycles, cis‐to‐trans photoisomerization of 8 occurred, which gave rise to the transformation from the discrete metallacycles to linear metallosupramolecular polymers (Figure  2.4b), as evidenced by dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements. Upon trans‐to‐cis back isomerization of 8 with UV‐light irradiation (λ = 360 nm), however, quantitative formation of the original discrete metallacycle was not observed as a result of a cis:trans ratio of 47 : 53 at a photostationary state (PSS). Instead, the average Dh of the resulting aggregates was larger than that of the original discrete metallacycles, suggesting the
52 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
formation of metallocyclic oligomers by integrative self‐sorting of cis‐ and trans‐8 with 9 (Figure 2.4b) [42]. The transformation between the linear metallosupramolecular polymers and the metallocyclic oligomers was photochemically reversible by alternating irradiation at the two wavelengths. The authors presumed that the photoresponsive transformation would proceed in an off‐ pathway mechanism. Transmission electron microscopic (TEM) analysis revealed that spherical nanoparticles formed by the discrete metallacycles converted upon UV‐light irradiation at 387 nm into long nanofibers with a width of c. 50 nm and a length of >1 μm.

sections.heading: 2.3 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Complementary Hydrogen Bonds
sections.text:
This section focuses on photoresponsive supramolecular polymers, wherein photochromic units are noncovalently polymerized through multiple hydrogen‐ bonding interactions. The high reversibility of hydrogen bonds plays an essential role in the dynamic properties of many supramolecular polymers. Because photoisomerization of azobenzene and other photochromic molecules generally occurs on subpicosecond to picosecond timescales, monomer units can change their structures upon absorbing light in the monomeric state supplied through aggregate–monomer exchange/reshuffling even though they are very tightly aggregated. The photoisomerized monomers should reassemble to form different assembled structures or even remain monomeric as a result of alteration of conformation or flexibility by photoisomerization.
Ghadiri and coworkers designed a pioneering photoresponsive supramolecular oligomer by using a peptide‐functionalized azobenzene 10, wherein two macrocyclic octapeptides can noncovalently dimerize through multiple hydrogen‐ bonding interactions (Figure 2.5) [43]. The trans‐isomer of 10 intermolecularly self‐assembled to form linear and polydisperse hydrogen‐bonded aggregates in chloroform (CHCl3). NMR studies revealed that upon UV‐light irradiation at 366 nm the linear aggregates transform into discrete species due to intramolecular hydrogen bonding. Although these photoswitchable assembled states are reversible, a remarkable resistance of the cis‐to‐trans thermal isomerization was observed as a result of the strong intramolecular hydrogen‐bonding interactions. An analogous effect was observed for the host–guest complex of 2 with alkali metal cations [44].
Complementary multiple hydrogen‐bonding (CMHB) interactions are essential for the biological recognition process and are one of the most powerful tools to control the organization of small molecular building blocks. High directionality and specificity with reversibility of CMHB interactions have motivated many  supramolecular chemists to create various supramolecular assemblies. For example, compounds having complementary centrosymmetric hydrogen‐ bonding arrays, such as DAD and ADA (D = hydrogen bond donor, A = hydrogen bond acceptor), are capable of assembling into cyclic or polymeric aggregates [45]. Because heteroaromatic compounds generally possess a rigid and geometrically well‐defined skeleton, they can be used as highly specific and directional
54 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
multiple hydrogen‐bonding modules. Needless to say, their high fidelity is epitomized by the base‐pairing in DNA and RNA strands. The conceptual background and studies of CMHB interactions organizing functional dyes and π‐conjugated systems have been addressed in several reviews [46–49].
Ureidopyrimidinone (Upy) is one of the most widely used CMHB units to prepare supramolecular polymers. A mono‐Upy derivative 11 has been known to dimerize in even CHCl3 with a high dimerization constant exceeding 106 M−1 [50]. Meijer and coworkers first demonstrated supramolecular polymers based on CMHB interactions by using a self‐complementary bis‐Upy derivative 12. To control the degree of polymerization of 12 by light, they developed a photoresponsive depolymerization system by in situ photogeneration of chain stopper 11 (Figure 2.6) [51]. For this purpose, they designed a “caged” stopper 13 protected with ortho‐nitrobenzyl ether group. Compound 13 was smoothly photodeprotected to give stopper molecule 11 by UV‐light irradiation [52], which can be confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Viscosity (ηrel) measurements of a supramolecular polymer solution of 12 in CDCl3 in the presence of 0.1 equiv. of 13 showed that after two hours of irradiation with UV light, the original ηrel value of 10.79 drastically decreased to c. 1.92, comparable to the value observed in the presence of 0.1 equiv. of externally added 11 instead of 13. The significant drop in ηrel value indicates that the formation of hetero‐ assemblies of in situ
552.3 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Complementary Hydrogen Bonds
photogenerated 11 with 12 inhibits the self‐ assembly of 12, leading to phototriggered depolymerization of supramolecular polymers of 12.
The open‐ and closed‐ring isomers of diarylethenes are generally  thermally inactive toward reversible isomerization [53, 54], which enables more stable and sustainable two‐state switching in comparison with azobenzene systems [55, 56]. Takeshita et  al. prepared a diarylethene derivative 14 functionalized on both ends by Upy quadruple hydrogen‐bonding groups (Figure  2.7) [57]. 1H NMR study of the open‐ring isomer of 14 (14open) in CDCl3 showed no shifts of the NH proton signals, and only small particles less than 10 nm were detected by DLS. The ring‐closing reaction of 14open proceeded in CHCl3 with a quantum yield of 0.26, indicating that the major and minor conformers are antiparallel and parallel, respectively [58]. DLS measurements showed that UV‐light irradiation (λ = 366 nm) of the CHCl3–ethanol (97 : 3) solution of 14open resulted in a gradual increase in the original particle size (<10 nm), which became constant at around 650 nm after three hours, indicating the formation of supramolecular polymers by the photogenerated closed‐ring isomer 14closed. Subsequent visible‐light irradiation (λ > 540 nm) decreased the particle size from 650 to 400 nm, whereas the resulting supramolecular aggregates with the size of c. 400 nm did not further collapse even after the ring‐opening reaction was accomplished. Conversely, after aging the solution at 60 °C for 30 minutes, the aggregates disassembled into the original small particles (<10 nm). The author concluded that the strong CMHB interactions prevent the large aggregates consisting of antiparallel 14open from disassembling into its own small aggregates.
Intermolecular photoreactions such as photocyclization and photodimerization reactions observed for acenes can also be applied to designing photoresponsive supramolecular polymers. Arai and coworkers employed a [4  +  4] photodimerization reaction to establish a photoreversible supramolecular polymer system [59]. Anthracene 15 equipped with an Upy moiety initially formed hydrogen‐bonded dimers in CDCl3 (Figure  2.8a). 1H NMR and UV–vis studies  showed that 15 undergoes photodimerization upon UV‐light irradiation (>310 nm) in CDCl3 to form the photodimer 16. The NH proton signals associated with intermolecular hydrogen bonds became broadened upon photodimerization, and the signals eventually became too broad to be observed after reaching a PSS (conversion = c. 80%), indicating the formation of oligomeric and/or polymeric assemblies consisting of 16. Considering the conversion yield at the PSS, hydrogen‐bonded oligomers of 16 should be capped with unreacted 15 (Figure 2.8b). The photoinduced oligomerization also showed thermal reversibility: upon heating the resulting oligomer solution at 125 °C, the retro‐reaction quantitatively proceeded with the rate constant of 3 × 10−4  s−1. Since the temperatures at which the half‐life of the photodimer is one hour are very different between a “head‐to‐head” photodimer (38 °C) and a “head‐to‐tail” photodimer (149 °C) for 9‐methylanthracene, the above result also suggests that the photodimer 16 has a “head‐to‐tail” conformation [60].
Yang and coworkers described a photoresponsive supramolecular polymer based on a stiff stilbene derivative 17 functionalized with Upy moieties (Figure  2.9a) [61]. Unlike azobenzene, cis‐to‐trans thermal isomerization of
592.3 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Complementary Hydrogen Bonds
stilbene is negligibly slow at temperatures below c. 147 °C [62]. 1H NMR and DOSY spectra of 17 (c = 5 × 10−2 M) in CDCl3 revealed that cis‐17 (at a PSS, >99%) forms two distinct species corresponding to a cyclic dimer as the major component and a monomer as the minor component. In contrast, trans‐17 (at a PSS, >99%) displayed smaller diffusion constants compared with cis‐17, indicating that trans‐17 can self‐assemble into supramolecular polymers. No critical point was observed for trans‐17 in viscosity measurements upon increasing its concentration. For cis‐17, however, the critical polymerization concentration (c. 0.1 M) was observed. On the basis of the viscosity measurements, it was proposed that the supramolecular polymerization of cis‐17 proceeds via a ring– chain exchange mechanism in concentrations above 0.1 M, whereas trans‐17 follows an isodesmic growth mechanism (Figure  2.9b). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observation at high concentration (0.4 M) revealed that cis‐17 self‐assembles into nanofibers with diameters of 0.3–3 μm and lengths of hundreds of micrometers, whereas trans‐17 forms a gel. UV‐light irradiation (λ = 365 nm) of the gel of trans‐17 caused the trans‐to‐cis photoisomerization to give cis‐17, leading to the dissolution of the gel.
Chi et al. reported a photoreversible transformation of hydrogen‐bond‐directed helical supramolecular polymers of a diarylethene derivative (S,S)‐18 to granular aggregates (Figure 2.10) [63]. The supramolecular chirality is governed by (S)‐ phenylalanine moieties of (S,S)‐18 and detected through excitonic coupling of naphthalimide chromophores cross‐linking diarylethene and (S)‐phenylalanine moieties of (S,S)‐18 (Figure 2.10a). In tetrachloromethane (CCl4), the open‐ring isomer of (S,S)‐18 ((S,S)‐18open) showed a sharp circular dichroism (CD) signal with a characteristic Cotton effect corresponding to the absorption regions of the diarylethene and naphthalimide chromophores. The methyl ester derivative of (S,S)‐18open showed much weaker CD signals compared with the carboxylic acid (S,S)‐18open, suggesting that (S,S)‐18open forms chiral supramolecular assemblies through intermolecular hydrogen bonding between the carboxylic groups. AFM visualized left‐handed helical nanofibers with a height of c. 6 nm and a helical pitch of c. 50 nm (Figure 2.10b). Upon UV‐light irradiation (λ = 365 nm) of the CCl4 solution of (S,S)‐18open, the CD signal remarkably decreased with the photoconversion of (S,S)‐18open to afford (S,S)‐18closed in 48% yield at a PSS. AFM showed the transformation of the original helical nanofibers into the granular particles (Figure 2.10c). The authors attributed this transformation to the rigidity of the diarylethene core, which hampers (S,S)‐18closed from adopting a helical geometry. This morphology transformation is completely photoreversible, as AFM imaging after the visible‐light irradiation (λ > 510 nm) recovered the original helical nanofibers with the active CD signals (Figure 2.10d). The optical isomer (R,R)‐18open showed the mirror image CD signal of the one observed for (S,S)‐18open, and AFM image for (R,R)‐18open confirmed right‐handed helical nanofibers. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations and molecular modeling, the authors proposed that the parallel conformer of (S,S)‐18open can self‐assemble through intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the carboxylic groups to form primary helical strands (Figure 2.10e,f ), which further organize into secondary helical fibers to accommodate the structural strain of the primary helical strands (Figure 2.10g). Considering this proposed assembled model, it can
612.4 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Stacking of Photochromic Molecules
be inferred that the photoinduced transformation could proceed via aggregate– monomer exchange, although the authors did not describe this (see Section 2.1).
Yagai et al. have designed a unique photoresponsive supramolecular polymer wherein the parallel conformer of a diarylethene monomer engages actively in supramolecular polymerization [64]. Based on the previous study on photoresponsive supramolecular complexes composed of a melamine‐functionalized diarylethene and a barbiturated merocyanine dye [65], they newly synthesized a tetratopic diarylethene receptor 19 bearing ditopic melamine groups on both ends and investigated the complexation with a ditopic tetraphenoxy perylene bisimide (PBI) guest 20, which has a propensity to form slipped (J‐type) aggregates (Figure 2.11a) [66, 67]. UV–vis titration experiments of 20 with the open‐ ring isomer of 19 (19open) in toluene revealed the formation of 2 : 1 supramolecular co‐assemblies [19open·(20)2]n, wherein the PBI chromophores form a J‐type stacking mode. AFM imaging of [19open·(20)2]n showed well‐defined nanofibers with lengths reaching nearly a micrometer‐scale regime (Figure 2.11b). A close‐ up AFM imaging revealed that the nanofibers have a helically twisted topology with a height of 2 nm and a helical pitch of 20 nm (inset in Figure 2.11b). Based on the spectroscopic and morphological observations, the authors constructed an oligomeric co‐assembly composed of the parallel conformer of 19open and the dimeric J‐type stack (J‐dimer) of 20 by means of force‐field molecular mechanics calculation, which could reproduce the helically extended structure due to the twisted geometry of 19 (Figure 2.11d,e). Upon UV‐light irradiation (λ = 313 nm) of the toluene solution of [19open·(20)2]n, photocyclization of 19open proceeded to afford 19closed while maintaining the J‐band. AFM observations revealed that the helical nanofibers were converted to granular nanostructures with diameters of c. 10 nm and heights of c. 1.2 nm (Figure 2.11c). Because the conrotatory photocyclization can proceed only from the antiparallel conformer of 19open [68, 69], aggregate–monomer exchange should occur to afford monomeric 19open, which quickly reaches parallel–antiparallel conformational equilibrium. The ring‐ opening reaction of 19closed by visible‐light irradiation (λ = 630 nm) reproduced 19open, and reconstructed the original fibrous nanostructures. This cycle could be repeated at least three times, thus demonstrating the photoreversibility of this supramolecular system. Notably, the granular aggregates composed of 19closed and the J‐dimer (20)2 cannot be obtained if 19closed and 20 were directly mixed. Accordingly, the J‐dimer as well as the granular nanostructures could form only through the photoconversion of supramolecular copolymers [19open·(20)2]n (Figure 2.11f ).

sections.heading: 2.4 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Stacking of Photochromic Molecules
sections.text:
In Section 2.3, we focused on photoresponsive supramolecular polymers whose main chains are formed by hydrogen bonds. Another fascinating approach to supramolecular polymers is the use of π–π stacking interactions between functional π‐conjugated molecules. Because most photochromic molecules have
632.4 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Stacking of Photochromic Molecules
fertile π‐conjugated systems, they are expected to self‐assemble into one‐ dimensional aggregates by proper functionalization with auxiliary interacting units. Moreover, photochromic molecules show fruitful changes in their molecular structures and chemical properties upon photoisomerization. This can be exploited to control or regulate the degree of supramolecular polymerization under proper conditions.
In the case of azobenzene, the trans‐isomer has a planar geometry favorable for π–π stacking, whereas the cis‐isomer has a bent conformation unfavorable for π–π stacking [70, 71]. Yagai et al. reported an archetypal example of photoresponsive supramolecular polymers consisting of azobenzene‐appended hydrogen‐bonded supermacrocycles (rosettes) [72–74]. A cyanurate dCA bearing sterically less bulky dodecyl groups aggregated complementarily with a bis(azobenzene)‐functionalized melamine 21 to afford rosette (21·dCA)3 in CHCl3, which further self‐assembles in nonpolar media into higher order columnar structures through π–π stacking interactions (Figure  2.12). At millimolar concentration regimes, this hierarchical association of rosettes resulted in the formation of elongated and entangled fibers organizing into organogels. Upon irradiation of cyclohexane organogels with UV light (λ = 350 nm), a gel‐to‐sol phase transition was observed even though the trans‐to‐cis photoisomerization efficiency was moderate (20–40% cis‐isomer, Figure 2.12b). The resulting solution phase could revert to the original gel phase with visible‐light irradiation (λ  =  450 nm) and subsequent aging (Figure  2.12b). Because the planarity of rosette (21·dCA)3 critically influences its stacking trend, even partial trans‐to‐cis isomerization of azobenzene moieties at the periphery can strongly deteriorate its supramolecular polymerization capability. In other words, the impact of photoinduced structural change of azobenzene on aggregation can be amplified through rosette formation. For a diluted supramolecular polymer solution, a similar photoresponsive behavior was confirmed by DLS measurements.
A photoresponsive behavior in contrast to the above example has been reported by Pavan and coworkers [75] for supramolecular tubular nanoassemblies composed of a V‐shaped chiral azobenzene amphiphile 22 (Figure 2.13a). The original design of this amphiphilic molecule has been reported by Lee and coworkers, who demonstrated that a series of the V‐shaped amphiphiles organize into tubular supramolecular polymers through the formation of hexameric supermacrocycles [76–79]. For trans‐azobenzene‐appended 22 (trans,trans‐22), the formation of tubular nanoassemblies in aqueous solution has been confirmed by TEM observation. The external diameter of c. 7 nm roughly corresponds to the estimated diameter of the hexameric supermacrocycle of trans,trans‐22 from molecular models (Figure 2.13b). A pronounced Cotton effect was observed for the absorption region of the azobenzene chromophore in CD measurements, indicating that supermacrocycles stack with an offset arrangement in a preferred handedness. Interestingly, a nonlinear disassembly process was observed upon irradiation of the nanoassemblies with UV light (λ  =  365 nm). The initial five minutes of irradiation resulted in a drastic decrease of the CD signal at 400 nm despite the fact that the fraction of photogenerated cis‐isomer was only 7%. In the absorption spectra, a bathochromic shift of the absorption maximum was observed. These complex behaviors were ascribed to the annihilation of the
66 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
helical twist due to the formation of cis,trans‐22 and cis,cis‐22, which were still embedded in the tubular nanoassemblies. The collapse of the tubular nanoassemblies was probed by fluorescent analysis using Nile red as an internal probe that could be encapsulated in the tubules. A gradual release of this lipophilic dye was observed after the UV‐light irradiation for c. 10 minutes, as shown by a steady decrease in the fluorescence signal from the dye. The authors proposed that photogenerated cis,trans‐22 and cis,cis‐22 give birth to strain energy that can trigger the depolymerization of the tubular nanoassemblies, and disassembly of the tubules takes place when the amount of these cis‐isomers reaches the critical concentration. If water‐miscible organic solvents such as acetonitrile were added as a co‐solvent, the depolymerization process more linearly responded to  the increase of the cis‐isomers. The observation indicates that a far‐from‐ equilibrated state could be achieved in pure water to show the initial lag regime by producing strain but not breaking the assemblies.
For synthesis of covalent polymers, light is one of the attractive energy sources that can initiate covalent bond formation in a chain reaction, e.g. living radical polymerization, click reaction, and thiol–ene and thiol–yne coupling reactions [80, 81]. With respect to supramolecular polymerization, if nucleation and/or elongation steps could be regulated by photoinduced geometrical change of monomer units, such a photoinitiated process may realize precise supramolecular polymerization. In this regard, poorly aggregative photoisomers, e.g. cis‐ azobenzene, are promising “dormant” monomers that can retard spontaneous nucleation. Recently, Sugiyasu and coworkers have successfully employed phototriggered supramolecular polymerization of an azobenzene monomer to realize photoregulated living supramolecular polymerization [82]. According to the typical design strategy for functional organogelators, they designed and synthesized an amide‐functionalized azobenzene derivative 23 (Figure 2.14a). In this study, cis‐23 behaves as the dormant monomer that can be activated for supramolecular polymerization through cis‐to‐trans photoisomerization. Upon cooling a hot methylcyclohexane (MCH)‐toluene (9 : 1) solution of trans‐23 to 10 °C, the azobenzene absorption band bathochromically shifted in a nonsigmoidal manner against temperature change, suggesting the formation of J‐type aggregates via the cooperative nucleation–elongation mechanism. AFM observation showed linear supramolecular fibers with lengths of several micrometers (Figure 2.14b). In sharp contrast, cis‐23, which had been prepared by cooling a hot solution of trans‐23 with UV‐light irradiation (λ = 351 nm), afforded amorphous films, indicating the less aggregative nature of cis‐23 due to its bent conformation. Upon irradiation of cis‐23 with visible light (λ = 520 nm), spontaneous nucleation of the photogenerated trans‐23 occurred when its concentration reached critical value (~1.0 × 10−5 M). Accordingly, careful visible‐light irradiation of cis‐23 can kinetically supply the active monomer. Based on these preliminary results, they irradiated the solution of cis‐23 with visible light ([cis‐23]  =  3.75 × 10−5  M) but in the presence of “seeds” of trans‐23 ([seed] = 1.25 × 10−5 M). Interestingly, the absorption spectra did not show the formation of free monomer trans‐23 upon visible‐light irradiation, but the direct growth of the J‐aggregates was observed. This observation suggests the successful photoregulated living supramolecular polymerization at the termini of seeds.
Indeed, the formation of nanofibers with controlled lengths and a narrow polydispersity were confirmed by AFM (Figure 2.14c,d).
Yagai et al. have applied phototriggered self‐assembly to prepare supramolecular polymers whose lengths are different from those prepared by thermodynamically controlled self‐assembly pathways. They previously reported that barbiturated naphthalene 24 can self‐assemble into well‐defined cylindrical supramolecular polymers through the formation of hydrogen‐bonded rosettes (Figure 2.15a) [83, 84]. To control the self‐assembly of 24, they newly designed and synthesized an azobenzene‐functionalized derivative 25 [85]. Upon cooling a hot MCH solution of trans‐25 to 20 °C, a hypsochromic shift was observed for
692.4 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Stacking of Photochromic Molecules
the absorption band of the azobenzene chromophores, indicating H‐type stacking upon supramolecular polymerization. The plot of this absorption as a  function of temperature “(cooling curve)” follows a nucleation–elongation mechanism. Notably, the subsequent “heating curve” corresponding to the depolymerization process shifted toward higher temperatures in comparison with the cooling curve, showing a higher critical temperature Te than the elongation temperature Te′ in the cooling process. The observed thermal hysteresis suggests that the polymerization proceeds under a kinetically controlled process, which was also supported by a van’t Hoff analysis. AFM analysis showed that lengths of aggregates of trans‐25 are dependent on the cooling rate. Lengths of slowly prepared aggregates (Aggslow) with a cooling rate of 1.0 K min−1 exceeded 1000 nm, whereas those of kinetically prepared aggregates (Aggfast) by fast cooling (quenching) were in the range of 50–400 nm (Figure 2.15c,d). Upon UV‐light irradiation (λ = 365 nm) of the MCH solution of Aggslow at 20 °C, trans‐ to‐cis photoisomerization occurred (Figure  2.15b, trans:cis ratio at a PSS is 79 : 21) but no significant morphology change was observed. Conversely, when a cis‐25‐rich CHCl3 solution was injected into MCH, amorphous films were imaged by AFM. Subsequent irradiation of the cis‐rich solution with visible light (λ = 470 nm) reproduced a trans‐rich state (trans:cis = 98 : 2) in a short period of 10 seconds, thus allowing supramolecular polymerization of the photogenerated trans‐25 under very kinetic conditions. This phototriggered kinetic pathway enabled the formation of short cylindrical nanofibers (Aggvis) with a narrower polydispersity index (PDI = Lw/Ln = 1.26) compared with Aggfast (PDI = 1.50) (Figure 2.15e,f ). Different size distributions of the aggregates were also shown by DLS measurements (Figure  2.15g). In the case of the phototriggered kinetic pathway, the more “supercooled” situation might be realized compared to the quenching procedure. In such a state where diffusion of the solute is not sufficient to supply monomers to the nucleus formed at the initial stage, further nucleation of monomers can take place, leading to the formation of a greater amount of supramolecular polymers with smaller aggregation numbers (shorter lengths) compared to those formed by the quenching procedure. These kinetically trapped small aggregates might be useful as “seeds” for living supramolecular polymerization [86, 87].
Unlike azobenzene‐based supramolecular monomers, the relative aggregation capabilities of the two isomeric forms of diarylethene vary depending on molecular design (Figure  2.16) [88–91]. For instance, in the case of amide‐ functionalized diarylethene 26 reported by Feringa and coworkers, the rigid closed‐ring isomer of 26 (26closed) can form thermally stable organogels in comparison with the open‐ring isomer 26open [88]. A similar trend was observed for an amphiphilic diarylethene 27 reported by Hirose et al., who found that 27closed can assemble into nanoaggregates in water through a π–π stacking interaction between the expanded π‐surfaces whereas 27open cannot assemble under the same condition [89].
In contrast, an inverse effect of the open‐ and closed‐ring isomers on the on/off switching of aggregation has been observed for a hydrogen‐bonding diarylethene 28 wherein the flexible open‐ring isomer 28open displayed higher solution viscosity compared with 28closed [90]. More prominent impact has been reported
70 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
by Yagai et al. They synthesized a diarylethene 29 equipped with highly aggregative oligo(p‐phenylenevinylene) (OPV) wings and found that 29open can form π‐ stacked nanoaggregates in MCH to form a gel (Figure 2.17b), whereas 29closed does not form the gel owing to the lack of extended assembly (Figure 2.17a) [91]. Based on a molecular modeling calculation, the authors proposed that the central two methyl groups of the diarylethene core of 29 can work as regulators for aggregation, because they are mobile by the rotation of thiophene rings in the open form, whereas in the closed form they align along the stacking direction (Figure 2.17c–f). This steric effect of the methyl groups should be pronounced if the aggregation is driven by π–π stacking interaction, which requires close contact between the building blocks. While the solution of 29closed can be converted to the gel of 29open by visible‐light irradiation (λ = 600 nm), the gel of 29open cannot be reconverted to the solution upon irradiation with UV light (λ = 313 nm). Because the two thiophene rings of 29open are fixed in a twisted conformation by strong aggregation, ring‐closure reaction might not be allowed.
A similar observation has been made by Ma et  al. for the supramolecular polymerization of a diarylethene‐introduced benzene‐1,3,5‐tricarboxamide (BTA) that has been extensively cultivated as a scaffold of the supramolecular monomer by Meijer and coworkers [92, 93]. A series of this C3‐symmetrical disk‐ shaped molecule has been shown to self‐assemble into robust one‐dimensional supramolecular structures owing to their high degree of functionalizability [94].

BTA supramolecular monomer 30 bearing three diarylethene units at its peripheral arms has been thus synthesized (Figure 2.18a) [95]. The FT‐IR spectrum of a toluene solution of the open‐ring isomer of 30 (30open) showed the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the amide groups. The fluorescence intensity of 30open in toluene was largely enhanced compared with that in dimethylformamide (DMF) at the same concentration (c  =  1 × 10−4  M), suggesting a fixed molecular arrangement that can restrict molecular motion. Hence, BTA 30open can form a one‐dimensional supramolecular structure through synergistic hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking interactions. SEM visualized crystalline one‐dimensional fibers. The photocylization of 30open with UV‐light irradiation
(λ = 365 nm) resulted in a low yield of the closed‐ring isomer of the diarylethene units according to the intensity of the new visible absorption band, which can be ascribed to the tight molecular packing of 30open. TEM observation revealed that the supramolecular fibers of 30open with diameters of 15–20 μm could be depolymerized by UV‐light irradiation (λ = 365 nm) for c. 1 hour. This process was photochemically reversible by ring‐opening reaction of the diarylethene units with visible‐light irradiation (λ > 450 nm) of the resulting solution of dissociated 30 (Figure  2.18b). Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations suggested that the conformation of 30close bearing three ring‐closed diarylethene units is unfavorable for aggregation compared with 30open due to the steric hindrance of the central methyl groups of the rigidified diarylethene units upon one‐dimensional stacking, which had been originally proposed by Yagai et al. (Figure 2.17). Such an adaptability of diarylethene for extended aggregation is one of the fascinating properties that support utilizing this remarkable photochromic molecule to create photoresponsive supramolecular polymers.
732.4 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers by Stacking of Photochromic Molecules
Recently, Ghosh and coworkers reported the phototriggered supramolecular polymerization of naphthalenediimide (NDI) by designing “caged” pro‐ monomer 31 (Figure 2.19) [96]. Compound 31 is protected on its amide site, responsible for aggregation, with an ortho‐nitrobenzyl group that has been also applied for the caged stopper 13 by Meijer and coworkers (Figure 2.6) [51]. Supramolecular monomer 32 self‐assembled upon cooling its hot MCH solutions to 15 °C to form entangled long fibrils as shown by AFM (Figure 2.19b). During cooling, the π–π* absorption band of the NDI chromophores underwent a redshift and the temperature dependence of this redshift followed a sigmoidal transition, indicating the formation of J‐type aggregates via the isodesmic mechanism. On the other hand, any self‐assemblies were not observed for the caged monomer 31, as shown by UV–vis and FT‐IR measurements. When the MCH solution of 31 (c = 1 × 10−3 M) was irradiated with UV light (λ = 254 nm), the ortho‐nitrobenzyl group was quantitatively cleaved to yield active monomer 32, leading to the gelation of the solution. During this phototriggered supramolecular polymerization, the Dh measured by DLS and the solution viscosity gradually increased in line with the conversion of caged 31 to activated 32. AFM images of the photogenerated supramolecular polymers showed spherulite structures (Figure 2.19c–e), which are different from the one‐dimensionally extended fibrillar topology observed for the spontaneous polymerization of 32 (Figure 2.19b). The authors suggested that the phototriggered supramolecular polymerization may occur via an in‐built growth mechanism, which is different from the spontaneous process. In the early stage of the photoelimination reaction of the caged 31, activated 32 could form co‐aggregates with 31 through hydrogen bonds, leading to morphology differences in the growth of supramolecular fibers.
Hirose et al. demonstrated an interesting strategy for control over the degree of supramolecular polymerization by photoswitching active/inactive states of monomers through metal–ligand complexation [97]. For this purpose, they employed symmetrically amide‐functionalized zinc porphyrin 33 bearing chiral aliphatic chains [98] and phenylazopyridine 34 possessing bulky mesityl groups as a Zn‐ligand (Figure 2.20a). The photoresponsive complexation of phenylazopyridine derivatives with metalloporphyrins had been well established by Inoue and coworkers [99] and Otsuki and Narutaki [100]. In a previous paper, Meijer and coworkers disclosed the self‐assembly of 33 as follows [98]. Upon cooling a hot MCH solution of 33 to 20 °C, the Soret absorption band hypsochromically shifted in a nonsigmoidal manner against temperature change, indicating a cooperative self‐assembly process. The self‐assembly of 33 showed a sharp CD signal with a characteristic Cotton effect in the Soret band of porphyrin chromophore, suggesting the helical stacking of porphyrin, which should be supported by amide–amide hydrogen bonding as shown by FT‐IR. AFM imaging visualized well‐defined fibrillar supramolecular polymers of 33 with micrometer lengths. To simulate the photoswitchability of the cooperative self‐assembly of 33 in the presence of 34, they designed a multiple‐equilibrium model using five parameters including equilibrium constants K2 and K in the cooperative process of 33 obtained by fitting the above temperature‐dependent data with a K2–K (dimerization–elongation) model, binding constants of the trans‐ and cis‐ isomer
76 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
of 34 (trans‐ and cis‐34) with 33 (Ktrans, Kcis), and the dimerization constant Kd of a porphyrin–pyridine complex 33·34 (Figure 2.20b). The Ktrans and Kcis were determined to be 3.6 × 104 M−1 and 8.1 × 103 M−1, respectively, by the titration experiment of N‐methylated derivative Me‐33 with trans‐34 (97% at PSStrans) and successive UV irradiation (λ = 360 nm) into cis‐34 (95% at PSScis). For Kd, the value of 33·pyridine was used because the dimerization process of 33 is independent of the ligand type. The simulation with the cooperative model in the presence of 40 equiv. of 34 predicted larger porphyrin stacks of 3100 monomers at PSScis while only 2% of short porphyrin stacks was predicted at PSStrans. Conversely, simulation with the isodesmic model resulted in a less photoinduced switchability of degree of polymerization, and porphyrin stacks of 22 monomers were estimated at PSScis. Taking into consideration the above simulation and the result of the titration experiment of 33 with trans‐34 as well as insufficient photoisomerization of 34 in the presence of porphyrins, they prepared an MCH solution of 33 containing 54 equiv. of trans‐34. When this solution was UV irradiated, trans‐34:cis‐34 = 10 : 90 was achieved at PSScis, and the growth of the Soret band and the CD signal suggesting the supramolecular polymerization of 33 was observed. The subsequent irradiation of the cis‐rich solution with visible light (λ = 420 nm) converted cis‐34 to trans‐34, which again disassociated supramolecular polymers of 33. The fraction of stacked porphyrin monomers increased significantly from 1% at PSStrans to 81% at PSScis, which is in good agreement with the simulated results (Figure  2.20b). These photoinduced depolymerization/repolymerization processes resulted in a change in viscosity from 0.637 to 0.704 cP for 4.0 × 10−5 M MCH solution of 33 upon trans‐to‐cis isomerization of 34 (c = 1.88 mM).

sections.heading: 2.5 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers with Photocontrollable 1D Topology
sections.text:
The photoisomerization of supramolecular monomers without breaking noncovalent interactions (without monomer exchange) is one of the challenging but intriguing research topics, because this could realize a topological control of supramolecular main chains. The topological control of one‐dimensional polymer chain is a key to induce a specific property beyond the functionality of monomer building blocks, as shown by the diverse topological features of proteins. To realize this, sufficiently strong intermolecular interactions are required between supramolecular monomers because their structural changes upon photoisomerization could cause significant changes in enthalpy and entropy associated with self‐assembly.
In this chapter, we focus on supramolecular polymers whose one‐ dimensional topology can be transformed by light stimuli in such a manner. In general, functions of naturally occurring and synthetic polymers are dominated not only by  the property of the monomer units but also by the topology of their one‐ dimensional chains. Photochromic molecules serve as an essential trigger in many important biological photoreceptors that can exhibit conformational changes. For instance, channel rhodopsins, the light‐gated cation channels, show
772.5 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers with Photocontrollable 1D Topology
a conformational transformation of one state to the other in response to light, finally leading to physiological responses such as opening/closing ion channels [101, 102]. Therefore, photocontrol over the topology of one‐dimensional supramolecular polymer chains is a fascinating and challenging research topic that paves the way for the creation of supramolecular polymers with dynamically controllable functions.
The research group of Stupp and coworkers has introduced photoresponsive units into their peptide amphiphile systems. For instance, they exploited a photoelimination reaction that triggered the untangling of supramolecular quadruple helical fibers composed of a peptide amphiphile 35 bearing a pentadecanyl chain (Figure 2.21) [103]. The photocleavable ortho‐nitrobenzyl group was introduced as a bulky substituent into the N‐terminal amide position of 35 (Figure 2.21a). Upon cooling a hot aqueous solution (pH 11) of 35 to 25 °C, the formation of quadruple helical fibers was observed by TEM (Figure  2.21b,c, arrow I). A closer inspection of the TEM image revealed that the entangled helix is formed by two smaller double helical fibers (arrows II), which are further composed of two nonhelical, cylindrical elementary fibrils (arrows III). The untangled double helical fibers and elementary fibrils were intertwined again with the neighboring supramolecular strands (Figure 2.21b, arrow IV). The elementary fibrils had a diameter of 11 nm, which was approximately twice as large as the calculated length of 35 (5.6 nm). The widths and pitches were 33 ±  2 nm and 92 ± 4 nm, respectively, for the quadruple helices, and 24 ± 1 nm and 106 ± 3 nm, respectively, for the double helices. In addition, both helices had right‐handed helical structures. FT‐IR studies revealed that the self‐assembly of 35 is driven by β‐sheet formation through hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic interactions between the amphiphilic chains (Figure 2.21c). The self‐assembly of 35 resulted in sharp CD signals in the absorption region of the ortho‐nitrobenzyl moiety, suggesting that the steric repulsion between the bulky substituents may induce higher order helical twisting. Accordingly, the irradiation of the aqueous solution of 35 with UV light (λ = 350 nm) for five minutes converted these higher order helical fibers into the elementary cylindrical fibrils with a diameter of 11 nm, which was demonstrated by TEM observation (Figure  2.21d,e). MALDI‐TOF MS and UV–vis analyses revealed that the ortho‐nitrobenzyl moiety was photoeliminated in c. 97% yield, thus producing deprotected amphiphile 36, which did not induce higher order helical architecture due to lack of the bulky substituent.
Similar photoinduced untangling of helically intertwined supramolecular polymers into linear fibrils has been reported by Yagai et al. (Figure 2.22) [104]. They designed a diarylethene derivative 37 bearing two monotopic melamine units and a ditopic cyanurate‐appended oligothiophene 38 (Figure 2.22a). The aggregation of these complementary components via CMHB interactions could lead to the formation of an ABAB type supramolecular copolymer (37·38)n (Figure 2.22b). The complexation between the open‐form isomer of 37 (37open) and 38 at 1 : 1 stoichiometry was confirmed by UV–vis titration experiments in cyclohexane, wherein the oligothiophene moiety of 38 quantitatively formed H‐type aggregates upon addition of 37open. At millimolar concentrations, gelation of cyclohexane was observed, suggesting the formation of elongated supramolecular polymers of (37open·38)n (Figure  2.22d, left). TEM and AFM observations
80 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
visualized thick helical fibers with widths of c. 20 nm (Figure 2.22c, left). Upon UV‐light irradiation (λ  =  313 nm) of the solution of (37open·38)n, ring‐closing reaction of 37open occurred and induced a structural transition of thick helical fibers into thin fibrils at a PSS (37open:37closed  =  13 : 87), as shown by TEM (Figure 2.22c, right). For the gel, this nanostructural transition induced a gel‐to‐ sol transition (Figure 2.22d, right). The original helical nanofibers were regenerated by visible‐light irradiation (λ = 602 nm) of the UV‐irradiated solution. This unique nanostructural transition could be attributed to the change in molecular rigidity of the diarylethene moiety upon the ring‐closing reaction. The supramolecular copolymers (37open·38)n would be flexible due to the twistable conformation of 37open, allowing the primary chains to further organize into higher order helical structures with folding and intertwining through the interchain π–π stacking between the pendent oligothiophene units of 38. On the other hand, due to a conformational stiffness of 37closed, supramolecular copolymers (37closed·38)n are unable to further organize into higher order structures, and exist as the primary structure.
In another example by Stupp and coworkers, photoresponsive supramolecular polymers have been constructed from a tripeptide amphiphile 39 bearing an azobenzene unit at one terminus (Figure 2.23a) [105]. In this system, the helical pitch of the superhelical nanostructure could be controlled by light. Amphiphile 39, when the azobenzene unit was the trans‐isomer (trans‐39), self‐assembled in cyclohexyl chloride to form superhelical nanofibers that were well visualized by AFM (Figure 2.23b). The superhelical nanofibers had a uniform helical pitch of 78 nm (Figure 2.23c,d). According to the mechanism proposed by the authors, trans‐39 first forms a “primary” helix, which further twists due to the torsional strain generated by steric repulsion between the bulky end groups (i.e. trans‐ azobenzene moieties). In other words, the bulky trans‐azobenzene moieties at the peripheries can be accommodated by helical twisting. Interestingly, UV‐light irradiation (λ = 360 nm) of the helical nanofibers in cyclohexyl chloride caused a decrease in helical pitches to 40–70 nm (Figure 2.23e–g). The photogenerated cis‐39 whose conformation was less planar (sterically bulky) compared with the trans‐conformer could induce the torsional strain, resulting in a reduction of the helical pitch. The resulting helical pitches varied from nanofiber to nanofiber, which arises from the inhomogeneity of the trans‐to‐cis isomerization efficiency of trans‐39 among nanofibers. Conversely, the helical pitch is uniform within each superhelix, indicating that the photoresponsive decrease of the helical pitches undergoes a relaxation process throughout the entire nanostructure.
Recently, an outstanding topological control of one‐dimensional supramolecular polymer chains has been accomplished by Yagai and coworkers [106] using barbiturated naphthalene–azobenzene hybrid molecule 40 (Figure 2.24a). They had previously found that a 2,6‐substituted naphthalene molecule 41 equipped with barbituric acid and aliphatic wedge self‐assembles via the formation of a hydrogen‐bonded rosette into toroidal nanostructures with a uniform diameter of c. 20 nm (Figure  2.24b,d,f ) [83, 107]. The size uniformity of the toroidal nanostructures established that naphthalene‐functionalized barbituric acid rosettes can continuously stack to generate spontaneous (uniform) curvature due to idiosyncratic internal order along the π‐stacked rosettes (Figure 2.24f ).
832.6 Summary and Outlook
The additional azobenzene π‐surface could strengthen the aggregation capability of the rosette, by which two important outcomes have been induced. First, the increased association force between rosettes prevented the growing supramolecular polymer chains from closing into discrete shorter assemblies, and instead yielded extended curved supramolecular polymers. Second, the strengthened rosette–rosette interactions allowed a direct deformation of columnar aggregates (supramolecular polymer chains) upon photoisomerization of the azobenzene moiety without monomer exchange (Figure 2.24c,e). When a hot MCH or CHCl3–MCH mixed solution of trans‐40 was cooled to 20 °C with various cooling rates, well‐defined nanofibers that ranged from randomly folded to helically folded supramolecular polymers were confirmed by AFM and TEM (Figure  2.24g). Upon UV‐light irradiation (λ  =  365 nm) of the solutions of trans‐40, these helical supramolecular polymer fibers (SPhelical) transformed into extended and unfolded fibers (SPlinear) via a randomly folded structure (SPrandom) (Figure 2.23g–i), indicating that photogenerated cis‐isomer‐containing rosette destroys the spontaneous curvature. Small‐angle X‐ray scattering (SAXS) analysis also showed a similar result, which indicates the deletion of spontaneous curvature upon UV irradiation. Subsequent visible‐light irradiation (λ  =  470 nm) that causes the cis‐to‐trans isomerization of cis‐40 allowed the extended fibers to refold up to the level of the randomly folded structure (Figure  2.24j). This topological transformation of supramolecular polymer fibers demonstrates that the photoinduced deformation of the folded structure of 40 can regulate the internal order of main chains by the deletion/recovery of spontaneous curvature, leading to control over higher order secondary conformation. Notably, mixing of two solutions exclusively containing folded and extended supramolecular polymers did not show any merging of these fiber morphologies, and each original fiber morphology has been confirmed upon aging for days. Based on this finding, the authors concluded that the photoisomerization of 40 proceeds within the supramolecular polymer fibers, and their unfolding/refolding undoubtedly occurs without aggregate–monomer exchange. As the observed photoinduced unfolding and refolding of supramolecular polymers is reminiscent of the protein unfolding/folding process, the authors expect that this study could advance the frontiers of supramolecular polymers toward applications by mimicking the functionality of biopolymers.

sections.heading: 2.6 Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Without any doubt, supramolecular polymers cannot hold a candle to covalent polymers in terms of bulk physical properties due to the reversible nature of main chains. However, such a weak point can turn into an exceptionally attractive property when one can successfully impart controllability in bond breakage and formation by using external stimuli. Thus, the implementation of host–guest recognition sites, complementary hydrogen‐bonding sites, extended π‐stacking moieties, and other noncovalent interacting sites to photoreactive units has been addressed by many supramolecular chemists to engineer a variety of supramolecular polymers exhibiting different types of photoresponse. Although the most
84 2 Photoresponsive Supramolecular Polymers
widely used photoreactive unit is azobenzene, similarly to other photoresponsive research fields, diarylethene as a molecular switch, stilbene as a photodimerizable unit, and ortho‐nitrobenzyl group as a photoelimination group have been successfully coupled with various supramolecular polymer systems.
From the viewpoint of supramolecular polymer backbones, a relatively unexplored system is one‐dimensional columnar structures formed from discotic molecules or supramolecules with extended π‐surface. Such π‐surface is available through the synthesis of C3‐symmetrical disk‐shaped molecules (e.g. BTA) and multicomponent rosette‐shaped supermacrocycles (e.g. barbiturated π‐ conjugated molecule). By introducing photoreactive units at the core or peripheries of these discotic building blocks, we would obtain fascinating photoresponsive supramolecular polymers that can control not only the polymerization/ depolymerization but also their one‐dimensional topologies without depolymerization. We believe that the latter approach sheds light on new responsiveness and the resulting functionality in supramolecular polymer chemistry.
