sections.heading: 3.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Bottom‐up fabrication of functional nanostructures and molecular devices from self‐assembling soft materials with tailored photonic properties is currently a burgeoning area of research. The liquid crystals (LCs) capable of forming self‐ organized, tunable one‐dimensional (1D) or three‐dimensional (3D) photonic nanostructures represent such an elegant system because of their unique ability to control the propagation of light by various external stimuli [1–8]. Light‐driven chiral molecular switches or motors in liquid crystalline media are of fundamental academic interest and technological significance since they could not only bring a new generation of multifunctional supramolecular 1D and 3D photonic materials with unprecedented properties but also exploit the benefits of light stimuli such as the ease of spatial, temporal, and remote control of the irradiation under ambient conditions [9–11]. These photoactive functional soft materials can be facilely fabricated from achiral liquid crystalline hosts by adding appropriate amount of a light‐driven chiral molecular switch or motor, and they have found many potential applications in color filters, polarizers, all‐optical displays, optical lasers, sensors, energy‐saving smart devices, and so on. Fundamentally, the photoresponsiveness of these supramolecular soft materials is a result of both molecular interaction and geometry changes in the chiral molecular switch or motor upon light irradiation, and one of their key features is the existence of a photonic bandgap (PBG) in the range of the wavelength of visible light, which sometimes extents to the near infrared (NIR) region and beyond. This PBG is analogous to the energy bandgap in the semiconductors and can exist in 1D cholesteric liquid crystals (CLCs), or 3D periodic superstructures such as blue phases (BPs), LC microdroplets, and microshells, depending on the number of directions in which the periodicity exists.
The ability of a chiral molecular switch or motor to impart a twist to an achiral LC host is usually quantified in terms of the helical twisting power (HTP), β, which is expressed by the equation β = 1/(pc), where c is the molar or weight concentration
Light‐Driven Self‐Organized Liquid Crystalline Nanostructures Enabled by Chiral Molecular Switches or Motors: From 1D to 3D Photonic Crystals Ling Wang and Quan Li
Kent State University, Liquid Crystal Institute and Chemical Physics Interdisciplinary Program, 1425 Lefton Esplanade, Kent, OH 44242, USA
92 3 Light‐Driven Self‐Organized Liquid Crystalline Nanostructures Enabled
of the chiral switch and p is the helical pitch of the LC. Photo isomerization of the chiral switch results in  the changes of the molecular conformation and HTP, which may lead to a change in the pitch or handedness of the chiral LCs [12–17]. One of critical challenges in this endeavor is the design and synthesis of light‐ driven chiral molecular switches with high HTP values that display large differences in HTP at their different isomeric states. High HTP values reduce the necessary concentrations of the chiral dopants, while large differences in HTP of the chiral dopants enable wide‐range pitch tunability of the photoresponsive chiral LCs. Therefore, light‐driven chiral molecular switches or motors based on diverse photoresponsive moieties have been developed to fabricate chiral liquid crystalline superstructures with superior photonic properties. Typical photoresponsive moieties include azobenzenes, dithienylethenes, spiropyrans, and their photoisomerization processes are illustrated in Figure  3.1. Azobenzenes could experience trans–cis isomerization under UV irradiation, and the cis isomer would be driven back to its trans form either by visible light or thermal relaxation [18]. Diarylethenes can transform from the colorless ring‐open state to the colored ring‐closed state under UV irradiation. The reverse process is thermally stable and can be only driven by visible‐light irradiations [19]. For spiropyrans, UV irradiation leads to the photochemical cleavage of C─O bond and the transformation from the initial colorless state to the colored merocyanine [20]. When the UV source is removed, they can thermally relax back to colorless initial states quickly. It should be noted that the large change in polarity and charge distribution could be obtained upon photoisomerization between the spiropyran state and the merocyanine state. The aim of this chapter is to highlight the current achievements in the field of light‐driven self‐organized liquid crystalline nanostructures enabled by chiral molecular switches or motors. Toward this end, we first introduce the recent advances in the development of light‐driven CLCs with 1D helical
933.2 Light‐Driven Cholesteric Liquid Crystals
superstructures by loading different photoresponsive chiral molecular switches or motors including chiral azobenzene, chiral dithienylethene, chiral spirooxazine, and overcrowded alkenes. Then, we move to a discussion of light‐driven BP LCs with 3D cubic nanostructures. We also address the recent endeavor in developing the light‐driven chiral liquid crystalline microdroplets and microshells. The last section of this chapter (Section 3.5) provides a perspective for the future scope of these emerging photoactive chiral liquid crystalline nanostructured materials. It should be noted that this chapter does not aim at including all accomplishments in this research field but rather points to important developments by introducing representative examples from different topics.

sections.heading: 3.2 Light‐Driven Cholesteric Liquid Crystals
sections.text: Cholesteric phase, i.e. chiral nematic phase, is a variant of the nematic, which spontaneously forms a macroscopic helical structure either when the LC molecules are inherently chiral or when chirality is externally introduced [21–27]. The presence of chirality causes the director profile to assume a twisted configuration throughout the medium. In the cholesteric superstructures, the LC molecules exhibit the spatial orientation in a helical manner along the helical axis, where the helical superstructures are typically characterized by handedness and helical pitch. Handedness describes the direction in which the molecular orientation rotates along the helical axis, while the pitch (p) is the distance over which the director rotates a full 360°. According to Bragg’s law, the cholesteric superstructure with homogeneous alignment could selectively reflect circularly polarized light (CPL) with the same handedness as its helix. The reflection wavelength (λ) is typically determined by λ = np, where n is the average refraction index of LCs. Many efforts have been made to fabricate a light‐ driven helical superstructure with tunable pitches by doping light‐driven chiral molecular switches with superior properties into achiral LC media. For example, the pitch of cholesteric superstructures becomes smaller upon light irradiations at appropriate wavelength, which enables the dynamic reflection color tuning from blue, green, to red and vice versa under light exposures at different wavelengths (Figure 3.2a) [28]. Furthermore, light‐driven dynamic handedness inversion of cholesteric superstructures has been obtained by doping unique light‐driven chiral molecular switches or motors into achiral LC media. Upon alternating UV‐ and visible‐light irradiations, the cholesteric helix of one handedness unwinds, and disappears at a critical point with infinite pitch, and then rewinds through self‐organizing into another helix of the opposite twist sense (Figure 3.2b) [29].

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Cholesteric LCs with Chiral Azobenzene Photoswitches
sections.text:
Upon light irradiations at appropriate wavelength, azobenzene‐based molecular  switches are known to exhibit reversible trans–cis isomerization, in which large conformational and polarization changes are often observed. The trans form of azobenzene exhibiting a rod‐like structure can stabilize the LC superstructure,
whereas its cis form exhibiting a bent-shaped structure destabilizes the LC superstructure. As a result of the dramatic difference in molecular geometry of the trans and cis forms, the HTPs of these geometric isomers are different, which in turn enables optical tuning of the cholesteric pitch and hence the PBG. In 1971, Sackmann reported the photochemically induced reversible color changes in photoresponsive CLCs prepared by doping azobenzene molecules into a non‐halide‐ based cholesteryl mixture [30]. The PBG reflection of the CLC mixture blue‐shifted from 610 to 560 nm upon irradiation with 420 nm light. Although the tuning range is quite narrow, this work is the first demonstration of reversible phototuning of cholesteric reflection colors, providing a pathway to the photoresponsive CLCs. In general, the HTP of the chiral molecular  switch in a CLC mixture depends on its structure of the molecules, the nature of the chirality, and the interaction with host molecules. To date, various azobenzene derivatives have been reported for this purpose, such as chiral mesogens doped with achiral azobenzene molecules, pure photoresponsive chiral mesogens, and nematic LC doped
953.2 Light‐Driven Cholesteric Liquid Crystals
with  photoresponsive chiral dopants [31–38]. Recently, the studies are mainly focused on the design and synthesis of powerful chiral azobenzenes that exhibit high HTPs as well as large HTP variations upon light irradiation.
Kurihara and coworkers synthesized a series of isosorbide‐ or isomannide‐ based chiral photochromic compounds with plural azobenzene groups, and the resulting azobenzene photoswitches exhibited high HTPs as well as large HTP variations upon light irradiation [34]. Gottarelli and coworkers introduced the photoresponsive chiral azobenzene based on the binaphthyl derivatives with axial chirality, where the unique combination of binaphthyl with azobenzene units was expected to generate a family of axially chiral azobenzene photoswitches with high HTPs [39, 40]. Li et al. have developed a series of binaphthyl‐ derived axially chiral azobenzene compounds [41–46]. These chiral switches have superior solubility in LC hosts and exhibit high HTP values and considerable differences in HTP among their various states, and they were all found to be capable of phototuning the reflection color across the full visible spectrum. Some of these compounds have been employed in the fabrication of chiral photodisplays, which do not require the driving electronics usually used in conventional electro‐optic LC displays. Absence of the driving electronics drastically brings down the cost of such displays and makes them lightweight [47, 48].
Some breakthroughs have been made when the binaphthyl‐derived axially chiral azobenzene was functionalized with rod‐like moieties, where the rod‐like units in these chiral dopants resemble the molecular structure of nematic hosts made of rod‐shaped molecules. It should be noted that these compounds displayed greater compatibility with the nematic hosts and exhibited exceptionally high HTP values. For example, a light‐driven chiral molecular photoswitch as shown in Figure 3.3a was found to exhibit high HTPs and superior solubility in achiral LC hosts, which could be used to develop an optically tunable helical superstructure capable of fast and reversible phototuning of the structural reflection across the entire visible region [49]. To be specific, a mixture of 6.5 wt% chiral photoswitch in nematic LC E7 was capillary filled into a 5‐μm thick glass cell with a polyimide planar alignment layer and the cell was painted black on one side. The reflection wavelength of the cell could be tuned starting from the UV region across the entire visible region to the NIR region upon UV irradiation at 365 nm (5.0 mW cm−2) within approximately 50 seconds, whereas its reversible process starting from the NIR region across the entire visible region to the UV region was achieved by visible light at 520 nm (1.5 mW cm−2) or dark thermal relaxation. The reflection colors across the entire visible region were uniform and brilliant as shown in Figure 3.3b,c. The reversible phototuning process was repeated many times without degradation. It is worth noting that the reversible phototuning process across the entire visible region can be achieved in seconds with the increase of light intensity. Furthermore, this chiral switch was used in a photo‐addressed colored LC display driven by light and hidden as well as fixed by the application of an electric field from thermal degradation. As illustrated in Figure 3.3d, the reflective image can be hidden in focal conic texture by applying a 30 V pulse and revealed by applying a 60 V pulse. Moreover, by applying a 30 V pulse to an optically written image so as to make the UV irradiated region going to the focal conic texture and the UV un‐irradiated region going to the planar
973.2 Light‐Driven Cholesteric Liquid Crystals
texture, an optically written image can be stored indefinitely because the planar and focal conic textures are stable even though the light‐driven chiral switch relaxes to the un‐irradiated state. It should be noted that wide‐range nonmechanical beam steering has been demonstrated by using CLCs with such rod‐like molecule‐functionalized axially chiral azobenzene [50]. More recently, we reported the first example of a novel halogen‐bonded light‐driven axially chiral molecular switch, where pyridyl‐substituted binaphthyl azobenzene served as a halogen‐bond acceptor and the 4‐iodotetrafluorophenyl derivative as a halogen‐ bond donor [51]. This chiral molecular switch was found to exhibit both optical and thermal sensitivity, which enabled red, green, blue (RGB) reflection colors by different light irradiations or by temperature control. This study provides valuable knowledge on the rational design of efficient light‐driven switches or motors for amplification and modulation of chirality in dynamic functional soft matter and nanosystems.
Li and coworkers have achieved reversible visible‐light‐driven dynamic tuning of RGB reflection colors in CLCs by designing a novel light‐driven chiral azobenzene molecular switch with extended conjugation [52]. Wang et al. looked toward the possibility of dynamic reflection tuning of cholesteric superstructures by remote NIR irradiation (Figure  3.4) [53]. The upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) are known to emit UV and visible light upon NIR exposures [54, 55]. A unique core–shell UCNPs was designed and synthesized, where the intensity ratio of its emissions at different wavelengths was highly dependent on the excitation power density of the NIR irradiation. Then they developed a novel chiral azobenzene photoswitch whose UV and visible absorptions exhibit significant
98 3 Light‐Driven Self‐Organized Liquid Crystalline Nanostructures Enabled
overlap with the emissions of the UCNPs. The photoresponsive CLCs were formulated by mixing the azobenzene photoswitch and the UCNPs with an achiral liquid crystalline host composed of commercially available components. The resulting nanoparticle impregnated cholesteric superstructure exhibited reversibly tunable RGB reflections by simply changing the power density of the NIR irradiation at 980 nm. The reflection wavelength of such a cholesteric hybrid superstructure redshifted upon NIR irradiation at high power density, whereas the reverse process occurred upon irradiation at lower power density. Such UCNP‐assisted photochemistry shall provide important insights into the future fabrication of NIR‐photoactive advanced soft materials.
Yu and coworkers demonstrated piecewise RGB reflection tuning of CLCs by developing a photoresponsive tristable chiral molecular switch [56]. The tristable chiral switch was constructed by incorporating two different photoresponsive azobenzene switches, i.e. parent azobenzene (Azo) and o‐fluoroazobenzene (F‐Azo), into one binaphthyl‐derived chiral structure with high HTP (Figure 3.5a). It should be noted that trans–cis isomerization of F‐Azo can be achieved by the irradiations with both UV light and visible light due to the good separation of the n–π* bands of trans and cis isomers. The resulting light‐driven tristable chiral switch was found to exhibit three different photostationary configurations, i.e. configuration I (trans, trans, trans, trans) upon irradiation with 470 nm light, configuration II (cis, trans, trans, cis) upon irradiation with 530 nm light, and configuration III (cis, cis, cis, cis) upon irradiation with 365 nm light as shown in Figure 3.5b. The CLCs loaded with the tristable chiral switch showed two tuning periods of cholesteric reflection upon appropriate light irradiations, i.e. one period tuned in the visible spectrum and another period in the NIR region (Figure 3.5c). To be specific, upon light irradiation at 470 and 530 nm, the CLCs show dynamic selective reflection in the visible spectrum covering the three primary RGB colors, whereas wide reflection tuning in the NIR region was achieved under irradiation with 530 and 365 nm light. Moreover, photoaddressable images of dynamic RGB colors with black background were further demonstrated based on this mechanism (Figure 3.5d).
Light‐driven dynamic handedness inversion of CLCs has attracted increasing attention due to its fundamental significance and the advantages of remote, spatial, and temporal controllability. One can achieve light‐driven dynamic handedness inversion through opposite‐handed doping of powerful photoresponsive chiral switch and photoinsensitive chiral molecules into achiral LCs [57–60]. This method can eliminate the need for complicated molecular design of chiral switches, but handedness inversion often occurs in infrared regions due to the limited solubility of photoresponsive chiral switch and poor miscibility between two dopants. Many strategies have been developed for the rational molecular design of single chiral molecular photoswitches that could confer handedness inversion capability to CLCs, but the event of light‐driven handedness inversion using such methodology is often encountered by chance. Mathews et al. found that light‐driven reversible handedness inversion of CLCs could be achieved by judiciously designing and synthesizing a chiral cyclic azobenzene photoswitch based on axially chiral binaphthyl derivatives [61]. Recently, Li et  al. further reported a novel design strategy based on the chiral conflict and equilibrium
shifting between multiple chiral moieties in a single molecule [62]. These molecular engineered chiral switches were found to confer handedness inversion in different LC hosts upon light irradiation with moderate to high HTPs, where the chirality of each chiral moiety does not need to be reversed. Since the R and S configuration of unbridged binaphthyls normally will induce right‐ handed and left‐handed CLCs, the design strategy is to incorporate multiple chiral binaphthyls with opposite chirality into a single molecule functionalized with photoresponsive groups, and helix inversion was thus achieved based on the chiral conflict and equilibrium shift between these chiral moieties. Using the same principle, Guo and coworkers demonstrated light‐directed dynamic handedness inversion of CLCs by developing intermolecular hydrogen‐bonded chiral azoarenes containing binaphthyl units of opposite chiral
100 3 Light‐Driven Self‐Organized Liquid Crystalline Nanostructures Enabled
configuration [63]. This principle should be applied to other photoresponsive systems toward dynamic chirality inversion capability.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Cholesteric LCs with Chiral Diarylethene Photoswitches
sections.text:
Compared with chiral azobenzene photoswitches, chiral diarylethenes possess the advantage of thermal irreversibility in both the open‐ and closed‐ring isomeric states. However, only a few derivatives of diarylethenes have been reported as chiral molecular dopants with applications as liquid crystalline phase switches [64–66]. Most of the reported chiral diarylethenes exhibit low to moderate HTPs and are not suitable for reflection wavelength tuning. These relatively low HTPs also give rise to the requirement of higher doping concentrations, which often leads to phase separation, coloration, and physical property changes of the LC host. Therefore, it would be of great practical interest to develop chiral diarylethenes with high HTPs as well as large HTP variations upon light irradiation. It was not until recently that we reported some chiral diarylethene switches for wide range reflection color tuning. Li et al. reported the first diarylethene switch with axial chirality, high HTPs, and large HTP variations upon light irradiation for wide‐range reflection color tuning (Figure 3.6a) [67]. When doping 0.4 wt% of the dithienylethene photoswitch into the achiral LC host, an achiral LC phase was initially obtained but would transform into the cholesteric upon UV irradiation and vice versa. A higher doping concentration of 7.7 wt% was used for phototuning of the RGB reflection colors of CLC mixtures (Figure  3.6b). The reflection central wavelength of this mixture was around 630 nm at the initial state. Upon UV irradiation, its reflection wavelength was tuned to 530 nm within 10 seconds and further reached a photostationary state in 25 seconds with a reflection central wavelength at 440 nm (Figure 3.6c). This photoinduced state was thermally stable and could be photochemically switched back to a nearly initial state by visible‐light irradiation at 550 nm within two minutes. Furthermore, the three primary RGB colors were simultaneously demonstrated in a single thin film by varying UV irradiation times and photomasking at different areas.
Binaphthyl‐derived chiral  diarylethene switches, i.e. dithienylcyclopentenes, were also demonstrated to enable light‐driven dynamic handedness inversion of CLCs with excellent thermal bistability and excellent fatigue resistance [68, 69]. It is believed that the reversible handedness inversion in these systems originated from the conformation change of binaphthyl moieties as well as the stereospecific intermolecular interactions between the binaphthyl moieties and the surrounding nematic LC molecules. Recently, Wang et al. achieved NIR‐light‐driven dynamic handedness inversion of CLCs by designing and synthesizing a novel category of core–multishell UCNPs and a binaphthyl‐derived diarylethene chiral photoswitch (Figure 3.7) [70]. The UCNPs acting as the NIR nanotransducers are composed of dual lanthanide upconverting activators, i.e. Tm3+ and Er3+ in separate layers, where the Tm3+ and Nd3+ ions were bridged by an array of Yb3+ ions, and the Er3+ ions were separated by an optically inert interlayer. The core– multishell nanotransducers were found to exhibit UV and visible luminescence on demand from the individual UCNPs by selective excitation with NIR light at two different wavelengths of 808 and 980 nm. Interestingly, the UV and visible
luminescences from the nanotransducers were able to drive reversible photocyclization of the chiral diarylethene molecular switch due to the synergetic interaction between the switch and the nanotransducers. The CLCs loaded with such chiral diarylethene photoswitch and UCNP nanotransducers exhibited reversible handedness inversion upon irradiations with NIR light of different wavelengths. Furthermore, Wang et  al. also reported NIR‐light‐directed dynamic
reflection of both left‐ and right‐handed CPL through the visible range spanning the RGB wavelengths by developing novel CLCs loaded with mesogen‐modified gold nanorods (GNRs) [71]. These studies provide significant impetus toward the development and realization of light‐driven functional soft materials for promising photonic applications where CPL is involved.
Recently, Zheng et al. reported the breakthrough of light‐driven 3D control of the helical axis in cholesteric superstructures by using the same chiral diarylethene photoswitch [72]. Upon continuous irradiation with UV light, the standing helix transformed to a lying state and the lying helix rotated in the plane of the LC cell until the system reached its photostationary state (Figure 3.8). The system can be driven back in the opposite direction by visible‐light irradiation. Facile 3D control over the helical axis of the cholesteric superstructures has also been utilized in a specially engineered bilayer LC cell to obtain 2D diffraction gratings. Interestingly, reversible transformation between 2D to 1D and 1D to zero‐dimensional (off state) diffraction states has been achieved under alternating UV‐ and visible‐light irradiations. The helical
axis of cholesteric superstructures could be controlled by surface alignments or by applying external voltage, which builds the foundation for their practical application such as reflective displays, thermography, mirrorless lasing, and tunable color filters [73–79]. This work is a step toward the realization of complex, light‐activated smart systems and dynamic, reconfigurable 3D architectures through dynamic, remote, and continuous control over the helical axis in 3D space.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Cholesteric LCs with Chiral Spirooxazine and Overcrowded Alkenes
sections.text:
Spirooxazines are an interesting family of photochromic materials due to their unique properties such as excellent photofatigue resistance, strong photocoloration, and fast thermal relaxation. The fatigue resistance of spirooxazines has led to their successful use in various applications including commercialized eyewear. Since the spiro‐carbon of a spirooxazine molecule has potential as a chiral center, spirooxazines could be used as chiroptical molecular switches. However, spirooxazines usually exist as racemates. Even if the enantiomers are separated, each enantiomer is racemized by thermal and optical interconversions. Therefore, if the spirooxazines are utilized as chiroptical molecules in achiral nematic LC systems, modification of the spirooxazine with a chiral group is required. Accordingly, Jin et  al. synthesized a series of binaphthyl‐ derived axially chiral spirooxazines [80, 81]. Light‐driven cholesteric superstructures with fast thermal relaxation have been demonstrated by using such chiral spirooxazines. However, much effort is still needed to achieve the chiral spirooxazine photoswitches that exhibit high HTPs as well as large HTP variations upon light irradiation.
In addition to chiral azobenzene, diarylethene, and spirooxazine, chiral overcrowded alkenes have also been intensively studied. Feringa et al. pioneered the sterically overcrowded alkenes with intrinsic helical conformations, which are able to induce handedness inversion of the cholesteric helix when used as chiral dopants [82–87]. These types of molecules are also found to be capable of tuning the reflection colors in CLCs. Take the light‐driven chiral motor in Figure 3.9a as an example [90]. Its initial HTP at (P, P)‐trans form in nematic E7 is +99 μm−1, but generation of a cholesteric helix with an opposite sign of similar pitch is impossible, as the (M, M)‐trans form possesses a minor negative HTP (βM = −7 μm−1, E7). As a result of the high HTP at (P, P)‐trans form, colored LC films were easily generated using this dopant. Photochemical and thermal isomerizations of the motor lead to irreversible color change in the LC film as shown in Figure 3.9b [88]. Interestingly, remarkable stripe rotations were observed in an open film of a photoresponsive CLC with this chiral overcrowded alkene placed on a glass substrate treated with a unidirectional alignment layer, and the collective action of overcrowded‐alkene‐based molecular motors embedded in the cholesteric matrix has been harnessed to controllably rotate microparticles with remote light

sections.heading: 3.3 Light‐Driven Blue Phase Liquid Crystals
sections.text:
Liquid crystalline BPs are among the most interesting self‐organized superstructures in the field of LCs, which are known to self‐organize into 3D periodic cubic nanostructures [95–97]. This phase usually exists only over a narrow temperature range before the CLCs clear to the isotropic liquid. Similar to CLCs, BPs can be observed either in pure chiral mesogens or can be induced from achiral LCs by adding chiral dopants. The cubic nanostructures are characterized by the double twist cylinders (DTCs) that are stabilized by disclinations. Normally, when chirality in the LC system is high enough, DTCs are more stable than a simple twist structure. However, DTCs cannot be densely packed to fill the entire space and disclination lines appear at the interstices among the cylinders to form a stabilized 3D cubic structure [98–109]. There are three types of BPs reported, namely, BPIII, BPII, and BPI, which are usually observed during cooling from the isotropic to the cholesteric phase in the order of decreasing temperature. BPI and BPII have body‐centered cubic and simple cubic structures, respectively, while BPIII is amorphous in nature. BPI and BPII are periodic in three dimensions and the periodicity is typically on the order of the wavelength of visible light. These nanostructures enable BPs to reflect light in the visible region and have been recognized as promising soft self‐assembled 3D photonic crystals in recent years [110–112].
Light‐driven self‐organized BP 3D cubic nanostructures that display distinctive photonic reflection in the three orthogonal directions have received increasing attention, especially in recent years, but the reflection wavelength tuning is usually quite narrow [113–115]. The ability to dynamically tune the PBG in cubic BPs across a wide wavelength range is highly desirable, but it has not been realized due to various obstacles including the instability and irreversibility of BPs under the light irradiations. Li and coworkers made a breakthrough of phototuning full visible range reflection in BPs by using an axially chiral azobenzene photoswitch as shown in Figure 3.10a,b [116]. The initial phase of the doped BPs was the BPII with (100) lattice confirmed by the Kossel diagram as shown in Figure  3.10d (0 second) with a blue reflection color as shown in Figure  3.10c (0 second). Upon 408‐nm light irradiation, photoisomerization of the azobenzene dopant enlarged the size of the BP lattice and shifted the corresponding reflection toward a longer wavelength. Increasing the irradiation time resulted in occurrence of the phase transition from BPII to BPI, which might be attributed to the chirality decrease with dopant isomerization. After the photoinduced phase transition took place, the lattice direction changed from (100) of BPII to (110) of BPI with the corresponding change of reflection wavelength from 520 to 575 nm. Subsequently, a redshift in reflection upon further irradiation at 408 nm was observed in BPI. If the irradiation was stopped at any time, the wavelength of the selective reflection does not change, except by the very slow thermal
relaxation effect of the dopant toward its initial trans form. The rapid reverse process can occur photochemically with 532‐nm light irradiation. Figure 3.10c shows BP images with various durations of pumping observed under a crossed polarized optical microscope at reflection mode. Upon 408‐nm light irradiation, the reflection color of the BP thin film changed from blue (BPII) to red (BPI) within 15 seconds. The BP thin films were also indexed using a Kossel diagram as shown in Figure  3.10d. Both blue and green images in Figure  3.10c corresponded to (100) lattices of BPII, while both yellow–green and red images represented (110) lattices of BPI. Figure 3.10d also exhibited the variation of the Kossel diagram with different exposure times at 408 nm. As the irradiation time increased from 0 to 15 seconds, the circle patterns of the (100) lattice of BPII enlarged, switching to a diamond‐shaped pattern corresponding to the (110) lattice of BPI, and gradually shrinking. It is noteworthy that increasing the dopant concentration shifted the initial BP reflection to the UV region, which was tuned across the entire visible region with a broad range upon 408‐nm light irradiation,

and the reflection bands of BPII redshifted from the UV to 520 nm. Once BPII transformed into BPI, the corresponding reflection bands discontinuously jumped to 560 nm, which was further redshifted from 560 to 710 nm within the BPI state.
Wang et  al. demonstrated NIR‐light‐driven dynamic tuning of 3D BP nanostructures by incorporating hydrophobic mesogen‐functionalized GNRs (M‐ GNRs) into a temperature‐sensitive BP medium composed of commercially available components [117]. Owing to the excellent thermoresponsive properties of BPs, their 3D nanostructures could be manipulated with the “photothermal effect” of M‐GNRs, i.e. converting NIR light into heat through a non‐radiative relaxation process of longitudinal surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) [118– 120]. In the experiment, the liquid crystalline composites doped with 0.07 wt% concentrations of M‐GNRs were prepared by dispersing the M‐GNRs into BP LCs. On cooling from isotropic phase, BPII firstly appeared at 46.4 °C and then transformed into BPI at 44.1 °C. As the temperature was further decreased to 37.2 °C, the phase completely changed into the cholesteric phase (Figure 3.11a). Additionally, the BPs formed the characteristic platelet textures, and the reflection color gradually changed to a longer wavelength with decreasing temperature. Kossel diagram was used to verify the BP lattice structures upon changing the temperature as shown in Figure  3.11b. The isotropic phase did not yield any Kossel diagram. A prominent circular pattern appeared in the temperature range of BPII, which resulted from the (100) lattice of the simple cubic BPII. As the temperature decreased from BPII to BPI, the diffraction ring switched to the characteristic diamond‐shaped pattern corresponding to the (110) lattice of body‐centered cubic BPI. The introduction of M‐GNRs was not only beneficial in stabilizing the cubic nanostructure, but also enabled the dynamic control of 3D BP nanostructures between body‐centered cubic and simple cubic symmetry under irradiation using an 808‐nm NIR laser due to the significant photothermal effect of M‐GNRs (Figure 3.11c). The reverse process occurs upon removal of the NIR laser irradiation. Furthermore, dynamic NIR‐light‐directed RGB reflections were for the first time demonstrated by tuning the lattice constant of the light‐driven 3D soft photonic crystals.
More recently, Zheng et al. demonstrated light‐directed crystallographic patterns of self‐organized 3D BP nanostructures by using a photoalignment technique (Figure 3.12) [121, 122]. The basic idea is that the cubic nanostructures of BPs exhibit a uniform crystallographic orientation on both microscopic and macroscopic scales at the UV‐light‐exposed areas, and a random orientation at the unexposed areas. As a result, various desired patterns of uniform crystallographic orientation could be obtained in a BP cell with appropriate patterned photoalignment treatment on one substrate. Interestingly, such an alternate uniform and random orientation pattern formed by the BP lattice could exhibit interesting optical diffraction and responsiveness to different external stimuli. The resultant crystallographic patterns could be reversibly erased and rewritten on demand by light thanks to the rewritable trait of the photoalignment thin film. This work could provide important insights on the controllability of crystallographic orientation of functional soft materials and their diverse photonic applications.
3.4 Light‐Driven Chiral Liquid Crystal Microdroplets and Microshells
Self‐organized 3D superstructures with spherical configurations have recently received considerable attention in the forefront of multitudinous research areas, such as optical sensors or manipulations, soft photonics, and microfluidics [123]. Liquid crystalline microdroplets and microshells, i.e. confining LCs in micrometer‐ or nanometer‐sized superstructures, represent an elegant example of the topic. Recent advances of microfluidic techniques have enabled the fast, simple, and convenient fabrication of stable 3D monodisperse microdroplets with controllable symmetry, shapes, and sizes [124]. Fan et al. demonstrated
the photonic cross‐communication between monodisperse CLC  microdroplets, where their self‐assembly was precisely manipulated by using the microfluidic method [125–127]. Only a central reflection spot was observed in the isolated single microdroplet due to the absence of any lateral communication (Figure 3.13a). In the groups of two or more microdroplets, it was surprising that the reflection‐related interactions were found between neighboring microdroplets (Figure 3.13b–e). When the microdroplets are densely packed into the hexagonally symmetric monolayer, the circular “lit fire‐cracker” patterns were formed because of the photonic cross‐communication in the neighboring microdroplets (Figure 3.13f ). Moreover, the intensity of photonic cross‐interaction was found to depend strongly on the distance between microdroplets, and the photonic cross‐communication completely disappeared when the distance was five times larger than the diameter of the microdroplets. It is worth mentioning that omnidirectional RGB reflections in the microdroplets have been
achieved by using a novel thermally stable photochromic chiral molecular switch. They could also readily modulate the reflection color of every single microdroplet independently, and Figure 3.13g,h illustrates the “flower‐ opening” patterns with light‐directed iridescent colors in eight monodisperse microdroplets. Such monodisperse microdroplets and their periodic arrays would not only provide a rich and fascinating platform for fundamental theoretical studies of micro/nanophotonics with geometric confinements but also hold great potential for applications in the photonic and opto‐electronic devices.
Recently, Wang et  al. reported optically reconfigurable monodisperse cholesteric microspheres with dynamic chirality using the capillary‐based microfluidic technique [128]. They judiciously designed and developed a cholesteric system with phototunable handedness inversion capability by the opposite‐ handedness doping of a powerful left‐handed chiral molecular switch and a photoinsensitive right‐handed chiral molecule into an achiral liquid crystalline host (Figure 3.14). The selective reflection of the handedness‐invertible CLCs was facilely tuned from infrared to visible and ultraviolet regions by appropriately adjusting the relative concentrations of both chiral molecules. The monodisperse chiral microspheres of photoresponsive CLCs with different initial chirality were fabricated using a capillary‐based microfluidic technique. Interestingly, they observed the light‐driven structural transformations accompanied by dynamic handedness inversion in the cholesteric microdroplets with low chirality. Reducing the concentration of both chiral dopants in the LC host, i.e. low chirality, enabled the direct observation of microstructure evolution upon light irradiations due to the pitch of cholesterics in the micrometer range. As shown in Figure 3.15a, left‐handed double spiralized patterns without apparent disclination were initially observed within the microdroplets under polarized optical
microscope. Upon UV irradiation at 365 nm, the period of spiraling structures gradually increased due to the decrease in the chirality of CLCs (Figure 3.15b–d), followed by the appearance of a bipolar nematic configuration with point defects at the two poles of microdroplets (Figure 3.15e). Continued UV irradiation led to the formation of right‐handed double spiralized patterns with decreasing periods (Figure 3.15f–j). The concentric ring pattern with line defects across the droplets (Figure  3.15k) and diametrical configuration (Figure  3.15l) with ring defects were subsequently observed until the photostationary state. The simultaneous observation of diverse characteristic patterns in this single dynamic system is unprecedented although these topological configurations have been theoretically predicted and experimentally investigated [129–132]. It is worth noting that phototunable RGB photonic cross‐communication patterns were observed in the handedness invertible CLCs with high chirality. A multicolored complex pattern with a bright red central spot surrounded by multiple radial blue lines was observed at the initial state due to the photonic cross‐communications among different cholesteric microdroplets. UV irradiations at 365 nm led to the elongation of the helical pitch of CLCs and subsequent redshift of central and peripheral reflections of microdroplets. Continued UV exposure enabled the vivid observation of handedness inversion in cholesteric microdroplets accompanied by the disappearance of cross‐communicated reflections, and the photonic cross‐communication reflections with opposite chirality would be
observed if keeping the sample at the photostationary state for around five minutes. These light‐driven dynamic processes were reversible and repeated many times without noticeable degradation. The research is expected to provide a new platform for fundamental studies of micro/nanophotonics with geometric confinements, which hold potential applications in the photonic and opto‐ electronic devices.
Microfluidic techniques have also been demonstrated in fabricating the CLC microshells with spherical configurations that can act as 3D omnidirectional lasers due to the radial molecular arrangement within the cholesteric microshells. Uchida et al. first reported the fabrication of cholesteric microshells with water–oil–water double phase by using the microfluidic method [133], in which the oil phase is composed of dye‐doped CLCs. By combining different laser dyes with CLC hosts, three types of laser modes, i.e. distributed feedback (DFB), distributed Bragg reflection (DBR) and whispering‐gallery‐mode (WGM) resonators, are successfully obtained on the basis of the CLC microshells. Subsequently, Chen et al. demonstrated the fabrication and lasing properties of photochromic monodisperse cholesteric liquid crystalline microshells through capillary‐based microfluidic techniques (Figure  3.16) [134], where the photoresponsive CLCs
were developed by loading a chiral azobenzene photoswitch responsive to visible light into a nematic LC host. When the cholesteric microshells loaded with DCM (4‐dicyanomethylene‐2‐methyl‐6‐p‐dimethylamino‐styrl‐4H‐pyran) laser dye were pumped under an external pulsed laser, laser emissions in all optical directions were achieved, where the emission wavelength was found to be able to self‐ tune because of the photoisomerization of the azobenzene chiral switch.

sections.heading: 3.5 Summary and Perspective
sections.text:
Liquid crystalline materials represent a fascinating state of matter that combines crystalline order and fluidic mobility on a molecular and supramolecular level. Such unique combination results in the LC being typically “soft” and responding easily to external stimuli. In this chapter, we provided a glimpse of the research advances in the development of light‐driven self‐organized liquid crystalline nanostructures enabled by chiral molecular switches or motors. Toward the fabrication of photoactive liquid crystalline nanostructures, a variety of new ideas and strategies have been developed for the design and synthesis of diverse chiral molecular photoswitches with exceptionally high HTPs and handedness inversion capabilities. The high HTP values have enabled the photoresponsive chiral LCs with superior properties by the addition of small
115Acknowledgments
quantities of the chiral photoswitches, and the wide tunability of the HTP furnishes reflection colors encompassing the whole visible spectrum and beyond in a reversible manner. Photomodulation of chiral LCs has been achieved by UV‐, visible‐, and NIR‐light irradiation. Through rational molecular design, some chiral photoswitches could confer helix inversion to the cholesteric systems for photonic applications involving CPL. Photoresponsive chiral LCs can be considered as a model system in soft matter research for induction, amplification, and inversion of chirality with dynamic and multifunctional qualities. Photoactive LCs with adaptive PBGs could find many new applications such as tunable mirrorless lasing, optical polarizers, and smart switchable reflective windows to control solar light.
It is anticipated that LC‐based photonic crystals could open a new area of research about soft matter photonics. Owing to the unique self‐organized properties and high stimuli sensitivity, these liquid crystalline photonic nanostructures can efficiently and selectively transmit and amplify local molecular information in a controllable manner, which undoubtedly offers an attractive route for versatile advanced photonic applications. For example, CLCs can be considered as 1D photonic crystals, while cubic superstructures of BP LCs and spherically symmetric superstructures of LC microdroplets are fascinating for tunable “soft” 3D photonic crystals. These liquid crystalline nanostructures could also function as powerful soft templates to direct the dynamic self‐assembly of nanomaterials into various well‐defined functional architectures via different noncovalent molecular interactions over multiple length scales. Although significant progress has been made in recent years, looking forward, the marriage of LC science with the emerging capabilities in nanoscience and nanotechnology could provide significant insights for developing programmable and reconfigurable advanced functional materials with myriad possibilities. Taking lessons from nature, researchers could develop novel soft photonic superstructures with extraordinary complexity, where the discrete building blocks can be self‐assembled through complex and multiple interactions of liquid crystalline matter. Future investigations in such a promising field with multidisciplinary cooperation of scientists and engineers from different backgrounds would not only broaden our knowledge of fundamental soft matter science, but also promote their diverse technological applications in areas of dynamic photonics, optoelectronics, and beyond [135].

sections.heading: 4.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Chirality or “handedness” is a prerequisite of the biological world, where life exists in a specific chirality. In living organisms, almost all the sugars are exclusively right‐handed (d‐isomer), amino acids are left‐handed (l‐isomer), and DNA coils assemble into right‐handed helices [1]. The reason behind this homochirality is still an unresolved issue. Inspired by the natural homochirality, the scientific community has been interested in exploring the mechanism of transmission of chirality from the molecular level of monomeric units to the macro‐ or supramolecular level, as well as the origin of chirality [2, 3]. The supramolecular chirality in nature from self‐assembled achiral molecules and its specific handedness play a crucial role in the evolution of life and the development of supramolecular materials. While the chirality of molecules is of configurational and conformational origin, supramolecular level chirality arises from the organization of molecules, with formation of a chiral superstructure by means of long‐ range positional and orientational orders of molecules [4].
The use of external stimuli to generate and control the asymmetry at various scales has been an important issue to mimic the homochirality of nature and to create smart supramolecular systems. Different types of stimulus such as chiral solvents [5, 6] and chiral additives [7] have been utilized to obtain enantiomeric imbalance from the achiral (racemic) system. Among the possible external stimuli, light is a versatile external stimulus with a tunable circular polarization of right‐ and left‐handedness in addition to light intensity and wavelength, which allow control of the mesomorphic reorganization. Soft materials exhibiting photoresponsive chiroptical functions provide genuine applications that include advanced displays, reflectors, information storages, chiral sensors with amplified responses, chiral recognition processes, and actuators [8, 9]. Moreover, they can offer photoresponsive chiral templates for enantioselective photochemical synthesis [10, 11], and circularly polarized light (CPL)‐triggered chiral photopolymerization with visible light [12] or near‐infrared (NIR) light source [13]. As a
Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials Yuna Kim, Noushaba N. Mafy, and Nobuyuki Tamaoki
Hokkaido University, Research Institute for Electronic Science, Laboratory of Smart Molecules, N20, W10, Kita‐Ku, Sapporo, 001‐0020, Japan
126 4 Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials
photo‐trigger/transmitter of chiral information from light to the soft materials, photochromic molecular switches (dopants) such as azobenzene [14–16], spirooxazine [17], fulgide [18, 19], naphthopyran [20], overcrowded alkene [21], and diarylethene [22] have proved their ability [23, 24]. Moreover, the elastic property of soft materials including liquid crystals, polymers, and gels has shown its capability: expression of chiral information to the entire system through amplification [25, 26].
In this chapter, we report on the recent progress harnessing chirality induction in achiral molecules by utilizing light as a chiral stimulus to achieve chiral assemblies based on photochromic switches in soft materials such as liquid crystals and polymeric organizations. In addition, we also discuss the modulation of their induced supramolecular chirality such as helix inversion between opposite handedness and helical twisting power (HTP) control through photochemical reactions. Our chapter would provide an opportunity to better understand molecular chirality control over a mesoscale chiral organization.

sections.heading: 4.2 Chirality Induction from Achiral Soft Materials by CPL
sections.text:
Chirality induction is a process in which chiral bias results in a significantly enhanced chiral effect, and CPL is considered as a natural chiral source that can transfer the chiral information of light to the single molecule as well as the supramolecules (Scheme 4.1) [27, 28]. of an enantiomeric excess and dynamic control of racemization has been investigated as a photo‐trigger (Figure 4.1) [30]. In these photo‐triggers, photochemical interconversion is possible directly between a pair of thermally stable enantiomers, or via non‐chiral intermediates. Feringa and coworkers [31] introduced the CPL‐induced photoresolution of sterically overcrowded alkene system 1, but the process required a relatively long irradiation time to get the enantiomeric excess. Tamaoki and coworkers accomplished the fast CPL‐induced chirality and molecular‐level enantiomeric excess for different types of cyclic and noncyclic azobenzenes exhibiting reversible trans (E)–cis (Z) isomerization upon light irradiation (Figure 4.1). The bicyclic azobenzene dimer 2 has a complicated enantio‐differentiating photoisomerization path with three isomers (EE, EZ, and ZZ) associated with planar chirality [32]. The monocyclic planar chiral azo‐molecule 3 also exhibits an enantiomeric excess that is induced by CPL irradiation where the r (right‐handed)‐ or l (left‐handed)‐CPL at 488 nm repeatedly induces the partial enrichment of the S or R enantiomers, respectively (Figure 4.1e,f ) [29]. Noncyclic achiral azobenzene dimer 4 with two symmetrically arranged azobenzene units generates the chirality and enantiomeric excess at its EZ isomer state under CPL irradiation at a single wavelength [33].
Although the photochemical generation of molecular level asymmetry has been achieved as described above, its amplification to the supramolecular system is considered as a challenging issue. The induced chirality plays an important role in the supramolecular system where chirality is generated by the molecular alignment of a large number of achiral molecules, through the asymmetry information transfer process from a small number of chiral molecules.
128 4 Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials
Usually in the supramolecular system, asymmetry information transfer occurs via noncovalent weak interactions, such as van der Waals interaction, π–π stacking, hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interaction, and host–guest interaction [8]. In this section, we introduce CPL‐ or circularly polarized UV light (CPUL)‐ triggered chirality induction from achiral soft materials doped or substituted with photoswitches including low molecular weight (LMW) liquid crystals, self‐ assembled supramolecules, and achiral polymers. Facile control of chirality upon CPL irradiation – not only the chiral induction with specific handedness, but also the erasing and changing of the handedness direction – is demonstrated.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Achiral LMW Liquid Crystals

At the LMW supramolecular level, helical organization usually occurs in chiral smectic and chiral nematic (cholesteric, N*) liquid crystals. In these liquid crystals, the director rotates in a helical manner around an axis with a pitch. The
sections.text:
pitch (P) is the distance along the helical axis when the molecules complete a full turn, and a positive handedness represents a right‐handed helix, whereas a negative handedness represents a left‐handed helix (Scheme 4.1). The helical pitch length is generally longer than a few hundreds of nanometers in the case of cholesteric liquid crystal (CLC). The periodic helical structures can selectively reflect the CPL of a certain wavelength matching its helical pitch length. The photoinduction of helical organization has been accomplished by irradiating CPL from achiral LMW liquid crystals (LCs).
In 1995, Schuster et al. reported on the first chiroptical trigger for a liquid crystal based on a series of axially chiral bicyclic ketones [28]. The racemic axially chiral bicyclic ketone exhibited a partial photoresolution (ee = 0.4%) by CPL irradiation although the enantiomeric enrichment hardly led to the efficient nematic to cholesteric phase transition. In 1996, Feringa et al. described a photoswitchable compound based on overcrowded alkene (1) capable of undergoing partial photoresolution within a nematic liquid crystal (NLC), a process that was able to induce the formation of a cholesteric phase [31]. Its two enantiomeric forms – P and M, due to its inherent helical shape – can interconvert by CPL irradiation at 313 nm (Figure  4.2). When photochemical resolution was undertaken in a nematic host, a cholesteric texture was observed from the racemic compound enriched with one of the enantiomers.
Choi et al. [34] utilized CPL as the irradiation source, which led to enantiomeric excess values in two chiral domains in the Bx phase of bent‐core achiral molecules (5) as shown in Figure 4.3. The helical direction was arbitrarily regulated by irradiating with l‐ and r‐handed CPL as observed from circular dichroism (CD) spectra of the BX phase (Figure 4.3c) of 5 before and after CPL irradiation (Figure 4.3b,c).
Moreover, columnar liquid crystals are also known to be suitable candidates to build chiral supramolecular architectures based on helical organizations. Sierra and coworkers exploited unique columnar liquid crystals such that CPL can be utilized to induce a chiral phase [35]. The authors combined the two systems by combining columnar LCs and supramolecular macrocycles to achieve transferring of the chirality of CPL to the achiral systems. Previous results of their
130 4 Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials
research showed that non‐mesogenic carboxylic acids endowed with a rigid V shape form H‐bonded complexes with a melamine derivative (6). These complexes self‐organize into helical columnar mesomorphic systems, the chirality of which is controlled by chiral building blocks and/or CPL (Figure 4.4).
Furthermore, by controlling the orthogonal action of H‐bonding interaction such as melamine–melamine and melamine–acid (Figure 4.5a, T : A [1 : 1]
complex), their hierarchical self‐assembly was integrated into rosette‐like two‐ dimensional hexagonal columnar (Colh) mesophases (Figure  4.5b) [36]. The modulation of the chirality of Colh mesophases was achieved with CPL. The rosette‐type association from 7 exhibits intense CD bands (Figure  4.5c) upon irradiation with CPL, indicating the induction of chirality into the supramolecular systems. On irradiation with light of the opposite handedness, the CD shows the opposite sign, which indicates that the supramolecular chirality of the mesophase can be inverted by the external chiral radiation. In particular, these columns could accommodate the ions of a salt such as lithium triflate (7‐LiTf complex), exhibiting comparable CPL‐induced chirality control of the mesophase as shown in Figure 4.5d.
A compensated nematic phase is an achiral nematic phase arising from a racemic mixture of equal amounts of chiral dopants with opposite twist sense in host NLC. It is generally observed during the switching between two chiral nematic phases of opposite handedness. Kurihara et al. [37] reported on the compensated nematic (racemic) phase at the nonirradiated initial state. By harnessing the mixture of chiral dopant (8) and the chiral azobenzene derivative (9) in nematic E44 (20 wt%), a reversible switching between the racemic and the cholesteric phases was obtained by trans–cis photoisomerization through UV and visible light irradiation, respectively (Figure 4.6). Li et al. [38] demonstrated that axially chiral dithienylperfluorocyclopentene (10) is able to induce a nematic‐like phase at a
very low doping concentration (0.1 mol% in 5CB), and it exhibits reversible isothermal phase transition between nematic and cholesteric phases upon light irradiation (Figure 4.7).

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Achiral Polymers
sections.text: In general, CPL or CPUL irradiation is introduced as a light stimulus for the induction and modulation of the chiral helical structures from achiral polymers bearing photochromophores (Figure 4.8). The dynamic control of polymer chiral functions can exploit not only the optical properties but also the dynamic micro

or macroscopic morphology and shape transformation of the soft matter system. The first demonstration on CD achieved from an achiral polymer was an induced chirality by irradiating it with CPL to 11 bearing azobenzene moieties through its chain alignment [39]. This phenomenon can be explained by the Weigert effect [9, 40]: the photoreaction efficiency of a molecule undergoing photoisomerization largely enhances when the direction of the transition moment of the molecule is parallel to the axis of the polarized light. Azobenzenes undergo repetitive trans‐to‐cis and cis‐to‐trans isomerizations by light irradiation so that the long axes of the molecules lie in a direction perpendicular to the optical field direction. In the case of CPL irradiation, the molecules align in the direction perpendicular to the optical field rotating in the thickness direction; then, the long axes of the molecules become gyratory in the thickness direction [41].
Tejedor et  al. [42] studied CD responses of a series of liquid crystalline homopolymers bearing a methoxyazobenzene group in the side chain, (12), by illuminating with 488‐nm CPL. The illumination of a nematic polymer film produced a helical organization as confirmed from CD spectra (Figure 4.9a), which resembles a chiral nematic phase as observed in the wedge cell image (Figure 4.9c) and under polarized optical microscope (POM) (Figure 4.9d). The CPL‐ irradiated region with a planar orientation exhibits an iridescent green color that corresponds to a selective reflection of a helicoidal organization. Moreover, vibrational circular dichroism (VCD) spectra after CPL irradiation (Figure  4.9b) indicate that only the mesogenic azobenzene units are involved in the chiral supramolecular organization. Consequently, using the chiral exciting light, supramolecular chirality is generated at the molecular level with an asymmetric photoisomerization, which possibly results in the conversion of a glassy nematic phase into a cholesteric phase at room temperature. Recently, the authors have achieved chiral photoinduction by CPL even in achiral amorphous azopolymers based on a constitutional repeating unit containing both a 4‐cyanoazobenzene moiety and a promesogenic 4‐cyanobiphenyl moiety (13) [43].
Choi et  al. reported on main‐chain polymeric liquid crystal systems doped with azobenzene‐containing W‐shaped molecules (14) [44]. The nucleated W‐ shaped molecules underwent preferential twisted conformation by CPL irradiation, and could trigger the local formation of a chiral structure in the doped main‐chain polymer LC medium.
Recently, Wang et al. have verified the CPL wavelength dependence on the photogeneration and photoswitching modes and regulated azobenzene supramolecular chirality in an optofluidic medium [45]. The authors chose azobenzene with flexible linkers attached to chain‐like polymethacrylate (15) dispersed as micrometer‐sized aggregates in an optofluidic medium with a tuned refractive index (nD). According to their careful study, it was revealed that the choice of CPL wavelength (313 nm and 365/405/436 nm) is the determining factor for photogeneration, photoresolution, and photoswitching of the azobenzene polymer aggregates, regardless of the sense of the CPL source (Figure  4.10a–c). Moreover, irradiating the aggregates with a CPL source at 365 nm induces almost optically pure chiral azobenzene aggregates with a maximum dissymmetry ratio of gCD ≈ ±1.0 × 10−2 at 313 nm. In addition, a distinctive chiroptical switching of 15 aggregates in dichloroethane/methylcyclohexane (0.5/2.5, v/v)
1374.2 Chirality Induction from Achiral Soft Materials by CPL
was attainable under alternating 313 and 436 nm CPL irradiation with the same sense (Figure 4.10d).

sections.heading: 4.2.3 Self‐Assembled Supramolecules
sections.text:
As described above, CPL‐triggered chirality induction and switching in achiral vinyl polymers with azobenzene pendant units have been achieved from various studies in the film state, whose chiroptical properties are mostly determined from supramolecular assembly of the pendant groups. On the other hand, diacetylenes are known to undergo topochemical polymerization during UV and γ‐irradiation in the solid state. Taking advantage of CPL‐triggered rearrangement of azobenzene chromophores in the side chains, Iwamoto and coworkers reported that chiroptically active polydiacetylenes (PDAs) bearing azobenzene residues could be obtained from achiral 16, by irradiation with either r‐ or l‐ CPUL or CP laser treatment (Figure 4.11) [46]. Upon unpolarized UV polymerization, a chiral structure of the PDA backbone was accidentally obtained and the sign of the chirality was not controlled. In contrast, the designed chiral structure of the PDA backbone could be realized by using CPUL, and the handedness direction could be modulated to opposite enantiomeric structures by irradiation with opposite handedness CPL (Figure 4.11b). The authors inferred that the stereoregular packing of azobenzene chromophores in the side chains plays a dominating role in the formation of enantiomeric helical PDA chains, and the CPL treatment is effective in adjusting the stereoregular packing of azobenzene units.
Meanwhile, Kim and coworkers have reported that helicity induction, modulation, and memory of supramolecular helical assemblies were achieved from an achiral triphenylamine derivative bearing photopolymerizable diacetylene units (17) by CPL and CPUL (Figure  4.12) [47]. Irradiation of 17 in a chlorinated solvent by r‐ or l‐handed CPL resulted in the formation of a preferred‐handed
supramolecular helical assembly, and the resultant helix sense could be reversibly switched by CPL irradiation with the opposite rotational direction as depicted in Figure 4.13. Interestingly, such switching did not occur after photopolymerization of the diacetylene unit helical assembly of 17 in the preferred handedness by irradiation using CPUL with the same rotational direction as the CPL used for the helicity induction of 17, due to the covalent fixation of the supramolecular helical structure.
Royes et  al. [48] showcased an achiral azobenzene‐based gelator exhibiting photochemical chiral induction in supramolecular organization. The organogel based on the achiral crown ether azobenzene gelator (18) shown in Figure 4.14a was supported by a 2D layer nanostructure (Figure 4.14b), and a new class of chiral material has been obtained by the 488‐nm r‐ and l‐CPL irradiation of the
achiral gel, as confirmed from electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra (Figure 4.14c). This chiral photoinduction is possibly attributed to the preferential excitation of nonplanar conformers of the azo‐gelator predicted from the crystal structure (Figure 4.14d).

sections.heading: 4.3 Photochemical Chirality Inversion from Chiral Soft Materials
sections.text:
Light‐induced helicity inversion has drawn profound attention for its importance in mimicking biological systems and fabricating three‐dimensional materials and optical devices with tunable chirality [49]. Furthermore, the conversion of light input into the macroscopic motional response of materials offers a significant advantage in the development of artificial molecular machines for soft robotics, micromechanical systems, and artificial muscles [50, 51].
In this section, we introduce different classes of photoresponsive chiral switches doped or tethered to chiral soft materials such as CLCs, helical polymers, and self‐assembled supramolecular systems exhibiting light‐driven helical sense inversion (Scheme 4.2). Especially the helix inversion of intrinsically chiral
140 4 Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials
materials is introduced. The achiral molecules processed with chiral induction by CPL are excluded from the discussion here to avoid overlap of contents, because their chiroptical intensity control such as inversion to an opposite handedness using unpolarized light or CPL has already been discussed in Section 4.2.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Photoresponsive Chiral Dopants for Cholesteric Liquid Crystals
sections.text:
When a photoresponsive chiral dopant is dissolved in an achiral NLC, its molecular chirality can be transferred to the NLC medium, resulting in the photoresponsive chiral nematic (N* or cholesteric) liquid crystal phase. The CLC superstructure is endowed with a helical pitch (P) and handedness. The pitch (P) is the distance along the helical axis when the molecules complete a full turn, and a positive sign represents a right‐handed CLC while a negative sign represents a left‐handed CLC. The right‐handed CLC can selectively reflect r‐CPL and transmit l‐CPL (those of opposite for left‐handed CLC) with the reflection wavelength corresponding to the pitch length of the helical superstructure. The ability of a chiral molecule to induce a helical structure in an achiral NLC can be quantified in terms of the HTP (β), as expressed in Eq. (4.1).

At the helix inversion point, the net HTP value of the chiral dopant becomes zero due to the presence of equal amounts of the isomers with opposite signs. Consequently, the pitch approaches infinite value, resulting in an achiral nematic phase. This nematic phase can also be referred as a racemic mixture of left‐ handed and right‐handed CLCs [53].
In the CLC system, it is noteworthy that a high initial HTP value and its large photoinduced variation are advantageous in terms of the amount required (low doping concentration) to induce and modulate the cholesteric phase, which contributes to the selective reflection color to be tuned over a wide range of wavelengths and the large amplitude of mechanical motion control [20, 54, 55]. Thus, numerous investigations have demonstrated a significantly wide range of pitch
