On the other hand, reports are relatively rare on the inversion of the handedness in CLCs despite its merits in switching the chirality of the CPL that they selectively reflect, the so‐called “wavelength‐tunable handedness‐specific CPL” [58] for advanced photonics.

sections.heading: 4.3.1.1 Azobenzenes
sections.text:
Azobenzene undergoing trans–cis isomerization appears to be a very attractive photo‐trigger in the study of the structure–property relation in cholesteric media, because of its photo fatigue resistance and the simplicity of the molecule. Among the chiral azobenzene dopants undergoing trans–cis photoisomerization, some planar chiral and axially chiral azobenzene derivatives have been reported to exhibit chiral inversion by UV and visible light irradiation. Planar chiral azobenzenes [54, 59, 60] are known to exhibit large HTP photoswitching, which is ascribed not only to the close distance between the chiral center and the mesogen unit but also to unifying the photoresponsive moieties and chiral moieties in a single moiety by cyclization. Tamaoki et al. demonstrated an interesting phenomenon that the bicyclic azophanes with planar chirality (19) shown in Figure 4.15A could reversibly change not only the HTP but also the handedness of a CLC by light irradiation without any molecular racemization of enantiomers during the photoisomerization (Figure 4.15B) [61]. (R) E,E‐19 of 1 wt% was dissolved in ZLI‐1132 and introduced into a wedge‐type cell at room temperature. As depicted in Figure 4.15C, a reversible change occurred in pitch length by irradiation of UV and visible light. N phase was obtained in between the transition of cholesteric phases with opposite handedness upon continuous exposure to UV light, and the photoinduced maximum HTP switching ratio was over 600% (Table 4.1).
144 4 Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials
Axially chiral binaphthyl moieties are feasible for controlling the helical sense and strength of the CLC. The binaphthyl derivative is known to have restricted freedom of internal rotation along the carbon–carbon bond between the 1 and 1′ positions of the binaphthyl rings. The helicity of the binaphthyl derivative therefore depends on the dihedral angle (θ) between the two naphthyl rings: cisoid (θ  < 90°) or transoid (θ  > 90°) conformation affects the helical sense and twist intensity of doped CLCs [69]. Some examples from axially chiral azobenzene dopants have also been reported to exhibit photoinduced reversible handedness inversion. Li and coworkers reported on cyclic azobenzophane dopants bearing binaphthyl units (20 in Table 4.1) with 425% of maximum HTP switching upon cis‐isomerization, and a recovery of the original handedness upon visible light irradiation [62].
The authors also developed a type of azobenzene compound substituted with axially chiral binaphthyl units of both the same and opposite chiral configurations (21) shown in Figure 4.16A [63]. The handedness inversion in LC hosts (5CB, E7 and ZLI‐1132) could be induced with CLC containing the dopants with opposite chiral configurations (S,R,S) upon UV light irradiation accompanying the chiral nematic and racemic nematic phases (Figure  4.16B), followed by a decent recovery of their original handedness and HTP (up to 90%) at photostationary state (PSSvis) as described in Table 4.1, whereas a compound with the same chiral configurations (R,R,R) exhibited no handedness inversion. Therefore,
1454.3 Photochemical Chirality Inversion from Chiral Soft Materials
the introduction of chiral conflict at the molecular level plausibly influences the handedness inversion of CLC through an equilibrium shifting between opposite chiral configurations in a single chiral switch.
Moreover, Fu et al. have investigated a dopant system similar to that mentioned above, where additional chiral units were incorporated into a chiral azobenzene unit by hydrogen bond (22 in Figure  4.17a) [64]. The binaphthyl azobenzene molecule was used as a proton acceptor, and binaphthyl acids with opposite chiral configuration were introduced as proton donors forming H‐bonded chiral switches. As shown in Figure 4.17b, a phase transition from N* to N accompanying the helical inversion and the HTP increase or decrease in N* could be achieved upon light irradiation. The length of a terminal alkyl chain in proton donors of 22 affected the HTP and helix inversion characteristics of CLCs. Although the HTP values of 22 are quite small compared to those of 21, the HTP switching ratio reaches over 800% (Table 4.1).

sections.heading: 4.3.1.2 Diarylethenes
sections.text:
Diarylethenes are of particular interest as chiral dopants for photoresponsive CLCs because of their excellent fatigue resistance and thermal stability in both the open and closed forms [38, 57, 70, 71]. Binaphthyl moieties are known as powerful helicity inducers in achiral NLCs as described above. Thus, diarylethene dopants coupled with axially chiral binaphthyl moieties have been widely studied for photonic applications of CLCs taking advantage of the large HTP and its stable photoswitching properties  [23, 24]. In terms of dopant molecular design, modification of the binaphthyl units by substituting mesogen units possessing similar conformation to NLC host and/or bridging naphthyl groups has been attempted and these approaches bring a significant difference in the miscibility with the nematic host or the rigidity of the chiral conformation, which leads to various HTPs and handedness switching behaviors [57, 70, 71].
Akagi et al. presented the first dynamic photoswitching of the helical inversion in CLCs based on a dithienylethene derivative bearing two axially chiral binaphthyl moieties (23) [65]. The photoisomerization of the dithienylethene moiety after irradiation with UV and visible light induces a reversible dihedral angle change of the binaphthyl rings. CLCs doped with the chiral dopant bearing the shortest alkyl chain in a binaphthyl moiety (23) exhibit reversible handedness switching via photoisomerization between the open and closed forms of the dithienylethene moiety (Figure 4.18).
Li and coworkers demonstrated bridged binaphthyl‐substituted dithienylcyclopentenes shown in Figure 4.19A, which exhibit the helix inversion of CLCs with a bridge length of n = 4 (24) [66]. The bridged binaphthyl derivative normally has a higher HTP than that of the non‐bridged moieties due to its narrow dihedral angles, and an increase in bridge length may lead to increase in molecular flexibility with larger phototunabilities. Indeed, those of shorter bridge lengths (n = 2 and 3) [57] exhibited smaller HTP switching without any inversion of handedness. According to their report, 24 doped in 5CB, E7, or ZLI‐1132 underwent right‐ to left‐handed inversion upon UV light irradiation as shown in Figure 4.19B. Moreover, it showed the highest initial HTP of 54 μm−1 in 5CB, while 517% of maximum HTP switching ratio was obtained in ZLI‐1132.
Photoinduced large HTP switching and handedness inversion are attributable to the significant increase in the θ value of (S,S)‐24 from the open to the closed forms (Figure  4.19C). Especially, several optical applications were carried out based on this handedness invertible dithienylcyclopentene dopant (24) such as reflection color control by photoswitching of a cholesteric pitch length and NIR‐ light‐induced handedness inversion. The authors utilized 24 and an upconversion nanoparticle in CLC as a handedness switching inducer and NIR transducer, respectively [72].
Furthermore, based on the unique helical sense inversion associated with dynamic reorganization of the entire superstructure, 24‐doped CLC was utilized for the three‐dimensional control of the helical axis [73]. UV irradiation (wavelength of 310 nm) of the chiral switch in a planar cell transformed the helical superstructure from its original standing helices (SHs) through the unwound homogeneous state and the SH arrangement with opposite handedness to the lying helix (LH) arrangement (Figure 4.20A). The authors confirmed the resultant control of helical axis by the transmitted light diffraction through a bilayer CLC sample as shown in Figure 4.20B. The dimensionality transformation was directly visualized between two‐dimensional, one‐dimensional, and the diffraction‐off states. In addition, the authors recently demonstrated the dynamically reconfigurable zigzag pattern deformation with (S,S)‐24 (3.7 wt% in E7) under the simultaneous influence of an applied electric field and light irradiation (Figure 4.21) [74]. The straight and zigzag‐shaped patterns could be generated and terminated repeatedly on demand, and easily manipulated by alternating irradiation with ultraviolet and visible light [74]. The cohesive and facile phototuning of the helical axis can be promising for advanced 3D photonic devices.

sections.heading: 4.3.1.3 Overcrowded Alkenes
sections.text:
Feringa and coworkers have developed a series of sterically overcrowded alkenes with intrinsic helical conformations, which include a stereogenic center at the rotor part and a fluorene group at the stator part [16, 75–77]. The photoisomerization around the C═C double bond of this molecular motor is known to invert the molecular helicity.
Figure  4.22 represents a reversible isomerization process of a representative  overcrowded alkene motor (25), which has broadened the application of
its unique photonic and mechanical functions [75, 78–80]. Irradiation with UV light results in its P‐helicity switching to M‐helicity, which accompanies the large HTP switching (Table 4.1). However, as the isomer with M‐helicity is not thermally stable, non‐photochemical transition from M‐ to P‐helicity occurs. The
corresponding light‐directing handedness inversion has been observed in a CLC fabricated from E7 doped with 1 wt% of 25 upon irradiation with UV light, with the reverse process occurring spontaneously at room temperature (Figure 4.23). After 135 seconds of irradiation with 365 nm light, it reached the helix inversion point and a non‐chiral nematic phase (compensated nematic, Figure 4.23b) was formed without a cholesteric fingerprint texture. Further irradiation induced the rewinding of the cholesteric helix with an opposite handedness (Figure 4.23c). In particular, a micro‐sized glass rod floated on the CLC film exhibited opposite rotational direction via non‐ rotational movement state according to the handedness change of CLC, reflecting that molecular level chirality change can be translated to the macroscopic level (Figure 4.23). White et al. [67] and Aßhoff et al. [81] confirmed the reversible and broad tunability of the helical pitch length and photoinvertible handedness of overcrowded‐alkenes‐based CLCs (Figure 4.24). Especially Aßhoff et al. showed that the thermal relaxation rate of the cholesteric helix can be fully determined through the helix inversion process of the overcrowded alkene motors.
Chen et  al. reported on 10,11‐disubstituted dibenzeosuberane (DBS)‐based helicenes (26), which undergo molecular helicity inversion upon photoisomerization (Figure 4.25A) [68]. The induced CLC phase in E7 was found to exhibit light‐driven handedness inversion through photoisomerization of the dopant by sequential irradiation with UV light of different wavelengths, 290, 310, and 330 nm. The selective photoswitching is driven by the conformation control of the top DBS template unit. Alternating irradiation at these three different wavelengths resulted in a diverse photomodulation of the pitch length, handedness reversal, and chirality turn‐off mode of the cholesteric mesophase (Figure 4.25B). Moreover, the authors demonstrated a unique type of helicene (27), which is a derivative of 26 incorporating aromatic amide (“aramide”) moieties in the top C2‐symmetric dibenzosuberane template  [82]. This C2‐symmetric dibenzosuberane‐based helicene bearing gallamide groups is converted into its pseudoenantiomeric helicene P′ through the photoisomerization of the dibenzosuberane
residue upon UV irradiation. This complementary helicity inversion was reversible, and the P/M ratio could be regulated by irradiation of a selected wavelength in the solution state (Figure 4.26a). Interestingly, 27 could reversibly self‐ assemble to form a gel depending on the ratio of P and M based on the intermolecular amide hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking (Figure 4.26b). Either a left‐ or a right‐handed helical superstructure was obtained as confirmed from transmission electron microscope (TEM) image and CD spectra (Figure 4.26c,d).

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Chiral Polymers
sections.text:
In helical polymers, stereoselective interactions between photoresponsive chiral guest molecules and polymers can induce the formation of helical structures of polymer chains or trigger a conformational change in the helical structure. The photochemical control of the macromolecular helical handedness or the cholesteric pitch has been achieved using multiple photochromic molecular switches in the side chains [83, 84], or a single photoswitchable unit at the end of the polymer chain [85]. Upon photoisomerization of the pendant unit, the
handedness of the polymer backbone reverses, which in turn prompts handedness inversion of the whole supramolecular structure. The relatively low free energy difference between the right‐ and left‐handed helical states allows the helical sense preference of the helical polymer to be switched into the opposite handedness dynamically. In 2000, Schuster et  al. demonstrated a system in which chiral information of CPL is used to control the helical sense of a polymer [86] (Figure 4.27). A racemic mixture of a photoresolvable ketone [28] and an achiral alkyl group was appended to a polyisocyanate (28) having equal populations of dynamically interconverting l‐ and r‐handed helical backbone conformations. Irradiation of the pendant ketone group with CPL results in its partial photoresolution (Figure 4.27b). The majority rule effect [87] transfers the chirality of the pendant group to the polymer backbone helix, resulting in amplification of the photoresolution as observed from CD signals that changed sign with a change in the sense of the CPL (Figure 4.27c,d). The small enantiomeric excess produced by the irradiation, even diluted with large proportions of achiral pendants, is capable of enforcing a disproportionate excess of one helical sense in the polymer [86]. Such helix‐sense switchable polymers have potential applications for chirality switchable asymmetric catalysts, optical devices, and displays [3].
156 4 Photochemical Chirality Induction and Inversion in Soft Materials

sections.heading: 4.3.2.1 Azopolymers
sections.text:
In 1994, Zentel and coworker succeeded  for the first time  in inducing photochemically reversible shift of the equilibrium between P and M helices in polyisocyanates [88]. Later, the authors discovered that the helix‐sense of an optically active polyisocyanate copolymer (29 in Figure 4.28a) of a chiral isocyanate bearing an azobenzene side group containing two stereogenic centers with an achiral isocyanate can be switched by the photoisomerization of the azobenzene moiety from the trans to cis form (Figure 4.28b) [83, 89]. The helix inversion permits the reversible switching between P and M helices by controlling the proximity of the chiral center to the polymer backbone (Figure 4.28c).
Barberá et al. [90] reported on the photomodulation of the chiroptical properties of the intrinsically chiral polymer (30) in a thin film state. In this system, the polymer, in the smectic phase (Figure 4.29a,b), is provided chirality originating at the molecular level by the asymmetric functionality of the l‐lactic acid unit. It is of highly homogeneous conformation with a prevailing chirality that appears related to the presence of H‐aggregates having conformational dissymmetry of one prevailing screw sense. Upon irradiation with l‐CPL, the CD spectra of the films show enhancement of ellipticity and a net inversion sign (Figure  4.29c). Additionally, the mirror image of the CD spectra could be restored by pumping with r‐CPL (Figure 4.29d).
Iamsaard et al. demonstrated a macroscopic helical motion control with a liquid crystalline chiral azopolymer [50]. It was prepared by photopolymerization of an azobenzene‐containing monomer (31), an achiral liquid crystalline monomer, and chiral dopants (Figure 4.30a). By cutting the resultant polymer film in a specific direction, a polymer spring was formed. Interestingly, molecular motions induced by reversible cis–trans photoisomerization resulted in the macroscopic helix modulation, i.e. winding, unwinding, and helix inversion, which can be directly observed, and led to a light‐driven mechanical work (Figure 4.30b,c).

sections.heading: 4.3.2.2 Overcrowded Alkene‐Based Polymers
sections.text:
In 2008, Pijper et al. [91] reported a light‐directed reversible handedness inversion process in the polyisocyanate system functionalized with a molecular motor 32 (Figure  4.31). The authors covalently linked an overcrowded‐alkene‐based molecular switch to the terminus of a polyisocyanate polymer (Figure 4.31A). This terminal functionalization with molecular motor enabled light‐driven reversible control over the handedness of the polyisocyanate backbone. The
reversible handedness inversion by photoirradiation was obtained from photoresponsive lyotropic CLC as seen in Figure  4.31A. Cholesteric texture and pitch clearly made transitions upon UV or visible light irradiation, which resulted in the ratio change between (2′S)‐(M)‐32 and (2′S)‐(P)‐32 form, as observed from POM images in Figure 4.31B.
Meanwhile, Zhao et al. [92] reported on molecular‐motor‐based double helicates (33 in Figure 4.32a) in which, for the first time, the multistage assembly process and helicity could be driven by light in a fully reversible manner. The responsive supramolecular systems with a stepwise change in self‐assembly of metal complexes were induced by a light‐driven rotary motor scaffold as described in Figure 4.32b. The sequence of events in this dynamic self‐assembled system (from oligomers to monomers and a direction of helix inversion of P′ → M′ or M′ → P′) is governed by the unidirectional rotary motion of the motor unit. Initially, coordination oligomers of bipyridine–Cu(I) complex can be formed by treating 33 with Cu(I). Then, these oligomers can split into monomers with P′‐helicity due to the unidirectional rotation of the molecular motor from the stable (P,P)‐trans state to the less stable (M,M)‐cis state upon light irradiation. The mechanism of disassembly of the oligomers or unfolding of the metal‐helicates following irradiation could plausibly be a partial unwrapping of the complex, assisted by acetonitrile as a small monodentate ligand for Cu(I), that precedes the photoisomerization steps. The inversion of the chirality of the Cu‐helicate from P′ to M′ is governed by a subsequent thermal helical inversion (from M,M to P,P) of the molecular motor core structure. Photoisomerization of stable (P,P)‐cis state to  (M,M)‐cis state through the rotary cycle via the
trans‐oligomeric state inverts the chirality of the Cu‐helicate back from M′ to P′. In UV–vis absorption spectra (Figure 4.32c), the change in the visible light region is ascribed to a metal‐to‐ligand charge‐transfer (MLCT) band, and the corresponding CD signals (Figure 4.32d) help determine the absolute configuration inversion of the dinuclear helicates (positive Cotton effect for P′ helicity and negative for M′ helicity).

sections.heading: 4.4 Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
The systems reviewed here highlight that light stimuli can be used to induce chirality from achiral systems and/or the inversion of the resultant chiral soft materials such as CLCs, self‐assembled helical supramolecules, or helical polymers. A photochromic molecular switch (dopant) such as azobenzene, overcrowded alkene, and diarylethene is introduced as a photo‐trigger/mediator of chiral information from the light to the host medium. It is demonstrated that either a right‐ or a left‐handed CPL can be utilized to induce a preferred‐ handed helical conformation in a dynamically racemic helical superstructure in the solid state, which appears to be one of the promising approaches for the handedness‐ selective synthesis of chiral soft materials with an optical and
161 References
mechanical function. In addition, the interconversion between enantiomeric chiral organizations in a reversible manner using orthogonal CPL or CPUL, or even turning off the photoinduced chiroptical properties by thermal treatment or using unpolarized light, is possible.
Moreover, photochemical helical inversion is achieved with chiral liquid crystals and polymers based on intrinsically chiral photoresponsive dopants with a certain handedness, and it also photochemically switches to the other handedness by UV or visible light irradiation in a reversible manner. Molecules of opposite handedness simultaneously influence the orientation of the host molecules, and a subtle unbalance between the two handednesses determines the helicity of the system. An initial HTP and its switching upon photoisomerization of a chiral dopant in CLC significantly affect the modulating degree of the helical pitch including the length, handedness, and director orientation.
One of the innovative aspects of the presented works is that photoinduced chiral transition is realized, and also the chiral information is amplified and expressed at various scales, which offers a significant advantage of photo‐ mediated chiral materials and their applications for advanced photonics such as CPL‐utilized display, reflectors, optical storage, and chiral sensors, and for attaining macroscopic work.
Nevertheless, it should be remarked that precisely predicting which system would provide certain targeted chiroptical or mechanical properties still remains a challenge. The interplay of ongoing efforts to reveal the underlying principle linking molecular events and the macroscopic phenomena and to develop novel chiral functions from photochromic switches would pave the way to providing a general method for the development of chiral photoswitches and chiral supramolecules with tailor‐made functions.

sections.heading: 5.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Microfluidics, also known as lab‐on‐a‐chip (LOC) and micro‐total‐analysis‐ system (μTAS), cover a set of multidisciplinary technologies dealing with the manipulation of small amounts of liquids to perform reactions, analyses, or fun damental investigations in biology, physics, and at the interdisciplinary frontiers. In contrast to the conventional bulky bench‐top instruments and the associated manual methods to handle large amounts of biological and chemical reagents that are pretty time consuming and not so environmentally friendly, a fine con trol over the motion of continuous fluids or nano/picoliter‐sized discrete drop lets in microscale channels is beneficial in miniaturized systems. Therefore, there is a growing interest in downscaling the corresponding processes within LOCs and still retaining cost‐effectiveness and ease of fabrication. The microflu idic systems possess intrinsic features including minimized consumption of rea gents, portability, increased automation, reduced time, and cost efficiency, which make them particularly attractive from a wide range of laboratory and industrial perspectives.
The successful operations of microfluidic devices typically rely on electroki netic, mechanical, hydraulic, or pneumatic forces and are usually driven by exter nal transducers, such as pumps, valves, and electrodes. Recent developments of novel stimuli‐responsive soft materials (e.g., polymers, gels, and liquid crystals) in response to small variations of environmental conditions [1–4] provide an alternative choice and contribute to the rapid evolution of next‐generation LOCs by integrating different functionalities onto the same chip, which comprises not only tiny channels but also multiple microactuators with mechanical properties (e.g., micropumps, micromixers, and microvalves) or optical properties (e.g., microlenses). In the sophisticated microsystems toward automotive control of liquid motions, micropumps and micromixers are essential for fluidic handling,
Soft Photoactuators in Microfluidics Lu‐Jian Chen1, and Quan Li2
1 Xiamen University, Department of Electronic Engineering, College of Electronic Science and Technology, 422 Siming South Road, Xiamen, Fujian 361005, China 2 Kent State University, Liquid Crystal Institute and Chemical Physics Interdisciplinary Program, 1425 Lefton Esplanade, Kent, OH 44242, USA
168 5 Soft Photoactuators in Microfluidics
and microvalves are crucial for fluidic control. Less energy is required for the operation, and the dead volume is minimized through the elimination of inter connecting tubes between the functional components.
It is believed that the integration of microfluidic actuators using stimuli‐ responsive soft materials offers new possibilities to facilitate simplified designs of efficient chip configurations as a means of noncontact microfluidic flow control consequently, reducing the dimensions and complexity of the microfluidic plat forms. In general, most of the functional stimuli‐responsive soft materials respond to a set of physical, chemical, and biochemical stimuli ranging from temperature, pH value, light, electric and magnetic fields, and chemical analytes to biological components, and hence change their shape with respect to the con figuration or dimension to exert mechanical force on surrounding fluids. Among these external stimuli, light is particularly appealing for LOC applications as it can provide contactless spatial and temporal control, thus allowing the microflu idic functions to be integrated in geometrically confined environments [5–8]. It is noteworthy that low‐energy light stimulus could be biocompatible to elicit responses in biological systems.
The term “optofluidics” is engendered by anything that involves both light and fluidics. In this context, it is a new paradigm and relatively straightforward to con sider two specific processes: (i) light can manipulate fluids and (ii) fluids can manipulate light. As depicted in Figure 5.1, most of the direct strategies to convert the light energy into liquid motions by using optical forces (through radiation pres sure and optical tweezers) and light‐induced capillary forces (from a light‐induced wettability gradient and Marangoni effects) have been well categorized by Baigl [9]. Nevertheless, the former approach requires special optical setups, and the latter
1695.2 Photoactive Soft Materials as Generic Microactuators
one is not practical because of the deficiencies such as short‐distance motion, local heating, and possible contamination problems.
Actually, a direct interaction between light and fluids is not necessarily required, thereby endowing the optofluidic devices with design flexibilities. To date, indirect interactions between light and fluids in microfluidics have been mostly mediated by means of photoactive functional soft materials that act as microactuators. Advanced LOC systems are integrated with these soft photoac tive components for pumping, mixing, and valving, as well as the fluid channels typically in microscale feature dimensions. Compared with the abovementioned direct light–fluids interactions, we would like to highlight that further opportu nities can be made available with the attempts that include and are not limited to the motion control of fluids by soft photoactuators.
The purpose of this chapter is to provide an overview on the advances and trends of photoactive functional soft materials aiming at the design and fabrica tion of microactuators, also known as soft photoactuators. In doing this, we occasionally cover potential microsystems that might find microfluidic applica tions in the future although it is a developing area. From the point of view of material types and working principles, the chapter is organized into four major parts, corresponding to the main application scopes of soft photoactuators in microfluidics. The discussion on the photoactive soft materials as generic micro actuators in enclosed microfluidic channels is followed by the exploration of photoactive soft materials as optical microcomponents. Finally, we offer general conclusions and the perspective for future work at the end of this chapter.

sections.heading: 5.2 Photoactive Soft Materials as Generic Microactuators
sections.text: As shown in Figure  5.2, the basic principles of microfluidic actuation for the most popular classes of stimulus‐responsive polymers have been classified by Hilber with respect to the two main applications in the generic microfluidic systems with enclosed channels: pumping/mixing (a–d) and valving (e–f ) [10]. Micropumps/micromixers and microvalves are essential microactuators to actively handle and control the fluid flow, respectively. The basic physical changes under stimulation are illustrated as follows: (i) change in mechanical properties, (ii) nonuniform strain generation, and (iii) change in volume. We review herein how to employ light to regulate liquid flow by using photoactive soft materials as generic microactuators, and discuss the general principles to improve the function and efficiency of LOC devices by soft photoactuators, thus offer intriguing possibilities in the facilitation of overall design of microfluidic systems. Microvalves are discussed first, followed by micropumps and micro mixers, since many micropumps could be built from a string of microvalves operated in sequence.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Light‐Driven Microvalves
In the past decade, many breakthroughs have been made in the development of
sections.text:
integrated microactuators with novel stimulus‐active polymer hydrogels (PHs),
which are three‐dimensional (3D) polymer networks with high water proportion. Hydrogel actuators do not require power, electronics, or control algorithms. With the variation of water proportion in the polymer network, which leads to almost instantaneous shrinkage or swelling of the polymer, PHs can undergo considera ble volume changes that reach a factor of 10 or even more. Obviously, hydrogels can be operated only in aqueous media, which is ideal for water‐based microflu idics. Existing studies of stimulus‐active bulk PHs suggest that these materials should be suitable for microfluidic applications. In contrast to the off‐chip mechanical valves, dimensions and complexity of microfluidic systems are greatly reduced by the use of hydrogels as on‐chip microvalves to enable the regulation of fluid flow in enclosed channels. The in situ photoinitiated polymerization process allows the fabrication of multiple components either sequentially or simultaneously.
Automatic microfluidic systems are built based on the phase transition behav ior of various stimulus‐active hydrogels in response to a set of external stimuli from the surrounding medium, e.g., physical values such as temperature, light,
1715.2 Photoactive Soft Materials as Generic Microactuators
electric, and magnetic fields, and chemical parameters such as pH value, solvent composition, and the concentration of specific ions. Recently, pH‐responsive hydrogel materials have been used as valves in microfluidic devices. However, many applications are not compatible with a wide range of pH values. Particularly, the utilization of light stimulus as a remote control mechanism is attractive and has been demonstrated to achieve independent control of microvalves based on various photoactive hydrogel systems.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.1 Hydrogel Microvalves Actuated by Photothermal Effect
sections.text:
Poly(N‐isopropylacrylamide) (pNIPAAm) hydrogels are one of the most promi nent PHs that can show a temperature‐induced phase transition, relying on swelling and deswelling occurring at a certain, well‐defined temperature called the lower critical solution temperature (LCST) of 32 °C. The first demonstration of thermally actuated valves was realized in the mid‐1990s [11]. The potential use of pNIPAAm hydrogels as thermoreversible microactuators in LOC devices has been well explored as microvalves [12]. Above the LCST, pNIPAAm chains collapse (valve is open) while below the LCST they undergo a rapid and reversi ble entropy‐driven phase transition to extended hydrated chains that block the flow (valve is closed). It was also found that fluid flowing in Y‐shaped micro channels with one inlet and two outlets could be controlled directly by infrared (IR)‐laser‐heating‐induced local sol–gel transformation of the fluid containing the block copolymer of poly(N‐isopropylacrylamide‐co‐n‐butyl methacrylate) and poly(ethylene glycol) [13].
The straightforward approach of incorporating light‐absorbing photothermal nanoparticles or molecules [14–16] into a thermoresponsive hydrogel can also lead to structures with even faster swelling or shrinking rates by photoinduced heating [17, 18]. To achieve reversible changes in shape and size in response to different light wavelengths, Sershen et al. proposed two hydrogel systems with composites of thermoresponsive pNIPAAm and gold nanoparticles in the form of colloid and nanoshells, respectively [19]. The gold–colloid nanocomposite hydrogel collapses in response to green light, while the one with gold–nanoshell collapses in response to near‐infrared (NIR) light. The laser light irradiation in the range of 1.6–2.7 W cm−2 was converted into heat by nanoparticles. The heat‐ induced shrinkage of the pNIPAAm hydrogels resulted in the opening of micro valves. As shown in Figure 5.3, they demonstrated independent control of two nanocomposite hydrogel valves at a T‐junction within a microfluidic device by light irradiation with suitable wavelengths.
The photothermal deformation mechanisms involved in a thermoresponsive hydrogel with light‐absorbing nanoparticles were investigated theoretically when considering the equilibrium thermodynamics of a swelling gel through a variational approach; in addition, a case study in which the composite was employed as a microvalve was carried out to validate the numerical approach [20]. Lee et al. found that the light‐induced volume change of a hydrogel compos ite was maximized when the temperature of the medium was just below the LCST [21]. By copolymerization with hydrophobic N,N‐diethylacrylamide (NDEAm), the LCST of pNIPAAm could be lowered to maximize light‐induced volume change at room temperature. Knowing this relationship between light‐
induced volume changes and thermal behaviors, the light irradiation time could be minimized to achieve a desired volume decrease in the hydrogel.
Jadhav et al. demonstrated that a pNIPAAm hydrogel with polypyrrole (PPy) nanoparticles was used to achieve a photoresponsive microvalve for remote actuation with NIR laser irradiation for flow control in microfluidic devices [22]. As illustrated in Figure 5.4, the microvalve is based on in‐channel trapping of microgel particles, which undergoes volume change and enables on/off switch ing of localized fluid flow upon NIR light irradiation. The response rate and the “open” duration of the microvalve can be simply controlled by adjusting the laser power and exposure time. The trapped nanocomposite microgel can be trig gered to shrink sufficiently to open a channel within as low as approximately one to two seconds, while it swells to reseal the channel within approximately six to eight seconds. This feature allows speedy flow switching applications. They also employed soft actuators to control fluidic interface between laminar flow streams within a Y‐junction device.
Two‐dimensional (2D) materials with exceptional surface‐area‐to‐mass ratio are promising NIR photothermal candidates that can be loaded with high cargo concentrations [16, 23]. Lo et  al. demonstrated a pNIPAAm hydrogel incor porated with glycidyl methacrylate (GMA)‐functionalized graphene oxide (GO) nanocomposite (GO–GMA) that underwent significant volume change in response to IR light irradiation [24]. The GO–GMA hydrogel carries a larger swelling ratio as well. In addition, the transition temperature is lowered by 10 °C due to the incorporation of GO. Zhu et al. reported a facile method to incorpo rate GO in pNIPAAm hydrogels by in situ γ‐irradiation‐assisted polymerization of an aqueous solution of N‐isopropylacrylamide and GO [25]. Chemically exfo liated MoS2 nanosheets were also successfully incorporated into pNIPAAm hydrogels by in situ polymerization [26]. Microvalves with excellent photother mal properties implementing such nanocomposite hydrogels with these 2D materials were fabricated to control the fluidic flow within the microchannel through remote NIR light actuation. The NIR‐light‐induced temperature change can be tuned effectively by variation of the GO doping concentration and the irradiation time.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.2 Hydrogel Microvalves Actuated by Photoisomerization
sections.text:
An alternative popular approach was implemented by copolymerization to cre ate photoactive PHs with covalent attachments between photochromic units and the polymer backbone. Only a few specific photochromic compounds that exhibit light‐induced isomerization have been investigated, such as azobenzenes and spiropyrans. Spiropyran derivatives are well‐known photochromes that can be reversibly isomerized between metastable states under light illuminations [27, 28]. In an acidic aqueous solution, the phenolate anion may be protonated in the dark, leading to a positively charged open‐ring merocyanine (McH) form, whereas visible‐light irradiation results in an effective photoisomerization of the open ring McH into closed‐ring spirocyclic (Sp) form. When the irradiation is stopped, the Sp form spontaneously converts back to the thermodynamically stable McH form. As shown in Figure 5.5, since the Sp is a highly hydrophobic molecule whereas McH is an ion and thus a more hydrophilic molecule, pNI PAAm hydrogels grafted with spirobenzopyran chromophore (pSPNIPAAm) undergo drastic light‐induced volume variation due to the hydration and dehy dration effects of the copolymer and solubility changes in aqueous solution. Consequently, pSPNIPAAm hydrogels can swell in the acidic aqueous solutions in the dark and rapidly shrink by visible light irradiation at room temperature. Notably, the volume change from Sp to McH is reversible in the dark.
Sugiura et  al. employed pSPNIPAAm hydrogels to fabricate microvalves in microfluidic systems [29], and on‐demand fluid flow systems constituting both arbitrarily rewritable microchannels and simultaneously controllable microv alves [30]. Blue light irradiation is applied locally to the discrete microvalves to induce the shrinkage of hydrogels, leading to the open state of each microv alve. The microvalve composed of pSPNIPAAm hydrogels can be opened by 18–30 seconds light irradiation. As shown in Figure 5.6, the unique noncontact programmed method facilitates the independent control of soft photoactive microvalves on one single chip.
Unfortunately, the abovementioned light‐mediated opened microvalve based on pSPNIPAAm hydrogels requires more than one hour to swell and be closed again although it is inherently compatible with microfluidics. For practical pur poses, the valve is only for “one time” operation. It is believed that chemical mod ification of the pNIPAAm backbone is expected to optimize its response time. Chen et  al. found that the mechanical strength and the pressure tolerance of pNIPAAm‐based microvalves could be tuned by choosing a suitable amount of monomer and cross‐linker for the polymer monolith inside the microchannel [31]. IR‐light‐induced heating was provided by a quartz halogen illuminator. The microvalves can withstand leakage at pressures up to 93 bar and feature response times of opening and closing in the order of only a few seconds.
Another solution toward fast, reversible, and repeatable open/close operations is to modify the chemical nature of photochromic molecules. Schenning and coworkers demonstrated that molecular design of spiropyran derivatives is important to improve the isomerization speed and the reversible swelling/ shrinking behaviors of associated hydrogels [32] (Figure 5.7). Acrylic acid acts as a proton source in solution/polymer to stabilize the open‐ring hydrophilic McH form in the self‐protonating pNIPAAm hydrogel. These improved gel valves
integrated within microfluidic channels allow reversible and repeatable opera tion in minutes. Recently, Coleman et al. described a method for microfluidic flow control based on photoactive pSPNIPAAm valves with rapid and reversible actuation properties within practical timescales [33]. Application of pulsed light (450 nm) allows the valves to be held at an intermediate position for extended periods of time, resulting in a forced oscillation and control over the valve through photoisomerization of spiropyran between the McH and Sp forms. Varying the extent of light pulsing enables the instantaneous regulation of flow rate up to 0–27 μl min−1.
Remarkably, a new concept in materials science is the incorporation of ionic liquids (ILs), organic salts that exhibit melting points below 100 °C, within poly mer gels to generate ionogels with the inherent advantages of ILs. Compared with an equivalent IL‐free hydrogel, the physical robustness of photoresponsive
phosphonium‐based ionogels was improved [34]. Upon irradiation with visible light, the ionogels decreased in volume due to McH to Sp switching and the asso ciated loss of water from the polymer. These ionogels were then incorporated into a microfluidic device as photoactuated microvalves. A simple LED with a mild output of approximately 1 mW cm−2 can be used to actuate the microvalve. The swelling/shrinking properties can be controlled by alternating the anion of  the phosphonium ILs entrapped within the gel matrix [35]. As shown in
Figure 5.8, the valve actuation time and liquid flow within each channel can be individually tuned, facilitating sequential actuation events under common illu mination conditions. Moreover, the microvalve fabricated by cross‐linked pNI PAAm ionogel can be reversibly actuated for up to eight times and resist pressures up to 1100 mbar [36].

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Light‐Driven Micropumps and Micromixers
sections.text:
Micropumps and micromixers are essential components for fluidic handling. In general, an off‐chip micropump is connected to the microfluidic chip to intro duce liquid samples and facilitate the fluid flow. The integration of micropumps offers potentials in miniaturized microfluidic systems. The involved mecha nisms can be classified into two categories: (i) mechanical type, which includes electrostatic, piezoelectric, thermopneumatic, and electromagnetic effects, etc. or (ii) nonmechanical type, which includes magnetohydrodynamic, electrohy drodynamic, electro‐osmotic, electrowetting, electrochemical, and evaporation effects, etc. Even though impressive progress on numerous designs and materi als has been achieved to realize on‐chip micropumps, the lack of remote on/off switching capabilities limits their applications in microfluidics.
Repeated light stimulus can be transformed into either mechanical or nonme chanical responses to pump fluids. It is found that light momentum can be trans ferred to trap and manipulate microscale‐sized particles, which are used as mobile elements to actuate liquids. Pioneered by Terray et al., time‐shared traps generated by optical tweezers were used to control the collective motion of col loidal particles inside microfluidic devices, working as a two‐lobe gear pump or as a peristaltic pump [37]. The advantage of this approach is that no specific microparticle fabrication is required, so that it offers a quite large versatility. However, the particles must be continuously trapped to avoid the contamination problem when being washed away by the flow.
Chen et al. proposed another mechanical micropump by the combination of an elastic pump membrane and a photodeformable liquid crystalline polymer
(LCP) film [38]. The assembled structure of the prototype device is shown in Figure 5.9. The bending behavior of the LCP film is utilized to work against a fixed lid and induces pressure strokes on the flexible membrane and thus the pump chamber.
Another example of the application of soft photoactuators in miniaturized device is the self‐powered rechargeable micropumps developed by Patra et al. [39]. The micropump is based on the formation of a β‐cyclodextrin/trans‐ azobenzene complex [40]. The complex can be activated by two different mecha nisms, i.e. the trans–cis isomerization of azobenzene by ultraviolet (UV) light and the disassembly of association between cyclodextrin and azobenzene by introducing a competing guest molecule (adamantine, ADA). As shown in Figure 5.10, the light‐induced cis‐isomer of azobenzene has less binding affinity toward β‐cyclodextrin and hence gets dissociated from the cyclodextrin cavity.
This dissociation leads to changes in the local fluid density, which is provided as a possible reason for the self‐powered fluid flow in the gel. The gel could be reused when soaked in a solution of trans‐azobenzene or left in the solution for some time. In this manner, cis‐azobenzene turns into trans‐azobenzene and forms the β‐cyclodextrin/trans‐azobenzene complex again. The micropumps might be of great help in fluid handling and circulation of culture media for the development of organs‐on‐a‐chip devices.
Microfluidic paper‐based analytical devices (μPADs) are a type of innovative, low‐cost, equipment‐free analytical platforms due to impressive properties com prising flexibility, lightness, and low thickness. Nevertheless, the effective meth ods to handle and control fluids on paper are still limited. Akyazi et al. provided a new concept for fluid flow manipulation in μPADs by introducing ionogels as passive micropumps [41]. Two types of pNIPAAm ionogels, with different chem ical and physical properties, were drop‐casted at the inlet of the μPADs by a PDMS‐based ink‐stamping process. The delaying effect of the ionogels depends on the characteristics (chemical and dimensions) of the ionogel, which deter mine the swelling degree of the gel. As a proof of concept, the fluid delay capabil ity of the ionogel was tested on a Y‐shaped μPAD. Furthermore, they integrated a gasket to ensure the fabrication of negative passive pumps with different
1815.2 Photoactive Soft Materials as Generic Microactuators
volumes of ionogel in a single μPAD [42]. The flow behavior of the μPADs can be modulated, redirected, and even reversed in the presence of an ionogel negative passive pump.
Microfluidic channels possess several characteristics, such as small overall volumes, laminar flow, and a large surface‐to‐volume ratio. Fluid flow in these microchannels is normally nonturbulent due to low Reynolds numbers. The mixing of confined liquids is critical yet challenging in most chemical and bio chemical processes. Passive mixers rely on diffusion or chaotic advection, while active mixers use the disturbance generated by an external field for the mixing process, and thus require external energy. Supplemental transducers such as pumps or electrodes were implemented in active mixers to enable dynamic and tunable mixing, thus increasing the complexity and fragility of the device while reducing its portability and flexibility.
Inspired by nature, a simple design of microactuators to facilitate pumping and mixing in microfluidic environments was adopted to mimic cilia, which are the greatest natural boon to living organisms; through them, organisms can manipu late, sense, and control their surrounding flow [43–45]. Artificial cilia driven by light have a promising future. van Oosten et al. used reactive liquid crystal mon omer inks in combination with the self‐assembling properties of an LCP to pro duce light‐driven artificial cilia by an inkjet‐printing process [46]. In order to remotely control the movement of the artificial cilia, they chose to use the pho tomechanical effect already developed using azobenzene‐containing liquid crys talline elastomers (LCEs). Microactuators created with different subunits can be selectively addressed remotely, thus allowing well‐controlled motions that have the potential to be more effective in mixing. Clearly, such a reversible photome chanical actuation requires a switching operation of dual wavelengths, which are not viable for many practical applications with a fast response. To improve the performance of LCE‐based photoactuators, Yang et al. proposed a robust strat egy for in situ grafting of graphene‐enabled LCE nanocomposites with superior and tunable photodeformable properties upon NIR irradiation [47]. In this NIR‐ actuated system, graphene sheets play an important role as a photoactive con stituent. The LCEs exhibit two distinct advantages, i.e. the self‐organization of LCs and the entropy‐driven elasticity that enables larger reversible deformations compared to conventional polymeric materials. The actuator performances, including deformation amplitude, actuation stress, and response rate, can be readily controlled by tailoring the quality, the loading content, and the degree of alignment of graphene in the LCE matrix.
Overall, there are still plenty of microscale‐responsive polymer systems that have not yet been but can be utilized as soft photoactuators and find applica tions in microfluidics [48]. Among these potential systems, LCPs have been the major subject of ongoing scientific research [49, 50]. The underlying principle is that the mesogens act as an anisotropic solvent for the isotropic polymer chains. A delicate interplay of the effects of surface‐induced ordering, elastic strain of LCs, and topological defects is involved in the study of LCP systems. Therefore, LCPs can undergo several forms of macroscopic shape deformations, including contraction (expansion), bending (unbending), twisting, and other complex forms, dictated by the change of molecular order from the aligned state under
182 5 Soft Photoactuators in Microfluidics
external stimuli [51]. Since stimuli such as heat and light are easily attainable, thermo‐driven or photo‐driven LCP actuators are a promising class of soft materials that exhibit a number of intriguing properties. We believe that the aforementioned approaches discussed in this section may extend the perspec tives of the microfluidic systems for future applications when complex mixing processes and remote controllability are required, in particular for biological applications.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Light‐Driven Emulsification and De‐emulsification
sections.text:
High‐throughput emulsification and de‐emulsification are an important concern for droplet‐based microfluidics. The interface between two immiscible liquids is increased and fragmented by mechanical actuation and hydrodynamic shear forces to generate microdroplets. For a given fluid composition and an appropri ate channel junction geometry, droplet size and frequency are controllable by varying flow rates. Generally, surfactants are used to stabilize microdroplets, and also account for many valuable rheological proprieties of the emulsion system. Similarly to the previous fluid mixing operation, the surfactant‐dependent strat egies to merge droplets can also be passive and active.
With the development of optofluidics, there is a need to explore new approaches to achieve the aforementioned microfluidic actuations by using light as a non contact stimulus. However, only a few light‐triggerable processes have been reported to mix a multiphase flow in microchannels or to realize photoactive emulsification and de‐emulsification.
Diguet et al. reported an intriguing method to induce reversible switches from a continuous two‐phase laminar flow to a droplet‐generating regime with a usual water‐in‐oil (W/O) flow‐focusing geometry, by introducing a photosensitive surfactant in the aqueous phase [52]. The chemical structure of the cationic pho tosensitive surfactant azobenzene trimethylammonium bromide (AzoTAB) is shown in Figure 5.11. The isomerization of trans‐AzoTAB to cis configuration upon UV illumination results in a more polar tail. As a result, the interfacial energy between liquids and the channel is modulated, leading to the fragmenta tion of the liquid into an emulsion with monodisperse droplets. The system can go back to the laminar regime as the light irradiation stops.
Later, Venancio‐Marques et al. described the reversible control of microfluidic mixing based on the light‐induced generation of W/O emulsion with water droplets, acting as reversible stirrers to mix two oil phase flows containing sam ples (Figure  5.12) [53]. Two continuous oil phases and a photosensitive water phase are injected in a flow‐focusing device. The AzoTAB molecule dissolved in the water phase is responsible for the photoisomerization‐induced change of wetting properties. Many cycles of reversible transitions between a nonmixing behavior and full homogenization of the two oil phases were demonstrated with the aid of light. Nurdin et  al. reported a new dual flow‐focusing microfluidic device configuration to generate stable dual jet and dual drop regimes [54]. After introducing the AzoTAB surfactant, the flow regimes were found to be depend ent on illumination conditions. The range of flow rates was identified where the
flow regime could be dynamically and reversibly switched upon UV illumination at 365 nm. The two phases were well separated and never mixed in the absence of illumination.
Recently, Takahashi et al. reported the photoinduced de‐mulsification of emul sions with a photoresponsive gemini surfactant (C7‐azo‐C7) bearing an azoben zene skeleton as a spacer [55]. Light‐induced isomerization of the azobenzene spacer allows reversible conversion between the trans isomer and the cis isomer. The modification of the interfacial tension leads to controlled coalescence. However, the de‐mulsification experiment was carried out for the overall emul sion without spatial differentiation. The several minutes of irradiation time that is required is considered to be too slow for microfluidic applications, where a response in the sub‐second range is more suitable.
Dunkel et  al. explored another light‐controlled merging approach by the irreversible photolysis of photosensitive surfactants (Figure  5.13). The amino quinoline (AQ)‐derived photosensitive surfactants is composed of polyethylene glycol/perfluorinated polyether (PEG/PFPE) diblock amphiphiles [56]. The light‐induced partial or total depletion of surfactants result in increased surface tension that would be equilibrated by the uptake of extra surfactants either from the bulk or from a neighboring droplet in oil‐in‐water (O/W) emulsions. The destabilization may lead to coalescence of droplets if the surfactant concentra tion goes below the threshold of critical value. Photolysis of microdroplets by using 355 nm picosecond‐pulsed laser light results in rapid, controlled fusion of vicinal droplets. Since the photolysis can be controlled precisely by adjusting the power, exposition time, and spot size of the laser beam, the method offers a new prospect of microdroplet merging with high stereospatial integrity in microfluidics.

sections.heading: 5.2.4 New Conceptual Light‐Driven Fluid Motion in Microchannels
sections.text:
Manipulating small amounts of liquids to perform reactions, analysis or funda mental investigations in biology, physics, or chemistry are important in both sci entific research and practical applications. As has been depicted in Figure 5.1, a light stimulus can be directly converted into fluid motion by optical forces or light‐induced capillary forces. Although these methods are effective to provide
contactless, spatial, and temporal control, several drawbacks still exist. For instance, the wettability gradients induced by light might be too small to conquer the contact line pinning in these cases. The Marangoni effect requires either local heating or addition of photosensitive surfactants into liquids, which limits their potential biomedical application because of contamination problems. In practice, simple and straightforward techniques are required to realize high‐ speed fluid transportation over long distances.
Inspired by the lamellar structure of artery walls, Lv et  al. proposed a con ceptually novel way to control fluid motion by capillary force arising from pho toinduced asymmetric deformation, instead of the aforementioned wettability gradients and Marangoni effect [57]. Robust tubular microactuators (TMAs) were prepared from a newly designed linear LCP (LLCP) that has a long flexible backbone containing double bonds and azobenzene moieties in side chains act ing as both mesogens and photoresponsive groups. As shown in Figure 5.14, the asymmetric geometry change of the TMA from cylindrical to conical is induced upon attenuated 470 nm light irradiation with intensity gradient along the long axis of the TMA. The photoinduced reorientation of LLCP results in a decrease in the thickness of the TMA wall and an elongation of the perimeter of the TMA, which together cause an increase in the cross‐sectional area of the TMA. By this means, the motion of a fully wetting liquid slug confined in the TMA microchan nel can be driven by light. The TMAs show unique abilities to propel not only common liquids spanning a broad range of polarity, but also complex fluids widely used in biomedical and chemical engineering. Furthermore, efficient liq uid mixing and the capture and movement of microspheres on the microscale in the photodeformable TMA can be triggered by external light, offering a versatile toolbox in microfluidic fields of microreactors, LOCs, and micro‐optomechani cal systems.

sections.heading: 5.3 Soft Photoactuators as Optical Microcomponents
sections.text:
The last range of soft photoactuators relies on the use of light stimuli to control, tune, and reconfigure optical microcomponents in microfluidics. As we know, optical microcomponents, typically fabricated by micromolding or photo lithographic processes, play a crucial role in imaging and display technology, biosensing, beam shaping, optical switching, wavefront analysis, and device miniaturization. Toward both industrial and academic pursuits with regard to  enhanced light manipulation capabilities of optical systems, tunable micro lenses are employed as responsive in‐line, phase‐modulating, intensity‐ preserving microcomponents. However, most of these microlens designs can only operate with fixed focal lengths, relatively large diameters, and/or slow focal length switching speeds. Currently, considerable research interests have been focused on the development of novel material systems with soft microstructures. Benefiting from the use of photoactive soft materials, the microlens array has the potential to allow for dynamically tunable focal lengths without mechanical parts. Notably, the focal length of an individual microlens can be addressed on demand and inde pendently of other lenses. And the fabrication technology is facile, inexpensive, and scalable. In contrast to traditional optical systems, a higher degree of integra tion of optical micro com ponents with microfluidics can be anticipated, repre senting an enabling technology for a new class of tunable optical microcomponents for adaptive optics, imaging devices, or sensors.
1875.3 Soft Photoactuators as Optical Microcomponents

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Tunable Microlenses Actuated by Photoactive Hydrogels
sections.text:
Hydrogel‐based lensing materials can be dynamically reshaped through various external stimuli after the optical elements are formed. Kim et  al. presented a simple wet‐chemical method to fabricate microlens arrays, which comprised of fast‐responding, reversible, photoactive hydrogel elements [58]. Glass substrates were functionalized by 3‐aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS), Au nano particles (16 ± 1.6 nm), and the cationic polyelectrolyte poly(allylamine hydro chloride) (PAH) subsequently. Then, anionic pNIPAAm‐co‐AAc microgels were attached to the APTMS‐Au‐PAH‐modified substrate through electrostatic inter actions. In this manner, colloidal Au nanoparticles allowed for local heating of the sample through excitation of surface plasmon modes. Figure 5.15 shows a schematic depiction and a scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of this construction, in which the laser‐power‐dependent lensing ability and the appar ent response time relate to the photothermal properties of Au nanoparticles and the thermoresponsivity of microgel lens elements. The unique micro‐optical characteristics also include the ability to spatially confine the tunable region to the single‐microlens scale with the aid of pulsed laser.
In another attractive demonstration as shown in Figure 5.16, Zeng and cow orker fabricated a liquid tunable microlens actuated by multiple micropost struc tures of Au‐pNIPAAm nanocomposite hydrogels photopatterned around the lens aperture [59]. Benefitting from the heat converted from absorbed light by entrapped Au nanoparticles, the swelling state (expansion and contraction) of the hydrogel network was controlled. The curvature of a liquid–liquid interface forming the microlens at the aperture and its focal length were regulated in turn. The focal length of the microlens can be tuned from −17.4 to +8.0 ± 0.4 mm in seconds under IR irradiation. This approach paves a potential way to replace cur rent technology that uses mechanical or electrical signals and intrinsically inte grates such light‐controlled tunable microlenses into optofluidic systems.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Microlens Arrays Actuated by Photoactive Emulsions
sections.text:
As mentioned previously in Section 5.2.2, microfluidic emulsification is one of the most powerful and important techniques for mixing and dispersing immisci ble fluid compositions within a continuous liquid phase. Complex emulsions, including multiple emulsions and Janus droplets (with faces of differing chemis tries), are of growing interest, especially in dynamic micro‐optics.
Taking advantage of the temperature‐sensitive miscibility of hydrocarbon, silicone, and fluorocarbon liquids, Zarzar et al. described a one‐step approach to fabricate complex emulsions with highly controllable and reconfigurable
morphologies after emulsification [60]. To endow these emulsions with photoac tivities, a photoresponsive surfactant consisting of an azobenzene moiety, which reversibly undergoes photoinduced isomerization between a more effective
190 5 Soft Photoactuators in Microfluidics
trans configuration and a less effective cis configuration, was synthesized and used in combination with a nonionic fluorosurfactant Zonyl FS‐300 with suita ble concentrations. As shown in Figure 5.17, the rapid and reversible morpho logic switch of hexane‐perfluorohexane droplets, between double emulsion (encapsulated) and Janus states (two‐sided) or to invert states entirely, results from changes in the balance between interfacial tensions. Thus, the dynamic reconfiguration of droplet morphology was observed in response to UV (365 nm) and blue (470 ± 20 nm) light by varying the duration or intensity of light expo sure. This yields a general strategy to create a wide range of photoresponsive elements for abundant applications of emulsions.
Very recently, Nagelberg et  al. produced stable bi‐phase emulsions with a highly uniform size distribution as tunable microlens arrays by glass‐capillary‐ based microfluidics [61]. Such complex droplets are composed of optically dis tinct, immiscible hydrocarbons, heptane (nHP = 1.387) or hexane (nHX = 1.375), and fluorocarbons FC‐770 (nFC = 1.27) in the aqueous phase (nW = 1.33). The
1915.4 Summary and Outlook
photoactive emulsion can be dynamically reconfigured through light stimuli in the presence of an azo‐surfactant, thus showing different optical properties depending on the configuration. Double emulsions with higher refractive index (RI) core phase strongly focus light, while those with higher RI shell phase show strong light scattering. However, Janus droplets do not significantly disturb the light wavefront when the light propagates along the surface normal of the inter nal interface.
The RI contrasts between hydrocarbons, fluorocarbons, and water, as well as the curvature of each interface contribute to the focusing power of refractive optical elements. By adjusting the droplet’s interfacial tensions with the aqueous phase, the focal length of emulsion‐based microlens can be varied from ±3.5× the drop diameter to infinity. Therefore, a light‐controlled switch of the droplet morphology consequently results in a predictable variation of the droplets acting as converging lenses projecting real inverted images, or as diverging lenses form ing virtual upright images. It is also confirmed that microscale optical tunability of the droplets could be translated to observable differences in macro scopic appearance, which can be used for the creation of patterns and images. Additionally, two potential applications of the microlenses’ functionality were demonstrated to be integral in microscale imaging devices and light field display technology. As shown in Figure 5.18, this feature allows for the creation of micro scopic and macroscopic patterns with tunable contrast, which could form the basis for light field displays capable of creating 3D images and projecting variable information content into different directions.

sections.heading: 5.4 Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Overviews of the photoactive soft materials, involving hydrogels, LCPs, and emulsions, have shown their unique microfluidic applications as photoactuators. Owing to the considerable scope of optofluidics, the related discussion in this chapter only focused on a few selected but significant topics. Basically, the struc ture and morphology changes of photoactuators are induced by light, thereby offering the on‐demand control and handling of fluids, as well as the manipula tion of light interactions. The mechanisms involved are also discussed in details. Until now, the practical implementations of light‐responsive soft materials with microfluidic functions are not satisfying and should be extended to broader aspects.
For instance, microscale channels have a high surface‐to‐volume ratio, leading to different characteristics from bulk volumes. The wettability change of micro channels based on photoactive soft materials can be used to modify the surface interactions and influence fluid movements. The trans–cis isomerization of azobenzene leads to large changes in wettability when the structures of a surface topography are in the micrometer size regime [62]. As stated before, spiropyran can also undergo a hydrophilicity change upon isomerization. Polymer surfaces functionalized with these organic molecules can be more hydrophilic or hydro phobic upon light exposure [63]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the integration of these polymer coatings with tunable wettability into microfluidic
192 5 Soft Photoactuators in Microfluidics
channels was rarely reported to be based on photoswitchable surface topogra phies. In addition, pNIPAAm hydrogels are widely used as prototype actuators, which can be only responsive to light irradiations in the presence of aqueous solutions with relatively low ionic strength, significantly restricting the types of fluids that can be manipulated. Furthermore, the approaches to tune the flow control with intermediate states, rather than a simple stop/start function with these gel‐based microvalves, are appealing and need to be further explored.
Fortunately, recent advances and trends show the possibilities to fully exploit the benefits of light stimulus by taking advantage of molecular design and tailor ing, which enlighten the development of new soft material systems. From this point of view, it is reasonably expected that the interplay among four main areas within microfluidics, i.e. material properties, functions, integration, and applica tions, are worthy of being reinvestigated to realize enhanced performance as desired. Our specific emphasis herein is that the discovery of new conceptual soft photoactuators would pave a promising way and bridge the gap between remote‐controllable LOC devices and many fields such as biomedical and phar maceutical research, chemical reaction manifolds, and for chemical/bioanalysis, which is undoubtedly the primary objective of future optofluidics involving pho toactive functional dynamic materials and systems.
