sections.heading: 6.1 Photoactuation: A New Paradigm for Soft
sections.text:
Micro‐robotics
“Robot” is a term first introduced by the Czech writer Karel Capek in a science fiction play “R.U.R.” in 1920 [1]. Another science fiction writer (and scientist), Isaac Asimov (1920–1992), stated that “today’s science fiction is tomorrow’s sci ence fact.” After a century of evolution, this statement has become a reality when it comes to robots, which continue disrupting our ways of living as well as trig gering our imagination on what tomorrow’s technologies will look like. For sev eral decades, scientists and engineers have focused their efforts on perfecting the mechanics and electronics of conventional robotic devices, to build ever‐ more sophisticated, precise, and reliable functions with faster actuation speed. However, new challenges have risen recently, as the robots of tomorrow should, instead of serving merely as a labor alterative or automation tool, act autono mously and adapt their function to overcome unexpected obstacles without human intervention, and all this in a human‐friendly and safe manner. Reaching such beautiful visions may be beyond the capabilities of conventional hard‐ bodied machines.
In contrast to the hard‐bodied robots with rigid components, soft robots con stitute soft actuators and flexible joints and links that can offer additional degrees of freedom and further sophistication in robotic movements [2]. Soft robots can adapt to unpredictable obstacles, and they are capable of continuous actuation and shape change. A comparison between a rigid‐ and a soft‐gripping device is shown in Figure 6.1. The rigid gripper (Figure 6.1a) requires pre‐programming in order to precisely reach the target and to control the force exerted on it. The soft gripper, composed of pneumatic actuators made of soft silicone‐based polymer and controlled by air pressure [3], can bend and adapt to the curvature of the object. Without any precise programming, the device can autonomously adapt
Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics Hao Zeng, Markus Lahikainen, Owies M. Wani, Alex Berdin, and Arri Priimagi
Tampere University of Technology, Laboratory of Chemistry and Bioengineering, Korkeakoulunkatu 8, FI-33720, Tampere, Finland
to unexpected geometries, and perform its task gently enough to handle also fragile objects (such as picking up an egg, as demonstrated in Figure  6.1b). However, hurdles remain in the pathway of soft robots when approaching practi cal applications. For instance, invasive surgery and task execution at small scales require the soft robot to be miniaturized and controlled by a wireless energy source. Most of the present‐day soft robots comprise pneumatic actuators that rely on air/liquid tube powering, a concept which is extremely difficult to realize at the microscale.
As an alternative to pneumatic actuation, smart stimuli‐responsive materials [6] stand out as particularly promising. In such materials, the powering source required for the actuation can be decoupled from the robot body, and the device can be fueled remotely. Various stimuli‐responsive materials have been imple mented into micro‐robotics, using power supplies based on magnetic fields [7],
1996.1 Photoactuation: A New Paradigm for Soft Micro‐robotics
light fields [8], and chemical reactions [9]. Among various energy sources, light stands out as particularly promising, because it is clean and tunable (in wave length, intensity, polarization), enabling sophisticated control with high spatial and temporal resolution. Light‐responsive smart materials can perform shape changes upon illumination (Figure  6.1c), thus paving way for miniaturized, remotely controlled soft‐robotic devices. The photoactuation process in these materials is typically triggered by molecular motors that, upon proper materials design, translate the molecular‐level movements into controlled actuation in the macroscopic scale [10]. This provokes a paradigm shift in soft robotics: the use of light‐responsiveness of the material itself to build up robotic actuators and sensors, resulting in a remotely controlled actuation strategy and miniaturiza tion of the entire system.
Liquid crystal (LC) polymer networks and elastomers (herein, we refer to them as liquid crystal networks (LCNs), without making a distinction between elasto meric and glassy polymer networks), are synthetic cross‐linked polymer systems constituting liquid crystalline building blocks, or mesogens [11]. The inherent tendency of liquid crystalline materials to self‐assemble opens up the possibility to pre‐design the molecular orientation within the polymer network [12]. Importantly, this orientational order can be reversibly controlled (or even destroyed, to yield order–disorder transition) under external light stimuli, result ing in a shape change of the LCNs [13]. The most popular light‐driven molecular motors in LCNs are azobenzene derivatives that can undergo reversible trans‐to‐ cis isomerization upon irradiation with a proper wavelength, dictated by the chemical structure (Figure 6.1c) [14]. This molecular‐level shape change can be amplified in LCNs to trigger large and reversible macroscopic deformation. To quote Zentel, one of the pioneers of LCN research, “the integration of photoac tive mesogenic units (i.e. azobenzenes) into LCNs has given rise to remarkable results and is currently judged the most promising candidate for commercial applications” [15].
Light‐driven, LCN‐based soft robotics has been a nascent research field in the past few years. From light‐controlled microscopic walkers to autonomous walking devices [16, 17], from swimmers in micrometer to centimeter length scales [18, 19] and from artificially manipulated grippers to intelligent autono mous gripping devices [5, 20], azobenzene‐driven light‐responsive systems serve as an important path to access small‐scale soft robotics (see the exam ples in Figure 6.1d,e), yielding imaginative results that are not achievable with other materials. In this chapter, we provide an up‐to‐date overview of light‐ fueled LCN robotics. We start by introducing the photoactuation mechanisms, making a comparison between photothermal and photochemical actuation strategies, which often times yield distinct actuation behavior and shape changes, introduced subsequently. We then move from photoactuation to light robotics and discuss the basic physics that a small‐scale LCN robot encoun ters, as the forces at the microscale are very different from our common every day experience. Finally, we will draw the historical outline for important light‐robotic achievements, and outline the future prospects of this exciting field of research.
200 6 Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics

sections.heading: 6.2 Photoactuation in LCNs
sections.text:
To obtain light‐fueled actuation, one must incorporate light‐sensitive elements, i.e. photoswitches (azobenzenes) or nanoscopic heat generators (dyes or nano particles), into the material [21]. Both serve to absorb the light and introduce disorder into the initially ordered polymer network. In an ordered LCN, the mesogens are aligned in directions specified during the fabrication process, and the polymer chains connecting the mesogens are elongated. Upon light‐induced order–disorder transition, the system loses this molecular order and becomes isotropic, and the polymer system adapts entropy‐driven random‐coil confor mation. The presence of cross‐links, in turn, ensures that the initial ordered state can be retained, and the process is reversible. During the phase transition, the volume of the structure is largely preserved. Therefore, the structure tends to contract along the molecular director (the direction in which the mesogens are aligned) and expand in the perpendicular direction(s), resulting in sometimes very pronounced macroscopic shape changes (especially in main‐chain LCNs) [12, 22]. This process is schematically illustrated in Figure 6.2a.
From a chemical point of view, the methodologies to synthesize LCNs are often times divided into two classes, one utilizing polymeric and monomeric precursors (denoted as “Two‐step reaction” in Figure 6.2b) and the other utiliz ing monomeric precursors only (“One‐step reaction” in Figure 6.2b). These are extensively described in various review articles [12, 23], and we refer the reader to these sources for a more elaborate discussion. A prototype example of the two‐step reaction is given by the pioneering work of Finkelmann and coworkers, who, in the beginning of the 1980s, demonstrated a two‐step method for obtain ing highly ordered, elastomeric LCNs based on siloxane chemistry [24]. The pro cess is illustrated in Figure 6.2b, together with examples of the materials employed (Figure  6.2c). In the first step, the vinyl groups, reacting very fast, build up a weakly cross‐linked polysiloxane gel connected by non‐mesogenic cross‐linkers. A mechanical load is then applied, in order to align the mesogens and obtain uniform director orientation, after which a second cross‐linking step is applied to ensure the formation of the (nematic or smectic) polymer network [25]. The method yields monodomain alignment with high‐order parameter over a large area, which further translates into efficient macroscopic actuation [26, 27]. The first example of a photomechanical actuator, which was demonstrated in 2001, was fabricated using this methodology [27]. The main drawback is limited con trol over the molecular alignment within the polymer network. Through proper materials engineering, the two‐step method is amenable to complex thermome chanical actuation modes [28], but in vast majority of cases, simple uniaxial con traction–expansion is demonstrated.
The one‐step reaction, developed by Broer et al. [29, 30] is based on photopo lymerization of an LC monomer mixture, within the temperature range where it exhibits LC phase. The process often times leans on radical polymerization of acrylated monomers (Figure 6.2c), yet recently also other reactions such as thiol‐ ene polymerization, have been used [31, 32]. This method has one great advan tage compared to the previously described one: as the polymerization is conducted in the low‐viscosity monomeric state, techniques developed for LC
202 6 Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics
displays (such as surface rubbing or photoalignment) can be adapted to control the molecular alignment prior to polymerization. As a result, the director orien tation can be spatially patterned with high resolution, and separately controlled at the two LCN surfaces to yield complex, pre‐programmed molecular alignment distributions within the polymer network [33]. This unique feature allows one to go beyond simple contraction/expansion or one‐dimensional bending deforma tions, and depending on the director distribution, LCNs with exactly the same composition may exhibit diverse actuation modes. The relation between the molecular alignment and the light‐induced shape change is further discussed in Section  6.3, after introducing photochemical and photothermal actuators and comparing their main differences.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 Photochemical Actuation
sections.text:
Photochemical actuation of LCNs is triggered by photoswitchable molecules, which can undergo a reversible shape change upon photon absorption. The most popular photoswitches in the context of LCNs are photoisomerizable azoben zene derivatives [11, 34]. They are aromatic compounds, in which two phenyl rings are bridged by an azo (─N═N─) group. Their attractiveness is based on several features. First, a huge range of azobenzene derivatives with different acti vation wavelengths and photochemical properties can be relatively easily synthe sized. Secondly, the rod‐like trans‐azobenzenes (Figure 6.3a) are well miscible with LCs, often times exhibiting LC phases themselves. Therefore, they can be mixed with several LC systems without problems of macroscopic phase separa tion or crystallization. Finally, cis‐azobenzenes (Figure  6.3a), which are more globular in shape, are incompatible with LC phases, and tend to disrupt or desta bilize them [37]. When incorporated into LCNs, the molecular‐level trans–cis isomerization process (which gives rise to huge change in geometry, the length of the molecule changing from about 9.0 to 5.5 Å upon trans–cis isomerization) very efficiently modulates the molecular alignment within the polymer network, and triggers the photomechanical actuation through isothermal, photochemi cally induced order‐to‐disorder, or LC‐to‐isotropic, transition [34, 37].
The lifetime of the metastable cis‐azobenzene determines the stability of the deformed state of the LCN photoactuator. Depending on the chemical substitu tion, the cis‐lifetime can be controlled over a huge range, from sub‐milliseconds in tautomerizable push–pull azobenzenes [38] to months or even years in het erocyclic or ortho‐substituted azobenzenes [39, 40]. Using the latter, bi‐stable photoactuators that preserve the photodeformed shape at least for several days have been reported [41]. Importantly, however, when exposed to a wavelength that triggers the reverse cis–trans isomerization, the initial shape can be retained at will. Chemical substitution also plays an important role in tuning the activa tion wavelength of the azobenzenes, and there’s a thrust to replace conventional UV‐absorbing azobenzenes with ones absorbing in the visible wavelength range, an important goal especially in applications in sunlight‐energy harvesting and photobiology [42, 43].
Azobenzene‐based photochemical actuators often times exhibit photoinduced bending as opposed to in‐plane photocontraction. This is due to the strong
absorption of the azobenzene moieties, which constrains the light penetration into the LCN and confines the isomerization‐induced loss in alignment order only to the surface of the films [35]. Therefore, the cis‐azobenzene concentration depends on the distance from the sample surface, which gives rise to nonuniform stress distribution across the thickness and bending toward the illumination source (Figure 6.3b). Interestingly, the light‐induced photochemical strain may display strongly nonlinear time response. This is because the trans–cis isomeri zation gives rise to significant spectral changes and reduction of the absorption coefficient at the pump (UV) wavelength. Thereby the LCN gradually “pho tobleaches,” which affects the equilibrium shape of the photodeformed actuator. The nonlinear dynamics has been theoretically studied by Corbett and Warner [44, 45], and it has been also experimentally observed in homogeneously aligned, strip‐like photochemical actuators (Figure 6.3c) [36, 46].
204 6 Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics

sections.heading: 6.2.2 Photothermal Actuation
sections.text:
Another route toward photoactuation in LCNs is to employ photothermal heating to induce phase transition of the material. The mechanism behind the photothermal actuation is straightforward: the LCN is loaded with organic dyes or nanoparticles that, upon photon absorption, convert the absorbed light energy into heat through non‐radiative thermal relaxation processes. This heat is transferred into the polymer environment, triggering the light‐induced order– disorder transition and the subsequent shape change of the LCN [21]. An example of photothermal heating in a strip‐like actuator is given in Figure 6.4a, where irradiation with green light gives rise to temperature increase from 23 to 43 °C and resultant deformation of the LCN actuator.
2056.2 Photoactuation in LCNs
As the role of the photosensitive moieties incorporated into the LCN is merely to transfer the light energy into heat, a plethora of organic dyes and inorganic nanoparticles can be used for this purpose, some of which are shown in Figure  6.4. Azobenzenes with sufficiently short lifetime of the cis‐isomer or simultaneous activation of both trans–cis and cis–trans isomerization reactions are efficient photothermal heat generators, a feature that has been recently uti lized in various elegant photoactuator designs [16, 17, 48]. Broer and coworkers demonstrated that several non‐photoisomerizable organic dyes and photostabi lizers doped into the LCN serve the same purpose, and efficiently trigger the photothermal actuation [49]. The main requirement is that the dopants should be soluble in the LC mixture, which in most cases is not a problem because only a minor amount of the absorbers is enough to trigger significant photothermal heat generation. By proper dye selection, the LCN can be activated over the whole visible–near infrared (NIR) spectrum, rendering the photothermal effect suitable for human‐safe operation and biological applications where UV light should be avoided and the NIR wavelengths are particularly attractive [50]. By doping the LCN with several dyes, one can cover the whole sunlight spectrum, providing a pathway toward sunlight‐driven actuators and solar energy harvesting.
The second focal area in devising photothermally driven light‐fueled actuators is doping inorganic carbon‐based or metallic nanoparticles into the LCN [51]. The most prominent examples in this context are carbon nanotubes, which can be aligned along the direction of the LC mesogens [35], and actuated by both light and electric fields [52–56]. Another approach to utilize carbon nanomateri als is to incorporate graphene oxide flakes into a polymer environment to trigger the photothermal effect [57–59]. Gold nanoparticles are also an excellent alter native, due to the wealth of sizes and shapes (spheres, rods, stars, etc.) that can be synthesized, which in turn determine the plasmon resonance (and thereby the photothermal activation) wavelengths. Gold nanorods have been shown in some cases to self‐align along the LC director, giving rise to reconfigurable photome chanical movements of LCN films [60] or micropillar structures [61]. Despite the fact that only a minor amount of nanoinclusions is needed to bring about the light‐triggered shape change (in the order of 0.1 wt%) [62, 63], the main challenge in utilizing inorganic nanoparticles in LCNs is the poor miscibility, leading to deterioration in mechanical properties  [51], decrease in order parameter, and increased light scattering. Even if these problems can be addressed by proper surface functionalization of the nanoparticles to increase the compatibility between the nanoparticles and the LC polymer network, at present we foresee organic dyes as more promising candidates as photothermal agents in light‐ fueled LCN robotics.

sections.heading: 6.2.3 Comparison Between the Photochemical and Photothermal Effects
As described above, the photochemical and photothermal effects can both be utilized to realize LCN photoactuators, being potentially useful for future micro‐
sections.text:
robotic applications. Both mechanisms have their own strengths, and are likely to
206 6 Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics
find distinct use cases when devising light‐fueled robots. Herein we attempt to highlight their most important differences, and some of the characteristic fea tures of photochemical versus photothermal actuators are given in Table 6.1.
From a chemical point of view, the main difference between photochemically and photothermally activated LCNs lies in the position of the active units within the polymer network. For efficient photochemical actuation, the azobenzenes should be covalently (or noncovalently) bonded, preferably as cross‐links within the polymer network. Conversely, photothermal agents can be simply doped into the polymer network to yield efficient photoactuation. Covalent bonding between the photothermal units and the polymer network may allow increasing the concentration of the former, but to the best of our knowledge, it has not been shown that the bonding would be important from the viewpoint of efficiency of actuation. Secondly, typical azobenzenes are activated using ultraviolet or deep blue light, the reverse cis–trans isomerization taking place upon irradiation within the 450–550 nm range. Efforts have been taken toward shifting the activa tion wavelength to the green [64, 65] or even NIR wavelengths (using up‐ converting nanoparticles) [66]; yet, examples on this are still but few. In terms of efficient photoactuation using “human‐friendly,” low‐intensity visible/NIR wave lengths, photothermal actuators seem superior compared to their photochemi cal counterparts. Thirdly, the concentration of the photoactive moieties may be very different in these two cases. Generally, it is thought that by increasing the amount of azobenzene within a photochemically actuated LCN matrix, one can generate larger absorption/strain gradients, thereby boosting the photoactua tion. In fact, the first examples of photoinduced bending reported by the Ikeda group solely used azobenzene moieties (as both cross‐links and side chains) to fabricate their actuators [67, 68]. Contrarily, photothermal actuators yield rapid actuation even if the dye concentration would only be in the range of a few mole percentage, which is enough to absorb majority of the incoming light [69].
Important distinctions between the photochemical and photothermal actuators can also be made from the physical perspective. The first is the actuation speed. For a photochemical actuator, although the molecular‐level photoisomerization
2076.3 Diversity of Shape Changes in LCNs
reaction occurs almost instantaneously upon irradiation, the macroscopic defor mation of the polymer network takes seconds or even minutes [34]. The slow response can be considered as a drawback, but on the other hand, long lifetime of cis‐isomer enables bi‐stable performance of the actuator (i.e. the deformed geometry being preserved when the excitation is ceased) [41]. Photothermal actuators deform rapidly, within milliseconds to seconds, depending on the heat capacity. However, the original shape is also retained rapidly once the irradiation is ceased and the actuator cools down. A clear advantage of photochemical actua tors is the ability to function in several environments, including aqueous media [70, 71]. This is not the case for photothermal actuators, since the process relies on heat conduction, and the thermal conductivity of water is 20 times higher than for air, thus efficiently reducing the temperature of the actuator in aqueous envi ronment [72]. This poses great challenges for photothermal actuation in liquids, at least using light intensity levels that would be practically useful. The third dif ference we would like to point out relates to the fact that the photochemical effect relies on absorption gradients, which (i) makes it challenging to yield in‐ plane photocontraction (as opposed to out‐of‐plane bending) and (ii) may be accompanied with nonlinear bending dynamics due to “photobleaching,” as described earlier [36]. Photothermal actuation in typical LCNs (thickness limited to tens of microns), where temperature is rapidly equilibrated, is dictated by molecular alignment distribution across the sample: splay alignment gives rise to out‐of‐plane bending (toward the planar‐oriented film surface) and planar align ment to photocontraction, whereas in photochemically driven systems both cases yield bending deformation.
To summarize this part, by perfecting the material composition (e.g. cross‐link density to determine the stiffness of the material; photoactive units to choose between photothermal or photochemical actuation, or utilize them synergisti cally), the molecular alignment within the LCN of desired thickness and the properties of the light field triggering the actuation process, efficient photoac tuation can be attained. What renders LCN robotics unique is the ability to obtain multiple deformation modes using the same material composition and the same stimuli, simply by controlling the molecular alignment within the LCN. Such “programmability” yields a huge diversity in the light‐induced shape changes, as will be demonstrated in Section 6.3.

sections.heading: 6.3 Diversity of Shape Changes in LCNs
6.3.1 Uniaxial Contraction/Expansion
sections.text: Uniaxially aligned LCNs can undergo reversible contraction–expansion along the molecular director axis n, thus presenting muscle‐like motion under external stimulus [26, 73]. The LC molecular alignment order is described by the order parameter S = ½(cos2θ − 1) [74], where θ is the average angular deviation of the

sections.heading: LC molecules from n. Under light irradiation, the LCN becomes more disor dered, resulting in an increase in θ and decrease in S. Owing to the anisotropic
sections.text:
nature of LCNs and the presence of cross‐links, increased θ manifests itself as
macroscopic contraction along the director axis, and expansion in the perpen dicular directions (Figure 6.5a). This macroscopic deformation, arising from the change in molecular orientation, was firstly theoretically predicted by de Gennes [75], and experimentally demonstrated by Finkelmann et al. [24]. The degree of stimuli‐induced contraction depends on the type of monomer as well as on the properties of the polymer chains forming the network. Different polymeric architectures can be adopted, e.g. main‐chain, end‐on, and side‐on polymers, among which the main‐chain LCNs display the highest strains and active forces (Figure 6.5b) [11, 12].

sections.heading: 6.3.2 Bending and Coiling
sections.text:
Bending deformation is by far the most studied photoactuation mode in LCNs. What makes LCNs unique compared to other light‐responsive materials is the ability toward bending motion in a monolithic material, i.e. without using a bilayer‐construction strategy [76, 77], alike in bi‐metallic cantilevers. This can be obtained by programming the molecular alignment, or by implementing light‐ absorption gradients that result in unhomogeneous stresses across the actuator thickness [74]. The typical molecular‐alignment configurations used (in addi tion to the homogeneous planar and homeotropic alignments) are twisted align ment (in‐plane rotation of the director by 90° from one surface to the other) and splay alignment (gradually tilting the director from horizontal to vertical), as illustrated in Figure 6.6a, respectively. Both twisted and splay alignment can trig ger inhomogeneous inner stress across the film thickness when exposed to homogeneous stimuli, leading to contraction along n and expansion in the other directions, and bending toward the planar‐aligned surface (in strip geometry with twisted alignment, the bending is toward the direction where the director is parallel to the strip).
In order to observe pure bending deformation in splay‐aligned and twist‐ aligned LCNs, the angle between the director and cutting axis (the long axis of the strip), denoted here as ϕ, should be close to zero. If ϕ is nonzero, the splay and twisted alignments can give rise to coils and helicoids, depending on ϕ. It is reported that a twist‐aligned strip with high aspect ratio having ϕ = ±45° exhibits helicoidal deformation, whereas a wider one tends to coil [79]. The sign of ϕ dictates the handedness of the structure, and deviation from ±45° results in dif ferent pitch of the coiling. Making use of this chirality, Katsonis and coworkers demonstrated the fabrication of right‐handed and left‐handed spiral ribbons that, upon light illumination, could undergo complex light‐induced motions and perform work (Figure 6.6b) [78, 80, 81].

sections.heading: 6.3.3 From Flat Sheets to Cones
sections.text:
The examples above represent one‐dimensional strip‐like actuators, whose alignment difference across the thickness yields bending or coiling deformations. A two‐dimensional LCN film with uniform director across the film thickness but spatially varying in the plane of the film yields very different actuation. Modes and Warner have theoretically predicted that if an azimuthally or radially aligned defect is adopted into an LCN, a flat film deforms out of plane, forming a cone or a saddle [82]. The existence of such a buckling deformation due to defect‐like molecular alignment was confirmed experimentally by Broer and coworkers and is presented in Figure 6.7 [83]. These pioneering studies have led to many follow‐ ups of inscribing defect structures onto LCN films by using different fabrication
techniques. For example, laser scanning [32], microchannels [84], and laser projector patterning [85], have been used to inscribe similar LC defects into different LCNs.

sections.heading: 6.3.4 Shape Changes via Complex Alignment Patterning
sections.text:
An elegant way of controlling the light‐induced shape changes in LCN films is to locally pattern the director alignment across the film area. To achieve this, pho toalignment is a powerful technique [86]. Photoalignment involves controlling the orientation of LC molecules by exposing a “command layer” with polarized light. The command layer contains light‐sensitive units such as azobenzenes that tend to orient perpendicular to the polarization of light, or photopolymers that give rise to LC alignment parallel to polarization [87]. Molecules in the com mand layer guide the orientation of the LC monomers. Thus, by spatially con trolling the light intensity or polarization, an arbitrary alignment profile can be patterned onto an LCN film [33]. In the following text we present some examples of such photoalignment patterning and the light‐induced shape changes obtained thereof.
Schenning and coworkers reported an accordion‐shaped actuator by pat terning directors into four distinct orientation areas [88]. Each area consists of a 90° twist across the film thickness, however, exhibiting opposite twist direc tions in adjacent areas as shown in Figure  6.8a. Bending occurs under light illumination, while the alignment patterning ensures that the strip bends toward alternate directions in the adjacent regions, resembling an accordion.
Broer and  coworkers patterned an array of defects onto an LCN film, which they carefully cut along some defect lines, thus obtaining a flat film with a series of apertures. Those apertures could be opened and closed in a reversible fashion under light irradiation [91]. White and coworkers used a scanning laser beam with controllable polarization to pattern a flat LCN film with a 3 ×  3 array of defect‐type alignment patterns, which deformed into pyramids upon
212 6 Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics
heating (Figure  6.8b) [92]. This concept has been further optimized by the same group in several follow‐ups [93, 94]. Our group has used a commercial miniature laser projector to locally pattern the LCN alignment to obtain an octopus‐like actuator, able to bend its arms in opposite directions, as dictated by the alignment patterning (Figure 6.8c) [85].
Despite all the significant advancements mentioned above, a major limitation associated with film‐like actuators is the restriction to two dimensions. Recently, this limitation has been overcome by introducing 3D printing in the context of LCNs [89, 90, 95]. Ware and coworkers demonstrated a 3D‐printed LCN where the LC alignment direction was controlled by the material flow through the nozzle. The structure could be efficiently actuated and reshaped through ther mal triggering (Figure  6.8d) [89]. 3D printing also provides access to tunable actuators with photonic/robotic functions, as shown by Sánchez‐Somolinos and coworkers who fabricated an adaptive lens by integrating a 3D‐printed LCN ring with polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) (Figure 6.8e) [90]. These are but the first steps taken with 3D‐printable LCN structures, and we expect several other breakthroughs to follow in the near future.

sections.heading: 6.4 Physics and Dynamics of Small‐Scale Robots
sections.text:
We have discussed diverse photoactuation modes in LCNs, due to pre‐designed distribution of molecular alignment. But, the question is: how to proceed from actuation to robotics? In other words, how to build a light‐fueled device that can not only move its legs, but also walk? To answer this question, the interaction between the actuator and its environment must be considered, which is the scope of this section.
In order to understand the dynamics of small‐scale robots, it is important to examine the forces involved in the system. Although the physics remains the same for small‐scale objects and the ones acting at a macroscopic scale, the ratio between different forces and their contribution to the robotic actuation, can differ a lot. The forces that dominate depend highly on the characteristic length L of the object, a feature known as the scaling effect [96]. For example, the gravity force G and inertia are related to the entire volume of the object that scales with L3, while active forces Fa, such as the muscular strength of an animal and the light‐induced elastic force of an LCN robot, depend on the area, scaling with L2. The ratio between Fa and G thus scales with L−1, rendering the overall force strongly size‐dependent. For a human weighing 80 kg (~800 N), the maximum pushing force from the legs is about 2000 N. Thus the ratio between Fa and G is small, <3. For an LCN robot with dimensions of, say, 5 × 1 × 0.02 mm3, the gravi tational force is c. 1 μN (for a material with density of about 1.1 g cm−3) and the light‐driven elastic force can reach 2 mN ( cross‐section of 1 × 0.02 mm2, active stress pressure c. 100 kPa), corresponding to Fa/G > 1000. The different Fa/G ratios at the different size scales point out that the design concepts for achieving efficient movement are distinct at the microscopic and macroscopic scales. This is evident in natural systems: big mammals build up strong skeleton to support their weight on land, and use two or four limbs to be able to walk or run; small
2136.4 Physics and Dynamics of Small‐Scale Robots
animals such as spiders or insets can easily jump over very long distances due to the minor role played by gravitation, yet they have evolved with four or six legs with specific gaits because of the enhanced adhesion at the microscale. Even the simplest type of motion – walking – requires very different strategies at different scales [97].
Walking is locomotion at an interface, where a robot encounters forces, most notably adhesion and friction. Adhesion can be defined as the force required to separate two objects that are close together (a pull‐off force). At the micro scale, this force arises from a combination of van der Waals, capillary, and other forces. Van der Waals forces originate from fluctuating dipoles, being present in all materials [98]. They are only significant over very short distances (a few nanometers), thus being strongly affected by the contact area and sur face roughness. When liquid exists at the interface, the capillary force becomes important. This attractive force originates from the desire to minimize the liquid surface energy between the surfaces [99]. The estimation of friction f for a soft‐bodied micro‐robot becomes very tricky, since the classical equation f = μN (μ: friction coefficient, N: the normal force) does not properly describe the forces between soft materials. With negligible gravitation and enhanced adhesion, the friction depends highly on the material rigidity [100]. Upon light illumination, an LCN is softened, increasing the efficient contact area leading to a higher adhesion. Because of this, a microscopic walker gets easily stuck on the substrate, and cyclic shape change can no longer generate walking motion. Several methods have been developed to decrease the friction experienced by a walking LCN robot. For example, one can use additional elements (legs) made of rigid materials and with a conical tip to minimize the contact area. One may also isolate the soft body from the substrate, using, e.g. spacer parti cles or silicon oil.
Swimming can be considered as locomotion in a homogeneous liquid medium. Also in this case, the interaction between the object (swimmer) and the sur rounding environment plays a significant role. The ratio between the inertial forces and the viscous forces is given by the Reynolds number [101], Re =  ρ vd/μ, where ρ and μ are the density and viscosity of the liquid, respectively, and ν and d the velocity and the characteristic size of the object. Since ν and d both depend linearly on L, Re scales with L2. Therefore, a gigantic whale in an ocean can reach an Re of 107, a typical fish usually has an Re around 1–10, and bacteria have an Re in the range of 10−5 [102]. A representation of the Reynolds numbers experi enced by different systems is given in Figure 6.9. For small‐scale LCN robots, using a micro‐swimmer demonstrated by Fischer’s group as an example (cylin drical structure, 1 mm in length and 200 μm in diameter, ν: ~1 μm s−1) [19], the Re is in the range of 10−4 in water, decreasing significantly, to 10−8 or so, in a viscous liquid such as glycerol.
Qualitatively, the swimming mechanics is governed by inertial forces for large Reynolds numbers, and when the Re is small, viscous forces dominate the motion. Clearly, LCN robots belong to the latter class. Quantitatively, for Re << 1, the flow of a fluid is described by the Stokes equation [101]:
∇ = ∇ +P v ff 2
where, Pf is the fluid pressure and f is the external force. The equation does not contain any inertial terms and it is fully time‐reversible. This implies that a per fect time‐reciprocal motion cannot create a net motion. Thus, in order to con struct an LCN‐based micro‐swimmer, a specific movement sequence must be chosen in actuation. Generally, in a nonreciprocal movement series, such as jellyfish type, travelling‐wave‐like, or spiral movement, is adopted [103].
Concerning the energy and control in LCN micro‐robotics, a wireless approach by using a light field provides important advantages in delivering energy into the robotic system. The powering intensity typically ranges from few tens of milli watt per square centimeter (a non‐focused light‐emitting diode (LED) source), to >102 W cm−2 when focused laser beams are used. The speed of photothermal heating of an LCN robot is governed by its heat capacity C, i.e. a measured physi cal quantity that estimates how fast the heat loss/gain is conducted in the system. Generally, C scales with the volume (L3) of the object. Thus if the size decreases, the LCN robot exhibits a rapidly increasing speed in actuation. Examples are shown in two LCN robots constituting the same material: an inching walker with body length of 1 cm that deforms in few seconds, while a 100‐μm‐sized LCN robot undergoes complete shape change within only 30 ms [72].
In an LCN, the actuation force originates from the light‐responsive elastic force, which scales with the cross‐section (L2), while the mass scales with L3. As a consequence, the acceleration, a = F/m (a: acceleration, F: active force, and m: mass) scales with L−1 and the robot’s movement speed is boosted by decreasing its dimensions. This brings about some unusual characteristics of LCN micro‐ robots. Namely the light‐induced force exerted by it can be remarkably huge: a vortexed LCN can lift up a load 150 times heavier than its own weight [92], and a 1.8‐cm sized LCN “catapult” can launch a cotton ball with a speed of 30 cm s−1 [104]. The elastic force, assisted by mechanical snapping motion, can exceed the
2156.5 A Historical Overview of Light‐Fueled Micro‐robots
weight of the actuator, leading to a jumping motion [89]. At the microscopic scale, the jumping can be very pronounced: being stuck on a rough substrate (e.g. paper), once the elastic energy is released due to some random fluctuations, the robot can jump over a distance of tens of its body lengths [16].

sections.heading: 6.5 A Historical Overview of Light‐Fueled Micro‐robots
sections.text:
After the invention of LCNs, extensive research effort has been put to com prehend the diverse possibilities offered by this intriguing class of materials. Actuators with different chemical composition, responses to different stimuli, and with increased sensitivity, have been devised, to provide ever‐more sophisti cated control over their movements. At the same time, several fabrication tech niques such as photoalignment [92], direct laser writing [105], and 3D printing [89] have been perfected to create diverse forms of actuators capable of fascinat ing shape changes for robotic applications. The pathway from an actuator to a robot is rather long as the material design parameters have to be re‐thought, and the concepts taken from existing robots cannot be directly generalized to the context of LCN robots. Yet significant developments have been made over the past decade. Herein, we have collected the achievements we deem the most important in light‐fueled LCN devices that perform specific robotic functions. Most of the highlighted results, comprising, e.g. walkers, swimmers, and grip pers, are compiled in Figure 6.10, together with their publication years. This his torical timeline reveals a clear trend: since 2008, which marked the beginning of light‐fueled robotics as we define it, the field is drawing more and more atten tion, and has reached a booming phase in the past three years.
In 2008, Ikeda and co‐workers reported a ring‐like LCN motor that could per form rolling motion by irradiating the motor simultaneously with UV and visible light at different positions (Figure 6.10a) [106]. This motor served as a plastic belt to drive the motion of a pulley system, transferring light energy directly into per petual mechanical motion. This pioneering work has acted as a source of inspira tion for much of the light robotics research to follow. For example, in 2017 Broer and coworkers fabricated a light‐driven “windmill device,” converting light energy directly into rotating motion, obtaining rotation frequency of about 1 Hz (Figure 6.10p) [113]. An important feature of these achievements as compared to robots introduced later on is that the systems operate “autonomously,” producing continuous movement under stationary illumination.
Shortly after introducing the plastic motor, the Ikeda group devised a bilayer actuator by laminating a polyethylene film with the same LCN material [107]. Using such a hybrid actuator, several deformation modes such as robotic‐arm movement, were demonstrated. Combined with an asymmetric plastic substrate, the bilayer actuator experienced friction bias at the robot–ground interface, thereby being capable of inchworm‐like movement (Figure 6.10b). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an LCN‐based walking robot. In 2013, Kohlmeyer and Chen reported a carbon‐nanotube‐doped LCN–polycarbonate bilayer actuator that could be driven with infrared illumination [108]. They devised a light‐driven inchworm capable of crawling up a surface at 50° inclination, assisted
216 6 Liquid Crystal Polymer Networks and Elastomers for Light‐Fueled Robotics
by ratcheted wood surface and asymmetric geometry of the polycarbonate (Figure 6.10c). In 2015, the Wiersma group presented the first microscopic LCN robot (Figure 6.10d) [16]. The robot was fabricated using direct laser writing, and was composed of photodeformable LCN body and conical polymer legs made of photo‐resin. The length of the robot was only 60 μm (less than the thickness of human hair), and it performed rotation, directional walking, and jumping, depend ing on the substrate conditions.
The above examples relied on temporal control of the light stimulus: the motion was driven by switching the light source on and off, which induced cyclic shape changes to the robot, while the pre‐patterned asymmetry gave rise

This was demonstrated in 2016 by Wasylczyk and coworkers, who devised a caterpillar‐ mimicking walker whose walking direction could be controlled by scanning a laser beam across the laser body (Figure 6.10e) [109]. In their device, the friction bias was not brought about by pre‐patterned structural asymmetry, but by the momen tum transfer from the scanned laser beam to the robot body, allowing locomo tion to both forward and backward directions. The same light actuation strategies (temporal versus spatial modulation of the light fields) can also be applied to realize swimming robots. In 2015, a hybrid LCN swimmer was reported by Yu and coworkers [18]. They connected an LCN element to a flexible flagellum, and temporally switched light‐actuation‐triggered cyclic flipping motion, mimicking the motion of a fish and propelling itself in water (Figure 6.10f ). In 2016, Fischer and coworkers reported a microscopic LCN swimmer driven by patterned light field obtained using a digital mirror array [19]. Similar to the laser scanning used for the caterpillar walker (Figure 6.10e), the modulated light field triggered trav elling‐wave deformation inside the LCN filament, enabling swimming motion in a high‐viscosity liquid (Figure 6.10g).
The fascinating story of walking light‐fueled robot continues, and the results published in 2016 and 2017 demonstrate, for example, a human‐friendly millimeter‐sized walker mimicking the inching motion of a caterpillar larva (Figure  6.10h) [4], and a spiral roller built in between two plastic wheels (Figure 6.10i) [110]. The most remarkable advancements of 2016 and 2017 relate to light‐driven robots capable of autonomous locomotion. In 2016, White and coworkers reported an LCN spiral ribbon that can roll over large distances under spatially and temporally stationary illumination (Figure  6.10j) [111]. In such a device, the upper part of the polymer tends to exhibit a larger twisting

The asymmetric deformation brings about dynamic strains that con tinuously deform the spiral geometry and give rise to a net twisting moment. In 2017, Broer and coworkers constructed a photothermally driven LCN confined between the walls of a two‐walled structure performing wave‐like oscillation under static illumination. They harnessed such an autonomous wave‐like oscil lation to achieve light‐fueled walking without any temporal or spatial modula tion of the light field (Figure 6.10k) [17].
Considering the light robots of tomorrow, the LCN walkers are likely to evolve toward fully automated movements. This is already happening, as the examples ranging from spatial (scanning the laser beam, pointing the illumination source at a specific location on the robot body) and temporal light modulation (switch ing the light source on and off ) to robots moving under stationary light fields demonstrate. Further, one may utilize yet another unique feature of LCNs, which is the coupling between the properties of the light field and the material shape changes. The light‐induced deformation can be dynamic, in the sense that it provides feedback to the original light field through changes in the light absorp tion, which in turn further modifies the deformation. This special feedback loop may provide a paradigm shift for “traditional light robotics” with structured light fields: just let the robot sense the illumination conditions and act autono mously based on the feedback received from the environment. In this context two examples are highlighted, one based on gripping devices and one on iris‐like devices. In 2010, Yu and coworkers realized a visible‐light‐controlled actuator based on an LCN–polyethylene bilayer structure [20]. They fabricated a grip ping device consisting of “hand,” “wrist,” and “arm,” by integrating photoactua tors into three segments, and demonstrating several photodeformation modes. This way, for the first time they demonstrated transportation of a micro‐object by a series of light illumination sequences exposing different parts of the robot (Figure  6.10l). About seven years later, another gripping device has been pro posed by Priimagi and coworkers, where the gripping action is triggered by opti cal feedback, without the need for human intervention (Figure 6.10m) [5]. The LCN actuator is fabricated onto the tip of an optical fiber, which emits light and forms a “field of view” to the front of the device. The gripping action only takes place when an object in the field of view reflects or scatters enough light to the LCN actuator, thereby “recognizing” and selecting different targets based on the optical feedback. A similar concept was used by Wiersma and coworkers, who fabricated a microscopic LCN hand that autonomously closes on hot particles, with the ability to recognize different colors [48]. The second example, the iris‐ like actuation, dates back to 2014 when Zappe and coworkers presented an LCN‐based iris device in which the aperture dimension could be tuned by elec tromagnetic heating (Figure 6.10n) [112]. To function like the human iris, the device was operated via a specific control circuit: the transmitted light intensity was measured with a photodetector, and the information was sent to the power ing source of the actuator, which in turn tuned the aperture size. In 2017, Priimagi and coworkers demonstrated an autonomous LCN‐based approach for an iris‐mimicking device acting without a control circuit. The device is made by using radial molecular alignment and a structure with 12 petals that are open in
2196.6 Outlook
dark conditions, and gradually close under light illumination, thereby control ling light transmission similarly to the human eye (Figure 6.10o) [69]. From the above examples, we can draw the conclusion that interplay between material properties and light fields results in autonomy, which may pave way toward small‐scale robots that not only mimic the movements of natural systems, but also their intelligence.

sections.heading: 6.6 Outlook
sections.text:
After decades of work toward comprehending and perfecting the chemical design and physical control of LCN actuators, the road is paved for a transition from photoactuation to light‐fueled robotics. It can be perceived that the time is ripe for taking LCN actuators toward robotic applications, as exemplified by the significant advancements taken during 2016 and 2017 (see Figure 6.10). What makes LCN photoactuators particularly attractive is their intrinsically dynamic light response: light absorption induces material shape change, while at the same time the deformed shape modifies the material absorption, thereby self‐ adjusting its own deformation. Such optical–mechanical feedback provides the LCN actu ators a very unique capacity, namely self‐regulation, which can be used to realize sophisticated, dynamic robots such as light‐driven oscillators and autonomous propellers and walkers. We can foresee such autonomous actuation, driven by dynamic light‐response in the material, to adopt a significant role in the design of future LCN robots.
Within the next years, significant breakthroughs can be anticipated in both fabrication technologies and materials design. Regarding the former, we espe cially point out the recently demonstrated 3D printing of LCNs, which we expect to yield monolithic, complex robotic structures with delicate motion control [89, 90, 95]. From the materials point of view, reconfigurable materials based on dynamic covalent bonds [114–116], actuators responding to multiple colors of light [117], and LCNs whose stiffness can be patterned [28, 118], are deemed particularly promising. Such studies pave way for adaptive LCN actuators, whose performance can be reprogrammed at will, and that respond not only to light, but to multiple stimuli (or distinctly to different colors).
Finally, great efforts should be put into devising efficient robotic movement strategies. For movements at interfaces, controlling the interactions between the LCN device and the substrate (friction and adhesion) is the key, and the dream case would be if these interactions could be dynamically controlled to yield, e.g.  locomotion steering. For movements in homogeneous medium such as swimming, nonreciprocal actuation strategies should be further developed. Although LCN robotics is inspired by nature, it should strongly interface with soft‐robotic research conducted with more traditional materials. To put the opportunities offered by LCNs in next‐generation soft robots into broader soft robotics context [119], it is important that the LCN researchers outreach the whole soft‐robotics community, increasing the awareness on the unique features offered by these materials and finding the niche where LCNs offer a break through for the future.

sections.heading: 7.1 Introduction to Liquid Crystals
sections.text:
The liquid crystal (LC) phase can be generally attained either by the action of heat on a mesogen or by dissolving an amphiphilic compound into an appropri ate solvent [1–4]. It is also known as “mesophase,” which refers to the amalgama tion of the intermediate order and mobility of LC phases as compared to those of solids and liquids. The unique combination of facile mobility with the inter‐ and intramolecular order makes mesophases extremely sensitive to external stimuli such as thermal, mechanical, chemical, electrical, light, or magnetic fields. Chemically, these mesogens can be organic, organometallic, or inorganic in nature. The mesophases obtained by temperature variation are called thermotropic. Thermo dynamically stable mesophases that appear on both heating and cooling are termed enantiotropic, while the thermotropic mesophases that appear only on cooling are referred to as monotropic. On the other hand, LC phases formed by dissolving amphiphilic compounds in an appropriate solvent (under given concentration and temperature conditions) are known as lyotropic. Besides, there are some molecules that exhibit LC phases under the influence of both heat and solvent; such systems are referred to as amphotropic LCs. Lyotropic LC phases are frequently encountered in everyday life, and most importantly, life itself is critically based on such ordered fluids [5–8]. Despite the significance of lyotropic LCs, thermotropic LCs have claimed relatively greater attention, firstly because they are simple to realize and handle, and secondly because they serve as an important component in the fabrication of low‐power display devices. Notably, both kinds of LCs, in part, have facilitated our understanding of the supramo lecular chemistry driven by secondary interactions [5, 6]. The classification of mesogens and mesophases has always been a complicated task; this is because over the past three decades a rich variety of mesophases have been discovered
Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications Ammathanadu S. Amrutha1, Ammathanadu S. Achalkumar1, and Quan Li2
1 Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Department of Chemistry, Near Doul Gobinda Road, Amingaon, North Guwahati, Guwahati, 781039, India 2 Kent State University, Liquid Crystal Institute and Chemical Physics Interdisciplinary Program, 1425 Lefton Esplanade, Kent, OH 44242, USA

through conventional, nonconventional, or new molecular architecture. None theless, some basic principles are followed to categorize them. First and fore most, as mentioned above, they are fundamentally classified as being either thermotropic or lyotropic given the fact that the method of their realization and therefore, the resulting mesomorphism differs significantly. In particular, the mode of mesophase formation in thermotropics is by the organization of the individual molecules in contrast to that in lyotropics wherein the constituent (solute) molecules firstly aggregate and these fine structures then form different mesophases that generally depend on the temperature and concentration. Besides, there are different ways to classify these materials; for example, in terms of their structure (into amphiphilic and non‐amphiphilic molecules); molecular shape (calamitic, discotic, banana mesogens, etc.); molecular size (as low‐ and high‐molecular weight compounds); and with respect to the type of mesophase formed (nematic, cholesteric, smectic, columnar, cubic mesophases, etc.). The work presented in this chapter focuses on thermotropic LCs and hence our dis cussion is restricted only to this topic .
Most of the crystals on heating transform into the isotropic liquid phase by simultaneous loss of the long‐range positional and orientational orders. If the molecules possess a certain amount of shape anisotropy, then the loss in one, two, or three dimensions of long‐range translational order in the crystal may precede the complete breakdown of the long‐range orientational order. Such compounds may show a series of mesomorphic transitions into fluid states that exhibit varying degrees of the structural symmetries. The temperature at which the crystal transforms into the mesophase is called the melting point while that from the mesophase to the isotropic state is called the clearing point.
Materials displaying thermotropic LC property are mostly organic or metal‐ containing organic compounds. Among the enormous number of organic compounds known, only a small fraction shows this LC behavior. Such types of compounds usually comprise hard (rigid) and soft (flexible) regions. The aro matic cores and some nonaromatic cores account for the rigidity while paraffinic chains are the soft regions of the molecule. However, these two distinct parts are combined in a specific way so as to attain a particular anisotropic shape of the molecule. The mobility in these systems is provided by large amplitude motions associated with molecules or molecular segments, namely the flexible tails/ chains. The orientational order arises from the parallel alignment of anisometric molecules, while the positional order is predominantly the outcome of specific attractive forces and amphiphilic nature. Further, these interactions are also influenced by the presence of permanent dipole moments, their magnitude or the anisotropy of the molecular polarizability. Thus the anisotropic shape of the molecule plays a very important role in determining the formation and type of the LC phases.
Conventionally, rod‐like and disk‐shaped mesogens exhibit thermotropic mes omorphism; they are popularly known as calamitics and discotics respectively. For many years, it was believed that only long or rod‐shaped molecules could be mesogenic (Figure 7.1a). However, in 1977 Chandrasekhar et al., demonstrated that even disc‐like molecules (Figure  7.1b) such as benzene‐1,2,3,4,5,6‐hexayl hexaoctanoate display mesomorphism [9].
In the following section, a brief account on the general molecular structural features of rod‐like mesogens is presented. In rod‐like molecules, the axial dimension is larger than the radial one, while it is the other way round in discot ics. As shown in a general template of a rod‐like mesogen, RC1 and RC2 are the rigid cores that are often aromatic in nature but may also be alicyclic. These two cores are connected either directly through a covalent bond or via a linking unit L (e.g. ─COO─, ─CH2─CH2, ─CH═N─ and ─N═N─). The terminal substitu ents R and R′ are usually either alkyl or alkoxy chains. In many cases, one of the terminal units is a polar substituent such as CN, F, NCO, NCS, and NO2. In some special cases, the lateral units X and Y (e.g. F, Cl, CN, and CH3) are incorporated in the main molecular structure. Further, by employing rod‐like mesogenic seg ments, both the main chain and side chain liquid crystal polymers (LCPs) have been designed and synthesized [2]. In the main chain LCPs, several rod‐like ani sotropic segments (the repeating units) join axially to form a long chain (the back bone). In side chain LCPs, rod‐like mesogens are attached to the side of the poly mer backbone. Inclusion of molecular chirality in rod‐like molecules furnishes chiral LCs, which are known to exhibit various chiral structures [10].
Driven by curiosity and also in a quest to obtain novel mesophases, a great deal of attention has been paid to the design and synthesis of several different novel molecular architectures wherein the anisometric shape deviates from the con ventional rod or disk forms [11–14]; they are collectively known as “nonconven tional liquid crystals.” A common feature of a majority of such materials is the structural contrast within a molecule i.e. these molecules are made up of chemi cally different molecular parts that are incompatible/immiscible with each other. Some of the important examples of nonconventional systems are oligomers, polycatenars, bent‐core molecules, polyhydroxy amphiphiles, octahedral com plexes, star‐shaped molecules, rod‐coil molecules, and dendrimers [2]. Based on the structural diversity or shape anisotropy and external stimuli such as tempera ture and pressure, a rich variety of LC phases have been observed. The structural differences between these phases are quite narrow and therefore the precise characterization of LC phases requires the use of different techniques such as polarizing optical microscopy (POM), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and X‐ray diffraction (XRD) . Other experimental techniques such as electro‐ optic measurements and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy are also in use for the characterization of mesophases. In the following section, mes omorphism exhibited by conventional calamitic and discotic molecules will be
230 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
discussed. Some of the nonconventional molecular structures mentioned in the previous section, which show a distinctive phase behavior, are discussed in recent review articles [5, 6, 15, 16].

sections.heading: 7.2 Classification of Liquid Crystals
7.2.1 Calamitic Liquid Crystals: Phase Types and Structures
sections.text: Originally, the mesophases exhibited by calamitic mesogens were classified into nematic, cholesteric, and smectic varieties based on the degree of positional and orientational orders (Figure 7.2). The discovery of new LC phases turns out to be usually associated with increased complexity. As discussed in previous sections, till date a number of liquid crystalline phases have been discovered with the help of several complementing characterization techniques [17].

sections.heading: 7.2.1.1 Nematic (N) and Cholesteric (N*) Mesophase
sections.text:
The simplest LC phase is the nematic phase and it generally occurs just below the  isotropic phase with a viscosity comparable to those of isotropic liquids. Depending on the substrate surface conditions, the N phase exhibits schlieren, marble‐type, and pseudoisotropic textures. In this phase, the constituent mole cules have no positional order but are on an average, oriented about a particular direction called the director, n. The molecular organization in the nematic phase is illustrated in Figure 7.2. Although the preferred direction of molecules varies from point to point in the medium, a uniformly aligned sample is optically uni axial (Nu) and birefringent. However, the biaxial modification of this phase Nb is also known [2]. Cholesteric mesophase is the chiral variant of the nematic meso phase and therefore it is also called the chiral nematic phase. It occurs in systems where the constituent molecules are chiral [10]. It can also be obtained by dop ing the nematic LC with optically active molecules. In these systems, there is a weak tendency for neighboring molecules to align at a slight angle to one another.
This leads the local director to form a helix (either right‐ or left‐handed depend ing on the molecular conformation) in space with a well‐defined pitch that is much longer than the size of a single molecule. The cholesteric state is illustrated in Figure  7.3a. This helical arrangement is responsible for the unique optical properties of the phase, such as selective reflection [18]. When plane‐polarized light interacts with this chiral macroscopic structure, its plane of polarization gets rotated along the helix direction. When the pitch of the helix corresponds to a wavelength falling in the visible region of the spectrum (~400–800 nm) the chiral mesophase is colored. Importantly, the pitch of the helix is sensitive to a small change in temperature, and therefore, also to the reflected wavelength. Furthermore, these helical structures can be untwisted by the application of an electric field, which drives the reorientation of the molecular axis along the field direction. Depending on the surface conditions, the N* phase exhibits finger print and oily streak textures.

sections.heading: 7.2.1.2 Smectic (Sm) Mesophase
sections.text:
In some phases, the average molecular center of gravity is arranged in equidis tant planes, and hence in addition to orientational order, a positional order also exists, leading to a layered structure. Such phases are known as smectics (Sm) (Figure 7.2). Depending on the molecular arrangement within the layer and the extent of inter‐layer correlations, smectic mesophases are further classified into different types [19]. Fluidity of the layer is an essential characteristic of all smec tic phases. A more rigorous way to treat the layering arrangement is to consider a one‐dimensional mass density wave [20]. There are many different smectic LC phases discovered thus far. They are smectic A (SmA), smectic B (SmB, also known as hexatic B) (non‐tilted Sm phases), smectic C (SmC), smectic F (SmF), and smectic I (SmI) (tilted Sm phases). The chiral smectic mesophases are formed when the constituent molecules are chiral. There are chiral SmA, chiral smectic C (SmC*), chiral smectic I (SmI*), and chiral smectic F (SmF*) phases. The SmA and SmC phases and their chiral variants are the most commonly
232 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
observed and extensively investigated fluid phases. In the following section, the structural details of some of the important smectic phases have been discussed briefly.
Smectic A (SmA) and Chiral SmA Phases In the smectic A phase, the director lies along the layer normal. The molecular packing within the layers is liquid‐like and has no long‐range positional correlation. Likewise, there is no correlation between the lateral positions of the molecules in successive layers. Similarly to biaxial nematic phase, SmA can also possess biaxial symmetry that has been termed the biaxial smectic A (SmAb) phase wherein the molecules are along the layer normal, but have an additional director in the plane of the layers.Although the chiral version of the smectic A phase (observed with optically active molecules) is structurally the same as that of achiral SmA, owing to molecular chirality the symmetry is reduced from D∞h to D∞. As a consequence, in the SmA phase, when an electric field is applied orthogonal to the layer normal direction there will be a coupling of the electroclinic susceptibility to the field and the long molecular axes of the molecules will tilt with respect to the layer planes. For relatively low applied fields, the tilt angle varies linearly with the field. This linear electro‐optic phenomenon is called the electroclinic effect [21]. Both SmA and chiral SmA phases exhibit characteristic focal‐conic texture in slides treated for planar orientation and a dark field of view in slides treated for homeotropic orientation.
Smectic C (SmC) and  Chiral Smectic C (SmC*) Phases The smectic C phase differs from the SmA phase, in that the director of each layer is inclined at an angle to the layer normal and this angle is identical for all layers (Figure 7.2) [22]. While the SmA phase is generally optically uniaxial, the SmC phase is optically biaxial. The tilt angle in this phase has been shown to vary with temperature and it often increases monotonically with decreasing temperature. X‐ray studies indicate that the layer thickness in this phase is considerably less than the molecular length. The symmetry elements of this phase correspond to the point group C2h. In the chiral smectic C (SmC*) phase, which is formed by optically active molecules, a macroscopic helical arrangement of the molecules exist. The helix occurs as a result of a gradual change in the molecular tilt direction (n) from layer to layer, about an axis perpendicular to the layer planes (Figure 7.3b). Owing to the presence of chiral molecules, the SmC* phase has reduced C2 symmetry, which creates inequivalence in the dipole moment along the C2 axis normal to the tilt direction, resulting in spontaneous polarization (Ps) in each layer. However, the presence of helix averages out the Ps to zero [22]. Nevertheless, to obtain a macroscopic Ps (ferroelectric behavior) the helix can be unwound by surface interactions or by the application of an electric field [23].

sections.heading: 7.2.1.3 Chiral Frustrated Phases
sections.text:
Chirality effectively reduces the molecular symmetry, which in turn can signifi cantly modify the mesomorphic behavior. Chiral molecules prefer to pack in a certain manner, but such a structure cannot be adopted everywhere due to
2337.2 Classification of Liquid Crystals
molecular constraints. Such a situation leads to the stabilization of frustrated phases [17, 18]. Examples include blue phases (BP) and twist grain boundary (TGB) phases, the structures of which are briefly described further.
Blue Phases (BP) These are distinct thermodynamic phases that appear over a narrow temperature range between chiral nematic and isotropic liquid phases in short pitch (<5000 Å) chiral nematic LCs [10] that are usually single component optically active rod‐like mesogens or mixtures composed of achiral and optically active mesogens. Recently, they have been also reported to occur in discotics [24, 25] and LC dimers [26]. Three distinct blue phases have been identified, i.e. BPI, BPII, and BPIII that occur in the same order with increasing temperature. The naming of these phases as blue is due to their Bragg reflections in the blue wavelengths indicating a partially periodic structure with lattice parameters of several hundred nanometers. Bragg reflection studies indicate that BPI has a body‐ centered cubic lattice, BPII a simple cubic lattice, and BPIII is probably an amorphous one. The structure of the BPs involves a radial twist of the director called a double cylinder. However, this double twisted structure cannot extend perfectly into three‐dimensional space. The structure of BPIII is proposed with a spaghetti model having randomly oriented wriggling double twist cylinders, while geometrical models of cubic blue phases (BPI and BPII) consist of cubic networks of double twist cylinders separated by disclination lines [17]. Combined interpretation of various experimental investigations on the structure of these phases has revealed that the BPII phase has a simple cubic unit cell of lattice defects, while the BPI phase is body‐centered cubic, both with lattice parameters in the order of several hundred nanometers (the wavelength of visible light). The blue phases are thus optically isotropic, i.e. linear birefringence is absent. The optical texture of the cubic blue phases is quite characteristic, generally with a platelet texture. Amorphous BPIII is characterized by its foggy appearance.
Twist Grain Boundary (TGB) Phases These phases usually appear at the transition from the SmA or SmC* phase to the N* or isotropic phase [10, 27]. For short pitch chiral materials, there can be a competition between the need for the molecules to form a helical structure due to their chiral packing requirements and the need for the phase to form a layered structure. Molecules overcome this frustration by forming the TGB phase that consists of blocks of smectic layers, the successive blocks being rotated by a constant angle to give a helical structure with helix axis orthogonal to the layer normal direction. Since the smectic layers cannot be continuously twisted, they are separated from one another by screw dislocations to form grain boundaries which themselves are periodic, leading to the presence of layering as well as helical twist. Further, depending upon whether the smectic blocks are of smectic A, smectic C, or smectic C*, three different types of TGB phases i.e. TGBA, TGBC, and TGBC* are possible [28] and are observed experimentally [27, 29, 30]. TGBA phase exhibits a filament texture on a homeotropically aligned slide, while the TGBC* phase exhibits an undulated filament on the same. A planar texture is noticed for TGBA, while a square grid pattern is noticed for TGBC* on planar alignment condition.
