sections.heading: 7.2.2 Discotic Liquid Crystals: Phase Types and Structures
sections.text: Discotic molecules primarily exhibit two types of mesophases, namely (i) nematic (N) phase and (ii) columnar (Col) phase.

sections.heading: 7.2.2.1 Nematic (N) Phase
sections.text: Discotic nematic mesophase is the least ordered mesophase formed by disk‐like molecules where the mesophase possess only orientational order, while long‐ range positional order is absent (Figure  7.4a). In contrast to their calamitic counterparts, the short axis of the disk‐shaped mesogens orient along the direc tor (n) of the nematic phase. Hence the disks align perpendicular to the director. Consequently, they show negative birefringence. The nematic phase of disk‐ shaped molecules is usually not miscible with the nematic phase of rod‐shaped molecules. The symbol “N” is often used to denote the discotic nematic meso phase [1, 2]. Similarly discotic analogue of cholesteric phase, chiral discotic nematic (N*) mesophase also exists. The nematic columnar (NCol) phase is char acterized by a columnar stacking of the molecules over a short range. However, these columns do not form two‐dimensional (2D) lattice structures. They dis play a positional short‐range order and an orientational long‐range order. Similarly, the lateral nematic (NL) phase is built of aggregates formed by multi ple discotic mesogens. These supramolecular aggregates then organize into a nematic phase [1, 2].

sections.heading: 7.2.2.2 Columnar (Col) Mesophases
sections.text:
Stacking of disk‐like molecules one above the other results in the formation of columnar (Col) mesophases and these are the most common phases observed in discotics (Figure 7.4b). These show orientational order and positional order in two dimensions. They show rich poly‐mesomorphism and are generally dis tinguished by the order within the columns and the order between the columns. Both are indicated in a subscripted suffix. Based on the intra‐ and intercolum nar order they are classified as: (i) Columnar hexagonal (Colh); (ii) Columnar square (Colsq); (iii) Columnar rectangular (Colr); (iv) Columnar oblique (Colob); (v) Columnar plastic (Colp); (vi) Columnar helical (H); and (vii) Columnar lamellar (ColL) phases. However, it is difficult to determine the type of Col phase exactly, because optical textures are ambiguous and X‐ray diffraction
2357.3 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals
frequently offers insufficient structural details. Chiral discotic molecules may organize in a helical fashion to form helical columnar structures.

sections.heading: 7.3 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals
sections.text: As discussed in Section 7.1, the molecular shape anisotropy is the major factor accountable for the formation of LC phases [1, 2]. Traditionally, controlling the shape anisotropy was carried out by altering the chemical structure of the mole cules, which may stabilize/destabilize LC phases. While this has been a very pop ular method that has resulted in varieties of conventional and nonconventional LCs exhibiting rich mesophase behavior, the possibility to control the shape ani sotropy by a nonchemical external stimulus is challenging and appealing. Photoisomerization is one such method, where the change in the molecular shape is brought by the photoisomerization‐driven conformational change in response to light of a particular wavelength, known as “actinic light.” Photochemical path ways have the advantage of specificity and selectivity over thermal and catalytic methods that result in giving mixtures of energetically unstable isomers. Photo isomerization can be defined as a photochemical process leading to isomerization of a certain chemical entity, either by bond rotation, structural rearrangement, or atom/functional group‐transfer [31] in chemical compounds. Several classes of organic compounds like azobenzenes, chalcones, stilbenes, and alkenes are good examples of photoisomerizable molecular systems. These are also sometimes referred to as photochromic/photoactive/photoresponsive compounds. Several reviews on the topic of light‐driven phase transitions in LCs exist in literature [32–37]. The following sections deal with a variety of photoresponsive systems that have been successfully exploited to bring about light‐driven isothermal phase transitions of LCs by reversible structural changes in their photoresponsive constituent(s).

sections.heading: 7.3.1 Azobenzenes
sections.text:
Among the various photoresponsive systems known, azobenzene and its deriva tives form a major and attractive class. They have been significantly used to bring about photoinduced phase transitions. This is due to the ability of azobenzenes to exhibit fast, efficient, and fully reversible photoisomerization, and to remain stable over a large number of isomerization cycles [32]. Therefore, most of the results discussed in this chapter are based on azobenzenes and their derivatives. The photoisomerization of azobenzene occurs between two geometric isomers, in the trans and cis forms, which are also known as E and Z forms, respectively (Figure 7.5). These two forms differ from each other with respect to the orienta tion of aryl groups substituted on the central ─N═N─ moiety. The E form, where the aryl groups are parallel to each other leading to an elongated molecular shape, is energetically more stable, as compared with the metastable Z form with a bent shape. These forms have different absorption spectra and dipole moment. The E form exhibits absorption maxima centered at around 350 nm (π–π* elec tronic transition) and another at around 440 nm (n–π* electronic transition).
The E‐azobenzene possesses a zero dipole moment, while the Z‐azobenzene is known to have a dipole moment of 3.1 D. These two forms are interconvertible by the use of actinic light. Usually, ultraviolet (UV) light (λ ≈ 350 nm) irradiation results in the E to Z transformation, which can be followed by the change in the absorption spectra of the compound. Interestingly, the shining of visible light (λ ≈ 440 nm) results in the spontaneous reversal to the original E form. However, heat can also drive the Z to E isomerization process, which is known as thermal back relaxation. Although light plays a major role in photoisomerization, the molecular constitution of the azobenzene derivative, temperature, and host envi ronment can also have a significant role. Azobenzene and its derivatives can be used as dopants. In addition, the azobenzene core can be efficiently tailored to obtain photoresponsive low molar mass and polymeric LCs. The methodology, wherein azobenzene and its derivatives are employed as dopants or as pendant moieties in a copolymer, provides a valuable opportunity to strategize different guest–host combinations, and thereby control various properties such as order parameter, birefringence, color, viscosity, and polarity of the resulting photore sponsive system. The following sections will deal with the various general aspects of photoinduced effects on LCs with a special focus on phase transitions.

sections.heading: 7.3.1.1 Photoinduced Nematic to Isotropic Phase Transition
sections.text: Photoinduced phase transitions, where the nematic LCs are further disordered to the isotropic phase (N–I transition) is one of the thoroughly investigated areas involving azobenzene‐derived systems. Azobenzene can be suitably func tionalized to show mesomorphic behavior, it can be covalently linked to a meso gen, or it can be physically mixed as a dopant in an LC system. In all these cases, the E form will be more compatible with the LC phase due to its elongated rod‐ like structure. However, the Z form is not favorable for the stabilization of the liquid crystallinity due to the reduced shape anisotropy and bent shape. As shown in Figure  7.6, the molecular length of the energy‐minimized structure of  the E isomer of 4,4′‐dipentylazobenzene obtained from CS Chemdraw 3D (version 12) program is 22 Å, while that of the Z isomer is 10.6 Å, which is less

sections.heading: 11.4 Å
sections.text:
than half of the length of the E isomer. This combination of a drastic change in the shape and overall molecular length, in association with the high photochem ical stability of azobenzenes, makes them highly suitable candidates to bring about photoinduced phase transitions. In fact, the Z form due to its bent shape is incompatible with the LC phase and thus acts like an “impurity.” This destabi lizes the LC phase and hence the E to Z photoisomerization leads to a lowering of the transition temperature. For example, consider a material containing the azobenzene derivative exhibiting an N–I phase transition. If the UV irradiation is carried out in the nematic phase, it results in the gradual lowering of the N–I transition temperature. This is due to the increase of cis‐isomers, which desta bilizes the N phase and finally leads to a collapse of the isotropic phase at a lower temperature. It must be emphasized that this transition is photochemical in nature and not driven by a change in temperature and hence it is known as an isothermal phase transition. Further, the photoinduced phase transitions in LC materials generally employ one‐photon excitation of the azobenzene group. Nonetheless, recently, a photoinduced phase transition has been accomplished through two‐photon excitations [32–34]. Such two‐photon‐driven photoi somerization holds promise in controlling the location and spatial extent of photoinduced structural changes and is therefore important for optoelectronic and photonic applications.
The high contrast in the birefringence of the LC phase and dark field view of the isotropic phase can be easily followed with the help of POM and the pho toinduced isothermal N–I transition is easily visualized. For example, if the sam ple in the N phase placed between two crossed polarizers is irradiated with UV light at a certain region with the help of a mask, the region that is irradiated with the UV radiation undergoes photoinduced isothermal N–I transition and there fore appears dark indicating the isotropic phase. In comparison, the central masked portion, which is unirradiated, stays as such in the birefringent nematic state. LCs are a kind of elastic soft matter that are very sensitive; thus, if a small portion of LC molecules change their orientation in response to an external stimulus, the other LC molecules are induced to follow that change. Similarly,

sections.text:
during the photoisomerization, the induced bent form of the photoactive mole cules initiates a local region of higher orientational disorder as compared to the regions of the host (rod‐like non‐photoactive) molecules. If the generated disor der is large enough, it leads to the formation of the isotropic phase domains at the irradiated sites, which appear as dark regions under POM (Figure 7.7). The zone of influence of the azobenzene molecules could become very large making the entire sample to undergo photoinduced N–I transition. It is interesting to note that if care is taken to block the light leakage, very sharp boundaries of the isotropic and nematic phases can be observed. Notably, if not illuminated with 450 nm light, it remains as such until the thermal back relaxation occurs [35, 36, 38]. Although the LC media is fluidic, the high nematic potential serves as a bar rier for the diffusion of Z isomers from the isotropic region to the unirradiated region. The sample used in the study is a host nematic LC mixture and an azobenzene derivative as a dopant (E7‐EPH mixture, Figure 7.8) [38].
Further, Prasad et al. showed that when they used LC dimers based on azoben zene derivatives, they observed that the photoinduced N–I transition was dependent critically on the length and parity (odd or even) of the flexible spacer. They observed a pronounced odd–even effect, with the even members of the series exhibiting higher clearing temperatures of the N phase, although the mag nitude of the alternation decreases on increasing the spacer length. This type of alternation is often observed with increasing length of the terminal chain in case of monomeric LC materials, but the magnitude of the effect is very large for the LC dimers. The observed behavior has been rationalized in terms of the overall molecular shape in its all‐trans conformation, i.e. the dimers with even parity for the spacer have a more elongated or rod‐like structure, while those with odd par ity possess a bent shape.
They have also investigated [38] the influence of the parity and length of the  flexible spacer of the photoactive LC dimers in a guest–host system (E7‐4AOmOA4) again for the photoinduced N–I transition. They reported a fascinating feature in this system: i.e. even when the guest azo dimers are present in a small concentration of ≈5 wt%, an odd–even spacer parity effect in a striking alternation of ΔT [=TNI(without UV) − ΔTNI(with UV)] is exhibited or a change in the magnitude of the photoinduced shift in the nematic to isotropic transition is
240 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
observed with respect to the spacer length of the 4AOmOA4 dimer. In other words, they observed that the spacer parity effect seen in the case of N–I transi tion temperature of azobenzene dimers was also extended when these dimers were doped in nematic host E7. It is interesting to note that such a large effect is seen despite the small concentration (≈5 wt%), which is due to the large confor mational change in the photoinduced isomerization. They explained these results through the equilibrium configuration of the dimer dopant molecules in their E and Z conformations using the MM2 module in CS Chem3D software (Figure 7.9). The findings were: (i) as expected, the E conformers of the even parity spacers have an elongated shape, while the ones with odd spacers have a significantly bent shape; (ii) a remarkable change in the shape was noticed for the Z conformer, with the even member exhibiting a “Z” shape and the odd member exhibiting a “C” shape; and (iii) the projected length l shows an alternation with m, the extent
2417.3 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals
of the alternation being much larger for the E conformers than for the Z conform ers. In other words, upon isomerization, the change in the effective molecular length is much larger for the even (1.87 nm for m = 4) member than for the odd (1.39 nm for m = 5) member. This greater change in the dimension of the even‐ membered molecules is the cause for the larger value of ΔT observed for them. Thus, by designing molecules with a suitable shape in the all‐trans conformation, it is possible to control the magnitude of the photoinduced shift in the transition temperature. Over the years the results obtained from various groups suggested that the photoinduced N–I transition depends on several aspects including the chemical nature of the photoactive molecule. This was even reported in one of the earlier reports on photoinduced N–I transition, where a small amount of azobenzene or its derivative, 4‐n‐butyl‐4′‐methoxyazobenzene (BMAB), was doped in a standard nematic LC, 4‐cyano‐4′‐n‐pentylbiphenyl (5CB) (Figures 7.10 and 7.11). These binary mixtures exhibited photo‐driven N–I transition and the trans–cis isomerization was found to be nearly linear with the reaction time. A parameter termed as amplification, specified by the authors was found to be superior for BMAB than for the unsubstituted azobenzene [39, 40]. In the past five decades, numerous single component low molecular weight/polymeric and guest–host nematic LCs exhibiting light‐driven N–I transition have been studied toward comprehending structure–property relationships [39–43].

sections.heading: 7.3.1.2 Photoinduced Nematic to Smectic Phase Transition
sections.text:
On exposure to UV radiation, photoactive molecules based on azobenzene are known to induce a transition from the N phase (ordered) to the isotropic (dis ordered) phase, due to their change from the elongated E form to the bent Z form  (Figure  7.12a). However, Prasad and Nair reported a novel example of a  photoinduced disorder‐to‐order transition, which is contrary to the gener ally  observed photoinduced order‐to‐disorder sequence. A photo‐controlled
nanophase segregation mechanism is utilized to explain this transition from a re‐entrant nematic to a lamellar smectic A (SmA) phase (Figure 7.12b). They have observed that the speed of this transition is much slower than the nematic‐ to‐isotropic transition, which occurs within 500 ns as compared to the 10 ns taken for nematic to isotropic transition [44].
The host material used for the measurements was a 24 wt% mixture of 4‐ cyanophenyl‐4′‐octyloxybenzoate in 4‐octyloxy‐4′‐cyanobiphenyl. The photo active guest compound was p‐(p‐ethoxyphenylazo)phenyl hexanoate doped at a low concentration of 2.9 wt% to the host mixture. The transition temperatures of the resultant guest–host mixture are isotropic 80.6 °C, nematic 48.8 °C, and smectic A 34.8 °C re‐entrant nematic (I‐N‐SmA‐Nre). The notable feature of this mixture is the existence of the N phase both above and below the SmA phase; the
lower temperature N phase is termed re‐entrant because of its reappearance on the temperature scale. When irradiated in the SmA and high‐temperature N phases, the material transforms into N and I phases respectively (ordered struc ture to disordered structure). This fact is in agreement with the results in the literature that suggest that UV irradiation can lead to a melting of the phase, or in other words, a transition to a less ordered state [45, 46]. But when the experi ment was done in the Nre phase, they observed a novel aspect, i.e. the transition of Nre phase to the SmA phase, i.e. to a more ordered state (Figure 7.13). This photoinduced effect, particularly in the Nre phase, can be explained with the help of photocontrolled nanophase segregation mechanism. The principle behind this nanophase segregation (see Figure 7.12b) is that when the UV radiation is absent the azo molecules are in their trans form, with a rod‐like shape and hence can be easily accommodated into the smectic layers. However, in the photoi somerized cis form, these molecules assume a bent shape, and thus get expelled from the layers and occupy the region between the layers. This shows up as an increase in the overall layer spacing value, as noted from XRD studies. It may be mentioned that in the UV irradiated state, no additional reflections, which may be expected to originate from the phase separated regions, have been seen. This is perhaps because of the low concentration of the photochromic molecules used.

sections.heading: 7.3.1.3 Photoinduced Phase Transition in Bent‐Core Systems
sections.text:
In 1975, Meyer et al. showed that the tilted Sm LC phases composed of chiral molecules exhibit a spontaneous polarization [47]. However, in 1996, Niori et al. reported a ferroelectrically switchable B2 phase exhibited by an achiral system with bent‐core or banana‐shaped molecules [48]. The origin of the spontaneous polarization (Ps) is attributed to a combination of factors such as (i) the highly
polar character of the molecules; (ii) their arrangement in layers with the dipoles pointing along a common direction within the layers; and (iii) a tilt of the mole cules with respect to the layer normal. These factors give rise to a chiral layer symmetry although the molecules themselves are achiral. The B2 phase is known to be antiferroelectric in nature. The doping of azobenzene derivatives in such B2 phase materials has shown changes in the magnitude of spontaneous polari zation [49]. The Ps values were measured before UV irradiation, after irradiation, and after switching OFF the radiation. UV radiation caused the decrease in the Ps values, and while switching OFF the radiation reversed and recovered the original Ps value. This can be explained as follows. The non‐photoactive bent‐ core molecules (PHDDB) (Figure 7.14) and the photoactive azo molecule coexist in a layer of B2 phase (Figure 7.15). Schematic arrangements of these molecules are shown later. The length of the PHDBB is more than the double of the azo molecule in its trans form. In the absence of UV radiation, the azobenzene deriv ative will be in its trans form with a rod‐like shape and will be arranged as shown in Figure 7.15a. When such molecules are arranged in pairs in a layer, they sup port the polar character of the smectic layer. On photoisomerization, they assume a bent shape (cis form) and due to the nanophase segregation they will be expelled and will occupy the region between the smectic layers (Figure 7.15b). This leads to an apparent increase in the volume of the system and thus to a reduction in the dipole moment/volume. Consequently, the measured Ps was found to be lower than the one obtained before UV illumination. X‐ray diffrac tion studies confirmed the increase in the layer spacing by 0.05 nm upon UV illumination. But this volume change of 1% is not sufficient to decrease the Ps to such an extent (Figure  7.15c). As an alternative, they proposed a mechanism
where the azo molecules remain within the smectic layer (Figure 7.15d). Unlike for the host PHDDB molecules, the polar axis of the bent azo molecules within one layer could point in either direction compared to the polar axis of the smec tic layer. This antiferroelectric nature of such an arrangement leads to a decrease in the Ps values.
2477.3 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals

sections.heading: 7.3.1.4 Photoinduced Phase Transitions Involving Smectic and Chiral Phases
sections.text:
The photoisomerization of photoactive LCs decreases their clearing as well as mesophase–mesophase transition temperatures due to light‐induced disorder ing of the system [32, 34–36, 51]. In some cases, even the intensity of the POM lamp source is sufficient to bring about such phase transitions [52–54]. Examples of photoactive compounds [53, 55] showing such effects and exhibiting meso phases SmA and SmC*, TGB, and N* and BP are given in Figure 7.16. The shifts in the mesophase–mesophase transition temperatures are found to be depend ent on the illumination intensity and the sample thickness. This is obvious because the rate of conversion from trans to cis isomers depends on the penetra tion length of the incident light. Moreover, the photo‐modulation of the sponta neous polarization of the SmC* phase has been established for some of these
248 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
compounds [52]. Further, in one of such compounds (18A in Figure  7.16a), a continuous decrease in SmC* to TGBA (TGB phase having SmA blocks) the phase transition temperature was observed with increase in the UV light inten sity [54].
It is worth noting here that the photoinduced SmA–Cr phase transition has  been observed in supramolecular complexes formed by interacting 4‐n‐ alkoxybenzoic acids with the bifunctional acceptor 4,4′‐bipyridine via hydrogen bonding (Figure 7.16b) [33, 42]. Hence, a transition from the less ordered state to a high ordered state occurs upon light irradiation, which is, in fact, contrary to that generally observed in other photoinduced phase transitions where photoir radiation triggers a reduction in the ordering of the system.
It is interesting to note that the photoinduced generation of BPs or the inter conversion between different BPs or BPI phase transition has been observed in some mixtures consisting of different photoactive nematic hosts and photoin sensitive chiral components [58]. For example, when irradiating the N* phase of one of the mixtures with UV light (λ = 365 nm) light at ambient temperature, BPII was formed while heating; and BPI and BPII were stabilized during the cooling cycle. This was the first report on photoinduced generation of BPs. In another mixture, the photoinduced interconversion of BPs has been observed; that is, when BPI is exposed to UV light for a period of two, three, and four min utes, transitions to BPII, BPIII, and the isotropic phase occurs, respectively. Further, they have shown the modulation of the BP selective reflection with low levels of UV and visible light [58] in this study. The observed phenomena have been ascribed to the changes in refractive indices and helical pitch. In this con text, it is worth mentioning that a photoinduced deformation in the BP struc ture has been established in chiral LC mixtures consisting of an N* LC, chiral dopant (S811), and azobenzene compound namely, 4‐dodecyloxy‐4′‐methoxya zobenzene [59, 60]. Irradiating the BP phase with the 473 nm light, led to the deformation in the cubic unit cell with a concurrent shift in the photonic band gap (PBG).
Photoinduced effects on a smectic Q (SmQ) phase have been reported in a chiral azobenzene derivative (S,S)‐DCAB (Figure 7.16c). It is interesting to note that the SmQ phase with a chiral 3D architecture can be modulated with the help of light and such materials can be utilized in the construction of photocontrol lable switching devices. This compound exhibits two SmQ phases, where the first one is a low temperature one (SmQL), while the second one is a high tem perature one (SmQH). The SmQL on UV irradiation transforms to the SmQH phase; while the SmQH phase transforms to the isotropic phase on UV illumina tion. On switching off the UV light reverse transitions to the earlier phases occur. The photoisomerization of (S,S)‐DCAB is responsible for these phase transi tions [57].
Several azobenzene containing chiral dimers (D4–D21, Figure 7.17), where the azobenzene is connected to cholesterol moiety through odd/even spacers have shown photoinduced phase transitions [41–43, 61]. The SmA–I (Figure 7.18a–c) and N*–I transitions were noted on irradiation of these materials with UV light (λ = 365 nm) [63]. A blue shift was noticed in the selective reflection wavelength of the N* phase, when it is exposed to UV light; however, the magnitude of the
shift was found to be dependent on the irradiation energy, temperature, and the  length of alkyl tail of the azobenzene segment. The authors exploited this phenomenon in a rewritable full color image recording in photon mode [61] (Figure 7.18d). The shift in the selective reflection wavelength is attributed to cis‐isomers, which have lower absorption maxima. These photosensitive dimers with a dicholesteryl ester have also been employed as dopants to obtain a stable glassy N* state [41]. In these materials, irradiating the SmA phase with UV light (λ = 366 nm) leads to the N* phase and with continued illumination the N* phase collapses to the isotropic phase; thus, SmA–N* and N*–I transitions have been observed [42]. In another dimer, exhibiting SmC*, SmA, and N* phases, a direct photoinduced SmC*–I transition occurs without passing through other two phases [43]. The percentage of cis isomer required for SmC*–I, SmA–N*, and SmA–I transition were estimated with the help of HPLC to be 30%, 6%, and 19%, respectively.
Li et al. synthesized two cholesterol appended azobenzene derivatives (1‐Me and 1‐Et, Figure 7.17 exhibiting cholesteric phase [62]. The compound 1‐Et was used as a chiral dopant in conventional nematic LC 5CB (achiral N–I transition at 35 °C); at the composition of 25% 1‐Et in 5CB, the mixture is homogeneously mixed and undergoes an N*–I transition temperature at 39.9 °C. UV irradiation at 365 nm for 10 seconds showed the photoinduced isothermal N*–I transition. Removal of UV light immediately leads to the reverse process of N* domain for mation from the isotropic phase appearing as droplet nucleation followed by coalescence. The reversion to the original polygonal fingerprint texture was reached within approximately two hours at room temperature in the dark (Figure 7.19).
Zhou et  al. showed the photoinduced reversible lattice deformation and transformation of a simple cubic soft lattice, i.e. blue phase II, in a chiral LC system to a helical superstructure, i.e. cholesteric LC (Figure 7.20) [63]. This is attained by doping an achiral photoresponsive molecular switch‐functionalized polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane nanocage (Azo‐POSS) into a chiral LC
host. Furthermore, a well‐defined conglomerate micro‐pattern composed of simple cubic soft lattice and helical superstructure, which is challenging to fab ricate in organic and inorganic crystalline materials, is produced using photo masking technology.
A photoinduced reversible SmC*–N* phase transition under the influence of an applied electric field has been reported in mixtures consisting of an achiral smectic C (SmC) liquid crystal (4‐hexyloxyphenyl‐4‐octyloxybenzoate, HOPOOB), chiral dopant [4‐(methyl‐heptyloxycarbonyl)phenyl 4‐hexyloxyben zoate: S811], and azo‐ benzene derivative (4‐diethyl‐aminoazobenzene) as a dopant in 3–7 wt% concentration (Figure  7.21) [50]. The SmC* phase formed upon cooling the N* phase held under the influence of a DC electric field shows uniform unidirectional layer alignment in the entire region of the rubbed cell. Upon reversing the polarity of the electric field, the molecules tilt with respect to rubbing direction; further, the photoisomerization of this state gives rise to an N*
phase where the molecules tend to orient along the rubbing direction and in the absence of UV light, the N*–SmC* phase transition occurs. This light‐assisted control of smectic phase alignment/switching, holds promise in fabricating LC display, optical memory, and grating devices.
Supramolecularly halogen‐bonded LCs (Figure 7.22) were successfully fabri cated using azapyridine derivatives with molecular iodine or bromine. The exist ence of halogen–base interactions was confirmed by XPS, Raman spectroscopy, and SAXS results. Among these complexes, the supramolecular LC compounds with bromine were first prepared with high stability, indicating that the N…Br interaction is strong enough to form ordered mesophases in this system. The iodine‐bonded LCs showed reversibly photoinduced phase transition upon UV irradiation, similarly to other photoresponsive LC materials based on azoben zene derivatives reported earlier. However, such a photoinduced phase transition was not observed in brominated compounds [64].

Tamaoki and coworker recently reported asymmetric chiral dimers containing cholesterol and azobenzene moieties connected through flexible alkylenedioxy bridges (Figure 7.23a). These dimers acted as photon‐mode chiral switches for reversible tuning of self‐assembled helical superstructures. The chiral switches were doped into nematic liquid crystals, resulting in an N* phase. Under irradia tion with UV light, photoisomerization of the azobenzene units led to unprece dented switching of the cholesteric pitch and helical twisting power (HTP, β), with a higher HTP found in the cis‐rich state (bent form) than in the trans‐state (rod form). They attributed this behavior to the elongated cybotactic smectic clusters disrupting the helical orientation of the molecules in the N* phase (Figure  7.23b). Their reversible decay and reassembly were evidenced upon

In addition to the photoisomerization of the azobenzene units, the odd/even parity of the alkylen edioxy linkers of the dimeric dopants also had a dramatic effect on the transi tions of the cybotactic smectic domains. On the basis of the large rotational reorganization of the cholesteric helix and HTP switching (Δβ/βini of up to 50%), they could control the macroscopic rotational motion of micron‐sized glass rods upon irradiating the surface of a cholesteric liquid crystal film featuring a polygo nal fingerprint texture using UV and visible light [65].

sections.heading: 7.3.1.5 Photoinduced Phase Transitions Involving Columnar Phases
sections.text:
Most of the photoinduced phase transitions reported involved calamitic meso phases, while very few reports are available with reference to discotic LCs [66]. This is surprising despite the reports on many photoactive DLCs [67–70]. Recently, Norikane et al. reported photoinduced Col‐isotropic phase transition in a macrocyclic compound containing three fused azobenzene mesogenic seg ments (Figure 7.24) [71]. Upon light irradiation, the room temperature Col phase of the compound transforms into isotropic liquid where nonplanar (bent) mole cules forms due to their E–Z isomerization destabilizing the stacking of the mol ecules in columns; this process is reversible due to thermal back relaxation and quite sensitive to even small fractions of Z‐isomer. Tanaka et al. reported triph enylene derivative with six 4‐tetradecyloxyazobenzene units connected through propylene‐ester linkages (1‐C14). This exhibited enantiotropic SmA and Colr mesophases due to the interchange of their shape from disk to rod‐like in response to temperature. Interestingly, the photo‐irradiation (λ = 365 nm) leads to the photoisomerization of azobenzene units from trans to cis forms. This results in isothermal phase transitions (Colr–SmA–I) as in the thermotropic ones, but with a certain decrease of phase transition temperatures. This serves as a first example, where the isothermal LC phase transitions are controlled by
photo‐irradiation among three phases (Colr, SmA, and Iso), which are also accompanied with the shape change of molecules between rod‐like and disk‐like (Figure 7.25) [72].
Cheng and coworkers reported polycatenar LCs containing two 1,3,4‐ thiadiazole rings interconnected by an azobenzene central linkage. The compound with two tetradecyloxy chains exhibited a photoinduced transition from SmC to I, while the corresponding tetracatenar showed a transition from Colh phase to isotropic phase. These transitions were found to be reversible upon visible light irradiation (Figure 7.26) [73].

sections.heading: 7.3.2 Axially Chiral Azo Compounds
sections.text:
As discussed in the introduction section, when a chiral molecule is dissolved in an achiral nematic LC, its molecular chirality gets transferred to the nematic solvent, with the stabilization of N* LC capable of selective reflection according to Bragg’s law. The wavelength λ of the selective reflection is defined by λ = nP, where P is the pitch length of the helical structure and n is the average refractive index of the LC material. The ability of a chiral dopant to twist the N LC phase is defined as its HTP “β,” which is defined according to the equation: β = (Pc)−1, where c is either the weight concentration or the molar fraction of the chiral dopant. The isomerization upon photoirradiation can control the HTP and the helical pitch of the cholesteric phases, providing the tool for optical display addressing. Presently, the chiral dopants are used at high concentrations (≥20%) and they have twisting powers of β  < 15 μm−1. Further, the addition of chiral
dopant in such a high amount will alter or destabilize the LC phase. As a solu tion, scientists started developing of a chiral azo benzene derivative with high HTP and good solubility in a nematic host. The helical twisting power of azobenzene switches was considerably enhanced by incorporation of axially chi ral binaphthyl moieties. Especially binaphthyldiamine‐based switches 67, 72, and 73 (Figure 7.27), represent a powerful system for optical switching of the N* pitch, as the high HTP values allow for color generation and switching without added chiral codopants [74, 75]. Furthermore, UV irradiation of an LC film doped with switch 73 (β = +37 μm−1) leads to a cholesteric phase of opposite helicity (β = −31 μm−1). Owing to the molecular switch having two azo linkages, UV irradiation leads to reversible trans–cis isomerization of azo configurations producing two other isomers containing one or two cis configurations, respec tively. The sequence of the photochemical switch of the three isomers is (trans, trans), (trans, cis), and (cis, cis). The reverse process from (cis, cis), (trans, cis),
258 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
and (trans, trans) can occur thermally or photochemically with visible light irradiation.
Li and coworkers reported the wide optical tuning of a PBG of a BP facilitated by an axially chiral azobenzene switch E,E‐67 (Figure 7.27) in a commercial LC mixture [75]. The resulting BP exhibited a light‐induced unprecedented reversi ble PBG tuning over the visible region across red, green, and blue wavelengths accompanied by a unique, not previously seen light‐induced isothermal phase transition from a BPII to a BPI phase, depending on irradiation time (Figure 7.28). The process of the light‐induced phase transition from BPII to BPI were verified with reference to a Kossel diffraction diagram [76]. The photoresponsive tempo ral behavior as a function of composition is also reported.

sections.heading: 7.3.3 Azoxybenzenes
sections.text: Although it is known that azoxybenzene compounds form LCs with properties similar to azobenzene materials, such systems have not been extensively investi gated, although they have been employed as the photoactive compounds in few experiments [58, 77]. Azoxybenzene compounds are stable and can be formu lated into mixtures with wide LC phase ranges. It is therefore of interest to know whether the optical properties of azoxybenzene compounds differ from those of similar azobenzene materials, or whether their LC properties are affected con trarily due to trans–cis isomerization (Figure 7.29). The absorption spectra for the trans isomer of azoxybenzene compounds also have a strong absorption at similar wavelengths to azobenzene compounds, but lack the weak absorption peak around 440 nm. ZhK‐440 (NIOPIK) is a mixture of two‐thirds p‐n‐ butyl‐p‐ methoxyazoxybenzene and one‐third p‐n‐butyl‐p‐ heptanoylazoxybenzene. If the molecules are trans isomers, ZhK‐440 possesses a nematic LC phase from 0 to 70 °C. The transition temperature from the N LC phase to the isotropic liquid phase decreases if molecules change from trans isomers to cis isomers, even tually reaching room temperature and probably eliminating the LC phase com pletely. Authors opine that azoxybenzene compounds should be just as useful in  optical applications as are azobenzene compounds [78]. The same group also observed changes of the pitch (color) and optical anisotropy and also N*–I phase transition in response to light, when they doped ZhK‐440 to a cholesteric LC [77].

sections.heading: 7.3.4 Spiropyrans and Naphthopyrans
sections.text:
Spiropyrans are an interesting family of photochromic materials due to their unique properties such as excellent photofatigue resistance, strong photocolor ation, and fast thermal relaxation. The colorless ring‐closed spiro forms of spi ropyran can be transformed into the colored ring‐opened merocyanine form upon UV light irradiation. Its reverse process occurs thermally in the dark or photochemically by visible light irradiation (Figure 7.30). An exclusive feature of spiropyran is its significantly increased dipole moment after photoisomeriza tion from the ring‐closed spiropyran form to the ring‐opened charge‐separated zwitterionic merocyanine form. The physical and chemical properties of the
two forms of spiropyran are specifically different; thus, the thermally reversible photochromic switching can be exploited for the construction of smart materi als. Since the geometric shape changes upon photoirradiation are not drastic and the initial and final isomeric states are more or less elongated, spiropyrans have been used in the development of photochromic LC materials. The phase transition behavior of mixtures of LCs and photochromic spiropyran deriva tives, induced by isomerization of the guest molecules, has been investigated. Two types of spiropyran derivatives were employed: normal spiropyrans that are stable in the closed form (spiropyran form, SPF) and open form (merocyanine form, MCF) stabilized derivatives. These spiropyran derivatives were doped into two LC compounds: 5CB and 4‐butoxyphenyl‐4‐ethylcyclohexanecarboxy late (ECH 204). SPF‐stabilized derivatives exhibited photoisomerization behav ior from SPF to MCF in LC media, which was accompanied by an isotropic to nematic phase transition of the mixtures. On the other hand, N–I phase transi tion of the mixtures was observed when the MCF‐stabilized spiropyran doped in both LCs was photoisomerized from MCF to SPF. The result was interpreted in terms of shape anisotropy of the guest molecule associated with each isomer of the spiropyrans [79].
Kosa et al. reported a class of naphthopyran‐based materials (Figure 7.31) that exhibit photoinduced conformational changes in molecular structure capable of yielding order‐increasing phase transitions [80]. Appropriate functionalization of the naphthopyran molecules leads to an exceedingly large order parameter in the open form, which results in a clear to strongly absorbing dichroic state. The increase in order with light exposure has profound implications in optics, pho tonics, lasing, and displays and will merit further consideration for applications
in solar energy harvesting. The large photoinduced isotropic to nematic transi tion switches the transmission through the cell from clear to strongly absorbing and dichroic (Figure 7.32). The clear to dichroic transition has been long pursued in ophthalmic applications, such as polarized variable transmission lenses.

sections.heading: 7.3.5 Fulgides
sections.text:
Fulgide‐based systems show thermal irreversibility and they are solely driven by light (Figure 7.33). The hexatriene group under UV irradiation undergoes cycli zation to yield a cyclohexadiene unit in the compound, whereas the reverse pro cess can be driven back by visible light irradiation. The research group of Schuster reported cholesteric LCs that do not show fatigue during light‐driven reversible pitch modulation with the use of chiral fulgide F1 as a dopant [81, 82]. The HTP values are different for the open form and closed form, which is the basis of light‐ driven pitch modulation in CLCs. Yokoyama and Sagisaka reported the N* pitch
modulation by using compound F2 as the light‐driven chiral dopant [83]. Further, they demonstrated light‐driven handedness inversion in a CLC by using a pho toinsensitive codopant with compound F2. Similarly, compound F3 has also shown the ability to optically reconfigure color‐stable cholesteric LC films.
Owing to the advantage of thermal irreversibility of the dopant, long‐lasting reflection colors at arbitrary spectral positions have been demonstrated [84].

sections.heading: 7.3.6 Ketones
sections.text:
Unsaturated ketones undergo trans–cis photoisomerization. Accordingly, many such compounds have been used as chiral dopants for the induction of photore sponsive cholesteric LCs and to modulate their properties by photoirradiation.
Yarmolenko et al. designed and synthesized menthone derivative K1 (Figure 7.34) to study its behavior toward the induction of cholesteric LCs [85]. By linking the menthone moiety through an exocyclic C─C double bond, they rendered this chiral compound photoisomerizable. It was noticed that the E and Z isomers show sign inversion of their HTP values in nematic LC host 4‐methoxyben zylidene‐4′‐butylaniline (MBBA). The E isomer induced a left‐handed helix, while the Z isomer induced a right‐handed helix in the LC matrix. This behavior
is attributed to the dramatic change in the molecular shape of the dopant upon irradiation with UV light (λ = 313 nm). Recently, Gvozdovskyy et al. used this dopant in combination with the photoinsensitive dopant R811 and observed light‐driven handedness inversion of the induced cholesteric LC fabricated from the nematic liquid crystal MLC6884 (Merck) [86, 87]. The observed helicity inversion is due to the interplay of the opposite HTP signs of the two chiral dopants in the nematic host. By taking advantage of this property, they demon strated optically controlled diffraction gratings and beam steering (Figure 7.35). By using CLC samples capable of handedness inversion, it was observed that a light beam could be steered in one or two directions in a single photoirradiation step. Krivoshey et al. studied light‐driven handedness inversion in CLCs contain ing the chiral unsaturated ketone K2 [88]. This dopant induced a left‐handed helix in 5CB and, upon irradiation with UV light (λ = 313 nm), the CLC under went helix inversion, thereby resulting in a right‐handed helical superstructure.
Lub et  al. designed and synthesized chiral dopants K3–K5 (Figure  7.34) based on methyl‐cyclohexanones and studied the effect of the position of the stereogenic center (i.e. methyl group) with respect to the carbonyl group on the CLC induction behavior in nematic host E7 [89]. They observed that the com pounds display a low HTP when the chiral center is moved away from the ketone group. However, these dopants were found to exhibit a change in the sign of the HTP upon photoisomerization with UV irradiation from the E form to the Z form in the E7 nematic host. Thus, these dopants enable handedness inversion of the induced CLCs. Although these and few other examples men tioning handedness inversion of helical mesophases do not exactly fall under photoinduced phase transition, such examples may enlighten the reader about the future possibilities. For more such examples, the reader could refer to a review article [90].

sections.heading: 7.3.7 Diarylethenes
sections.text:
Dithienyl cyclopentene or diarylethene derivatives as chiral dopants were intro duced by the Feringa group. They studied the induction of photoresponsive
N* LCs by doping compound D1 (Figure 7.36) into a nematic host. Light‐driven modulation of these N* LCs was carried out [91, 92]. The photocyclization of the dopant leads to the pitch variation of the N* LC and even the N* to nematic phase transition has been reported. These events are a result of the different HTPs of the open and closed forms of the chiral dopant. Similarly, compound D2 was used as a chiral light‐driven molecular switch in the induction of N* phase. Reversible photocontrol over the pitch of the induced N* LC was demonstrated through irradiation with UV and visible light. It was found that usually the open form showed higher HTP than the closed form. Similar tansitions from chiral nematic to nematic was reported by the Irie group by utilizing chiral dithienylcy clopentene‐based compounds as dopants [93–96]. Owing to good fatigue resist ance of the dopant, CLC to the nematic reversible transition could be repeated many times. The drawbacks of these dopants were lower HTP values. To over come this, Li and coworker synthesized compounds with a dithienyl cyclopen tene moiety flanked by two axially chiral binaphthyl groups, which exhibited higher HTP values [37].
266 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
Akagi and coworkers reported a dynamic photoswitching of the helical inver sion in the N* LC phase that contains photoresponsive axially chiral dopants [97]. These chiral dithienylethene derivatives had two axially chiral binaphthyl moieties. The dihedral angle of the binaphthyl rings changes via the photoi somerization between the open and closed forms of the dithienylethene moiety. The N* LCs induced by the dithienylethene derivatives that are used as chiral dopants exhibit reversible photoswitching behaviors, including a helical inver sion in the N* LC and a phase transition between the N* LC and the nematic LC. These compounds are the first chiral dopants that induced a helical inversion in N* LC via the photoisomerization between open and closed forms of the dithie nylethene moiety (Figure 7.37).

sections.heading: 7.3.8 Butadienes
sections.text: Diphenylbutadienes form an important class of photochromic materials. The EE isomers of alkoxy‐cyano‐substituted diphenylbutadienes (Figure 7.38a) exhibit

sections.heading: N and Sm LC phases depending on the length of their terminal chains [98]. The
sections.text:
methoxy‐substituted derivative (BC1) exhibited an N phase. A nematic LC phase was also observed for BC4, whereas both nematic and smectic LC phases were observed for BC8. The BC12 compound possessed only an SmA phase. The EE isomers of these derivatives undergo photoisomerization to yield thermally sta ble EZ and ZE isomers, and neither of these photoisomers possesses LC phases. The drastic difference in the phase transition characteristics between the all‐ trans isomer and the photoisomers makes these materials very suitable for study ing photoinduced phase transitions. Photoirradiation with 360 nm light of the SmA phase of BC12 at 120 °C resulted in the destruction of the LC nature and in the isothermal transition to the isotropic phase. Because of the thermal stability of the photoisomers, the isotropic phase thus formed does not revert to the LC
268 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
phase even on heating. However, the photochemical recovery of the SmA phase was achieved.
Alkoxy cyano‐substituted diphenylbutadienes were found to be good candi dates for studying the molecular basis of photoinduced changes of cholesteric pitch lengths because they possess a rod‐shaped structure and transform into thermally stable bent Z isomers upon light irradiation [99]. Doping the glass‐ forming N* LC, dicholesteryl‐10,12‐docasadiynediote, with 1‐(alkoxyphenyly)‐ 4‐(cyanophenyl)buta‐1E,3E‐dienes (Figure  7.38b) resulted in a red shift in the wavelength of light reflected by the host CLC. The extent of the red shift was dependent on the concentration of the dopant, the temperature of the film, and also on the molecular length of the dopant. The photoisomerization of these dopants leads to a blue shift of the reflected light, allowing color tuning of the films over a large part of the visible region. The cholesteric pitch and hence the reflected light by these materials could be fixed in a glassy state by cooling them from their cholesteric temperatures to 0 °C. They reported that the dimesogenic liquid‐crystalline molecules (Figure 7.38b) [100] possessed glass‐forming prop erties (from the cholesterol moiety) and photochromic properties (from the butadiene moiety). Photoinduced cis–trans isomerization of the butadiene chromophore in these materials could be utilized to bring about an isothermal smectic to an N* phase transition. By photochemically controlling the cis–trans isomer ratio, they could tune the selective reflection color of the film over the entire visible region, and the color images thus generated could be freezed by converting them to glassy N* states by rapidly quenching the irradiated film to ~0 °C (Figure 7.39). Upon photoirradiation, the formation of the cis isomers
2697.3 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals
initially destabilizes the SmA* phase, bringing about a reduction in the SmA*–N* phase transition temperature. With the increasing concentration of the cis iso mers, the pitch of the N* phase decreases, leading to a blue shift in its reflection band. At high cis concentrations, an isothermal N*–I phase transition occurs. The isotropization temperature was lowered by around 90 °C, which is substan tially larger than in any of the previous reports on photoresponsive LCs. Although the photogenerated cis isomers were thermally stable, they could be reverted photochemically. Thus, 266 nm photoirradiation of a film containing a mixture of the cis and trans isomers in the solid state resulted in nearly complete recovery of the all‐trans isomer. Using this procedure, the images recorded using 366 nm light could be erased by irradiating them with 266 nm laser light. The pitch of the N* phase of the trimesogenic derivatives containing two cholesterol terminal moieties linked to a central diphenylbutadiene chromophore (Figure 7.38c) [101] could also be continuously varied thermally and photochemically to tune the color of the film over the entire visible region, and the color images thus gener ated could be stabilized by converting them to glassy N* states.

sections.heading: 7.3.9 Near Infrared Light‐Driven Phase Transition in Hybrid Materials
sections.text:
Recently, plasmonic gold nanorods (GNRs) have attracted increasing attention especially in biomedical applications due to their appealing “photothermal effect,” i.e. converting NIR light into heat through a non‐radiative relaxation process of longitudinal surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) [102]. It is also note worthy in this context that the characteristic wavelength of the LSPR signal cor responding to NIR absorption can be expediently tuned on demand by suitably altering the aspect ratio of GNRs [103], and therefore GNRs have been proposed for use in a few triggering systems where UV or visible light is not favorable [104]. However, adequate and homogeneous dispersion of conventional GNRs into a complex LC medium with self‐organized 3D photonic superstructures has always been a challenging task due to their poor miscibility in LCs and destabi lization of the 3D lattices. Li and coworkers reported an NIR‐light‐responsive self‐organized 3D photonic superstructure that was fabricated by incorporat ing new hydrophobic mesogen‐functionalized GNRs (M‐GNRs) into a BP LC medium composed of commercially available components (Figure 7.40a) [105]. The introduction of M‐GNRs was found to be beneficial in stabilizing the cubic nanostructure. Importantly, the resultant 3D photonic nanostructures could be switched between body‐centered cubic and simple cubic symmetry under irra diation using an 808 nm NIR laser due to the significant photothermal effect of M‐GNRs. The reverse process occurs upon removal of the NIR laser irradiation. Furthermore, dynamic NIR‐light‐directed red, green, blue (RGB) reflections of the light‐driven 3D soft photonic crystals were demonstrated for the first time (Figure 7.40b,c).
Further, Li and coworkers also reported mesogen‐functionalized GNRs that were soluble in organic solvents and displayed the typical transverse surface plas mon resonance and LSPRs of GNRs (Figure 7.41a). The protected GNRs were homogeneously dispersible in a commercially available thermotropic nematic liquid crystal host E7. The homogeneous LC nanocomposites were found to
undergo a reversible N–I phase transition within a few seconds upon NIR laser irradiation, resulting from the photothermal effect of the embedded plasmonic GNRs (Figure 7.41b) [106]. The nanocomposites with higher concentration of GNRs exhibited faster phase transitions.
272 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications

sections.heading: 7.4 Applications of Light‐Driven Phase Transitions
7.4.1 Holography
sections.text:
Photoactive LCs, especially the polymer‐based ones, exhibiting photoinduced N–I transitions have been explored from the viewpoint of their application in dynamic holography phenomenon. This holds great potential for real‐time image processing, phase conjugate mirrors, and other optical communication applica tions [107]. Photoresponsive polymeric LC as a holographic recording medium has been discovered to have good thermal stability of the stored information, high resolution, and storage capability. Moreover, a variety of low molar mass LCs [108–111] and LC/polymer composites [112, 113] have also been studied extensively in the context of both static and dynamic holographic gratings. The pioneering work in this direction was done by Wendorff ’s group, with the pro duction of holograms in LC copolymers containing azobenzene moieties and mesogenic groups [114–117].
Following this, Ikeda and Tsutsumi [118] established the high potentials of N–I transition in optical image storage application by achieving fast photochemical change (200 μs) both in low molar mass (BMAB and 8AB8) and polymeric (PA6AB2) nematic LCs (Figure 7.15). In this report, the N phase of polymeric LCs, covered with a photomask, is subjected to photoinduced N–I transition. Here the light illuminated regions transform to the isotropic liquid phase, while the unexposed regions remain in the N phase. The sample was then taken to the glassy state that maintains the stored pattern, although a reverse isomerization (cis–trans) occurs, pointing to the fact that no phase transition takes place in the glassy environment. This feature has been ascribed to the fact that while the segmental motions of polymer chains are possible, no macroscopic ordering (necessary for the isotropic liquid state to return to the equilibrium N phase) is accomplished. Following this, different types of azobenzene–low molar mass LC composites [119, 120], azobenzene–polymeric LCs [121], polymeric LCs [122], and copolymers [123] have been synthesized and their performances were investigated.

sections.heading: 7.4.2 Optical Storage Device
sections.text:
Some nematogens possess the dual frequency feature, and this can be utilized to create an optical storage device. The N phase of such materials exhibits a crosso ver frequency “fc” at which the dielectric anisotropy (difference between the par allel and perpendicular values) changes its sign, from being positive for f < fc to negative for f > fc. Hence, upon application of an electric field, the molecules would experience opposing dielectric torque when the field frequency is below and above the crossover frequency. In other words, above a certain magnitude of the electric field (Freedericksz threshold), the director prefers to be aligned along or perpendicular to the electric field in the two cases, allowing the orientation (homeotropic/planar) to be controlled by the field itself, instead of being con trolled by surface forces. Such a switching of configuration can be achieved, by maintaining a constant frequency and by illuminating the sample with actinic
2737.4 Applications of Light‐Driven Phase Transitions
light [124]. The principle behind such a device is the substantial increase in the dielectric relaxation frequency fR (and thus indirectly in the crossover frequency fc), induced by the radiation. These changes are connected with strong changes in the transmitted intensity of the LC cell. Thus this phenomenon can be exploited to fulfill a photonic addressable device in which the bright and dark states are achieved without allowing the material to transform to the isotropic phase, a highly desirable aspect particularly in view of enhancing the chemical stability of the LC substance employed.

sections.heading: 7.4.3 Photocontrol in Liquid Crystal Displays
sections.text:
The characteristics of LCs such as dielectric constant, magnetic constant, viscos ity, elasticity, and so on are hugely dependent on their alignment. Owing to their optical properties, LC materials can be used as actuators for light, which is the underpinning aspect for the modern LCD industry. When low molecular weight LC materials are placed in a cell and sandwiched between two transparent elec trodes (usually ITO) coated with alignment layers, an LC cell is obtained. Upon application of an electric field with a driving voltage between the two electrodes, these LCs in the cell change their alignment directions from parallel (homogene ous) to perpendicular (homeotropic) with respect to the conductive substrates. Since LC molecules can change the polarization direction of light to their optic axes when the linearly polarized light (LPL) passes through them, and its trans mittance through a pair of crossed polarizers, with the LC cell placed between them. A bright/dark contrast is produced at each electrically controlled pixel, and two‐dimensional images can be displayed in the flat panel of LCDs. Usually, unidirectionally rubbed polyimide layer is used on the electrodes to attain the alignment for liquid crystals. Although it is widely used it has some drawbacks like dust contamination and production of static charge during the rubbing pro cessing, which may lead to serious problems such as speckles and reduced dis play contrast of LCDs. Moreover, the rubbing method is limited to flat surfaces, which cannot be applied on curved substrates. Therefore, the noncontact method of photoalignment is considered to be one of the promising ways to solve the above‐mentioned problems and can be easily used to assemble LCDs with high quality, wide viewing angles and large‐area display.
Phototuning of N* LCs are expected to be very important, as these can act as active media for reflection‐type displays, particularly if the wavelength of the reflected light is in the visible region. Such cholesteric LC materials have high potential for full‐color LCDs with high quality and extremely low energy con sumption. Further, the freezing of the cholesteric color by immobilizing the molecular ordering in a glassy state provides a way to achieve optical materials with a static function and for optical data storage [37]. Similarly, the ferroelectric LCs (FLCs), based on the helical SmC* phase, possess spontaneous polarization (Ps) and exhibit microsecond responses to the change in applied electric fields in a surface‐stabilized state (flip of polarization). If a flip of polarization of surface‐ stabilized FLCs (SSFLCs) can be photoinduced in the presence of an applied elec tric field, a photoresponse of FLCs in the microsecond time region can be obtained. Here, the bias voltage remains constant before and after photoirradiation, but the
274 7 Light‐Driven Phase Transitions in Liquid Crystals and Their Applications
threshold value for the flip of polarization is reduced by photoisomerization of the photoactive LCs. As a result, a flip of polarization is induced by photoirradiation, which leads to a change in alignment of the FLCs [125, 126]. A similar method was extended to antiferroelectric LCs too and already a device has been fabricated based on anti‐FLCs [127].

sections.heading: 7.4.4 Photocontrol of Mechanical Motion in Liquid Crystal Elastomers
sections.text:
Alteration of LC alignment by light not only induces an extreme change in refrac tive index, which is very difficult to achieve with amorphous materials, but also gives rise to some promising phenomena, e.g. photomechanical and photomo bile effects in liquid crystalline elastomers (LCEs), molecular cooperative motion in low molecular weight LCs and LCPs, and supramolecular cooperative motion in LC block copolymers (LCBCs) [107].
Recently, the photoinduced N to I transformation has been also used in devel oping soft actuators derived from LCEs. This provides a possibility of coupling between orientational order and mechanical properties in LCEs, which was ini tially predicted by de Gennes [128, 129]. This concept finds potential application in the development of artificial muscles and mechanically tunable optical ele ments [130]. Experimentally, this was supported by a spontaneous contraction along the director axis of the nematic LCE films upon heating toward the N–I transition [131]. Notably, the deformation in the shape up to the extent of 300% has been achieved in nematic LCE films derived from side chain siloxane poly mers [131]. Based on the concept of photomechanical effects of a polyamide‐ based monolayer [132], large and reversible light‐driven deformation of LCEs has been demonstrated. The motion of LCE films was controlled by the gradient of the cross‐linking density, polarization direction of actinic light, and the initial alignment of the LC molecules, etc. [133–135]. The occurrence of this photome chanical effect has been attributed to the decrease in the order parameter caused by trans–cis isomerization. An example, is the achievement of photoinduced three‐dimensional deformation of the azobenzene‐based nematic LCEs swollen in suitable solvents or heated above their Tg in air by Ikeda’s group [136–138]. They successfully developed a single film capable of repeatedly bending precisely along the guided direction [107, 137, 138]. Similarly, a number of investigations have been reported to show that the LCEs containing azobenzene moiety, in response to the illuminated light, exhibit extraordinary changes in shape and volume where the light energy directly gets transformed into mechanical energy. Photoswitchable ferroelectric LCEs have also been realized as alternate ways to control the shape changes through optical (by photoisomerization) as well as electric (Piezo effect) means in addition to the existing thermal path [139].

sections.heading: 7.5 Summary and Perspective
sections.text:
Over the years, application of several physical stimuli such as temperature, con centration of the solvent, pressure, and light of a specific wavelength (actinic light) has been demonstrated and documented in driving LC phase transitions.
275 References
The ability of light to alter/stabilize a particular LC phase through photoisomeri zation and consequent change in the molecular shape of the constituent mole cules, provides an interesting tool to investigate condensed matter from a new dimension. Nature has been utilizing such photoinduced effects to perfection, as in the case of retinal protein rhodopsin, which enables vision. Scientists have been mimicking nature with the utilization of photosensitive organic molecules, which has resulted in a number of photoactive materials, for example, azoben zene or its derivatives. These photoactive materials are being utilized either in pure form or as a guest component in guest–host mixtures, to investigate their response to the light stimulus provided by the photoresponsive part and its effect on the whole system. In LC systems, a distinct variety of photoinduced phase transitions have been observed involving achiral as well as chiral materials, nematic, smectic, columnar, and blue phases. Thus, after a brief overview of LC systems, a detailed account of these photostimulated but isothermal transforma tions provided in this chapter illustrates their importance in both basic research and applied sciences.
Considering the fact that phase transition involving different mesophases or mesophase to isotropic phase leads to enormous changes in their optical proper ties, the usage of light to achieve such goals continues to be a captivating field for exploration. Since azobenzene systems are easily accessible, most of the studies are based on azobenzene‐derived LCs or dopants. In addition, several other sys tems such as diarylethenes, azoxybenzenes, diphenylbutadienes, spiropyrans, fulgides, and several axially chiral azo compounds have also been discussed. In recent years, the effects of parameters such as molecular conformation, surface fields, electric field, elevated pressure, anisotropy reducing component, and magnitude of orientational order on the photoinduced N–I transition have been well studied to give a new dimension to their technological potential. Similarly, dynamic self‐assembly of a layered phase induced and stabilized by light of a particular wavelength, tilt susceptibility of chiral smectic system, photoferroe lectric effects in an antiferroelectric LC, etc. emphasize the fact that actinic light can be used as a new tool to study phase transitions and the associated critical phenomena that could also bring about effects that are not seen in equilibrium situations. Most importantly, two applications originating from the photoi somerization, i.e. optical storage and photomechanical effect, have been well corroborated. In addition, these studies will motivate several non‐display appli cations of photoactive LC materials. With progress in the design of new pho tochromic molecules and photoinduced phase transitions, it can be expected that new technological advances and/or breakthroughs would occur in LC sci ence in the future.

sections.heading: 8.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Photomechanical materials can directly transform light energy into mechanical movements that provide mechanical devices with many advantages, such as non contact, remote control, and spatiotemporal resolution. In the past decades, a variety of photoresponsive materials have been developed, and the system based on liquid crystalline polymers (LCPs) is one of the most fascinating ones from the viewpoint of applications as soft photoactuators [1–8]. However, a simple‐ component material system sometimes develops into a bottleneck, such as dif ficulty in the realization of multiwavelength responsiveness or the flexibility of fabrication. Recently, nanocomposite materials, which combine the superiority of both organic and inorganic materials, have shown more and more potential in photomechanical researches. It is necessary to summarize the recent progresses made with reference to photomechanical soft nanocomposites. In this chapter, we will mainly discuss their design strategy, fabrication, operating principle, and potential applications.
Being one of the outstanding candidates for stimuli‐responsive materials, some nanocomposites not only respond to light, but also to other stimuli, such as moisture [9–11], electric field [12, 13], magnetic field [14], temperature [15– 18], and chemical energy [19], and may also simultaneously respond to multi‐ stimuli [20–25]. Such photomechanical soft nanocomposites are usually made up of soft matrices and functional additives, which utilize the synergistic effect in each component and magnify the microcosmic molecular changes into macro cosmic device motions. The photo‐driven actuators originating from these soft nanocomposites have broader materials choices while performing multiple deformations under different light‐irradiation conditions. To interpret the data from researches made on photomechanical soft nanocom posites in a systematic way, their classification from different perspectives is
Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites: Synergies Between Soft Matrix and Energy Conversion Additives Jing Hu1, Shudeng Ma1, Haifeng Yu1, and Quan Li2
