286 8 Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites
summarized, as shown in Table 8.1. From the perspective of fabricating a nano composite actuator, they can be mainly divided into two classes: homogeneously dispersed functional additives in soft matrix [26–45] and asymmetric assembly [46–51]; however, there must be a soft matrix to act as a structural foundation of the material system and functional additives to respond to the specific light‐ stimuli. Making sense of the working principle is essential; we can also classify the nanocomposite materials into photothermal actuators [38–42, 52] and pho tochemical actuators [53–58]. In some cases, the same system can be actuated by both the photoconversion mechanisms [30, 34, 59]. Moreover, if considering the nanocomposite actuators through their responsive light parameters, they can be sorted according to the differences of light wavelength, light polarization, light intensity distribution, light interference, and so on [60–63]. In this chapter, the second classification method is adopted to introduce the photomechanical soft nanocomposites, in the order of the nanocomposites actuated by photothermal effect, than the photochemical ones.

sections.heading: 8.2 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photothermal Effect
sections.text:
Photothermal effect refers to the phenomenon of directly converting light energy into thermal energy. Several kinds of materials possess outstanding pho tothermal conversion efficiency, and the most commonly investigated photo
2878.2 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photothermal Effect
thermal conversion agents are noble metal nanostructures, such as gold (Au) nanoparticles, nanorods, nanoshells, hollow nanospheres and nanocages, as well as carbon materials including graphene, graphene oxide (GO), and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [23, 64–69]. In addition, organic compounds such as indo cyanine green (ICG) dye and polyaniline, as well as copper chalcogenide semi conductors including CuS and Cu2‐xSe nanocrystals, are also reported for their excellent photothermal performances [70]. Among these photothermal conver sion agents, metal nanostructures exhibit close to the highest conversion effi ciency due to their intensive near‐infrared (NIR) absorption and tunable surface plasmon resonance (SPR) [42, 70–74]. These photothermal materials have been widely used in solar energy harvesting, cancer photothermal therapy, drug deliv ery, and biomedical imaging. Recently, researchers of photomechanical materi als have become conscious of the advantages offered by photothermal agents, compositing them with soft matrix, which finally produces many interesting works.

sections.heading: 8.2.1 Design Strategy
sections.text:
Generally, photomechanical soft nanocomposites based on photothermal effects utilize the thermal energy generated by the photothermal agents, heating the soft matrix and causing changes in the volume of the material system. To actuate the whole system by light, there must be a connecting bridge between the microcos mic change and macrocosmic deformation. It is well known that the elevating temperature can bring about the phase transition of crystals or liquid crystals (LCs) [75], the movement of polymer chain segments [76, 77], and the changes in volume of macromolecules or hydrogels [78]. A rational design strategy is essen tial to magnify these changes into mechanical deformation.
Figure  8.1 summarizes the design strategies employed for fabricating soft nanocomposite photoactuators based on the photothermal effect. Two main stream design methods are demonstrated as homodispersed single‐layer film and asymmetric bilayer or multilayer film. The former has been mainly devel oped from liquid crystalline elastomers (LCEs), and the latter has been under development recently. The Noble Prize winner de Gennes first theoretically pre dicted that, similar to muscles, the nematic LCPs would deform in response to environmental stimuli through calculation [1, 2]. Then, the German scientist, Finkelmann, successfully fabricated monodomain‐aligned LCEs and observed a large deformation when inducing the LC to isotropic phase transition for the first time in the laboratory. Later, the groups of Ikeda and Keller further indepen dently developed this.
Photoactuating LCEs usually rely on the photoisomerization of azobenzene moieties upon irradiation of actinic light [79, 80]. It is well known that an LCE simultaneously possesses the order of an LC and the elasticity of an elastomer [4], enabling it to exhibit reversible deformation enabling diverse applications as functional materials. When the ordering of LCs is disrupted, the LCE will deform along the longitudinal axis of the LC molecules due to the molecular cooperative motion, which is one of the most fascinating properties of LCs. Excluding the exertion of polarizing light, we can find that the two key points of LCEs, which
are very important for their actuating behaviors, are namely the orientation of the LCs and cross‐linking. Both guarantee the coherent and coordinating defor mation of LCE‐based materials. Then, the question as to how to get the deforma tion of LCEs can be simplified by focusing on how to disrupt the orientation of LCs. In addition to the photochemical reactions of azobenzene and cinnamate derivatives, the elevating temperature can also cause the disorder of LCs by inducing phase transition. By introducing the photothermal agents into the LCEs, the obtained nanocomposites can be easily photo‐manipulated.
However, we should notice that the LC property is not a prerequisite to design ing the photomechanical soft nanocomposites. The nanocomposites relying on sol–gel transition [35] or shape‐memory effect (SME) [38] can also perform pho tomechanical motion with the aid of photothermal agents, as shown in Figure 8.1. Firstly, the monomers or the precursors of the soft matrix, such as cross‐linked LCPs (CLCPs), shape‐memory polymers (SMPs), and gels, are mixed homogene ously with the photothermal agents, which are then used to fabricate freestand ing films through different routes. When the composite film contains LCs, two common ways are often applied to orient the mesogenic molecules, namely mechanical stretching or pre‐alignment by the LC cell, as shown in Figure 8.1a,b.
2898.2 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photothermal Effect
The homogeneously dispersed single‐layer film can contract, expand, bend, and twist or perform other mechanical activities due to the deformation gradient along the film thickness caused by the nonuniform light illumination and molar extinction coefficient of chromophore additives [81].
The second strategy for fabricating soft nanocomposite photoactuators is asymmetric fabrication, as shown in Figure 8.1c. In this way, the nanocomposite materials usually have two layers with a large numerically differential coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE). The general structure of asymmetric fabrication is bilayer or bilamellar. It is worth noting that either layer can be either polymer or gel containing homogeneously dispersed functional additives (Figure 8.1a,b) or just a slice of a single component film. The nanocomposite actuating complies with the well‐known principle of bimetallic mechanism [82], and the photother mal agent acts as the part of a nanoheater.
Table  8.2 shows the Young’s modulus, CTE, and coefficient of hygroscopic expansion (CHE) of some often applied materials in flexible electronics. It is con venient to design a photomechanical device by choosing two materials with a largely different CTE, such as poly (dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) and graphene to fabricate a nanocomposite film [50]. As given in Table 8.1, the CTE of GO and CNT is negative, which offers a large amount of photo‐energy converted heat and shrinks them, endowing the bilayer films with a larger light‐manipulated deformation. Therefore, carbon photothermal agents are widely used in design ing the bilayer structure.

sections.heading: 8.2.2 Fabrication
sections.text:
In the following sections, several concrete examples are introduced as fabrica tion prototypes of photomechanical soft nanocomposites based on photother mal effect.
290 8 Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites

sections.heading: 8.2.2.1 Homogeneous Single‐Layer Films
sections.text:
GO‐5CB/PVA and  GO/PVDF‐HFP Recently, Yu’s group carried out several photo actuating researches on GO/polymer nanocomposite materials [27, 29]. GO is usually prepared by the modified Hummers method [85, 86], which can be ultrasonically homo‐dispersed in deionized water or organic solvents such as dimethylformamide (DMF) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). With easy modi fication, GO often possesses relatively better dispersibility in solvents than do CNTs or gold nanoparticles. In the fabrication process, GO was firstly dispersed in the solution of a soft matrix, such as a polymer‐dispersed LC  system like 5CB/polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), or an SMP system like poly(vinylidenefluoride‐ hexafluoro propylene) (PVDF‐HFP). Then the homogeneous mixture of GO and polymer in solution was coated on a substrate (e.g. glass slide), forming a film by volatilization (Figure 8.2a,c). To acquire the photoactuating feature, the GO‐5CB/ PVA film should undergo mechanical stretching to orient the LC molecules. It is  well known that 5CB is a typically nematic LC with an LC‐to‐isotropic phase transition temperature slightly higher than room temperature. As a result, the heat originated from the photothermal effect of GO can induce the phase transition of 5CB, enabling the film to deform quickly (Figure 8.2b). As for the GO/PVDF‐HFP system, the heat energy stimulates the reversible crystal‐to‐ crystal phase transition of PVDF‐HFP and facilitates the nanocomposites with a specific shape in a particular range of temperature.
Organic Near‐Infrared (NIR) Dye/LCEs In 2016, Yang’s group reported the design and synthesis of one kind of LC‐like NIR absorbing dyes YHD796 [37]. This organic photothermal agent was inspired by Smith’s croconaine dye [87], as compared with the ICG dye. In addition, they noticed the potential of the thiophene‐croconaine dye to become the rigid mesogenic core for building calamitic LC molecular structures. By utilizing the like‐dissolve‐like theory, they mixed the synthesized NIR dye with LCEs via the LC cell fabrication method as shown in Figure 8.1b to ensure the stability and efficiency of the photothermal agent. The LC mixture and the NIR dye were simultaneously injected into the LC cell, which were then cured under illumination of one UV light. The freestanding film was obtained by dissolving the glass substrates with hydrofluoric acid (HF).
AuNPs/Semicrystalline Polymers (SCPs) and AuNRs/LCEs Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) or gold nanorods (AuNRs) have a very high molar extinction coefficient and photothermal conversional efficiency thanks to their inherent SPR feature [41, 42]. However, they are generally immiscible with an organic matrix and easily aggregate, losing their SPR properties. In the nanocomposite actuating system, the well‐dispersed gold nanostructures should be grafted on the polymers with the assistance of a thiol ligand. Zhao’s group successfully fabricated optically controllable LCPs‐based actuators by surface functionalization of AuNPs with thiol‐substituted poly(ethylene‐co‐vinyl acetate) (EVA) [41]. Zhang’s group [42] stabilized the AuNRs through a three‐step sequential thiol‐click approach and embedded the AuNRs into the LCEs. More interestingly, the nanocomposites
consisting of gold nanostructures were found to deform and perform self‐ propelling motions [35].

sections.heading: 8.2.2.2 Asymmetric Assembled Films
sections.text:
Bilayer Films with Single Component in Either Layer SWCNTs/Polycarbonate (PC) and GO/BOPP Owing to the immiscible feature between organic and inorganic components, the inevitable microphase separation is a challenge to the fabrication of com posite material systems [20, 88]. This problem has been elegantly overcome in the bilayer structure with only single component in either layer. However, the
interfacial interaction between the inorganic and organic layers should be seri ously considered. As shown in Figure  8.3a,c, Javey’s group [88] and Zhang’s group [20] independently reported the fabrication of a bilayer film by adopting an easy and economical way of vacuum filtration. To obtain single‐walled car bon nanotubes (SWCNTs)/PC film, the commercially available SWCNT pow der was first ultrasonically treated to remove impurities and the residual metal catalyst particles, which was then deposited on a polycarbonate (PC) membrane by vacuum filtration to form a bilayer film. In the fabrication of a GO/BOPP bilayer film, the GO sheet was firstly obtained by vacuum filtration, which was then attached to the biaxial oriented polypropylene (BOPP) film pre‐coated with pressure‐sensitive adhesive of acrylic ester.
SWCNT/PVDF As shown in Figure 8.3b, Yang’s group reported another method for fabricating bilayer films by directly spin coating on a suitable and separable substrate [84]. When fabricating the SWCNT/PVDF bilayer film, they firstly spin coated one homogeneous PVDF solution on a glass slide and then dried the PVDF layer, which was then treated with plasma to make it hydrophilic. The SWCNT layer was deposited on the PVDF layer by the second spin coating. The bilayer film could be easily peeled from the glass substrate due to the high surface energy of the plasma‐treated PVDF.
2938.2 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photothermal Effect
Multicomponents in one of the Layers Graphene‐chitosan/PE and RGO‐CNT/PDMS Xie’s group successfully fabricated the graphene‐chitosan/PE bilayer film by choosing chitosan and polyethylene (PE) as the matrix for the sake of material transparency [50, 89]. The GO was synthesized from purchased graphite oxide according to the modified Hummers method, and then the reduced GO (RGO) was obtained through a typical refluxing method [90]. The PE film was chemi cally treated to become hydrophilic, enabling the homogeneous mixture of chi tosan and graphene to be easily coated on the film surface. After drying, the nanocomposite film was peeled from the glass substrate, as shown in Figure 8.4a. Similarly, Chen’s group utilized PDMS as the polymer matrix due to its large CTE discrepancy from the RGO‐CNT film, as given in Table 8.2 [50]. The RGO‐ CNT film was prepared by casting their mixed suspension on substrate followed
294 8 Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites
by evaporating the solvent. Then the viscous PDMS mixture was coated on the RGO‐CNT film and cured at a high temperature (Figure 8.4c).
SWCNT‐LCE/Silicone and CNT‐Paraffin Wax/PI Since CNTs easily agglomerate when mixing with most organic liquids, it is a big challenge to get well‐dispersed and uniform CNTs in matrix [15, 91]. Researchers have developed several methods such as shear‐mixing and ultrasonication to avoid the aggregation [92, 93]. One of the elegant ways is to introduce a dispers ing agent, which can interact with both the CNT and polymer matrix, making the CNT to homo‐disperse in matrix [40]. For instance, poly(p‐phenyleneethy nylene) (PPE)‐SWCNTs were synthesized and mixed with LCE monomers, and then the mixture was poured into molds and made to undergo photo‐polymeri zation [91]. The SWCNT‐LCE nanocomposites were further composited with silicone rubber slice to fabricate SWCNT‐LCE/silicone bilayer film (Figure 8.4b). Another example is CNT‐Paraffin wax/PI reported by Peng’s group. They firstly deposited the paraffin wax on the famous Kapton (polyimide) film by heating and spin coating [15]. Then the CNT sheet synthesized by chemical vapor depo sition was stacked on the bilayer film. Finally, the nanocomposite was reheated to make the CNT merge in the wax to obtain CNT‐Paraffin wax/PI bilayer film, as shown in Figure 8.4d.

sections.heading: 8.2.3 Properties of Photothermal Actuators
8.2.3.1 Characterization
sections.text:
After the photothermal nanocomposite actuators are fabricated, it is necessary to characterize their surface and interface morphology, degree of orientation, mechanical performances, photoresponsive properties, etc. For measurement of the surface and interface morphology, the most commonly utilized methods are scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Figure 8.2c, Figure 8.3b, and Figure 8.4d) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) [42]. When the composites have birefringent crystal or LC phases, polarizing optical microscope (POM) comes in handy [29]. To test the mesogenic or photothermal agents’ orientation degree of LCEs and polymer‐dispersed LCs or other ordered systems, the small‐angle X‐ ray scattering (SAXS), two‐dimensional (2D) SAXS [15, 39] and polarized ultra violet–visible absorption spectroscopy (UV–Vis) or polarized Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) techniques are often useful. The dynamic mechan ical analysis (DMA) or dynamic mechanical thermal analysis (DMTA) has been widely applied for characterization of the mechanical properties of the nano composite films, especially for the SMP‐based polymer composite films [21]. Owing to the existence of photothermal agents, it is very important to know the in‐situ photothermal conversion efficiency in the composites with the assistance of an infrared thermal imager or a thermometer [15, 88]. Finally, the photore sponsive properties, or in other words, the photomechanical performances of the nanocomposites can be studied under different light‐irradiation conditions. The main parameters are responsive velocity, deformation displacement, repeat ability, and stability.
2958.2 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photothermal Effect

sections.heading: 8.2.3.2 Properties
sections.text:
Photothermal nanocomposite materials mainly respond to NIR and visible light, while the reports on the UV‐responsive photothermal actuators [38, 39] are fewer, since the photothermal agents usually have intensive absorption in the NIR region. In practice, visible light or NIR light has an advantage over UV light for its safety and innocuity to humans [37, 40]. Besides, NIR light possesses bio logical tissue penetration ability and, therefore, exhibits excellent biocompatibil ity and broad utility in biomedical applications [37]. However, visible light is easily available and cheap.
Generally, the photomechanical nanocomposites based on photothermal effect often respond to visible and NIR light, while those responsive to UV light are often based on photochemical effect. This is decided by the functional addi tives’ response to the wavelength of light. Obviously, if the photothermal agents and photochemical agents are simultaneously integrated into the same matrix, the nanocomposites may realize the NIR–Vis–UV full‐range light responsive ness. Multi‐wavelength‐responsive nanocomposite actuators can be fabricated by a similar method [30, 34, 59]. Thus, we can acquire different shape changes under photoirradiation of different light wavelengths [34, 59]. Since some photo thermal agents are sensitive to the wavelength of light, there are some reports about wavelength‐selective actuators [88, 91]. One such report mentions that the researchers can modulate the responsive wavelength band of the actuators by choosing CNTs with different chirality distributions [88].
Some photomechanical nanocomposites not only respond to multi‐ wavelength light, but also to other stimuli, such as temperature [15] and moisture [20, 84]. The deformation of photothermal nanocomposites fabricated by asymmetric bilayer structures relies on the thermal expansion discrepancy between the two layers. As a result, the nanocomposites themselves can directly deform according to environmental temperature changes [15]. In addition to the CTE differential between the two layers, researchers find that the CHE differential of materials also can be used to prepare selective actuating (Table  8.2). For instance, the bilayer actuators made up of GO/BOPP [20] or SWCNT/PVDF [84] can deform by light illumination or by changing environmental moisture content.
The mechanical performance of the photomechanical nanocomposites is also an important parameter to evaluate from the viewpoint of applications. The introduction of carbon nanomaterials such as CNTs or metal nanoparticles into the soft matrix may reinforce the Young’s modulus of the nanocomposites to some extent [94]. However, the ductility and durability of the nanocomposites may be influenced by the microphase separation between organic and inorganic matters. This is another challenge in the fabrication of photomechanical nano composite materials.
The photoinduced deformation velocity and degree are the basic indexes to evaluate photomechanical nanocomposite materials. The responsive and recov ery velocity of photothermal actuators are often decided by several factors, such as the photothermal conversion efficiency of the photothermal agents, the ther mal conductivity of each component [40], the CTE discrepancy between the two layers, the modulus of the matrix, and other related elements. Owing to the time cost of the photothermal conversion, the responsive time of the photothermal
296 8 Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites
actuators may range from several milliseconds [35] to few tens of seconds [21]. The deformation extent is generally decided by the photoinduced driving force, the modulus of the matrix, and so on. Usually, photothermal actuators with the maximum bending of 90° can easily realize the functions such as switches [41] and robotic arms [15]. The bending direction of the azobenzene‐LCEs is usually phototropic while the bilayer system can easily realize the phototropic and pho tophobic bending in one film, which originates from its asymmetric structure. To improve the properties of photothermal actuators, researchers may change and modify the photothermal agents or choose a suitable soft matrix. To make the actuators carry out specific work, researchers can design and combine the nano composites in a specific way [50, 91].

sections.heading: 8.3 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photochemical Effect
sections.text: Photochemically induced deformation essentially relies on the microscopic photosensitive chromophores in the composite materials. Over the past dec ades, much attention has been paid to photochemical strategies such as photoi somerization of spiropyran [95, 96] or azobenzene derivatives [4, 97, 98], photoinduced dimerization of diarylethenes [99], and cycloaddition of anthra cene derivatives [100]. As for soft actuators, azobenzene and its derivatives are the most widely utilized photoresponsive moieties for the great changes in molecular conformation and convenient attachment into the polymer chain or hydrogel system. In addition, host–guest inclusion complexes whose interac tions break under appropriate wavelength of light irradiation were introduced, especially in photodeformable SMP‐based polymer composites. Unlike the photothermal part (see Section 8.2) which is classified according to the struc ture of nanocomposites, we introduce this part based on the different functions of the additives.

sections.heading: 8.3.1 Photodeformable Supramolecular Systems
sections.text: SMPs or hydrogels are among the most intensively studied stimuli‐responsive materials. Generally, the shape‐transform “switches” are based on thermally induced effects such as glass transition of polymers or phase transition of LCs. Photoresponsive supramolecular systems were integrated into shape‐memory materials to achieve low temperature response and remote and precise control.

sections.heading: 8.3.1.1 Reversible Metal–Ligand Coordination
sections.text:
Organic ligands such as amidogen, pyridine, triphenylphosphine, and others can be readily attached to polymer chains [101–103]. When metal ions like Zn2+, Cd2+, and Co3+ are integrated into the polymeric system, the metal–ligand coor dination can aid cross‐linking that reinforces the materials and fixes the shape. Through breaking of these bonds, the nanocomposite materials can acquire the shape‐memory capability due to the release of residual stresses.
2978.3 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photochemical Effect
Rowan and coworker studied end‐capped polybutadiene with pyridine groups to form metallo‐supramolecular polymers when mixed with the metal salts in solution [39]. Then the cast films were photo‐crosslinked through a thiol‐ene reaction with tetra‐functional thiol to form a permanent shape. Upon irradiation of UV light, the metal–ligand complexes absorbed the light energy and converted it into heat. The localized heating disassembled the coordinated complexes and softened the polybutadiene chain, making the polymers deformable. When removing the UV light, the interaction between the metal ions and the pyridine groups rearranged to fix the temporary shape. Subsequent exposure to continu ous UV light released the films to the original shape. Thus, the shape‐memory performance was obtained in this way.
Note that the above‐mentioned disintegration still relied on photothermal effect, and the photoacid generator (PAG) provided a pure photochemical approach to trigger the shape‐memory effect. Yang and coworkers synthesized a  slightly cross‐linked poly(‐acrylamide‐co‐N‐vinylimidazole) hydrogel [104]. They forced the hydrogels into predesigned shapes and then immersed the hydrogels into solution containing metal ions and diphenyliodonium nitrate (that served as the PAG) without removal of the load. As a result, the imidazole groups interacted with the metal ions and held the temporary shape. The PAG generated protons under UV light irradiation lowering the pH value and further leading to the disassembly of the metal–ligand complexes, which ultimately brought the films back to the original permanent shape (Figure 8.5a).
It is worth pointing out that the PAG strategy can also be applied to polyelec trolyte hydrogels. Aoyagi and coworkers integrated nitrobenzaldehyde as the PAG into bilayer hydrogels composed of a polyacid layer and a polybase layer [105]. Under irradiation of UV light, the PAG accomplished a fast proton release, reducing the pH value, which enables the polyacid layer to contract and makes the polybase layer expand together, leading to a bending deformation, as shown in Figure 8.5b. More appealingly, with short and localized UV irradiation, the gels returned to their original shape after the removal of the light source due to the diffusion of protons and the increase of pH within the whole gels.

sections.heading: 8.3.1.2 Interaction Between Cyclodextrin and Azobenzene Derivatives
sections.text:
Cyclodextrin (CD) refers to a series of ring‐like sugar molecules that have been extensively utilized in the construction of various supramolecular systems because of the existence of distinctive cavities [106]. Many kinds of stimuli‐ responsive inclusive guests have been developed including photoactive azobenzene groups. Generally, trans‐azobenzene has superior complementa rity with CD molecules whereas cis‐azobenzene has a low association with CD molecules because of the bending configuration [107]. Thus, remote light irra diation can switch on or off the interaction between CD and azobenzene derivatives.
Recently, Wu and coworkers reported supramolecular hydrogels based on tetra‐ortho‐methoxy‐substituted azobenzene and β‐CD (7‐membered sugar ring molecule) [108], showing red‐light responsive properties. The two com ponents were mixed in dark conditions to fabricate the supramolecular gel. When the obtained gel was exposed to red light (625 nm, 60 mW cm−2) after
30 minutes, gel‐to‐sol transition occurred because of the triggered disassembly between cis‐azobenzene and β‐CD, as shown in Figure 8.6. The blue‐light irra diation or heating can trigger the cis‐to‐trans isomerization of azobenzene, leading to the reverse sol‐to‐gel transition.
Furthermore, much effort has been made to induce macroscopic deformation in hydrogels beyond the mere gel‐to‐sol transition. Takashima et al. reported an excellent approach by slight covalent cross‐linking of polymer chains containing azobenzene and α‐CD (6‐membered sugar ring molecule) groups [109]. It was found that the formation of host–guest inclusion complexes altered the total cross‐linking density, thus endowing the hydrogel with expansion–contraction ability (Figure  8.7a). The α‐CD‐azobenzene gel immersed in water expanded approximately 24% in weight under 365 nm UV irradiation and shrank almost to  the original state upon exposure to 430 nm visible light. Furthermore, they achieved the away‐from‐light bending motion in hydrogel strips with several millimeters thickness (Figure 8.7b), because of the poor penetrability of UV light in polymers containing azobenzene.
Li and coworkers designed triple shape‐memory hydrogels by integrating the above‐mentioned light‐responsive azobenzene‐CD inclusion complexes with pH‐responsive dansyl‐aggregations [110]. The initial flat film was deformed into an arc‐shape under UV light exposure and then the temporary shape was fixed by visible light irradiation. Once UV light irradiated the deformed film again, the azobenzene–CD inclusion complexes separated and the film returned to the permanent flat shape in 60 minutes. Thus, the light‐controlled reversible shape‐ memory was obtained.

sections.heading: 8.3.2 Liquid Crystalline Polymer Nanocomposites
sections.text: LCs have been intensively investigated ever since their discovery in the late nine teenth century and have been applied in various aspects such as display [111], detection [112], biomedicine [113], and as actuators [48]. LCP materials perform well in stimuli‐responsive actuators due to the assembly of mesogens and the order change they undergo when exposed to external stimulus such as light [30], electric field [114], temperature [115], and solvent [116]. The difficulty lies in fixing the orientation of the mesogenic molecules. Finkelmann and coworker provided a two‐step cross‐linking technique in which polymers were stretched under a slightly cross‐linked state and then the alignment was fixed by the sec ond cross‐linking reaction [117]. Besides, another method was employed by using pre‐assembled LC cells to align the mesogenic monomer capillary filled inside and usually a subsequent photo‐polymerization to fix the alignment by chemical cross‐linking [48, 118]. As both the approaches are complicated and time‐consuming, recent works have aimed to promote several new methods to achieve the orientation through the composite strategy.

sections.heading: 8.3.2.1 Aligned Carbon Nanotube
sections.text:
CNTs have been widely utilized for their mechanical, electrical, and photo thermal properties [119]. However, taking their intrinsic one‐dimensional (1D) nanostructure into account, CNTs can be applied directly for the alignment of mesogenic molecules instead of employing a polyimide layer [26]. After injec tion of LC monomers containing azobenzene mesogens, cross‐linkers, and pho toinitiators and the following scheduled polymerization, light‐responsive
3018.3 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photochemical Effect
CLCPs were obtained with CNT sheets integrated in both surfaces of the film. It was confirmed that the azobenzene mesogens were aligned along the orien tation of the CNT sheets through POM and polarized UV–Vis absorption spectroscopy. Under irradiation of UV light, the trans‐to‐cis isomerization of azobenzenes caused a reduction of the orientational order, leading to a contrac tion of the irradiated surface layer and eventually inducing a bending motion toward the light source. The bent films reversibly returned to their flat state by exposure to 530 nm visible light. It is worth noting here that the surface CNT sheets reinforced the polymeric film and endowed it with additional electrical conductivity.
Furthermore, Peng and coworkers mixed aligned CNT arrays with the same CLCP [33], but in this condition, polymer chains were attached along the parallel CNTs and the mesogens were aligned perpendicularly in the voids. Surprisingly, this CLCP/CNT composite strip exhibited photodeformable reversibility when UV irradiation was applied alternately on both sides of the strip. They indicated that during the recovery of the strip shape induced by UV light, azobenzene mesogens at the firstly irradiated side experienced cis‐to‐trans isomerization due to the strong π–π interaction between azobenzene molecules and the aligned CNTs.

sections.heading: 8.3.2.2 Polymer‐Dispersed Hybrid Film
sections.text:
Researches on dispersing photoresponsive microparticles in supporting poly mers resulted in providing solutions for the flexible regulation of integral mechanical properties by simply replacing parts of the substrate. This method elegantly provides another advantage that simply stretching the composite mem brane can orient the particles inside the composite films. Yu et al. first reported such a kind of photoresponsive polymer‐dispersed liquid crystalline polymer (PDLCP) films [26], as shown in Figure 8.8. They prepared wrinkled microparti cles with an azobenzene‐containing side chain LCP, which were homogeneously dispersed in polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) aqueous solution. After casting the mixture on clean glass substrates and drying for one day, the PVA‐based PDLCP compos ite films were mechanically stretched to orient the azobenzene mesogens. During the evaporation of water, the LCP microparticles gradually concentrated on the upper layer of the films due to the low density of the polymer compared to that of water. Thus, upon irradiation of UV light, the upper layer underwent more contraction resulting in the bending motion toward the light source, as shown in Figure 8.8.
Then the same group developed a similar method by introducing both a pho toresponsive azobenzene compound (5CAZ) and a low clearing‐point LC (5CB, TNI = 35 °C) together with GO as the nanoscale heating source into the PVA sub strate [30], as shown in Figure 8.9. In addition to the UV light, GO can absorb visible and NIR light and converts  these into thermal energy, inducing the nematic–isotropic phase transition of 5CB. The thermally induced changes in vol ume had the same effect as that of the trans‐to‐cis isomerization of 5CAZ. In addi tion, the responsive speed of photoactuating was much faster than that in the PVA‐based PDLCP system (Figure 8.8) since the phase transition occurred in low‐ viscous small molecules. To obtain reversible actuating properties, Zhou et  al.
replaced the PVA with SMP polyurethane. After UV‐light irradiation, the bent PDLC films recovered to the initial flat shape when being heated to 85 °C coincid ing with the shape‐memory temperature of the pure polyurethane [34, 120].
Interestingly, the stretched nanostructure in polymer films could also orient the mesogens filled inside. Ryabchun et al. utilized stretched porous PE mem branes, which anchored the orientation of LCs along the direction of stretching
3038.3 Photomechanical Nanocomposites Based on Photochemical Effect
[28]. They infiltrated polymerizable LC monomers containing an azobenzene mesogen into the porous PE films and obtained a highly cross‐linked polymer network after polymerization. Such a bent film induced by asymmetric UV irra diation can be entirely recovered in about two minutes after removal of the light source. The reversibility is dependent on the cross‐linked structure and the mechanical property of the PE films.
Besides soft materials, photoinduced deformation was also observed in molec ular crystals [121–124]. However, in these systems, actuators were always fragile and it was difficult to control size. Chen and coworker took advantage of the polymer‐dispersed strategy to solve these problems [125]. They added molecular crystals of 2‐hydroxynaphthylidene‐1′‐naphthylamine (HNAN) into a PVDF– HFP co‐polymer. Upon exposure to UV light, the rod‐like nanocrystals showed contraction along the long axis and expansion along the short axis, which reversed when the irradiation of UV light was stopped. They mixed the HNAN and PVDF–HFP in DMF to get a homogeneously dispersed solution and then cast the mixture onto a glass slide. Upon heating to remove DMF, the nanocrys tals concentrated in the lower layer and the long axis tended to align along the membrane surface for decreasing the surface free energy during the fabrication process. Finally, the composite film was obtained after removal of the solvent. Interestingly, these microscopic structures determined the bending toward the lower surface regardless of which side was illuminated.

sections.heading: 8.3.2.3 Bilayer Composite Film
sections.text: Bilayer composite film is often utilized to transform the volume change of the LCP film into bending motion or to provide a tough supporting material for acquiring excellent mechanical properties. Current approaches required pre fabrication of aligned mesogenic membranes and combination of two layers subsequently through adhesion [55, 126]. To simplify the method further, two steps were integrated by combining a commercially available soft film with photoactive materials [56]. As shown in Figure 8.10, as one typical example, low‐density polyethylene (LDPE) was chosen as substrate, which was first pol ished carefully with silicon carbide sandpaper. The films were immersed into a solution containing small azobenzene molecules to obtain a photosensitive crystal layer and then put into a 40 °C oven for annealing. The microgrooves aligned the azobenzene crystals and simultaneously enhanced the interaction between the two layers. The bilayer films bent to the azobenzene layer upon

sections.heading: UV irradiation due to the contraction of this layer along with the trans‐to‐cis isomerization.
8.3.3 Incorporation of Upconversion Nanophosphors
sections.text:
To date, the majority of the reported photoresponsive actuators undergo mechanical deformation upon UV light irradiation, which originates from the intrinsic property of integrated photosensitive molecules. However, UV light has a relatively short wavelength leading to a high energy density and a low pen etrability, which is harmful to human health, thus blocking potential biologic applications. Large efforts have been made to develop photomechanical systems
triggered by visible or NIR light such as incorporation of photothermal carbon nanomaterials [29, 127, 128] and modification of the substituent [129, 130].
Recently, a novel approach was reported on embedding upconversion nanoparticles into CLCPs. Originally, upconversion nanophosphors (UCNP)
3058.4 Applications
composed of NaYF4: Yb, Tm was chosen with emission peaks that matched the absorption band of azotolane groups and then the UCNP was coated on the sur face of the homogeneously aligned CLCP film [44]. Upon irradiation with a 980 nm laser, the composite film bent toward the light source and returned to the flat state upon removal of the laser due to the rigid UCNP layer. However, this system required a high irradiation density of 15 W cm−2 that caused an overheat ing effect. Thus, a low‐power excited triplet‐triplet annihilation‐based upcon version system was introduced in the composite system [45]. These composite films were fabricated by adhering upconversion particles containing polyure thane film to aligned CLCP film. Owing to the excellent penetration of  the 635 nm excitation light source, the composite film can response to the light source blocked by a piece of pork, indicating its potential in biological applications.

sections.heading: 8.4 Applications
sections.text:
Soft matters have always been expected to be promising alternatives to artificial muscle [117]. When they are incorporated with photic driving, various applica tions such as in actuators, switches [88], oscillators [131], generators [53], and tumblers [27] have been successfully obtained. As shown in Figure 8.11, a biomi metic actuator that simulated the blooming and fading of flowers was realized by taking advantage of triple shape‐memory hybrid films with azobenzene and GO dispersed in polyurethane matrix [34]. Upon irradiation of UV light, the pre‐ stretched nanocomposite films bent toward the light source, which mimicked the blooming of flowers. When exposed to successive NIR irradiation, the GO served as a nanoscale heating source and triggered the shape‐memory behavior of SMP polyurethane. As a result, the films reverted to the original short and flat state as if the flowers faded.
The most basic application of photomechanical soft nanocomposite materials is  in actuator fabrication, but the challenge mainly lies in how to achieve
306 8 Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites
more complicated motion than the bending deformation. Anisotropic orienta tion was utilized to realize complicated motion in LC systems and recent researches even achieved 2D and 3D deformation through introduction of topo logical defects [132, 133]. However, it is rarely reported in other soft matters. Recently, an anisotropic photothermal actuator was fabricated, which was inspired by hygroscopic seed dispersal in plants [15]. Aligned CNTs were embed ded in paraffin wax on a polyimide substrate, and when cut into strips with the long axis parallel or perpendicular to the CNT orientation, the obtained strips showed opposite bending direction under irradiation of visible light. Peng and coworkers also designed a telescopic arm consisting of a pre‐shaped helical strip that served as elevator, which underwent untwisting upon light irradiation, and six curving strips that served as claw, as shown in Figure 8.12A.
3078.4 Applications
In addition, actuators with novel designed structures have been developed into more functionalized devices. For example, an IR‐light‐ driven actuator was reported based on bilayer composite materials composed of CNT‐doped LCE layer and silicone layer [91]. The actuator can climb a slope in the loop of bend ing and reverting with the help of two PC films in different shapes (Figure 8.12B). Similarly, Jiang et  al. prepared a PDMS platform with graphene nanoplatelets composited in one side [134]. They fabricated a fish‐like swimmer that can move forward, backward, and sideward on water (Figure 8.12C).
As the global energy crisis is becoming increasingly serious, photovoltaic materials have been intensively studied as novel energy sources producing electricity energy from light energy. More efforts have also been taken for the same purpose in photomechanical soft nanocomposite materials. As shown in Figure 8.13, an optical pendulum generator was designed with copper coils in the front of a bilayer LCP/LDPE photoactive film [53], as shown in Figure 8.13. Being placed in a magnetic field, the device generated a voltage pulse when the light was turned on and a damped oscillate voltage when the light was turned off according to Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction. Interestingly, continu ous electrical output was also achieved by self‐shielding the light exposure real izing alternating photoinduced motions of bending and unbending. The fabricated optical pendulum generator showed advantages of simplicity, low cost and stability for coupling the photomechanical energy.
308 8 Photomechanical Soft Nanocomposites
Peng and coworkers proposed a new strategy by integrating photomechanical actuation and electrostatic effect. They prepared a 1D yarn containing two elec trodes. One electrode was aligned CNTs coated with polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) and the other was the afore‐mentioned CNT/paraffin wax/PI bilayer photoactuator [135]. The yarn was then treated by plasma to produce negative charge on the PTFE surface and then positive charge accumulated on CNT parts in both electrodes due to electrostatic attraction. When light was turned on, the photoinduced bending of yarn changed the distance between the PTFE surface and two CNT electrodes resulting in an electron flow. When the light was turned off, the recovery of distance led to an opposite voltage.
Recently, photoresponsive lamina and flexible GO/PVDF‐HFP nanocomposite films were prepared by one simple solution‐casting method. Fast, stable, and reversible photomechanical behavior of the nanocomposite films upon irradia tion with visible light was observed based on the photothermal effect of GO and the shape‐memory effect of the polymer matrix. According to the principle of equilibrium apparatus, light‐powered tumbler movement was achieved in these films by imitating the structure of one wobbly man [27], as shown in Figure 8.14. Once the tumbler movement started, the oscillation continued for several hours as long as the visible light was irradiated. It is expected that more complicated movement can be achieved in these photomechanical nanocomposite films for full‐plastic devices of advanced functions driven by visible light.
There are still many excellent works that are not mentioned in this chapter [136, 137], but to be honest, all these applications would be far away from being practical. They have shortcomings in mechanical properties, stability, repeatabil ity, manufacturing, cost, and others. However, these shortcomings cannot over shadow the prospect of photomechanical actuators and that is the reason why this aspect attracts so many outstanding researchers.
309 References

sections.heading: 8.5 Summary and Perspectives
sections.text:
In this chapter, we systematically introduced the fabrication, properties, and applications of photomechanical soft nanocomposite materials from different perspectives. The nanocomposites are on the basis of traditionally studied poly mer matrices, such as LCPs, CLCPs, SMPs, hydrogels, supramolecular polymers, and other commercially available polymer films. By doping or asymmetric assembling the functional additives with soft matrices, the fabricated nanocom posites show amazing photomechanical properties. Besides, the nanocompos ites usually possess more designability and easier fabrication features than the pure polymer matrices. The nanocomposites perform photodriven motions due to the photothermal or photochemical effect of the functional additives and the synergies between the additives and matrices, indicating their large potential in the photoactuating field.
However, the existing defects in the nanocomposites still could not be ignored. The interface between the composite components, organic and inorganic mate rials, makes the phases or layer separation of nanocomposites to probably occur, which may intensely influence the service life and application range of the nano composites. The requirements of durability, stability, and adaptability to various working conditions are still challengeable for novel composite photoactuators. Other challenges not only for photomechanical nanocomposites but also for other systems are how to enhance their driving force and mechanical strength, and how to utilize their various deformations in real life.

sections.heading: 9.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Nature is unmatched in its esthetics and precisely controlled complexity of bio chemical structures of life and the way they function. Nature’s sophisticated functional hierarchical structures are mostly made from biopolymers like poly peptides and polysaccharides, which, over time, have evolved to respond to vari ous adverse external stimuli at levels ranging from molecular to macroscopic. The responses include change of color, shape, porosity, and stiffness [1, 2]. To cite a few, Cuttlefishes have mastered the art of color change for purposes of camouflage or as a way of warning against potential predators [3]. Mimosa pudica is a tropical plant that undergoes change in leaf orientation by closing and opening its foliage with response to touch and light [4]. The Venus flytrap, an insectivorous plant, can close its leaves to catch insects that touch its trigger hairs [5]. A vital organ in the human body, the heart, undergoes constant beats at the rate of 60–100 bpm, triggered by electrical impulses (Figure 9.1) [8]. Most of the man‐made polymers on the other hand are robust, but lack the stimuli‐ responsive functional properties seen in their natural counterparts. Many of these synthetic polymers are extensively used in our day‐to‐day life, but modern nanotechnology and biomedical applications, for example, require functionally active smart polymers.
The most commonly used synthetic commodity polymers are polyolefins. But, just as most known synthetic polymers, functional properties of polyolefins are static. The challenge is to develop a commercially viable stimuli‐responsive poly mer material, based on commodity polymers such as polyolefins. If we can make it respond to external stimuli, like light, such photoresponsive materials will have a wide range of applications [9, 10] in optical storage, sensors, actuators, artificial muscle, and soft‐robotics, etc. This chapter will discuss briefly the pho toresponsive polymeric systems in general and the need for photoresponsive commodity polymers, followed by recent developments of photoresponsive
Photoresponsive Polyolefins Shaji Varghese, John R. Severn, and Albertus P. H. J. Schenning

polyolefins with suitable examples. Furthermore, the challenges and future direc tions of advancing the same are also discussed.

sections.heading: 9.2 Photoresponsive Polymers
sections.text:
Photo‐activation with a specific wavelength is one of the most commonly adopted external triggers for changing the properties of stimuli‐responsive materials and also for the development of photoactuators and other micro‐ devices as it is very convenient to apply remotely, cheap, and easy to control intensity and wavelength. Such photo‐activation of polymeric materials generally requires a photoresponsive chromophore incorporated in them. Azobenzene, spiropyran, and dithienylethene are examples of molecules that can reversibly change their  chemical structure upon light excitation and are also the most commonly used  light‐responsive chromophores in stimuli (photo)‐responsive polymers and materials. For example, azobenzene under goes light‐induced reversible isomerization with large geometrical changes between its thermally stable trans form with length of 0.9 nm and a metastable cis form with length of only 0.55 nm [11]. When this molecule is incorporated into a special polymeric network, it induces wavelength‐controlled macro scopic deformation. Such photoresponsive materials can convert light energy
322 9 Photoresponsive Polyolefins
into mechanical energy and demonstrate reversible three‐dimensional shape changes, photomechanical actuators, etc. and a variety of such responsive sys tems have been reported during the past decade [12–14]. However, most of them are based on photoresponsive chromophore‐embedded hydrogels and liquid crystalline networks (LCNs) [15, 16]. LCNs combine the property of pol ymer networks and the properties of liquid crystals (LC) with prominent aniso tropic expansion. Azobenzene‐ related LCNs are very popular photoresponsive materials that undergo wavelength‐controlled reversible shape changes due to their cooperative molecular effect and have found wide range of applications in nonlinear optics, holography, actuators, soft‐robotics, etc. This wide explora tion of azobenzene based LCNs is due to the greater control of relative degree of order or phase associated with macroscopic deformation by light of appro priate wavelength [17]. The response process is caused by a small reversible change of the local molecular order. In case of a uniaxial molecular orientation, this leads to shrinkage in the direction along the molecular director while expansion will occur in all other directions. This disorder can be induced by molecular switches such as azobenzenes. Altering the chemical structure by the derivatization of the azobenzene core was studied in order to use different wavelengths of light ranging from UV to visible light; these modified structures also influence the photochemical properties of LCNs. One recent example of such an advanced LCN‐based photomechanical actuator was developed by Kumar et al. [18] to demonstrate the ability of utilizing sun light, the most abun dantly available source of energy, to create a self‐sustained oscillatory motion (Figure 9.2). This system used an engineered azobenzene moiety by ortho‐sub stitution, which absorbs the light from the visible region of the electromagnetic radiation. This ortho‐fluoro azobenzene polymer actuator has the potential for directly converting the solar energy into mechanical work, in addition to creat ing autonomous oscillatory function.

sections.heading: 9.3 Need for Non‐liquid Crystalline or Commodity Polymeric Materials
sections.text: Tremendous progress has been made in the fabrication of photoresponsive hydrogels and LCNs with the development of next generation micro‐devices that are capable of mimicking natural movements [19, 20]. However, the photo‐ mechanical work output or light energy conversion efficiency is not high. One possible reason for this may be due to the low elastic modulus and low strength [21]. For the future, for commercial development of light‐controlled micro‐ devices and soft‐robotics greater photomechanical force output with minimal expense is required as the mechanical work output is an important performance tool for the polymer actuators or micro‐devices. The work output of natural mus cle is a common efficiency indicator to compare the performance of these devices; for example, mammalian skeleton muscle generally produces 0.35 MPa stress and

sections.heading: 40% strain with the work density of 40 kJ m−3 and power to mass ratio of 284 W kg−1 at its highest performance [22, 23]. Figure 9.3 demonstrates the work efficiency of
sections.text:
various responsive materials including LC materials, shape‐memory alloy and
biological systems (e.g. natural muscles), which clearly shows the need for new materials for the responsive applications with maximum work output [24]. To improve the work efficiency, dielectric elastomers have been demonstrated with the potential of creating artificial muscles [25]. An alternative strategy that is both cost‐effective and direct, is to use responsive flexible semi‐crystalline commodity plastic materials [26].
High photo‐mechanical work output can be obtained by photoresponsive semi‐crystalline polymeric materials such as polyolefins, because of their flexi bility and high Young’s modulus. Since mechanical energy is directly related to the Young’s modulus, using such polymeric systems is one way to improve work output significantly [25]. Additionally, these polymers are also available in large quantities at a cheaper price. However, it should be noted that the strains of these materials are low, which can be overcome by careful device design. Research in this direction requires renewed effort although the first reported photoresponsive material is based on such a category of polymer. In 1966, Merian observed that a semi‐crystalline polymer fiber, nylon dyed with an azobenzene derivative shrank upon photoirradiation [27]. Although the observed contraction was very small (0.1%), his research laid the foundation for azobenzene‐based photoresponsive materials. The photoinduced contraction in this case may have been a combined effect of trans–cis isomerization and photothermal effect or just the latter. This work was followed by Eisenbach
in  1980 who demonstrated improved responsive nature when azobenzene‐ functionalized poly(ethyl acrylate) was used. The improvement, however, was not very remarkable as the photoinduced contraction reached only ~0.25% [28]. The plastic objects evolved from static to next generation complex responsive materials (Figure 9.4) during the last decade after the discovery of large photoin duced bending of liquid crystalline elastomers (LCEs) in 2001 [17, 30]. The development in this direction includes the semi‐crystalline‐based polymers as well [31].

sections.heading: 9.4 Polyolefins
sections.text:
Polyolefins can range from ultra‐rigid thermosets to high‐performance elasto mers via all conceivable thermoplastic and elastoplastic materials in between. As a result they account for more than 55% of the global commodity plastic materi als demand (Figure 9.5). Yet, if one looks at their chemical composition, poly olefins are surprisingly limited: polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), a few copolymers of ethylene with propene or another α‐olefin, and little else [33]. This success has come from a deep understanding of the synthesis and pro cessing of these polymers at a multiple‐length scale, from chain topology to crys talline morphology and orientation. The combination the know‐how of this structure property, cost of the materials, and base monomer means that a poly olefin solution often finds itself as the preferred option, from a price/perfor mance balance. Consequently, polyolefins are employed in a wide range of applications such as infrastructure (water and gas piping and energy transmis sion); advanced packaging, light and reliable packaging that reduce transport emissions while increasing the self‐life of perishable goods; and automotive application replacing metal with light material that allows for lighter automo biles and niche areas such as biomedical material and high‐strength ultra‐high molecular weight PE (UHMW‐PE) fibers. Highly oriented UHMW‐PE fibers are
special types of linear polyolefins containing very long chain PE with an average molecular weight over 1000 kg mol−1 and crystallinity of more than 90%, which makes them impressive polymers with highly remarkable mechanical properties such as high Young’s modulus (>200 GPa), high abrasion resistance, high impact strength, and low coefficient of friction. Owing to these unique qualities of UHMW‐PE fibers, they are highly suitable for high‐ performance applications such as protective clothing and gloves, fishing lines, marine ropes, anti‐ballistics, prosthetic implants, surgical sutures, etc. [34]. Dyneema®, is one of the commer cial brand of highly aligned UHMW‐PE fiber from DSM and is already market ing such high‐performance products [35]. The intriguing question we can ask here, is, can we make these static material into functional systems that can mimic nature? In other words, is it possible to make a responsive polyolefin for advanced applications? To answer this question, we highlight some of the impres sive research done in that direction.

sections.heading: 9.5 Photoresponsive Polyolefins
sections.text:
Polyolefins have good mechanical properties, but the functional properties of their products remain static to light. In order to make photoresponsive polyole fin‐based micro‐devices, researchers combined well‐known responsive proper ties of LC materials with polyolefins. One notable earlier approach was to make composite bilayer film of LCs and PE or PP. PE layer in these responsive films act
326 9 Photoresponsive Polyolefins
as the low‐cost, flexible base or supportive layer to provide good mechanical strength. Some of the work based on such bilayer composite layer films is sum marized further.

sections.heading: 9.5.1 Bilayer Actuators
sections.text:
Ikeda’s light‐driven plastic motor device is one of the first examples that used PE bilayer layer films based designs. This plastic motor is based on a composite film consisting of a light‐responsive, azobenzene‐based LCN layer laminated on unstretched low‐density PE (LDPE) sheet [29]. The resultant bilayer sheet is connected to both ends to form a ring, which in turn is attached to a homemade pulley system as a belt in such a way that the azobenzenes are aligned in the ring direction (Figure 9.6) facing the light source. When the prepared system is irra diated by UV light (365 nm, 240 mW cm−2) from the top right and by visible light (>500 nm, 120 mW cm−2) from top left simultaneously, the plastic belt is rotated, which in turn drives the two pulleys in a counterclockwise direction at room temperature. This is the first plastic device that was reported to be able to con vert the light energy into mechanical work in the form of continuous rotation in one direction. They have explained the mechanism of the light‐controlled, uni directional movement as follows: a local contraction force was generated along the alignment direction of the azobenzene mesogen upon UV irradiation due to the trans to cis isomerization of azobenzene, which is parallel to the long axis of the ring. This contraction force acted on the right pulley to rotate in the coun terclockwise direction. At the same time, irradiation by visible light produced a local expansion force due to the cis to trans isomerization, which caused a counterclockwise rotation of the left pulley. These continuous contraction and
3279.5 Photoresponsive Polyolefins
expansion forces generated at different parts along the long axis of the belt, resulting in the rotation of the pulleys with the ring was unidirectional. Although the PE layer did not contribute directly to the photoresponsiveness, it provided better mechanical strength and flexibility to the system.
The bilayer composition of a flexible PE (or PP) film and an LCN was also used to demonstrate light‐driven micro‐devices such as: (i) a simple device that moved like a “robotic arm”; (ii) a device that can walk in one direction like an “inch worm”; (iii) a soft micro‐robot that can pick, lift, move, and place objects; and (iv) a plastic wheel with tunable rolling (or moving) direction and speed. The detailed design and working principle of such photoresponsive devices are described further.
Ikeda and coworkers have also developed a “robotic arm” based on a lami nated  film, which consists of photoresponsive azobenzene LCN and a flexible unstretched PE layer [36]. As shown in Figure 9.7, the laminated film contains LCN layers at two places with the azobenzenes aligned along the long axis. This system shows sequential and flexible motion upon continuous irradiation of the
UV and visible light. A bent laminated film is based on a similar bilayer design but the LCN layer at the central part shows lateral movement by alternate irra diation with UV and visible light, which mimics the walk of an inchworm [36]. The plastic inchworm had an asymmetric end‐shape design to make such photoresponsive directional movement (Figure 9.8). Upon alternate irradiation with UV and visible light at room temperature, the sharp and flat edges of the plastic inchworm acted as the stationary points, respectively. As a result, the inchworm walked unidirectionally.
In addition to the controlled thermal back isomerization, the main advantage of azobenzene‐based photoactive material is that the substitution pattern can result in difference in absorption and, therefore, a modified azobenzene can be used for visible light or even direct sunlight as the energy source. Yu and cowork ers designed and synthesized a new LCN/PE bilayer composite film that contains longer conjugated azotolane structure in the side chain (Figure  9.9b) as the photo‐reversible chromophore in the LCN layer, transfers visible light directly into mechanical energy [37]. Using this approach they have demonstrated a vis ible‐light‐driven soft micro‐robot, which was manipulated to pick, lift, move,
and place milligram‐scale objects by light irradiation at different part as shown in Figure 9.9. Opening and closing motion of the hand part of this plastic robot was achieved simply by switching the light on and off instead of changing the wavelength of the light used. This is because the bilayer curvature can be reverted to its original flat shape by turning off the light.
Lu et al. fabricated a light‐driven wheel based on a laminated bilayer composite film composed of azobenzene‐containing LCE layer and a transparent PP layer of thickness around 45 μm [38]. Carefully laminated architectural design by con trolled setting of the LCEs film as the outer or inner layer of the bilayer wheels enabled the wheels to roll away from and toward the light source, respectively on a flat surface (Figure 9.10). They have explained the mechanism of the movement as the nonuniform bending of the LCE layers, which can create a curvature of the laminated film by incident UV light. This asymmetric deformation of the wheel is considered to be the driving force of the rotatory movement. The speed of the rotatory movement can also be controlled by adjusting the strain energy stored in the film. For example, film with more energy stored in it moves faster. To achieve this, the wheels were fabricated with LCEs films stretched to either 200% or 100% strain before lamination. They have also demonstrated that the speed of
rotatory movement can be controlled by other parameters such as intensity of incident light or the radius of the wheel.

sections.heading: 9.5.2 Single‐Layer Actuators
sections.text:
The above examples of bilayer composite design have already shown the use of polyolefins as a supportive layer for the photoresponsive micro‐device design due to its flexibility and modulus. However, the laminated composite actuators with an adhesive layer may suffer low life time due to the delamination of the two layers after long exposures to the light source [39]. Direct incorporation of a
332 9 Photoresponsive Polyolefins
photoresponsive chromophore or materials in the polyolefin matrix is a very straightforward strategy to make a cost‐effective (mass‐production) responsive material. Commercial availability, low cost, flexibility, and high Young’s modulus of the polyolefins make it the best host polymer matrix for the large‐scale pro duction of light‐responsive actuators or soft‐robotics based on monolayers. Some of the attempts in this direction are mentioned further.
Ryabchun et al. have reported such an approach for the first time. They have used the stretched porous PE as the matrix for azobenzene‐based LCNs to create photo‐actuators. These plastic films were capable of reversibly deforming with response to light irradiation [40]. High deformation values of these new PE com posites film and its reversibility were demonstrated (Figure 9.11). These plastic photoactuators combined several advantages such as lack of the need for align ing coatings and complex cell preparation process, good mechanical properties, and relatively low‐cost fabrication. They have also studied the kinetic and ther modynamic features of the process of bending of the LCNs/PE monolayer com posite actuators.

sections.heading: 9.6 Photo Patterning
sections.text:
Apart from photoactuators based on polyolefins, photopattering, or surface micro‐patterning of PE films have wide range of applications including in optical recording, optical memory devices, sensors, biofouling, and tissue engineering [41]. Several methods were developed for micro‐patterning of polymers like photolithography, holography, micro‐ and nanoprinting and inkjet printing, etc. Bobrovsky et al. [42, 43] reported a photopatternable polymer composite film based on stretched porous PE and LC. The resultant film was analyzed by SEM (Figure 9.12a) in order to confirm the porous aligned nature of the LC/PE com posite matrix as showed in Figure 9.12b. The chemical structures of LC mono mers and cross‐linkers are showed in Figure 9.12c. This film was then irradiated with UV light through a mask, Figure 9.12d–f shows a polarized optical micros copy image of such optical photo‐recording. This pattern is quite stable over time, due to the slow cis–trans back isomerization. This slow back isomerization is mainly due to the controlled substitution pattern of the azobenzene unit.
Uchida et al. extended such a photopattering approach into a useful three bits eight state recording system by incorporating three different photoresponsive diarylethene derivatives into a polyolefin matrix (poly(cyclopentene) polymer) [44]. When irradiated with UV light, the three different diarylethene derivatives changed to their closed‐ring structure with the formation of yellow, red, and blue colors. They were able to selectively bleach the color by applying the specific wavelength of UV light that matched the closed ring form of different deriva tives. Since the spectra of the closed forms of the diarylethene derivatives are in the IR region in addition to UV–Vis, IR light of a specific wavelength could be used to read the eight states. Figure 9.13 shows the schematic of the recording on photochromic polymer film.
Surface micro‐patterning of uniaxially drawn high‐density PE (HDPE) films using interference holography with a nanosecond pulsed laser was demonstrated
recently by Shen et  al. [41]. They used UV absorber, 2‐(2H‐benzotriazole‐2‐ yl)‐4,6,‐diterpentylphenol (BZT) incorporated oriented HDPE film to generate a micro‐pattern. Upon illumination with an interference pattern, the BZT mole cule induces transition from light to heat creating a height relief grating. This topography was found to be dependent on the concentration of the BZT used and also on the light energy dose applied. The detailed schematic diagram of the experimental setup for the interference is shown in Figure 9.14A. The generated surface patterns were analyzed by AFM technique. Figure 9.14B (a and b) shows the AFM images and the height profile of the oriented HDPE films containing 5 wt% BZT after illumination with interference pattern (Λo = 9.5 μm) at an energy dose of 120 mJ cm−2 and at various angles (α) between the grating direction and the film drawing direction. Additionally, this aligned and chain‐extended PE films with the surface relief gratings are also evaluated as strain sensors in tensile deformation. By this approach, strains below 10% are monitored accurately in a transmission mode.
Polyolefins‐based photoresponsive systems are not limited only to the above‐ mentioned applications. Despite the fact that these are the old polymers, incor porated functions offered us exciting new perspectives, which cope with the current society demands. The following section will discuss some of the chal lenges, recent developments, and future directions.
336 9 Photoresponsive Polyolefins

sections.heading: 9.7 Challenges for Photoresponsive Polyolefins and Future Directions
sections.text:
One of the major challenges to be addressed during the development of polyole fin‐based photoresponsive materials is photo‐oxidative degradation. It should be noted that UV radiation is the greatest contributor for deep deterioration of ulti mate mechanical properties and degradation of polyolefins in the presence of oxygen [45]. This can be addressed by choosing an appropriate photoresponsive unit that can also act as the stabilizer, in addition to maintaining the photore sponsiveness [46, 47]. This approach will prevent the auto‐oxidation cycle of the photodegradation of responsive polyolefins and will increase the lifetime.
Another challenge is the incorporation of the photoresponsive chromophore to the polyolefin, due to its immiscibility with the polymer matrix as polyolefins are highly nonpolar. But this can be addressed by careful design and chemical modification of the photoresponsive molecular unit while maintaining the ther mal stability and photoisomerization. Compatibility with biological systems for the development of integrated bionics can also be considered. UHMW‐PE already showed utility in human hip/knee transplants in the static forms [48]. Recently, advanced medical textiles based on medical grade UHMW‐PE fibers have also been developed for various implantable devices. These developments shed the hope for the easy human–machine interface of responsive‐polyolefins. One of the immediate practical medical applications we can consider are pho toresponsive intravenous needles of such highly oriented polymer fibers, which can be activated by near‐infrared (NIR) light inside the body. If successful, they can be promising tools with minimal invasive medical application [49, 50].
Other semi‐crystalline, amorphous commodity polymers (Figure 10.5) also can be used instead of contemporary light‐responsive polymers in order to design devices that can do greater mechanical work. For example, azobenzene‐ functionalized polyimides have shown large deformation and higher photo‐ generated force output by White and coworkers [51, 52]. These polymers are amorphous to semi‐crystalline and exhibit high glass transition temperature (Tg) and high storage moduli with good thermal stability. Photoinduced bending behavior with a bending angle ranging from 0° to 90° in 30 minutes has been demonstrated for one such polymer. This research already indicates that a care ful rational design and polymer modification of polyolefins with an azobenzene unit can be used to create photoresponsive polymeric materials. The above work additionally signals that the alignment of the photoresponsive chromophore in the polymer matrix is one of the key factors to be considered while developing the photoresponsive semi‐crystalline or commodity polymers. This can be achieved either by synthesizing the polymer with photoresponsive unit incorpo rated in the main chain [53] or creating a composite polymer material where the photoresponsive chromophore is aligned within the host polymer matrix as a guest.
The responsive nature of semi‐crystalline polymers need not only be limited to photoresponsiveness; we can also consider other external stimuli such as humid ity, pH, temperature, electricity, mechanical stress, etc. The amorphous and the crystalline region of some of the highly oriented (e.g. Nylon, PE) fibers contract
337 References
in length and expand in volume, respectively, in response to temperature [54, 55]. Based on this principle, temperature‐responsive artificial muscles were devel oped utilizing such commercial polymers by Baughman and coworkers with the specific work output of 2000 J kg−1 during contraction which is 20 times larger than that of natural muscle [55]. The same group earlier developed a guest‐filled, twist‐spun carbon nanotube yarn, which is not only temperature responsive, but also photothermal responsive [56]. Moreover, semi‐crystalline polymers based on shape‐memory response were studied for several interesting applications [57]. These include the strong polymer fiber, UHMW‐PE [58]. In addition to temperature‐responsive commodity polymers, humidity‐responsive polyamides have also been demonstrated with the possibility of developing next‐generation smart textiles [59]. Other responsive functions such as change of color can be obtained by incorporating chromophores such as spiropyran; the resultant system can be used for the development of sensors. Recently, responsive cho lesteric liquid crystals having structural color have been attached to nylon to fabricate color changing textile and optical strain sensors [60]. Such develop ments and outlooks are in the direction of future commercial development of smart materials with interesting yet useful functions.
The responsive materials based on semi‐crystalline (non‐liquid crystalline) or commodity polymers have begun to grow in demand due to their commercial availability, easy fabrication process, flexibility, and high Young’s modulus which are expected to generate greater work output in addition to mechanical stability.

sections.heading: 9.8 Conclusions
sections.text: This chapter has highlighted some of the recent developments in the area of photoresponsive polymeric systems and the possibility of generating future responsive functional materials out of semi‐crystalline commodity polymers especially using polyolefins. Converting light energy to mechanical energy or motion utilizing photoresponsive polymeric materials have led to smart micro‐ devices that can do useful work. The work output most likely can be improved by utilizing high Young’s modulus, semi‐crystalline commodity polymers such as polyolefins with careful device design. Such photoresponsive systems are a promising yet inexpensive way of converting light into mechanical work. Additionally, this approach provides a tool to control the bulk polymer proper ties of polyolefins remotely. These developments foresee a future commercial development of responsive commodity polymers in fields such as soft‐robotics and micro‐devices with greater adaptability, sensors, motors and artificial muscles, etc.

sections.heading: 10.1 Introduction
sections.text: Over the last half‐century, advances in science based on the evolution of semi conductor physics and transistor electronics have greatly influenced the devel opment of our lives. The key to this was the ability to design crystalline materials that tailor the conduction properties of electrons to suit diverse applications. More recently, the optical communication revolution has shifted the frontier in high‐speed, multiplex, and wide‐bandwidth information processing from elec trons to photons, a shift that demands a new kind of synthetic soft material to mold the gigabits [1–3]. To address this need, recent research has suggested a way to tailor the propagation of light much like that of electrons, via the creation of periodic optical media dubbed photonic crystals (PCs).

sections.heading: 10.1.1 Photonic Crystals
sections.text:
Many colors found in nature cannot be explained simply by the phenomenon of absorption and reflection of light. The origins of such colors were not understood until the middle of the last century and it was only after electron microscopy had become an established technique, that the origins of these colors could be explained. These colors arise from the interaction of light with highly ordered structures, the sizes of which are in the order of the wavelength of visible light. The most promi nent feature of such structures is that they present iridescences as a result of dif fraction. Some natural examples are the multilayered structure of pearls, the flashing wings of several insects, and natural opals as shown in Figure 10.1.
Recently, there has been growing interest in developing bioinspired nanostruc tures that suppress defects, and control the symmetry and size of PCs [4–10]. PCs are composed of spatially ordered dielectric structures with their lattice parameter comparable to the wavelength of light. PCs are largely divided into one‐dimensional (1D), two‐dimensional (2D), or three‐dimensional (3D) accord ing to the dimensionality of the periodicity as shown in Figure 10.2. At specific

wavelength ranges, the propagation of light can be suppressed to travel through PCs by strong interference. Thus, PCs can reflect the light coming onto the crys tal. The forbidden wavelength ranges are called a photonic band gap (PBG), which performs similar behavior as the electronic band gap created by the peri odic arrangement of atoms in a semiconductor [11, 12]. Based on the properties of PCs confining a light, increasing attention has been paid recently to manipu late a light for optical signal processing, optical integration technology, and color display by using PCs.

sections.heading: 10.1.2 Tunable Photonic Crystals
sections.text:
Many potential applications of PCs require some unique capabilities for tuning the PBG through external stimuli. The PBG mainly depends on the angle of inci dence, the lattice constants, and material composition of PCs. When the light passes in a PC of spherical particles as shown in Figure 10.3, the diffraction of light can be described by the Bragg–Snell law [3, 7, 13–20],
