Therefore, any vari ation in either spacing or refractive index results in a shift of the Bragg reflection peak.
Some practical schemes for tunable PCs that are based on the concept of changing the lattice constants have been reported. For example, control of the spatial structure has also been realized by taking advantage of the volume phase transition of hydrogels, where PBGs have been tuned by controlling the tempera ture, the pH, and the ionic state, or by using photoisomerization of azobenzene derivatives [21–24]. Figure 10.4 shows an example of the tuning of a PBG based on the concept of changing lattice constants by trans–cis photoisomerization of azobenzene molecules attached in a hydrogel network around a self‐assembled crystalline colloidal array [22]. 3D periodic structure was constructed by self‐ assembly of colloidal particles due to long‐range electrostatic repulsions between particles, and following the formation of the hydrogel network.

Large shifts in PBGs have been demonstrated by controlling the lattice con stants. However, these techniques have a disadvantage because of incomplete recovery and deformation when structural changes occur on the order of micrometer dimensions, resulting in difficulties for practical applications. On the other hand, PBG depends on the refractive index change as well as lattice constant according to Eq. (10.1). The photochemical PBG switching by refractive index change will be the main focus in this chapter.

sections.heading: 10.2 Photo‐Tunable 1D PCs
sections.text: Several methods of fabricating such materials have been explored since the con cept of PCs was proposed. The simplest example of a PC is the multilayer‐stacked material. A multi‐bilayered film, which is one of the multilayer‐stacked materi als, can be prepared by stacking of alternate hydrophilic and hydrophobic poly mer layers. When a photoresponsive azobenzene polymer was employed for a hydrophobic layer, the refractive index of the multi‐bilayered film was controlled by changing the molecular orientation of an azobenzene group, thermally and photochemically. In this section, we specifically describe the tuning of the PBG of multi‐bilayered films depending on the refractive index change with molecu lar orientation of an azobenzene group attached to a polymer segment.

sections.heading: 10.2.1 Photoresponsive Properties of Azobenzene Molecules
sections.text:
Since the wavelength and intensity of the reflection strongly depend on the changes in refractive indices of the materials, PBG switching is possible by using a liquid crystal (LC) exhibiting stimuli‐responsive orientation behavior. Among various promising stimuli, light shows distinct and significant advan tages due to its spatial, remote, and temporal controllability. It is also notewor thy that the light sources with different wavelengths, intensity, and polarization are readily accessible. Photocontrol of chemical and physical functions of vari ous materials has been studied vigorously using the photochemical configura tional change of azobenzene derivatives. The photochromism of azobenzene and its derivatives due to trans–cis isomerization has been widely investigated [17, 25–30]. The azobenzene compounds are well known to show reversible photoisomerization between the trans and cis forms (Figure 10.5). In particular, an irradiation with linearly polarized light results in re‐orientation of the
34510.2 Photo‐Tunable 1D PCs
azobenzene groups perpendicular to the polarization axis of the light when the azobenzene molecules are in a viscous media, or are attached to polymer seg ments. A trans‐azobenzene molecule has an anisotropic shape; consequently, the change in the molecular orientation causes the change in the optical anisot ropy, the so‐called Weigert effect. Therefore, the change in PBG will be achieved by controlling the molecular orientation of azobenzene molecules or other ani sotropic molecules in PCs, resulting in the change in optical anisotropy.

sections.heading: 10.2.1.1 Optical Anisotropy Based on Molecular Orientation
sections.text:
Molecular orientation of low molecular weight liquid crystals (LMWLCs) can be controlled easily: e.g. in‐plane as well as out‐of‐plane molecular orientation (Figure 10.6) can be achieved statically by the use of alignment layers. In addi tion, application of external stimuli such as an electric field causes a dynamic change in the molecular orientation perpendicular or parallel to the direction of the external stimuli corresponding to the property of LMWLCs [32]. However, it is not easy to control the molecular orientation of polymer liquid crystals (PLCs) mainly because of their high viscosity. Therefore, the development of a facile technique to control the molecular orientation of PLCs uniformly, or the devel opment of PLCs showing spontaneous molecular orientation, will open the door for new functions or new materials. There are some reports on polymers show ing out‐of‐plane molecular orientation by annealing: side chain type PLCs, main
346 10 A Photoresponsive Multi‐Bilayered Film for a Tunable Photonic Crystal
chain type PLCs, and so on [33–39]. It is likely that the polymers possessing a smectic phase tend to show thermal out‐of‐plane molecular orientation by annealing at the smectic phase. Bobrovsky et al. have reported that a polyacrylate copolymer having both 4‐ethoxy‐4′‐hexyloxyazobenzene and cholesterol groups as a side chain group showed spontaneous out‐of‐plane molecular orientation on a glass substrate by annealing at 75 °C, whereas less out‐of‐plane molecular orientation was observed for a polymethacrylate homopolymer having the same azobenzene side group (PA6Az2 in Scheme 10.1) [40]. In contrast, we found that a polyacrylate homopolymer consisting of 4‐methoxy‐4′‐hexyloxyazobenzene (PA6Az1 in Scheme 10.1) aligned spontaneously in the out‐of‐plane orientation on a glass substrate by annealing at a smectic phase (80 °C) [31]. It is interesting to note that a very small difference in the terminal substituent has a large effect on the spontaneous molecular orientation behavior of the polymers. However, there are few systematic studies on the thermal out‐of‐plane molecular orienta tion of polyacrylates and polymethacrylates with azobenzene side groups.
Figure  10.6 shows the annealing effect on the molecular orientation of a PA6Az1 film. The film was prepared by spin coating a PA6Az1/cyclohexanone solution onto a glass substrate, and annealed at 80 °C. Before annealing, there were two strong peaks at c. 250 and 350 nm corresponding to φ–φ* and π–π* transitions, respectively. Upon annealing, the absorbance at 350 nm was signifi cantly decreased, whereas no change in the absorbance at 250 nm was observed. It has been reported that the φ–φ* transition is insensitive to the orientation; consequently, the change in the relative intensity of the π–π* absorption band to the φ–φ* absorption band (Aπ–π*/Aφ–φ*) is related to the transformation from the in‐plane orientation to the out‐of‐plane orientation. The film was rotated hori zontally by 45°, and polarized absorption spectra of the PA6Az1 film at an inci dent angle of 45° to the normal of the film were measured by rotating the polarization plane of the monitor light (dotted line). As shown with the dotted line in Figure 10.6a, the π–π* absorption band at the rotation angle of 0° (moni tored with horizontally polarized light, curve A0) was shifted to a shorter wave length, whereas at 90° a weak π–π* band was observed (curve A90). In order to clarify the change in the molecular orientation by annealing, the absorbance at 250 and 320 nm was plotted as a function of the rotation angle in Figure 10.6b. A significant rotation angle dependence was observed for the absorbance at 320 nm. These results revealed that the annealing at 80 °C contributed not only to a transformation of the molecular orientation from the in‐plane orientation to

sections.heading: 10.2.1.2 Refractive Indices Depending on Molecular Orientation States
sections.text:
For normal direction to the films, refractive indices of out‐of‐plane orientation and random orientation rely on no and nav, respectively. Birefringence properties of azobenzene‐containing polymers depend on their molecular structures. Refractive indices of PA6Az1 were measured by using a wedge cell with align ment treatment. A He–Ne laser light (633 nm) was used as a monitor light. For the refractive indices of PA6Az1 for ordinary and extraordinary lights of 633 nm, ne and no, are estimated to be 1.71 and 1.48, respectively [42, 43]. Namely, the refractive index of the out‐of‐plane orientation of the PA6Az1 film should be 1.48. Assuming random orientation of the azo chromophores of PAmAz1, the average refractive index nav is estimated to be 1.60.
Therefore, if PA6Az1 undergoes an out‐of‐plane orientation and photoisomer ization in the multi‐bilayered film consisting of PA6Az1 and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), on–off switching of the reflection will be expected. Because, the refrac tive index of the PA6Az1 film must be controlled between 1.48 (no, out‐of‐plane state) and 1.64 (ne, in‐plane random state) by the annealing and following photoi somerization, and the refractive index of PVA is 1.49, which is nearly equal to the refractive index of the out‐of‐plane state of PA6Az1.

sections.text:

The wavelength of the reflected light from a periodic multi‐bilayered material depends on the optical thickness of each layer and refractive index difference. The reflection wavelength is given by Eq. (10.3).

In such multi‐bilayered films, the wavelength of the reflection can be controlled by varying the thickness of each layer and/or the refractive index of the stacked materials. Namely, the multi‐ bilayered films reflect the light of specific wavelength which depends on the dif ference between the refractive indices of PA6Az1 (1.60, nav) and PVA (1.49) layers, and the bilayer thickness.

sections.heading: 10.2.3 On–Off Switching of Reflection Based on Refractive Index Change
sections.text: It is well known that azobenzene compounds show reversible photoisomeriza tion between trans‐ and cis‐forms, and there are some studies on the phase transition from a liquid crystalline phase to an isotropic phase relating to photo isomerization. For the multi‐bilayered film composed of PA6Az1 and PVA, the reflection band disappeared by annealing at 80 °C for 60 seconds as can be seen in Figure 10.10a. The reflective state was visibly transformed to a transparent state as shown in the bottom part of the image given in Figure 10.10b. This result demonstrates that the annealing caused a transformation of the molecular orien tation of the PA6Az1 layers from the in‐plain orientation to the out‐of‐plane one even in the multi‐bilayered film, and the small difference between the refractive indices of PA6Az1 (1.48, no) and PVA (1.49) contributed to the disappearance of the reflection band. The reflection band appeared again upon UV irradiation, because of the transformation from the out of‐plane orientation to the photoin duced random state with photoisomerization from the trans‐ to cis‐form (solid color line in Figure 10.10a and the upper part of the photographs in Figure 10.10b). The schematic diagram of the on–off switching of the reflection relative to the change in the molecular orientation is shown in Figure 10.11.

sections.heading: 10.2.4 Improvement of Response Speed
10.2.4.1 Introduction of Biphenyl LC Group
sections.text:
The on–off switching of reflection was achieved by change in the PBG of the multi‐bilayered film. However, long‐time irradiation was required, because of higher absorbance in the UV region due to the azobenzene chromophores in the multi‐bilayered films. To improve the light response efficiency across the entire
films, the non‐photoresponsive LC mesogen groups were employed because it is possible to dilute the azobenzene chromophore concentration and to help change the orientation states. So, the effect of introducing a biphenyl group as the non‐photoresponsive LC mesogen in the hydrophobic azobenzene polymer (PA6Az1–PA6B1 (m:n) copolymers given in Scheme 10.2) was explored. If a UV transparent biphenyl group possesses cooperative orientation ability synchro nized with motion of azobenzene group, the switching speed will be improved based on the improvement of the penetration property of UV light in the film due to the decrease in the azobenzene chromophore concentration (Figure 10.12) [46]. Irradiation time required for re‐coloration was reduced to one‐third by introduction of a biphenyl group more than 25% molar ratio. The patterns of the PA6Az1–PA6B1(m:n)/PVA‐20‐bilayered film through photomask was evidently clear even with low intensity of UV light (Figure 10.13). Furthermore, it was pos sible to write the number on the multi‐bilayered film by scanning the UV laser at 130 mm s−1. (Figure 10.14)

For Az, Schi, and To groups, they were respectively estimated to be 0, 1.24, and 0 D for dipole moments; and 4.22, 3.65, and 3.72 for log P. sections.heading: 10.3 Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Development of bioinspired materials attracts growing interest, because nature is replete with hierarchically assembled hybrid materials where multi‐scale structures provide unique properties and various functions. Therefore, mimick ing nature allows us to develop ideal functional materials with high efficiency and sustainability. PCs observed in nature are based on the interaction of light with highly ordered structures.
Many potential applications of PCs require some capability for tuning PBG through external stimuli. Since the wavelength and intensity of PBG strongly depends on the changes in the refractive indices of the materials, PBG switching is possible by using a LC exhibiting stimuli‐responsive orientation behavior. Among various promising stimuli, light shows distinct and significant advan tages due to its spatial, remote, and temporal controllability. It is also noteworthy that the light sources with different wavelength, intensity, and polarization are readily accessible. Photocontrol of chemical and physical functions of various materials has been studied vigorously using photochemical configurational change of azobenzene derivatives.
This chapter described the on–off switching of reflection of 1D‐PC. The 1D‐ PC was prepared by alternative spin coating of a hydrophobic polymer consisting of azobenzene groups and PVA as hydrophilic polymer, providing multi‐ bilayered films with precisely controlled layer thickness. The on–off switching was achieved by combining thermally spontaneous molecular orientation of azoben zene molecules and their photoisomerization between trans‐ and cis‐forms, resulting in the change in PBG of the 1D‐PC. To improve the light‐response effi ciency across the entire films, the molecular structure of azobenzene polymer was studied by introducing non‐photoresponsive LC mesogen groups because of their UV transmittance, molecular orientation behavior, and birefringence characteristics. A reflection intensity higher than 90% was observed for the 1D‐ PC stacked with 20‐bilyers, and contrast of reflection change was visually suffi cient. The entire thickness of the 1D‐PC is within a few microns, so they are light. Therefore, the photoresponsive 1D‐PC will be promising candidates for applica tions to optical materials that need to be light, thin and save energy such as mate rial replacing paper, self‐standing reflective color display devices, and so on.

sections.heading: 11.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Liquid crystals (LCs) have attracted considerable attention due to their pro nounced high optical anisotropy/transparency over a wide electromagnetic spectrum, high sensibility to various external field stimuli (such as electric/ magnetic field, light irradiation, and heat) and strong capability for matter and electromagnetic field interactions [1–4]. Thanks to their large birefringence and reconfigurable director (i.e. local optical axis) orientation, LCs have become one of the most attractive candidates for making optical devices requiring versatile functionalities. Particularly, liquid crystal display (LCD) holds a dominant posi tion in the flat panel display market nowadays. Essentially, they are composed of a huge number of separate light intensity modulators in the visible range [3, 5]. In addition to amplitude, LCs can freely manipulate other spatial degrees of light, such as polarization and phase. Through specifical designing of the director dis tribution of LC domains, one could arbitrarily manipulate the optical field [6, 7].
Optical field control is a key requirement for optics and photonics. Structured light, also known as shaped light or tailored light, is a light beam that has cus tomized intensity, polarization, and phase. Recently, specific beams including vortex beams [8, 9], vector beams (VBs) [10], and Airy beams [11] have been studied intensively due to their fantastic properties and diverse applications in optical trapping, laser processing, high‐resolution imaging, etc. Generally, these beams can be directly generated from Gaussian beams by spatially manipulating the amplitude or phase of light. Such manipulations could be accomplished by lens [12, 13] or plates [14, 15] with specific curvature radius, photoresist masks [16–18], or metasurfaces [19–21] with delicately designed structures. However, their optical characteristics are static once the respective device is fabricated, which severely restricts corresponding applications. Thanks to the electro‐ optical tunability of LCs, structured LC domains make these devices dynamic and more efficient.
Photoinduced Liquid Crystal Domain Engineering for Optical Field Control Wei Hu, Peng Chen, and Yan‐Qing Lu
Nanjing University, Department of Quantum Electronics and Optical Engineering, College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, 22 Hankou Road, Nanjing, Jiangsu, 210093, China
362 11 Photoinduced Liquid Crystal Domain Engineering for Optical Field Control
To date, several strategies have been developed for LC domain engineering. Typically, patterned electrodes [22–25] and polymer‐dispersed LCs [26] were adopted to locally and poloidally guide the LC directors to form binary domains. However, their manufacture is complicated and the devices suffer from fixed structures. Dynamic LC domain generation could be accomplished by a com mercial spatial light modulator (SLM) [27, 28]. As shown in Figure 11.1, an SLM consists of numerous discrete micro‐size LC pixels driven separately. Never theless, the complex electrode matrix makes the SLM costly, optically inefficient, and limits the quality of the generated beams. All the above LC microstructures are realized through the polar angle control of LCs. Actually, their azimuthal angle could also be employed to form LC multi‐domains. Micro‐ rubbing [29– 31] and patterned rubbing [32, 33] are adopted to carry out the patterned align ment and subsequently guide the local directors to form the desired pattern. Compared to these mechanical methods, photoalignment is much more suitable for implementing accurate and high‐resolution multi‐domain LC alignments
36311.2 Photoalignment Technology and Photopatterning System
[34, 35]. In the initial research, multistep photolithography [35, 36] and hologra phy [37–40] are commonly utilized. More recently, several techniques exhibiting superior image‐output flexibility are developed [41–44], facilitating the realiza tion of complex LC orientations and subsequent optical characteristics. These techniques fully unlock a new degree of freedom to manipulate LC domains.
In this chapter, we concentrate on the recent progresses made in optical field control via photopatterned LCs over the past few years. A brief review on photoalignment technology is presented and some of the recently developed photopatterning techniques suitable for generating complicated LC domains are  emphasized. Subsequently, fascinating microstructured LC domains with binary or space‐variant orientations are demonstrated. Novel optical fields, including arbitrary optical vortices, VBs, and Airy beams, are identified and characterized. The photoinduced LC domain engineering drastically extends the capability of optical field control and affords a promising approach for arbitrarily tailoring the wavefront. It is likely to improvise traditional LC optics and photon ics, and inspire promising innovations to this rapid developing field.

sections.heading: 11.2 Photoalignment Technology and Photopatterning System
11.2.1 Photoalignment Technology
sections.text:
Since the first work on LC photoalignment in 1988 [45], tremendous improve ments have been made over the past 30 years [46]. Compared to conventional contact LC alignment techniques such as rubbing, photoalignment is more promising for high‐quality and high‐resolution multi‐domain LC alignment. Photoalignment avoids any mechanical damage, electrostatic charge, or dust contamination, and also possesses the ability for efficient LC alignment on curved or flexible substrates [46]. These years have witnessed a rapid develop ment in LC photoalignment. The commercially available photoalignment agents are now widely adopted in information display industries.
LC photoalignment originates from the anisotropic intermolecular interac tions between the alignment agent with a photoinduced order and adjacent LC molecules. The photoalignment agents can be divided into four types according to the following different mechanisms: (i) photochemical reversible cis–trans isomerization in azo‐dye containing polymers [47–49], monolayers [50], and organic dye films [45, 51]; (ii) diffusion of azo‐dye molecules due to their chromo phore reorientation under the action of polarized light [52]; (iii) topochemical cross‐linking in cinnamoyl side‐chain polymers [34]; and (iv) photodegradation in polyimide materials [53, 54].
One photoaligning mechanism of azo‐dye photoalignment agents is the reori entation of azo‐dye molecules [52, 55]. The model of rotational diffusion is used to explain the azo‐dye reorientation under the action of polarized UV light. Here, we focus on a typical photoalignment agent, i.e. sulfonic azo‐dye SD1 [56] shown in Figure 11.2. The azo‐dye molecules with transition dipole moments parallel to the direction of incident polarization will most probably get the excess energy, which
results in their reorientation from the initial position. This results in an excess of chromophores with the absorption oscillator perpendicular to the recorded UV polarization. Hence, a thermodynamical equilibrium in the new oriented state will be established [52]. The orientation of SD1 will spread to adjacent LC molecules via intermolecular interactions and thus guide the local LC directors. The azo‐dye layers supply sufficiently high anchoring energy to LCs. Additionally, SD1 is photo‐rewritable and only the last written polarization information will be recorded. That will drastically facilitate the LC domain engineering.

sections.heading: 11.2.2 Photopatterning System
sections.text:
During the past few years, several techniques suitable for flexible and high‐ resolution image output have been developed [41–43], facilitating the realization of complex LC domains that can present versatile optical functions. Figure 11.3 presents three photopatterning systems. As shown in Figure 11.3a, the first one enables arbitrary interferometric holographic recording via a modified Mach– Zehnder interferometer. The first polarizing beam splitter (PBS) separates the object (O) and reference (R) arms into orthogonal linear polarizations, which are then recombined by a second PBS. A quarter‐wave retarder is utilized to trans form the beams into orthogonal circular polarizations. The object is placed before the second PBS and interfered with the reference beam (usually a plane wave) to record its wavefront [6]. The second one directly writes the desired pattern by scanning a focused laser beam [43]. The laser direct writing system consists of a polarization rotator and a precise 2D translation system as depicted in Figure 11.3b.
Figure  11.3c exhibits the third one, namely a digital micro‐mirror device (DMD) based dynamic microlithography system [41, 42]. The DMD consists of 1024 × 768 micro‐mirrors, each of which can be independently tilted by an elec trostatic force. These mirrors play the role of a dynamic mask. A uniform and collimated UV beam is reflected onto the DMD controlled by the computer. Subsequently, the bundle of light reflected by the “ON” state mirrors carries on the designed pattern. On subsequent focus by a 10× apo‐chromatically corrected projection lens and polarized by a motorized rotating polarizer, the beam then projects onto an LC cell or glass substrate spin‐coated with photoalignment films placed at the image plane. A charge‐coupled device (CCD) is utilized to collect the light reflected by the sample in order to monitor the focusing process. The optical path between the sample and the DMD is conjugated to that of the sam ple to CCD. Owing to the excellent flexibility of image‐output capability of the DMD, arbitrarily fine LC multi‐domains can be conveniently obtained.
In addition to the above techniques, some others have also been introduced to accomplish high‐resolution multi‐domain LC alignments. For example, the plas monic photoalignment technique enables patterning LC molecular directors with a diffraction‐limited spatial resolution and single exposure [44]. The reali zation of well‐fabricated LC domains is at the heart of all optical LC devices. These photoinduced LC domain engineering techniques make arbitrary tailor ing of optical fields possible.

sections.heading: 11.3 Binary LC Domains for Binary Optics
sections.text:
Through an LC cell with locally controlled azimuthal angles, the same linearly polarized light will experience different phase shifts due to the angle‐ dependent efficient refractive index. The predesigned LC director distribution results in a patterned phase profile. Therefore, arbitrary optical elements in binary optics can be obtained by properly designing alternative LC domains. Usually, a two‐ step photo‐exposure process is performed [36, 58]. At first, the substrate or cell
366 11 Photoinduced Liquid Crystal Domain Engineering for Optical Field Control
spin‐coated with photoalignment layers is uniformly exposed with a linearly polarized UV light, and then is exposed again to receive the designed pattern with the polarizer rotating at a certain degree (for example, 90°). The exposed areas are realigned to be orthogonal to the first orientation. Therefore, the substrate(s) are synchronously imprinted with alternative 0° and 90° alignments consistent with the desired phase pattern.
The grating, a typical binary optical element, can be divided into two kinds: amplitude grating and phase grating. By introducing periodically orthogonal LC parallel alignment (PA) domains, binary phase grating is formed, while ampli tude grating can be formed by alternative twist nematic (TN) domains. In initial researches, micro‐rubbing [29–31], two‐step rubbing [32, 33], and holographic recording method [59, 60] have been adopted to produce these gratings. In 2012, Hu et al. [36] introduced SD1 into the formation of an orthogonal PA LC grating (Figure  11.4). Different domains in adjacent regions are achieved by two‐step photo‐exposure to guide orientations of SD1 layers and further align the LC mol ecules. Both one‐dimensional (1D) and two‐dimensional (2D) switchable phase gratings have been demonstrated. Its polarization‐independent diffraction is theoretically studied and experimentally tested. Such polarizer‐free gratings show very high transmittance (~92%), diffraction efficiency (over 31%), and opti cal contrast (over 150). The alternate PA/TN gratings are also demonstrated in cells placed between two crossed polarizers [61, 62]. Both 1D‐ and 2D‐tunable gratings are demonstrated. The work is based on the combination of phase and amplitude modulation. Some special LC materials, including dual‐frequency
LCs [63] and ferroelectric LCs [64], are introduced to improve the response of these gratings. Thanks to the rewritability of the photoalignment agent, the opti cal function of these elements can be dynamically changed [65, 66].
The electrically tunable and switchable lens is desired for wide applications. LC lenses have attracted extensive attention. Among them, LC Fresnel lens is promising due to its outstanding electro‐optical performances. It can be realized by specifically aligning the LC directors to form a nonperiodic refractive index profile (Figure 11.5). Similar to those LC gratings, different alignment modes are adopted, including alternative PA and TN domains [67], single‐side‐patterned domains [68], and hybrid photo‐aligned domains [69]. Different LC materials are also employed, including ferroelectric LCs [70] and dual frequency LCs [69], to improve the performance of these lenses.
Let us come back to grating. If a dislocation is introduced at the center, the so  called “fork” grating is obtained. It is a computer‐generated hologram of a Gaussian beam and an optical vortex (OV). OVs are characterized by helical phase fronts and donut‐shaped intensity distributions. Their unique helical phase fronts result in an orbital angular momentum (OAM) of mћ per photon [12]. More generally, they can be described by the so‐called Laguerre–Gaussian (LG) mode with two specific indices: the topological charge m and the radial index p. The OAM of OVs adds a new degree of freedom to the manipulation of light, leading to applications such as optical tweezers, quantum informatics, and OAM based optical communications [8, 9, 71]. With fork grating, a Gaussian beam can be conveniently diffracted into a series of OVs.
LC fork gratings in various alignment modes with arbitrary topological charges are fabricated [58]. Figure 11.6 exhibits the micrograph and diffraction properties of a sample with m = 1. Thanks to the design of orthogonal alignment, the two perpendicular components derived from all incident polarization
experience the same refractive index change, resulting in an excellent polariza tion independency [36, 63]. A maximum efficiency of 37% (74% for total ±1st orders) is obtained (ON state) as shown in Figure 11.6c. Here, the obtained effi ciency is close to the theoretical limitation, and is significantly improved com pared to that generated by a commercial SLM. The dynamic switching between Gaussian mode and OVs can be easily accomplished through electrical tuning. Besides, the electrically tunable half‐wave condition makes the device suitable to a broad wavelength range. Since SD1 is optically rewritable, the pattern could be erased and then rewritten at the optical isotropic state to obtain a new holo gram. This means that the mode variation is also dynamic [58]. Ferroelectric LCs can be further introduced to accomplish a ferroelectric LC fork grating with the merit of ultra‐fast response [72].
36911.3 Binary LC Domains for Binary Optics
For conventional grating and fork grating with only two phase regions in each period, the efficiencies of higher orders are quite limited, restricting their appli cations. Dammann gratings (DGs) [73, 74] can satisfactorily solve this problem. Each period of a DG is composed of certain binary phase regions of different widths. By optimizing the number and values of phase transition points, the light energy can be distributed into desired orders with good uniformity and high efficiency [75]. Such DGs can be realized by photopatterning LCs as well [76, 77]. The concept and implementation of DGs can be introduced into various optical elements based on phase modulation, such as circular grating and fork grating. On one hand, different‐order binary‐phase LC circular DGs with two mutually orthogonal photoinduced domains in every two adjacent alignment domains are proposed for generating annular uniform‐intensity optical fields (Figure  11.7a–c) [78, 80]. Such LC circular DGs exhibit merits of high effi ciency, good uniformity, and outstanding optical/electrical tunability. On the other hand, by encoding DGs into fork gratings, the so‐called Dammann vortex gratings (DVGs) are achieved. DVGs can provide equal‐energy OV array with specific OAMs at designed diffraction orders [18, 81, 82], enabling parallel OAM detection that is a key requirement in OAM based optical communica tions. The LC DVG featured by alternatively orthogonal PA regions is presented [79]. Figure 11.7d exhibits the micrograph of a 5 × 5 LC DVG with m = 1 & 1. The diffraction pattern at 632.8 nm in Figure 11.7e shows a 2D donut‐like OV array in high quality and good energy‐distribution uniformity. Thanks to the electro‐optical tunability of LCs, equivalent high efficiencies could be achieved
370 11 Photoinduced Liquid Crystal Domain Engineering for Optical Field Control
for different wavelengths by slightly tuning the applied voltages. A case for 532 nm is shown in Figure 11.7f. These LC DVGs present excellent polarization independence, electrical switchability, and tunability, which are crucial charac teristics for OAM generation, manipulation, and detection.
For the above discussed binary LC elements, the desired phase profiles arise from dynamic phases introduced by the in‐plane optical path differences. Theoretically, the maximum diffraction efficiency for traditional binary optics is 40.5% for a single first order. To further improve the efficiency for optical field control, much higher phase orders between 0 and 2π should be adopted to maxi mally mimic a continuous phase modulation. These could be hardly realized via traditional SLMs which work based on dynamic phase modulation.

sections.heading: 11.4 Space‐Variant LC Domains for Geometric Phase Modulation
sections.text:
Unlike a dynamic phase, the geometric phase (also named Pancharatnam– Berry phase [83]) originates from the spin–orbit interaction of light, i.e. the coupling between the polarization and the trajectory of light [84, 85]. The geo metric phase depends only on the geometrical characteristics and can be cre ated from inhomogeneous anisotropic media, such as LCs [6, 86] and anisotropic scatters based metasurfaces [19, 87, 88]. Usually, its magnitude is proportional to the orientation angle of the effective local optical axis, and has a polariza tion‐dependent sign. Arbitrary wavefront shaping can be realized by encoding the desired phase profile into the in‐plane optical axis orientations. As it is very easy to manipulate the optical axis for geometric phase elements, a continuous geometric phase change can be conveniently achieved. Therefore, the input energy can be 100% diffracted into a single order.
Again, we choose grating as an example. Polarization grating (PG) is a geomet ric phase element characterized by periodically and spatially variant optical axes. It is usually fabricated with LCs. As shown in Figure 11.8, the LC directors are homogeneous along the z axis and obey the following equation in the x–y plane: α(x) =  −πx/Λ [89], where Λ is the pitch of the polarization grating. The diffrac tion property of the PG can be obtained by Jones matrix calculation [4]. The PG has only three diffraction orders: ±1st orders and 0th order. The intensity distri bution among the three orders depends on the phase retardation Γ and the inci dent polarization. By adjusting Γ, switching between 0th and ±1st orders can be realized. If Γ = π, the incident linearly polarized light will equally diffract to the ±1st orders. If the input light is circularly polarized, only one first order will be obtained. In this manner, theoretically we can predict a 100% diffraction effi ciency for a single first order.
To accomplish such a space‐variant LC director distribution, polarization holography is usually adopted, which employs two orthogonally circularly polar ized beams [90–92]. The interferometric pattern is uniform in light intensity, but
has a spatially variant linear polarization obeying α(x) = −πx/Λ. After recording such a polarization hologram onto the photoalignment films, the director distri bution of the LC PG can be realized. Besides, the laser direct writing method and the DMD based microlithography can also be used [43, 93]. LC PGs can be applied in broad fields, including wide viewing angle displays, polarization beam steering, Stokes parameters measurement, and polarization image sensors [89]. Most recently, dual frequency LCs have been introduced to the design of PGs to realize fast‐response and high‐efficiency optical switch [93]; by integrating multidirectional LC PGs and multilayered functional LC polymer films, the high transmittance holographic polarizer is demonstrated with a transmittance effi ciency up to 90% [94].
The focusing/defocusing function of traditional LC lens is independent of inci dent polarization, while geometric phase lens can locally modulate the incident polarization states and result in a circular‐polarization‐dependent continuous lens phase profile [95, 96]. The theoretical optical axes of such a lens are homoge neous along the z axis and obey = + −( )/ r f f2 2 in x–y plane, where α is the azimuthal angle, r is the radius, r2 = x2 + y2, f is the designed focal length, and λ indicates the free space wavelength. Through Jones matrix calculation, the prop erty of the helicity‐dependent focusing/defocusing can be theoretically predicted. As shown in Figure 11.9, when the phase retardation satisfies the half‐wave condi tion Γ = (2n + 1)π (n is an integer), for a right circularly polarized (RCP) incident beam, the output is transformed into left circularly polarization (LCP) with a spherical phase profile, leading to a concave spherical wavefront. Thus, a focused beam is obtained. On the contrary, for an LCP incident beam, the transformed RCP is defocused. Such helicity‐determined lenses are promising in 3D displays, compact photonic spin filters [97], and multi‐spot focusing engineering.
Q‐plate  [86, 98–100] is another attractive geometric phase element, which has been intensively studied in OAM‐lightened fields. Among various tech niques for OV generation, the q‐plate is especially promising due to the cou pling of spin angular momentum (SAM) and OAM [86]. It not only plays an important role in classical optics [101, 102], but also enables many quantum‐ optical applications [103, 104]. As shown in Figure 11.10, the q‐plate is a half‐ wave plate with space‐variant optical axis in the transverse plane, which follows α(r, φ) = qφ + α0, where r is the polar radius, φ is the azimuthal angle, and α0 is the initial angle when φ = 0. The number q, which denotes the changing rate of the optical axis with respect to the azimuthal angle, depicts the specific geom etry. The q‐plates will convert circularly polarized light into an OV (topological charge m = ±2q). When a circularly polarized light beam with OAM states of m traverses the q‐plate, an OAM variation of ±2qћ is imposed. Herein, the sign depends on the input polarization, positive for LCP and negative for RCP. The output polarization is sign‐inverted. The q‐plate will convert linearly polarized light into a VB  (polarization order P = 2q, depicts the degree of polarization symmetry) [99, 105]. Unlike OVs with phase singularity, VBs are featured by spatially variant polarization states and centric polarization singularities. They exhibit unique focusing properties thus enabling high‐resolution imaging and optical manipulation [10].
Owing to the pronounced optical birefringence and controllable director dis tribution, LCs are the first choice for q‐plate fabrication. Recent years have wit nessed great progress in both the design and the fabrication of LC q‐plates. The objective LC orientations can be obtained via self‐assembled [106, 107] or extra‐ field‐induced [108, 109] LC topological defects, and circular rubbing or photoa ligning [99, 110]. In 2016, the concept of “meta‐q‐plate” was proposed, which enabled the arbitrary control of q and α0 along r and φ [57]. The meta‐q‐plate supplies a point‐to‐point beam shaping method, thus drastically enhancing the capability of manipulation of geometric phases. By further integrating the spiral geometric phase of the q‐plate with a PG, a geometric phase lens, or both of them, one can obtain a forked PG [111], a vortex lens [112], or a forked vortex lens [113]. These integrated geometric phase devices combine the features of polarization‐dependent diffraction, OV/VB generation, and focusing and defo cusing functions. Besides, vector vortex beams can be generated by stacking
different q‐plates and waveplates [114]. Both the topological charge and polari zation order of generated vector vortex beams can be controlled independently by stacking and reordering different optical films.
By encoding the phase profile of desired structured beams into the LC director orientations, arbitrary optical field shaping can be realized. Other examples include Airy beam [115] (Figure  11.11), Bessel beam [116], depolarized beam
[117], and even complex hologram [6]. Airy beam exhibits features of non‐ diffraction, transverse acceleration, and self‐healing [11]. It has attracted consid erable interest in broad fields including optical manipulation, micro‐fabrication, and biology science. The geometric phase has been introduced to Airy mask to form an LC polarization Airy mask, in which the azimuthal angles of LC cubi cally vary along both x and y axes [115]. Via incident polarization control, switch between single‐ and dual‐branch Airy beams is realized. Their non‐diffraction and transverse acceleration features are verified. Furthermore, self‐healing and transverse accelerating OVs are generated via modulating Gaussian beams through subsequent LC q‐plate and polarization Airy mask [118].
All the above LC geometric phase elements are made of nematic LCs, which can be considered as a space‐variant wave‐plate. For such transmissive elements, half‐wave conditions should be precisely satisfied to maximize the conversion efficiency. EO tuning is necessary for matching different wavelengths, restricting their applications in fields with wavelength‐independency requirement.
Recently, the spin–orbit geometric phase was discovered for the light reflected off planar cholesteric liquid crystal (CLC) chiral superstructures  [119–122] (Figure 11.12). CLC is a topical liquid crystalline phase, where the rod‐like mol ecules self‐assemble into a periodic helical superstructure, contributing to a natural 1D photonic crystal. Thanks to the circular‐polarization selective Bragg reflection and the external‐field tunablility [123], CLCs have attracted much attention in versatile applications beyond mere displays [124–128]. For light propagating along the CLC helix axis, a circular‐polarization‐selective Bragg reflection is exhibited over a wavelength range nop~nep, where p is the helical pitch, and no/ne are the ordinary/extraordinary refractive indices, respectively
[4]. The circularly polarized light with the same handedness as the chiral helix of CLCs is reflected, while the orthogonal one is transmitted. The reflective geo metric phase is attributed to the preservation of the polarization helicity from such circular Bragg reflection, which implies flipping of the optical SAM [119]. The magnitude of the reflected light phase is twice the local orientation angle of  CLC planar alignment and exhibits a CLC handedness‐dependent sign [120, 129]. Therefore, it supplies a new platform for broadband reflective geo metric phase manipulation. Similar to those in nematic LCs, via preprogram ming the CLC domains, planar reflective elements including light deflectors [121], lenses [121], and OV generators [122, 130] can be obtained.

sections.heading: 11.5 Digitalized LC Domains for Digitalized Geometric Phase
sections.text:
Traditional geometric phases are usually limited to handling single‐structured beams and are unsuitable for parallel manipulation. If this challenge could be overcome, the capability for programming geometric phases and tailoring
376 11 Photoinduced Liquid Crystal Domain Engineering for Optical Field Control
structured beams will be drastically extended. For instance, the creation of higher order Poincaré (HOP) sphere beam arrays would inspire multiple optical tweezers [131], parallel laser fabrication, and higher efficiency‐stimulated emis sion depletion microscopy [132]. The HOP sphere generalizes OVs and VBs, and vividly describes their higher order polarization states [133, 134]. Compared with traditional Poincaré sphere whose poles indicate two opposite SAM eigen states, the poles of an HOP sphere represent orthogonally circularly polarized OVs. Two such eigenstates are featured by helical phase‐fronts and OAMs. Each point on the HOP sphere is a linear superposition of them. Especially, the equa tor indicates VBs featured by space‐variant linear polarizations. The HOP sphere incorporates SAM and OAM, thus extending to a higher dimension angular momentum and adding a new degree of freedom to the manipulation of light.
In 2016, the concept of digitalized geometric phase modulation was proposed and demonstrated by means of digitalizing LC domains [135]. As shown in Figure 11.13, traditional space‐variant spiral geometric phase was digitalized by imprinting a particular binary phase referring to binary optics. With such digital ized geometric phase elements, HOP sphere beam lattices available for SAM and OAM parallel encoding are demonstrated for the first time. Through tuning the incident spin state, any point on the HOP sphere can be achieved, including spe cial cases of VBs and OAM modes. Square as well as hexagonal lattices with dif ferent desired orders are realized in high efficiency and good energy uniformity. By electrically tuning, the phase retardation can reach π at different wavelengths, making the digitalized LC domains wavelength‐tolerant. Besides, the electro‐ optical tunability of LCs makes it possible to dynamically switch between ON/ OFF states.
The idea is not restricted to Dammann encoded spiral geometric phase, and can extend to other integration of binary phases and space‐variant geometric phases, thus enabling tailoring of versatile optical beams. Actually, the medium is not limited to nematic LCs. Other natural or artificial birefringent materials could be adopted as well. As a special case, CLC chiral superstructures can be digitalized for advanced functionalities [136].
CLC chiral superstructure exhibits unique features of polychromatic and spin‐ determined phase modulation. By encoding a specifically designed binary pat tern and emphasizing the spin‐dependent phase invariance, an innovative CLC OV processor is demonstrated. As exhibited in Figure 11.14, up to 25 different OVs are extracted with equal efficiency over a wavelength range of 116 nm. The multiplexed OVs can be detected simultaneously without mode cross talk or dis tortion, permitting a polychromatic, large‐capacity, and in situ way for parallel OV processing [136]. Such CLC domains exhibit versatile functionalities, and provide a satisfactory platform for OV‐lightened and other cutting‐edge territo ries, especially, the OAM‐incorporated wavelength‐division multiplexing (WDM), which is expected to dramatically expand the communication capacity [137, 138]. It is a vital step forward to extending the fundamental understanding and fantastic applications of ordered soft matters.

sections.heading: 11.6 Discussion and Conclusion
sections.text:
In addition to visible range, devices with structured LC domains are demon strated in the telecomm band [117] and THz range [139, 140] as well. Thanks to the broadband birefringence (visible, infrared to terahertz [141, 142]), further exploitation of the beam shaping extra visible range is still of great significance [143–145]. As the elements here are all induced by azimuthal angle control of LCs, the absorptive electrodes are avoidable; therefore the optical damage threshold will be drastically increased. In previous experiments, no damage was observed after 600 pulses (0.5 J cm−2, 1064 nm, 10 ns, 1 Hz) received [115, 146]. The value is one order higher than the damage threshold of commercial SLM. This means the LC domain engineering based optical devices are promising for short‐pulse intense‐light applications, such as light bullets and industrial laser processing.
Thanks to the rewritability of the photoalignment agent, the LC orientation can be reconfigured, enabling dynamic beam shaping. Besides photoinduced LC PA domains, TN domain based LC polarization converters, which consist of one uniformly aligned substrate and a counter one with space‐variant alignment, are suitable for arbitrary VB generation [22, 33, 147–149]. For most mentioned ele ments, traditional nematic LCs are used. In fact, the technique is compatible to various LCs, such as cholesteric, smectic [150], ferroelectric, and blue phases [151, 152]. Attempts toward new LC phases and materials is another meaningful topic.
In this chapter, recent researches about optical field control via photoinduced LC domains are briefly introduced. Some powerful photopatterning technolo gies are presented, which are very suitable for implementing accurate and arbi trary azimuthal orientation control of LCs. Not only binary, but also space‐variant LC domains are demonstrated for the generation, manipulation, and detection of novel optical fields with high quality, high efficiency, and with unprecedented flexibility. The objective LC orientations of the discussed photoinduced LC domains can also be obtained via external‐field‐driven [153], self‐assembled LC microdroplets or topological defects [106, 107, 154]. Compared to other tech niques, the photoinduced microstructured LC devices exhibit merits of compact size, easy fabrication, and low cost and are suitable for mass production. The technique drastically enhances the capability of optical beam shaping and steer ing, and settles a fundamental requirement in optics and photonics. Researches on this subject may further drive the need for optical field manipulation, and bring new opportunities in the fields of optical manipulation, high‐resolution imaging, OAM based informatics and quantum optics, and even some unchar tered territories.
