sections.heading: 12.1 Why Azobenzene‐Based Photoactive
sections.text:
Nano‐objects?
One of the most important goals in nanosciences and nanotechnology is greater miniaturization of information systems. This miniaturization of components for the construction of systems and machines used in everyday life is currently car ried out by a top‐down approach. This approach that leads physicists to manipu late or gradually transform material into small pieces by photolithography and related techniques has been carried out so far in a remarkable way. It is becom ing increasingly obvious, however, that the top‐down approach faces drastic limitations for dimensions smaller than 100 nm [1]. Even if this dimension appears very small for most experimenters, it remains very large at the level of atoms and molecules. An alternative and the most promising strategy to be exploited in science and technology to build nanostructures at the nanometer scale is the use of a bottom‐up approach. One of the ways to achieve the realiza tion of the nanometric structure by the bottom‐up technique is the controlled assembly or the self‐assembly of nano‐objects and the modification of these nano‐objects. Nature allows the assembly of molecules in an elegant and effi cient way by multiple noncovalent interactions. The bottom‐up approach is the mainstay in the field of nanoscience and nanotechnology. This is why chemists who are able to manipulate atoms and molecules are in an ideal position for the development of nanosciences and nanotechnology. The realization of surfaces containing micro/nanoscale objects or patterns offers the possibility to develop at a large scale new modifications and new possibilities of properties developed at the nanoscale with micro/nano‐objects. Toward that goal, polymer micro‐ or nano‐objects can be used as building blocks for self‐ or control‐assemblies that find applications in many fields of research including nano‐sensors, nanomede cine, or nano‐energy [2].
Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects Régis Barillé1, Ewelina Ortyl2, and Sonia Zielinska2
1 Université d’Angers/UMR, MOLTECH‐Anjou, CNRS 6200, 2, Bd Lavoisier, 49045, Angers Cedex 01, France 2 Wroclaw University of Technology, Faculty of Chemistry, Department of Polymer Engineering and Technology, ul. Wybrzeze Wyspianskiego 27, 50‐370 Wroclaw, Poland
390 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
In terms of nano‐ or micro‐objects, we refer to micro‐ or nano‐scale objects as nanoparticles (NPs), colloidal spheres, nanorods, nanotubes, microwires, three dimensional posts, microspherical cap array, needles, polymeric strip, micro disks, etc. (Figure 12.1). The lithography technique used electrons (Ebeam), which is not suitable to transform the shape of polymer micro/nano‐objects or to pattern the whole curved polymer surfaces of microspheres, especially the bot tom parts of the surfaces. Further modifications of the surfaces of nanospheres are even less possible. So, conventional lithography techniques such as beam lithography methods or chemical methods, which are usually used to modify planar surfaces, are not very supportive to be used to pattern colloidal surfaces or similar size nano‐objects. Polymeric materials containing azobenzene and its derivatives (azochromophores) have been actively studied and developed in recent years [3]. We show how small objects representing different shapes and dimensions (0D, 1D, 2D) can be individually modified at the nanoscale leading to surface or shape changes.
One primary strategy to achieve the functionalization of a surface is to induce a pattern or to apply “a dimension‐controlled elevation” [4]. For the purpose of preparing functional polymer nano‐objects in terms of modification of surfaces, the light is used as a stimulus for photoinduced surface changes. The whole shape or part shape modification of surfaces is challenging and appears as a top
39112.1 Why Azobenzene‐Based Photoactive Nano‐objects?
research subject due to their potential scientific and technological applications such as drug delivery, chemical and biological sensors, or mechanical actuators. The modified surface could be used as a biological sensor. The detection method is based on the modulation of the diffracted light, which is caused by the interac tion between the light illuminating the biological analytes and the nanopatterned surface used as test platforms. Diffraction gratings on the surface can be pre pared either by nanopatterning an azopolymer‐responsive material into a peri odic array or by using this photopatterned surface as a duplication for different biocompatible materials. When the grating surfaces interact with the target mol ecules, either absorbed onto the surface or internalized within the gratings, the geometrical parameters of the gratings and/or the refractive index contrast is changed, which results in measurable changes in the diffraction efficiency (DE). The measurements rely on the values of the ratio between the diffraction inten sity in the first order with and without the analyte to be tested on the azopolymer grating. This methodology has been successfully used in the sensing of biomol ecules such as human immunoglobulin‐G (H‐IgG) detection [5]. The quantita tive detection of H‐IgG was achieved by detecting the modulation of the DE when the gratings were exposed to antigen solutions. The gratings showed high sensitivity and specificity for H‐IgG detection. Another potential application was the possibility to develop a new glucose‐sensing strategy by using diffraction‐ gratings of a stimuli‐responsive hydrogel bearing phenylboronic acid groups [6]. The gratings showed a fast and highly sensitive response to glucose in buffer solutions measured by the increase of the DE of the incident light. The saturated value was linearly correlated to the glucose concentration of the solutions. Authors claimed that this approach can be further explored to prepare various grating sensors for saccharide recognition and detection.
Azopolymer nano‐objects contribute also to the design and development of low‐cost sensors that can either be embedded or surface coated in engineering structures to continually provide quantitative information. In particular, an example of azobenzene contribution is the measurement of moisture which is an important parameter in many applications such as agriculture, food quality assessment, and materials processing [7]. In these activities it is important to be able to continually access information on the moisture content. One example is the fabrication of an FBG (Fiber Bragg Grating) sensor using a custom‐ synthesized azobenzene‐based polymeric gel.
The information is acquired from the investigation of the strain behavior of the sensor in response to water absorption and desorption. The changes of strain and Bragg peak shift as a function of water ingresses by the gel. The application of the sensor for moisture detection in various materials could also be achieved.
Potential applications of polymeric nano‐objects in the field of drug delivery have come into particular focus recently. The site‐specific drug release at the pathological location is highly important for cancer chemotherapy. If triggered drug release can be achieved in response to specific in vivo conditions in the case of tumors, which could improve drug deliveries and decrease side effects, with local treatments the challenges can be realized. The degradation by gastrointes tinal microflora of different azopolymers was studied by performing permeabil ity experiments on isolated films and solution viscosity measurements before
392 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
and after incubation [8]. The conclusion was that polyurethane was found to be degraded in a culture of intestinal flora with the azo group. To reconfirm this, drug pellets containing water‐soluble drugs were undercoated with (carboxym ethyl)(ethyl)‐cellulose and overcoated with a segmented polyurethane contain ing azo aromatic groups in the main chain in order to examine the drug‐releasing profiles in the culture of intestinal flora. Colon‐targeted drug delivery and cir cumventing drug resistance are extremely important approaches for colon can cer chemotherapy. Azopolymeric micelles for colon‐targeted dimethyl fumarate (DMF) delivery in colon cancer therapy has been designed based on the pharma cological properties of DMF and azo bond in olsalazine chemical structure. DMF exhibited anti‐tumor activity on colon cancer cells. Azopolymeric micelles have been synthesized as a star‐shape amphiphilic polymer with azo bond and the fabricated DMF‐loaded.
Nano‐energy is an important research field with large applications in the reversibly storing solar energy. Azobenzene‐based nanostructures can be used to carry on solutions with molecular photoisomers, known as solar thermal fuels. A review is given by Zhang et al. [9]. The efficient capture, conversion, and storage of solar energy in the form of chemical bonds have potentially great interests. Recently it was shown that solar thermal fuels, with metastable forms by photoisomerization is capable of releasing close to 100% of the stored energy as the heat source under an external stimulus along with the reversion to stable forms [10]. A reversible transformation can transfer energy from and to the environment transforming the light into heat or a thermal storage of sunlight, respectively. This effect can increase the low storage capacity and short‐time storage of sun energy. A nano‐template with covalent attachment of new azobenzene chromophores on graphene is used as solar thermal fuels. The intermolecular hydrogen bond and proximity‐induced interaction, result from high functionalization density and inter‐planar bundling interaction, and lead to an improvement of both the storage capacity and lifetime. This nano scopic template exhibits a high energy density up to 112 W h kg−1 and long‐ term storage with a half‐life of more than one month (33 days). Novel hybrid solar thermal fuels have also been prepared through covalent linkage of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with azobenzenes, as demonstrated both theoretically and experimentally [11].
In the field of nano‐actuators for the purpose of deriving a machine or a robot in order to perform specific functions, azobenzene nano or micro‐objects can be stimulated by light to provide power and information [12]. Light is used as a stimulus to remotely supply energy and transport control information to the azobenzene‐based nano‐actuator or robot and is suitable to mode transform from light energy to mechanical energy (Figure 12.2). It was shown that a single film of a liquid crystal (LC) network containing an azobenzene chromophore can be repeatedly and precisely be bent along any chosen direction by using linearly polarized light. This is a very smart way of controlling the direction and degree of orientations of mesophase formation using the azobenzene photoisomeriza tion. This important photomechanical effect results from a photoselective vol ume contraction and is useful in the development of micro‐ or nano‐actuators for microscale or nanoscale applications, for example, when light can propel
microrobots in medicine or optical catapult [16]. Most of the objects have the shape of strips and the light reversibly actuates the bending but some results have also demonstrated the possibility to induce movements with spiraling objects or rolling objects.
Recently, a micro swimming robot was designed with a head and a flexible long flagellum with the whole length of 2.6 cm moving in a liquid‐filled tube with a low Reynolds number [13]. The swimming mechanism is similar to microorganism with a swing flexible oar‐like flagellum, for example spermato zoons. Additionally, a gripper was added on the robot head to introduce a func tion to grab and release loads. Another study explored further in the design of LC polymer films incorporating azobenzene molecules for the fabrication of
394 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
stimulated light materials [14]. They modified the photophysical properties by incorporating azobenzene derivatives with fast cis‐to‐trans thermal relaxation into LC networks in order to accelerate the relaxation after photoisomerization. They showed that photoactive polymer films with this new molecular design can exhibit continuous, directional, macroscopic mechanical waves under con stant light illumination, with a feedback loop that is driven by self‐shadowing. They provide a mechanism of wave generation to the azopolymer thin film and demonstrate the potential application of the photoactive films in light‐driven locomotions and self‐cleaning surfaces.
The photoinduced motion called photomotility of thin strips of a photore sponsive polymer is made with an azo‐liquid crystalline network (LCN) com posed of 20 wt% of an azobenzene cross‐linker that transforms flat structures into spiraled ones under irradiation [17]. The material is anisotropic and the intrinsic granularity of the actuation mechanisms is done by a trans–cis photoi somerization at the molecular level. Owing to a twisted nematic orientation, the variation in the director profile offsets the alignment of the director to the prin cipal axes of the strips and results in the formation of spiraled shapes. The direc tionality of the photomotility is programmed by the orientation of the anisotropy to the principal axes of the specimens. The motion occurs without modulating or multiplexing the actinic light source. The material does not require any other special conditions other than its own capability to be actuated by directly trans ducing photons into motions.
The first light‐driven plastic mill was demonstrated [15]. It converts the incom ing light directly into a continuous rotation. This device is composed of four blades made of azo‐based LC polymer films able to bend under focused light irradiation and create a force causing the rotation of the mill. The study has shown that by accelerating the rate of the thermal Z to E back‐isomerization, macroscopic deformations with fast strain rate can be obtained. The rapid trans formation of the film under light is the key factor to perform the continuous rotatory motions of the mill.
Other experiments have also observed the photomotility with other type of materials as crystals. The deformation is due to a change in crystal dimensions combined with local melting and can elicit crystal creeping across a surface, such as that observed with azobenzene crystals [18]. The motion is supposed to be driven by crystallization and melting at the front and rear edges of the crystal, respectively, via photochemical conversion between the crystal and liquid phases induced by the isomerization of azobenzenes. These crystals can crawl for around 15 μm in 10 minutes when they are exposed to 365 nm light. Another experiment involves objects floating on a liquid/air interface able to create motions [19]. The experiment is similar to the well‐known one with a camphor boat which is a self‐propelled system in which dissolution of camphor molecules from the solid attached to the boat generates spontaneous motion of the boat on the water surface. In this experiment, a crystal of a simple azobenzene (4‐methoxyazobenzene) moves on a water–air interface. The motion is triggered by irradiation with UV light. The maximum velocity of the boat was 5 cm s−1. The phenomenon is explained by the photoinduced crystal–liquid phase transition and dissolution of the cis‐isomer into water. The motion of the crystals or the
39512.1 Why Azobenzene‐Based Photoactive Nano‐objects?
boat continued even after the UV irradiation is stopped meaning that the motion is not caused by the heating effect.
Nanoparticles composed of a polymer network of azobenzene moieties with LC, capable of reproducible, photoinduced mechanical actuation was demon strated. A 20% height contraction of nanoparticles adsorbed on a substrate was obtained [20].
The advantages of liquid crystalline actuators are their ability to act similarly in dry and wet environment as well as their reversibility of mechanical actuations. The bending direction can be adjusted in two directions. However, the design of biodegradable azobenzene liquid crystalline actuators is not easy and is limited for in vivo applications.
Until now, we have shown that the control of azobenzene nano‐ or micro‐ objects can be moved on a glass surface or on the surface of a liquid. However, an important situation is the possibility to control the direction of nano‐objects in a 3D environment and in particular in a liquid even if this result has been partly shown with the directional control of azobenzene liquid crystal strip with a long flagellum The directionally controlled motion of nanosized polymer particles in an aqueous medium, as observed by fluorescence microscopy imaging was dem onstrated [21]. These NPs are specifically designed to reduce or eliminate the Brownian motion dominating the mechanical behavior in liquid. The nanosized particles consist of azobenzene‐dye‐decorated polymer nanoparticles in the 16 nm‐diameter range. The phenomenon in liquid with these nanoparticles is similar to the mass transport of the azopolymer when the surface is illuminated by interferences of a laser beam. The molecules move to the dark region and an accumulation of matter is observed corresponding to modulation of the photoin duced surface. The light‐induced isomerization of attached molecular motors leads to a motion toward the dark regions of the modulated illumination of the sample. The photomechanical energy conversion with optical control through light‐intensity gradients corresponding to the interferences illuminating the sample is transformed by the isomerizable dyes grafted on the particle surface as molecular propellers. The Brownian motion is reduced by the gradient force and can be used to explore active illuminated areas of the 3D medium efficiently, therebyleading to a directed motion. A power‐tunable velocity, over tens of micrometers toward the dark regions of the optical gradient can be obtained.
Kaneko et al. have demonstrated the phototactic behavior of micrometer‐sized oil droplets in a far‐from‐equilibrium state using photoresponsive surfactants [22]. The controlled motion of droplets was explained by heterogeneity in the interfacial tension at the droplet surface that was induced by the molecular pho toactive conversion of system components with the molecular structure of the photoresponsive surfactant containing an azobenzene. The negative phototaxis was very sensitive and exhibited a directional change within 0.5 second. Such sensitivity can find applications in the spatial arrangement of micrometer‐sized objects and also as transporters.
Another strategy is to create soft materials in which macroscopic motions of molecular assemblies are actuated by small amounts of molecular machines. A Japanese group has also reported reversible and spatially controlled photoin duced macroscopic motions of oleate assemblies containing smaller amounts of
396 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
azobenzene with submillimeter lengths [20]. They prepare mixtures of oleic acid and oleate. The mixture exhibits a highly elastic response to mechanical stress because of the highly ordered stacking structure of oleate molecules in the assembly. They put azobenzene derivatives dissolved in oleate assemblies. Irradiation with 366 nm light induced a slight increase in the size of the vesicles. The vesicles were restored to the original size upon irradiation with 435 nm light. This reversible change in size is associated with the mechanical behavior of the azobenzene derivatives. The inner motion exhibited by the helical assemblies and the presence of an induction period strongly suggest that there are coopera tively propagating mechanisms such as domino effects occurring inside or at the surface of the supramolecular assemblies. It was assumed that the change in effective volume of azobenzene units by photoisomerization causes the propaga tion of expansion or contraction of inter‐molecular geometry among oleate molecules.
The mechanisms associated with azobenzene can be used to probe different phenomena, in particular, with the field of plasmonics. The fabrication of hybrid core‐shell nano‐assemblies involving a nondoped azophotochromic core coated with a dense shell of gold nanoparticles with a diameter of 140 nm was reported for investigating the influence of localized plasmons onto the azo‐core photoi somerization [23]. Such coupling causes a partial quenching of the azophotoi somerization but does not impact the thermal back relaxation.
Azobenzene is a powerful molecule able to photomechanically modify nano‐ devices and nano‐objects. A brief summary of the main description of this mol ecule is then given in the following text.

sections.heading: 12.2 Azopolymer as a Photoactive Material
sections.text:
Azobenzene used in the previously described experiments is an aromatic mole cule where an azo linkage (─N═N─) joins two phenyl rings. The name is often referred as “azobenzenes” or simply “azo”. A large class of compounds based on this molecule can be obtained by substituting the aromatic rings with various substituents, to change its geometry and electron donating/withdrawing charac ter. The most interesting behavior common to all azo‐based material is the effi cient and reversible photoisomerization, which occurs upon absorption of a photon within the absorption band. Azobenzenes have two isomeric states: a thermally stable trans configuration, and a meta‐stable cis form. Under irradia tion, a fraction of the transazobenzenes will be converted to the cis form, which will thermally revert to the more stable trans on a timescale dictated by the chemically engineering molecule substitution pattern.
One of the most interesting properties of the materials is the photoinduced mass transport [24]. When azopolymer films are illuminated by an interference pattern of coherent laser beams in the absorption band, a surface relief grating (SRG) can be formed on the film surface at temperatures well below the glass transition temperature (Tg) of the azopolymer. The photoinduced mass transport is caused by the repeated cis–trans isomerization of azochromophores under polarized light irradiation, which forces the chromophore to continually change
39712.2 Azopolymer as a Photoactive Material
their orientations. The deformation is then caused by the variation of the orien tation order and conformational change of the polymer backbones triggered by the photoisomerization of azobenzenes. The mass transport ends up with stabi lization of the molecular movements in a direction perpendicular to the polari zation. The photoinduced surface patterns or SRG in most of the cases are stable below the Tg and can be erased by heating samples with a temperature above the Tg or with an illumination with a circularly polarized laser beam. The SRG for mation is neither a thermally driven process nor an ablation of the surface and can be attributed to different phenomena depending on the azo materials and consisting in: (i) internal pressure gradients caused by an isomerization‐driven free volume expansion, (ii) a force based on the dipolar interaction of the azochromophores with the optically induced electric field gradient, (iii) a trans lational worm‐like diffusion caused by photoisomerization of the azobenzene chromophores, and (iv) a mean‐field force caused by molecule alignments.
The photoinduced orientation and related properties have been extensively investigated for various polymeric materials, such as azochromophore‐doping polymers (guest–host systems), azo‐functionalized liquid crystal polymers, and azo side chain to azo main chain amorphous azopolymers. Among them, pho toinduced deformations observed in different forms have boosted considerable research interest because of their unique nature and potential applications where small objects can transform their properties when it is remotely modified with a light stimulus. The deformations and modifications can be induced for any kind of objects at the nanoscale.
Grebel‐Koehler et al. [25] introduced azobenzene photochromes into the core of rather spherical dendrimers, resulting in (quasi) isotropic nano‐objects that display significant changes in a hydrodynamic volume upon photoirradiation, with contractions as high as ΔVh = 37% as evaluated by a gel permeation chro matography (GPC).
A recent study has shown that a photomechanical effect occurs in thin films of azopolymers called photofluidization appearing as a new possible mechanism to explain the formation of an SRG on azopolymer films [26]. The photoinduced pattern implies that the light force could drive the azopolymers to move at least within the sub‐micrometer scale. The photo‐softening effect of azopolymers upon light exposure was measured by in situ monitoring force displacement of a tip penetration [27]. The study revealed that azopolymers behaved like elastic solids without light irradiation and became viscoelastic under illumination. This photofluidization is anisotropic and depends on the polarization of the incident light. Another study found a photo‐expansion effect inducing reversible as well as irreversible changes in the mechanical properties of azopolymers. Photo‐ expansion based on repeated cis–trans photoisomerization generates a free volume in the surrounding polymer matrix. After multiple trans–cis photoi somerization, the total volume of azopolymer films is increased. The experiment was confirmed using neutron reflectometry [28]. Two competing photomechan ical effects in azopolymer systems were demonstrated: one that causes expansion of the polymer matrix, and one that induces contraction of the material. In this experiment it was able to measure the expansion and contraction effects since neutron reflectometry probes the physical density rather than the optical
398 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
refractive index. Later, a photoisomerization induced a softening of the polymer matrix followed by a polymer chain migration which well agrees with a study of nanoindentation with an AFM used for the acquisition of both surface time‐ dependent and time‐independent results. Indeed, their photoinduced surface patterning provides evidence of a plastic (or viscoplastic) photosoftening far beyond what thermal effects could be responsible for. The experiments on PMMA‐DR1 films [29] confirmed that the decrease of the irreversible viscosity by 1 order of magnitude is observed under illumination indicating that light strongly reinforces the viscoplastic behavior of the film. This was confirmed by indentation measurements. Additionally, the significant reduction of the com posite hardness under illumination indicates a significant decrease in the hard ness and/or plastic threshold (yield stress) of the material.
Different models have been tested to account for the molecular motion phe nomena for amorphous polymers and liquid‐crystalline side‐chain polymers to explain the long‐term stability of trans–cis isomerization. We can refer to mod els to study SRG formation in azopolymer films based on the interaction between molecular dipoles [30]: the semi‐implicit moving‐particle model [31], random‐ walk model [32], a stochastic model [33], and a model based on Fick’s law of dif fusion as a phenomenological description of the molecular motion [34]. This last model is used to explain the self‐organization of photoinduced azopolymer sur faces when the light illuminates the samples. This model is based on Fick’s law of diffusion that scales with light intensity. Further, light is trapped in the sample and couples into counter propagating guided modes, which interact with the azopolymer. Using this approach, it is possible to explain the self‐patterning of the azopolymer film illuminated with a single beam and the surface profile and intensity evolution of azopolymer thin films during exposition to a single laser beam. The model is based on both the coupled mode theory and a phenomeno logical description of the molecular motion.
A unified modeling framework for the light actuation on azo‐based materials was explained allowing for the understanding of surface deformation and bulk deformation of polymer films that are controlled by different laser beam polari zations: linear or circularly polarized light or a vortex shape of the laser beam [35]. It is shown that dipole forces strongly respond to polarized light in contrast to higher order quadrupole forces that are often used to describe SRG deforma tion through a field gradient constitutive law. Dipole forces strongly influence the evolution of trans and cis azobenzene states within monodomain and poly domain polymer networks. The coupling between the polymer network and azobenzene leads to significantly different photostrictive deformations.

sections.heading: 12.3 Fabrication of Photoactive Nano‐objects
12.3.1 Fabrication of Photoactive Nanospheres
sections.text:
Colloidal spheres can be prepared by methods such as controlled precipitation, emulsion polymerization, and aggregation of amphiphilic block copolymers. Amphiphilic polymers are also well known for their ability to form other types of
39912.3 Fabrication of Photoactive Nano‐objects
structures through self‐assembly processes. The incorporation of azopolymers into colloidal spheres, allows demonstrating that the colloidal spheres can show the photoinduced anisotropy function of the polymers and other interesting properties related with colloids.
Different techniques are used to fabricate azopolymer nanospheres. The first experimental demonstration of the photoinduced deformation of azopolymer nanospheres was done by Wang and coworkers [36]. The colloidal spheres were prepared by a method similar to those used to obtain micelles and other self‐ assembled aggregates of amphiphilic polymers. The method of preparation of the colloid nanospheres is based on the technique of Zhang and Eisenberg [37] and consists in first dissolving the azopolymer in a good solvent for the chosen polymer, and then adding a suitable amount of milli‐q water dropwise into the solvent solution. When the water content reached a critical value, uniform col loidal spheres were obtained. The polymeric chains started to aggregate and form colloidal spheres. When the water content reached 40–50% (vol%), the polymeric chains collapsed gradually as the water content increased further. When micellization occurs, the nanospheres are dropped on a glass substrate. Density of the nanospheres on the surface can vary depending on the concen tration in the solution. A scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of the nanospheres dispersed on the surface of a microscope glass slide is presented in Figure 12.3A. The external diameter measurement by a statistical analysis of the spheres can vary from nm to micron meter. With this method, different azo polymer spheres have been prepared and tested under laser illumination. An amphiphilic random copolymer functionalized with branched azo side chains has been prepared [41]. The microphase transition and structure formation are closely related with the water content in the systems. Other materials have been prepared such as four‐arm‐shaped amphiphilic azobenzene compound [42] epoxy‐based azopolymers [43], methacrylate‐based azohomopolymers [44], azopolyurethanes bearing push–pull type azochromophores [45], an amphiphi lic random azocopolymer (PEAPE), and a polydispersed azohomopolymer (BP‐ AZ‐CA), which were functionalized with azobenzene type and pseudo‐stilbene‐ type chromophores, respectively [46], or amphiphilic azobenzene‐containing random copolymer, poly(2‐[4‐(phenylazo)phenoxy]ethyl acrylate‐co‐acrylic acid) (PPAPE) [47]. Another study [48] shows that the electron‐withdrawing groups on the azochromophores have a significant influence on the photoin duced deformation behavior of the azopolymer colloids mainly through their modulation to the absorption band position. The colloid deformation can be more efficiently induced by irradiation with the laser beams at the intermediate wavelengths between the maximum and the absorption band tails of the azochromophores. Furthermore, the electron‐withdrawing groups can also affect the photoinduced deformation behavior through their influence on the hydrophilicity of the polymers. Another technique that produced azopolymeric microspheres used a glass capillary microfluidic device in which the outer phase can hydrodynamically focus on the inner phase, so as to result in droplet breakup in a dripping mode and subsequent generation of highly monodis persed oil‐in‐water single emulsions [49]. They used two differently sized injec tion orifices (20 and 100 μm in diameter) in microfluidic devices with a collection
40112.3 Fabrication of Photoactive Nano‐objects
orifice 200 μm in diameter, wherein the inner flow rate (i.e. of the oil phase) was fixed at 300 μl h−1, and the outer flow rate (i.e. of the water phase) was varied. A typical azopolymer poly(disperse red 1 methacrylate) (pDR1) was selected for study. Two compatible oil‐phase solvents of toluene and chloroform were chosen for comparison with each other. After droplets of pDR1 emulsion were collected, the oil phase was allowed to evaporate at room temperature. They obtained highly uniform and smooth pDR1 microspheres considering the various microfluidic conditions (polymeric concentration within droplets, flow rate, and fluid).
A novel method based on noncovalent bond self‐assembly technology pro vided hollow nanospheres with azo functional groups [49] (Figure  12.3C). Azocomplex nanospheres with a diameter of 300–1000 nm were obtained by the H‐bond (noncovalently) self‐assembly of poly(acrylonitrile‐stat‐4‐vinylpyridine) (PANstat‐P4VP) and azobenzene m‐methyl red (MMR) in aqueous solvents. Polymeric hollow nanospheres with azobenzene chromospheres were formed in the THF–H2O mixed solvent with 65 vol% H2O in mass. Azocomplex nano spheres with a diameter of 300–1000 nm were obtained. These hollow nano spheres exhibit potential as photoinduced deformation due to the azobenzene group.
The fabrication of complex architectures of the nano‐ or microspheres is also interesting and in particular micro‐ or nanoparticles possessing noncentrosym metric architectures like Janus particles (JPs) (Figure 12.4a). The name originates from ‘Janus,’ the Greek god with two faces.
The JPs consist of two distinct parts whose volume ratio is about 1 : 1, which is very close to the original feed ratio. Wang and coworkers have shown that JPs with the red part is the PAZO–ADMA phase and the transparent part is  the PMMA phase [39]. Owing to high incompatibility between the two polymers, the Janus nanoparticles with symmetric compartment volumes are obtained, meaning that two volumes are self‐assembled together forming two faces.
It is also necessary to reduce the interfacial tension between the dispersed droplets and dispersion medium with a suitable surfactant for forming snow man‐like particles. Azobenzene‐containing layer‐by‐layer films and microcap sules have been prepared with a range of cationic and construction of photosensitive devices. This review summarizes the syntheses of azobenze [51].
Azopolymer microspherical cap arrays have been fabricated through soft‐ lithographic contact printing using colloidal arrays as masters and a duplicated PDMS elastomer as stamps [52]. The size of the microspherical caps can be fea sibly altered by adjusting the size of polystyrene (PS) colloids and the “ink” con centration. After irradiation of the linearly polarized laser single beam, the microspherical caps can be elongated along the polarization direction.
Most of the experiments presented until now show that the nanoparticles are well dispersed on a surface of glass substrate. However, the attractive capillary force can cause the colloidal spheres to organize into hexagonally close‐packed 2D arrays or monolayers. One method is frequently used: the vertical deposition method in the goal to realize the capillary‐force‐driven self‐assembly. In the ver tical deposition method, a substrate, usually glass, is immersed vertically in
a  suspension containing colloidal spheres, which in our case, are azopolymer nanospheres [53]. By evaporation of the dispersion medium or lifting of the sub strate out of the suspension at constant speed, the surface of the liquid moves down and the colloids are deposited onto the substrate during the decline of the surface. The average size of the spheres was estimated to be 180 nm. Dynamic light scattering (DLS) has shown monomodal distribution for the sizes of the col loidal spheres.
40312.3 Fabrication of Photoactive Nano‐objects
These assemblies of colloids on a surface can be used to design porous sur faces. The assembly of colloids can be used as a reverse surface [47]. Polymeric porous structures are very important for possible applications in selective trans portation, as biosensors and as photonic opal materials. It was demonstrated that the ordered mesoporous films can be obtained by in situ sphere‐pore inver sion of 2D arrays of the azopolymer spheres. The mesoporous films were obtained by placing the 2D colloidal sphere arrays in an enclosed chamber for solvent annealing for 6–9 hours. Before solvent annealing, the colloidal surfaces are composed of hexagonally close‐packed spheres. After the solvent treatment, the spheres are transformed to the mesoporous structure directly, which main tains the character of a hexagonal close‐packed array. The average pore diameter is 150 nm.

sections.heading: 12.3.2 Fabrication of Nanotubes and Nanowires
sections.text:
Azopolymers can also be used to adjust the shape and size of polymeric nano/ microwires (Figure 12.3B). However, it is difficult to fabricate nano/microwires through a feasible approach. It was demonstrated that microwires with a uni form sub‐micrometer‐scale transverse dimension and macroscopic longitudi nal dimension, made of an epoxy‐based azopolymer can be fabricated through a soft lithographic approach [38]. The microwires can be processed by a laser beam in order to alter the transverse dimension of the microwires or inscribe regular surface relief structures on the microwires. First, elastomeric stamps made with PDMS (poly(dimethylsiloxane)) were prepared by replica molding. Then the azopolymer solution was deposited on the surface and the excessive liquid on the surfaces was removed.
Sheng et al. report the hierarchical self‐assembly of a cationic gemini amphi phile azobenzene compound in a composition gradient solution generated using solvent evaporation [54]. As the gradient solution is formed, the azobenzene compound forms nanorods in the lower region of the solution. Depending on solvent composition, these nanorods can be developed into nanofibers, which can then intertwine to form double helices and other types of nanohelices in the upper region of the solution. Macroscopic wire bundles can be formed by the fusion of nanohelices. These bundles exhibit photoresponsive properties that affect the deformation.
Tubular azopolymer nanostructures with controlled diameters were prepared by wetting porous anodic alumina membrane templates consisting in an array of parallel and straight channels [40] (Figure 12.3D). The alumina membrane filters have a typical diameter of 13 mm and thickness of 60 μm. The individual cylin drical pores can be viewed as a beaker in which a piece of the desired material can be synthesized. The pores in the membrane have monodispersed diameters of 200 nm. A nanocylinder of azopolymer can be obtained from each pore. The nanotubules were prepared by filtration of a solution of the azopolymer into the pores of the template membrane. About 1 ml of the azopolymer solution was dropped into a 1 cm2 area on the top surface of the template membrane. The membrane was left at ambient conditions until the solution was infiltrated through the membrane. It was then placed in an oven for solvent evaporation
404 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
during one hour at 60 °C temperature. Nanotubules were freed by dissolving the membrane by soaking in 3 M aqueous NaOH for 10 minutes. The difficult part was to eliminate the NaOH from forming crystals on the surface. Toward achiev ing this, azopolymer nanotubes were extracted from the resulting mixture by three 30‐second‐cycles of centrifugation at 8000 rpm, followed by two more cycles in distilled water. Nanotubules were then dispersed into water by sonica tion. The water suspension of dispersed nanotubules was then dropped on the surface of clean microscope glass slides and dried in an oven for water evapora tion (Figure 12.3D).

sections.heading: 12.3.3 Fabrications of Other Different Nano‐ and Micro‐objects
sections.text:
Rigid‐rod polymers incorporating azobenzene photoswitches in a poly(para‐ phenylene) (PPP) backbone were fabricated [55]. The rod‐like polymers have shown reversible and efficient shrinkage that have been demonstrated and quantified by static and dynamic light‐scattering measurements. The deforma tion is accompanied by an unprecedented decrease in hydrodynamic volume. Furthermore, the design of multi‐azobenzene rods with reduced solubility have led to the formation of spherical aggregates in organic solvents, which could reversibly be disrupted by alternating irradiation with UV and visible light.
Exotic nano‐objects can also be designed by illumination of a pre‐formed sur face [50]. Doughnut‐shaped nanostructures at the tailored surface of an azopoly mer film have been fabricated by an incoherent unpolarized light illumination (Figure  12.4b). The method chosen is a solvent‐droplet‐induced dewetting of thin azopolymer films on glass substrates. The contact of a thin polymer film to a solvent droplet reduces the glass transition temperature to below the room temperature as the solvent molecules penetrate into the film matrix. The stable polymer thin film is destabilized by the introduction of polar interactions and nano‐holes are created. Then an incoherent light is used for growing the nano structures and simultaneously directing the final shape of a nanostructure by the initial seed of tiny nanoscale holes rather than for optically erasing. The sample was illuminated for 30 minutes. The volume of the doughnut has shown to grow to reach a mean value of 0.065 μm3.

sections.heading: 12.4 Results
sections.text:
SRG or photo‐nanostructuration can be induced on the azopolymer surface of any nano‐object as microspheres (Figure 12.5A), wires (Figure 12.5C), and thin films. The surface of the microspheres can be photopatterned with illumination by interferences of a laser beam [56] (Figure 12.5D). The observation showed a grating on the surface of the microspheres and a contraction of the pores. It was shown that azopolymer nanotubes with a diameter of 100 nm present different surface deformations as a function of the laser beam polarization [40].
After irradiation of an individual nanotube with a transverse electric field exci tation, the width is observed to shrink. Using an AFM profiling, the shrinkage is estimated to be about 60% of the initial width. With a p‐polarization the same
experiment was repeated. At the beginning of the process, the surface profile of the measured nanotube in the longitudinal direction is flat. After 30 minutes irradiation, the nanotube presents a quasi periodically structured surface.
The force exerted on azopolymer nanospheres to induce a deformation was calculated using the Hertz theory, which considers the contact deformation of elastic spheres under normal loads in the absence of adhesion and friction. A force of 1 μN was detected. It is an order of magnitude larger than typical forces needed for the deformation of hollow polyelectrolyte microcapsules using an atomic force microscope [58]. Moreover, the stress that is exerted on a polymer during SRG formation given by Toshchevikov et al. [59] was calculated. It yields a force of FZ ~ 2 μN onto the nanospheres, readings that are rather close to the estimation with the Hertz theory.
Ortyl et  al. demonstrated that an assembly of colloidal azopolymer nano spheres could accelerate the process of SRG formation [57] (Figure 12.5B). One of the reasons is that the surface is already pre‐formed and the process of photo structuration starts on small nano‐objects. Only anisotropic photofluidization by polarized light deforms the nanospheres along the polarization direction. The phenomenon is amplified by the self‐lensing effect of the azopolymer nano spheres absorbing the laser wavelength. The single beam SRG formation is accel erated by the initial natural roughness of the colloidal assembly, suppressing the long incubation time usually observed in the spontaneous grating organiza tion. The subduction mechanism of nano‐spheres pushing each other along the
406 12 Azobenzene Polymers as Photoactive Materials for Shape Changes of Micro/Nano‐objects
polarization direction enhances the grating modulation amplitude. Altogether, exceptionally large and fast SRG formation gets self‐organized using a single beam irradiation in the colloidal nanosphere assembly. This method is a generic method and can be used for any material already tested during SRG formation on thin films. The preformed pattern on the surface of the azopolymer can also be used to photoaccelerate the structures of what was called nanodoughnuts
407 References
(Figure 12.6A). The light amplifies the structures and can modify the geometry with a nearfield setup.
Ambrosio and coworkers have used light‐driven mass migration in order to reconfigure a pre‐patterned tridimensional superficial texture consisting in an array of azopolymer micropillars so as to induce a controlled directional wetting anisotropy [60] (Figure 12.6B). The wetting state of a water droplet onto the pris tine cylindrical pillar array is recognized as a result of the pinning effect of the triple‐phase contact line (TCL) at the sharp pillar edges. The experiment there fore shows the potential of using light parameters with the aim to design light‐ driven two‐dimensional wetting pathways onto the surface of a single pre‐patterned azopolymer pillar array. The last experiment shows that the directional aniso tropic wetting is transformed into a unique direction of the liquid spreading by a superficial hydrophilization treatment of the surface.

sections.heading: 12.5 Summary and Outlook
sections.text: We have demonstrated the huge capabilities of nano‐objects made with azo benzene or azopolymers. In particular, we have shown that the mechanism of the photo‐orientation of azo molecules can induce mechanical actions. These mechanical actions can be further used for directional movements of micro/ nanosystems or display significant changes in volume [61]. We have reviewed the different nano/micro‐ objects obtained up to now including azobenzene in their designs. In terms of nano‐ or micro‐objects we have presented the fabrica tion and use of micro‐ or nanoscale objects as nanoparticles, colloidal spheres, nanoparticles, nanorods, nanotubes, nano/microwires, three dimensional posts, microspherical cap arrays, needles, polymeric strips, micro disks, etc. All these nano/micro azobenzene based objects can find applications in different media. Large possibilities of applications can be developed and can, in particular, open the way for future applications concerning the future of nanotechnology in sen sors, nano‐medicine or nano‐robotics. We can imagine, for example the recon figuration of subdevices with light like metamaterials to match different optical properties such as chirality or can imagine nanorods as nano reconfigurable barcodes. The inclusion of emitting compounds in azopolymer nanotubes can be tuned by opto‐mechanically changing the volume of the nanotube.
