sections.heading: 13.1 Introduction
sections.text:
The process of encapsulation involves the incorporation of active ingredients into a relatively small capsule or particle. Such systems are employed for various reasons such as enhancing the stability of specific active ingredients by delaying their degradation, protecting species from substances that could prematurely react with them, improving the processability of materials by altering their phys icochemical properties, or even for safe handling of toxic components [1, 2]. Encapsulation technologies are also available for the production of systems incorporating controlled‐release properties. In general, controlled release refers to the presentation of compounds in response to stimuli at a desired time, and at a specific rate (delayed, sustained, or even pulsed release). A timely and targeted release improves the effectiveness of the actives, ensures optimal dosage, and broadens the application range of ingredients. In many occasions, localized release allows reduction of the total amount of active ingredient that must be delivered to achieve the desired effect. Controlled release is pursued in a number of areas including agriculture, food sciences, and pharmaceuticals.
Externally triggerable encapsulants have been engineered to address these challenges and a wide palette of inputs can be used as triggering events including changes in pH, temperature, and magnetic fields, and the presence of specific chemical species. In this regard, light is an efficient and clean stimulus. Light‐ controlled substance release, as compared to other mechanisms, is attractive in many ways. It is a versatile stimulus, which can act in a noninvasive fashion and provides excellent spatiotemporal control by means of modulation of properties such as wavelength, intensity, and polarization. Light also shows a high degree of orthogonality toward a great deal of chemical species and functionalities [3]. Indeed, light has gained significant interest as a trigger in drug encapsulation and delivery on account of its clinical relevance (light has a number of therapeutic uses and it is currently used in photodynamic therapy [4]).
Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies Jesús del Barrio1, Milagros Piñol2, and Luis Oriol2
1 Instituto de Nanociencia de Aragón, Campus Río Ebro. Edificio I+D. C/ Mariano Esquillor, 50018 Zaragoza, Spain 2 Departamento de Química Orgánica, Facultad de Ciencias, Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Aragón, Universidad de Zaragoza‐CSIC, C/Pedro Cerbuna 12, 50009, Zaragoza, Spain
As illustrated in Figure 13.1, several parameters need to be considered when formulating encapsulated products, which also applies to light‐controlled sys tems. The physicochemical characteristics of the encapsulated species and its functionality in the final product, the appropriateness of the encapsulating pro cess with respect to the stability of the actives, the physicochemical properties (size, shape, surface chemistry, etc.) and storage conditions of the final product, the release‐trigger mechanism and scalability, and cost constrains are all impor tant aspects of encapsulating systems. A further step in the design flow (Figure 13.1) involves the comparison and contrast of design elements and appli cation specification. In such a process, a set of characteristics, like the type of encapsulant material, the concentration of the active ingredient, and the type of process to produce the formulated product, need to be selected for the preferred system. A wide range of encapsulation processes exist such as atomization, cocrystallization, emulsification (liposomes, interfacial polymerization, etc.), and inclusion complexation, and each of them has its own set of limitations and advantages and disadvantages. On the materials side, it is possible to differenti ate between inorganic and organic materials including surfactants, polymers, oligomeric, and macrocyclic species. In many instances, the applicability of a specific encapsulation method or cargo‐release mechanism is constrained to a very limited set of materials, which evidences the complex interdependencies between processes and materials.
There exist excellent recent reviews on photocontrolled delivery systems [5– 8]. Considering the framework of this book, we highlight several polymer‐based encapsulating systems exhibiting light‐controlled release capabilities. In this chapter, rather than being comprehensive, we focus on those aspects and attrib utes of photoresponsive polymer materials that make them particularly attrac tive for the delivery and controlled release of active ingredients, mainly pharmacological formulations. Our goal is to provide a general sense of current research and to assist the reader in the identification of trends and challenges facing the development of practical photoresponsive polymer‐based delivery
41513.2 Photoresponsive Groups
systems. We begin this chapter by discussing some generalities of the design of light‐responsive polymeric encapsulants (Section  13.2). Looking toward the application of light switches and photoinduced reaction in polymeric encapsu lants, the families of polymer micelles and vesicles (based on amphiphilic block copolymers, BCs), capsules, microgels, nanogels, nanoparticles (NPs), and uni molecular systems will each be discussed in turn (Sections 13.3.1–13.3.6).

sections.heading: 13.2 Photoresponsive Groups
sections.text:
In the framework of this chapter, the realization of light‐controlled substance release requires the polymeric materials, e.g. amphiphilic BCs, which are typi cally capable of undergoing micellization in aqueous media, that they include at some point in their macromolecular architecture at least one photoresponsive chromophore [9–11]. Changes or reorganizations of the chromophore structure can be selectively induced with light (UV, vis, NIR), which result in temporally and spatially controlled substance delivery. This process depends, more com monly, on the light wavelength, intensity, and irradiation time. In general, three major photoinduced changes may be induced in polymeric nanocarriers. These include (i) a local polarity change (typically associated with a change of the over all hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance of the encapsulant [see Figure 13.2]), (ii) a photoinduced degradation of the polymeric structure via selective cleavage of photolabile bonds, and (iii) the photocrosslinking of specific polymeric compo nents (see Figure 13.2). Furthermore, these photoreactions can be reversible or irreversible [12, 13].
The reversible trans–cis–trans photoisomerization of azobenzenes has been widely used for the preparation of photoresponsive materials due to the high synthetic versatility and stability of these compounds. As the cis isomer has a bent geometry and a higher polarity than the trans isomer, photoisomerization is accompanied by local polarity changes in the system which, without necessarily achieving a complete distortion the self‐assembly, increases the level of molecu lar mobility and induces cargo‐release. UV light is used more commonly although the photoisomerization of azobenzenes with visible light has also been described [14–16]. The photoinduced reversible ring opening/closure of spiropyrans can also alter the hydrophilic/hydrophobic balance of a given system, sometimes to a larger extent, as the open merocyanine form is zwitterionic in nature. Irreversible photoreactions such as the Wolff rearrangement of diazonaphtoquinone (DNQ) or the photocleavage of o‐nitrobenzyl, perylenylmethyl or coumarinyl esters can also induce substantial local polarity changes. Furthermore, chromophores as DNQ or coumarins can also be efficiently stimulated via two‐photon processes using NIR light (650–900 nm), which is interesting for systems of biomedical rel evance, as NIR light exhibits deeper tissue penetration (up to 10 cm in some cases) than UV light (c. 1 cm).
The light‐induced degradation of a polymer system typically relies on photo cleavable chromophores, which can specifically serve as a bond connecting two blocks of different nature (as in BCs) or randomly distributed along a polymer backbone. O‐nitrobenzyl derivatives are usually selected for this purpose due to
their high synthetic versatility. Finally, some photocrosslinkable moieties as cou marins or cinnamates can be used to induce changes on the macromolecular self‐assembly and stability that occur due to cross‐linking‐induced shrinkage. Coumarins are particularly useful for this purpose as they undergo reversible photocrosslinking using UV light. Other chromophores such as dithienylethenes have been evaluated in the search for photoactive macromolecular materials, including applications as nanocarriers [17]. When looking toward biomedical
41713.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release
applications, other aspects must be considered in addition to the light‐response of the chromophore such as the cytotoxicity of the polymer, which is particularly relevant in the case of photolabile and degradative moieties. Indeed, the genera tion of nitroxobenzaldehyde derivatives may induce cell death as it has been reported for o‐nitrobenzyl‐containing polymer micelles exhibiting phototrig gered cytotoxicity [18].
13.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release

sections.heading: 13.3.1 Polymer Self‐Assemblies from Linear Amphiphilic BCs
sections.text:
One of the most common materials for the production of polymeric encapsu lants are amphiphilic BCs, which are defined as polymers consisting of at least two immiscible blocks (frequently, one hydrophobic and one hydrophilic). When a BC is dispersed in a liquid that is a “good” solvent for one of the blocks and, at the same time, a precipitant for the other, the BC associates in a reversible fash ion forming self‐assemblies (micelles and vesicles) of various shapes and dimen sions, which to some extent are similar to those of low molecular weight surfactants. BC micelles consist of a collapsed core of the insoluble block and a corona of the soluble block. When water is used as a solvent, and depending on the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance of the BC, spherical, ovoid, lamellar, worm‐like and rod‐like micelles have been found to form spontaneously. In such species, encapsulation of hydrophobic cargo at the micellar core can be readily achieved. Polymer vesicles are particularly relevant self‐assemblies for encap sulation applications. They are composed of a bilayer of amphiphilic species enclosing an aqueous compartment. Hydrophilic actives can obviously be trapped inside the interior lumen, but there also exists the possibility of encap sulating hydrophobic cargo substances at the vesicle wall (a combination of both modes of encapsulation is also possible). In addition to the hydrophobic/hydro philic ratio, there are other parameters that play a role in determining the self‐ assembly morphology and structure including the establishment of secondary interactions (hydrogen bonding, π–π stacking, etc.) or the crystallization of the core‐forming block. Amphiphilic BCs exhibit substantially higher molecular weight as compared to lipids, thus leading to a less dynamic, more robust and mechanically tougher membrane than surfactant‐forming micelles. In addition, BCs can be easily functionalized at either the polymer ends or side chains pro viding a useful approach to the modulation of specific properties such as mem brane permeability or the incorporation of stimuli‐responsive features, including photoresponsive moieties. Regarding the preparation of polymer self‐assem blies, a variety of different methods have been explored. Two of these are prefer entially used and are the film rehydration and the solvent switch methods. In the latter, the BC is initially dissolved in an organic solvent that is “good” solvent for both the hydrophilic and hydrophobic blocks, followed by the addition of an additional solvent (typically water), which selectively induces the collapse or nanoprecipitation of the solvophobic polymer block. Several parameters such as the
418 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
type of organic solvent, solvent to water mixture ratio, and mixing rate may affect specific characteristics of the final system including the morphology and permeability of the hydrophobic domains (core of a spherical polymer micelle; and wall, in the case of a polymer vesicle). A final purification step is generally performed where the residual organic solvent is removed by dialysis or is allowed to evaporate. The use of organic solvents is undesirable for in vivo applications or for the encapsulation of specific bioactive compounds. The film rehydration is, to a certain extent, a method which minimizes the use of organic solvents. Here, a thin polymer film is rehydrated in aqueous media in bulk or by means of electrical methods (electroformation). Again, the method of choice will depend upon factors including size as well as the nature of the polymer and the active ingredient. Alternatively, micellization can also be achieved by less conventional methods including pH and temperature switches, and through the complexation of polyelectrolytes. The use of microfluidic, nanoimprinting and centrifugation technologies has also been described.
On amphiphilic BC self‐assemblies, the response to light depends on the type of transformation induced by light and the location of the photosensitive unit into the BC. The chromophore is usually located at the blocks junction or as a pendant moiety of one of the blocks, usually the hydrophobic one, either as a repeating unit or as a side‐chain. There is a wide variety amphiphilic BC designs and all combinations of hydrophilic and hydrophobic monomers are possible. The number of hydrophobic blocks studied to construct amphiphilic BCs is rather large; nevertheless, considering potential in vivo applications, degradabil ity is a critical aspect [19]. Poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) is most commonly used for the hydrophilic segment as, in addition to being biocompatible, it is resist ant to immunological recognition, thereby improving circulation times. Alternative  hydrophilic and responsive polymers, such as thermoresponsive poly(oligo(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate) or poly(N‐isopropy lacrylamide), may also be considered for the design of nanocarriers operating under multiple combined stimuli. Systems that are able to respond to more than one stimulus provide the opportunity to selectively regulate the release of various cargoes independently or induce a burst release by combining the effect of several of them, which greatly enhances the versatility of the systems in practi cal applications [20]. Indeed, temperature is a convenient stimulus that can trig ger a reversible hydrophobic‐to‐hydrophilic transition and has been frequently combined with light stimulation.
One approach consists of the utilization of a photocleavable unit to cova lently  link the hydrophobic and hydrophilic segments of an amphiphilic BC (Figure 13.3). An irreversible photolysis at the linker breaks up the copolymer into their individual constituent blocks, which is accompanied by the destabiliza tion of the self‐assemblies and cargo‐release. The vast majority of the reported examples have used o‐nitrobenzyl‐ based linkers. Under UV or two‐photon NIR absorption, the o‐nitrobenzyl moiety cleaves at the benzylic site and disrupts the polymer micelles or vesicles. The performance of amphiphilic poly(acrylic acid)‐ b‐poly(methyl caprolactone) diblock copolymer (1 in Figure  13.3) vesicles as phototriggerable nanocarriers was tested using hydrophilic fluorescent probes and proteins [21]. Vesicles disintegrated into small micelles upon exposure to
light (λ = 365 nm) concomitantly to cargo‐release. The authors also demonstrated a light intensity dependent release, which enabled some level of control over the release process. In an attempt to achieve multi‐stimuli‐responsiveness, ABC‐ type triblock copolymer combining a o‐nitrobenzyl unit with a disulfide bond, one at each block junction, were described to generate micelles in aqueous media where a combination of reducing agent and UV light induced significant disrup tion of the micelles [22]. With this system, the release profile of Nile Red was tuned depending on the sequences in which the stimuli were applied. An analo gous approach was followed for the design of light‐responsive vesicles based on a 2‐nitrophenylalanine linker connecting a block of polycaprolactone with a block of PEG. After analyzing the encapsulation and release properties of the vesicles in aqueous media using biocytin, it was suggested that copolymer pho todissociation induced a gradual collapse of the vesicle membrane which resulted in the precipitation of polycaprolactone aggregates [23].
Photoremoval of o‐nitrobenzyl functionalities was used to activate self‐ immolative processes due to end‐to‐end backbone depolymerization [24, 25]. The principle was applied to ABA‐type amphipilic triblock copolymers of PEG‐b‐poly(ethyl glyoxalate)‐b‐PEG with o‐nitrobenzyl units at the junction blocks. Nile Red and doxorrubicin (DOX) were used to demonstrate the encapsulation and release properties associated with the light‐triggered disintegration of the micellar self‐
420 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
assemblies [26, 27]. The same principle applies to the concept of self‐immolative vesicles using amphiphilic diblock copolymers having a hydrophobic block whose cascade depolymerization is triggered in this case by a pyrenyl or an o‐nitrophe nyl photocleavable terminal group [28].
A few recent examples have demonstrated the utility of boron‐containing pho tolabile linkers. Patil et al. have reported the synthesis of a PEG‐b‐polystyrene amphiphilic BC with a photolabile boron dipyrromethene linker (2 in Figure 13.3), which exhibits a clear absorption band in the visible range. Disassembly of the micellar self‐assemblies was monitored by encapsulation of Nile Red, and its triggered‐release capabilities under light (λ = 470 nm) irradiation was demon strated [29]. A boronate ester linker, from a boronic acid and nitrocatechol end‐ functional polymers (3 in Figure  13.3), was used by Coumes et  al. to impart multiresponsive (pH, UV light, and sensitivity toward carbohydrate molecules) properties to the BC self‐assemblies. The potential of the self‐assemblies as drug delivery nanocarriers was evaluated using Nile Red [30].
Insertion of photocleavable groups along the main chain of the hydrophobic block induces the breakdown of the hydrophobic backbone into smaller frag ments allowing for the release of cargo, which has been proposed as a more effi cient strategy to achieve a burst‐release effect [31]. Han et al. have reported the synthesis and self‐assembling properties of a series of ABA amphiphilic triblock copolymers, where the B block contained multiple photolabile o‐nitrobenzyl repeating units along the polymer backbone (4 in Figure  13.4). The triblock copolymers had the capability to undergo self‐assembly in aqueous media yield ing core–shell micelles, which could be degraded upon exposure to UV light. The encapsulating capabilities of the systems where initially evaluated with hydrophobic fluorescent probes [32, 33]. Han and coworkers also prepared DOX‐loaded micelles that showed enhanced anticancer activity against tumor cells after UV illumination [34]. In addition, use of light was shown to be a more effective method to induce release than pH. Micelles disruption triggered by main‐chain photodegradation of a polyurethane hydrophobic block has also been reported using DOX to demonstrate the encapsulation and efficient release of hydrophobic payloads [35]. Pasparakis et  al. have reported the synthesis of
42113.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release
polyacetals and polyketals, which can undergo main‐chain photocleavage with very low energy inputs. These systems were tuned to make them sensitive to vis ible light through the derivatization with 2‐nitroresorcinol moieties, which are in close proximity to the acetal moieties (5 in Figure 13.4) [36]. BC micelles based in these polyacetals were capable of encapsulating and releasing camptothecin and hematoporphyrin via two‐photon absorption photolysis (λ = 532 nm) in a process that was accelerated at low pH.
Another general approach consists of the attachment of light‐sensitive chromo phores to the backbone of a polymer chain or segment of a BC.
The polarity of these side‐chain moieties can be switched from hydrophobic to hydrophilic by using light irradiation. Lightinduced changes of the pendant chromophores can switch the polarity of the segment from hydrophobic to hydrophilic (or vice versa), inducing the destabilization of the self‐assembly and the release of any encapsulated active. This strategy has been vastly explored because it is possible to easily combine several units at the hydrophobic block creating multiresponsive polymeric carriers where release can be regulated by applying either one or a combination of two or more stimuli. These polymers can be synthesized via direct polymerization of functional monomers or by post‐ polymerization functionalization of macromolecular precursors. The second approach requires a polymeric skeleton with chemical groups that are suitable for efficient functionalization with several chromophores. This offers versatility versus the polymerization of functional monomers. Several of these systems consist of a PEG‐b‐poly(meth)acrylate BC where the hydrophobic poly(meth) acrylate carries a number of light‐responsive moieties (Figure 13.5). Upon expo sure to light, the pendant photocleavable groups, including pyrenyl [37], o‐ nitrobenzyl [38], and coumarin [39], undergo a photoinduced reaction that leaves a highly polar carboxylic acid/carboxylate residue at the polymer chain. Thus, micellar self‐assemblies with the core formed by the hydrophobic block are unable to retain self‐assembly and the release of any physically entrapped
422 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
active can take place. Florescent Nile Red has been used to verify the controlled release of payloads.
Recently, the development of polymeric nanocarriers that are triggerable at the visible or the NIR wavelength range has been identified as a key step forward toward the realization of systems with relevant biomedical applications. In this sense, the photolysis of o‐nitrobenzyl moieties is possible via one‐photon UV absorption or two‐photon NIR absorption; however, the rate of release is slowed down in the latter case due to inefficient two‐photon absorption [15]. Micellar systems using coumarin with larger two‐photon absorption cross‐section can also be used as NIR light‐triggered systems due to disruption of micellar self‐ assemblies after photolysis [16]. Additionally, coumarins can dimerize by revers ible photo[2 + 2]cycloaddition activated by UV and visible light. The process affords stabilized micelles and controlled‐release capabilities by photoregulated micelle core cross‐linking–decross‐linking [40].
Azobenzene is one of the most popular photoswitches for light‐triggered applications. As the photoinduced process is reversible, micellar dissociation may be partially reverted. Additionally, azobenzenes with electron‐donor or electron‐acceptor groups enables the production of micelles that are sensitive to visible or NIR light [41]. Similarly to azobenzene, spiropyran can undergo revers ible photoisomerization, which may lead to the disruption and regeneration of polymer micelles [42]. Encapsulation, UV light stimulated release, and visible light stimulated re‐encapsulation by amphiphilic BC micelles have been demon strated using coumarin 102.
In the pursuit of multi‐stimuli responsive systems, Yang et al. have reported the synthesis of a poly(N‐isopropylacrylamide)‐b‐poly(2‐nitrobenzyl meth acrylate) BCs where the hydrophilic poly(N‐isopropylacrylamide) is responsive to temperature and the hydrophilic poly(2‐nitrobenzyl methacrylate exhibits photolabile groups. Micelles based in this BC exhibited release capabilities, which could be tuned in a two‐way manner by changing either the temperature or the irradiation conditions [43]. Light‐ and temperature‐response groups can be both introduced in the same hydrophobic poly(meth)acrylate block by copo lymerization of suitable monomers, such as N‐isopropyl acrylamide [44, 45], or post‐polymerization functionalization of a preformed thermoresponsive hydro phobic block. Indeed, Chen et al. have decorated a PEG‐b‐poly(oligo(ethylene glycol) methacrylate) with DNQ moieties that converts into 3‐indenecarboxylic acid upon exposure to UV light [46]. The biocompatibility of these micelles was evaluated on HepG2 and HUVEC cell cultures and controlled‐release proper ties were confirmed using the hydrophobic model coumarin 102. An analogous system was reported by Li et  al. which uses poly(dimethylaminoethyl meth acrylate) (PDMAEMA), a temperature‐ and pH‐responsive polymer, as a hydro philic block [47]. Multi‐stimuli responsive micelles capable of encapsulation release coumarin 102 under both UV and NIR light stimulation were obtained through the partial functionalization of the PDMAEMA block with DNQ moieties. Cargo‐release was enhanced under the combined stimulation of pH and light. The vast majority of BCs micelles include one hydrophobic poly(meth)acrylate polymer chains in their structure, which is appropriate for proof‐of‐concept
42313.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release
studies. However, the lack of biodegradability significantly hampers any potential in vivo applications. This limitation is stimulating research to develop photoresponsive BC nanocarriers based on biodegradable polymers such as polycarbonates [48–50] or polypeptides [51–54].
Unlike micelles, vesicles are capable of transporting hydrophilic and hydro phobic cargo, either packaged inside the lumen or embedded within the vesi cle wall. In these systems, light‐responsive hydrophobic blocks that enable the regulation of the permeability and cargo‐release capabilities is an attractive strat egy [55]. Wang et al. reported a couple of studies of amphiphilic diblock copoly mer vesicles with a PEG shell and a spiropyran or an o‐nitrobenzyl‐ functionalized polymethacrylate‐based wall. Concurrent light‐triggered reactions at the polymer‐ forming wall enabled the release of both hydrophilic and hydrophobic actives. The release capabilities of the systems were also evaluated in vitro and in vivo [56, 57].

sections.heading: 13.3.2 Polymer Self‐Assemblies from Linear‐Dendritic and Branched BCs
sections.text:
Interest in linear‐dendritic block copolymers (LDBCs) arises from the combina tion of the easy synthesis and the excellent processability of conventional linear polymers with the well‐defined branched structure of dendrons, which is charac terized by a precise and high number of peripheral ending groups [58]. Their unique macromolecular architecture and the derived hierarchical self‐assembly properties are responsible for them gaining significant interest in bionanotech nology, e.g. drug or gene delivery [59–63]. Furthermore, the chemical modifica tion of the peripheral groups allows to introduce the exact number of functional moieties, which facilitates providing functional properties to the resulting mate rials. Limitations in the development of these BCs arise from their challenging synthesis. However, the synthesis of functional LDBCs may be achieved via direct coupling of preformed blocks. This coupling strategy requires implemen tation in two complementary clickable groups, one at one end of the linear block (or both ends in dendritic‐linear‐dendritic BCs), and another at the focal point of the dendron [64].
Our group reported the synthesis of a series of amphiphilic LDBCs by coupling end‐functionalized alkyne PEGs to 2,2‐bis(hydroxymethyl)propionic acid (bis‐ MPA) dendrons of different generations. The dendrons were decorated with 4‐ cyanoazobenzene moieties at their periphery and an azide group at their focal point (see Figure 13.6). The amphiphilic LDBCs undergo self‐assembly in aque ous solution and micellar structures of different morphologies were obtained. These include nanofibers, sheet‐like micelles, and vesicles. It was shown that the self‐assembly behavior of the BCs was dictated, in part, by the hydrophobic/ hydrophilic balance (associated with the length of the PEG block and the genera tion number of the dendron) of the polymer. Light‐induced breakup of the vesi cles was only observed under somewhat high intensity light irradiation conditions [65]. The morphology and photoresponse of the self‐assemblies were later theo retically studied by Lin et al. using dissipative particle dynamics [66]. The authors concluded that the photoisomerization of azobenzenes arranged in the membrane
of the LDBC vesicles should lead to distortion and eventually the rupture of the membrane consequently increasing the permeation of the nanocapsules.
The theoretical studies of Lin et al. (vide supra) prompted the design of a new series of LDBCs based on 4‐alkoxyazobenzene peripheral moieties, which leads to a less intense packing of chromophores in the inner part of the membrane and  a higher modification of polarity by photoisomerization with respect to 4‐cyanoazobenzene analogues. The derived vesicles were then easily stimulated (λ = 365 nm, at 2.6 mW cm−2) and their application as light‐responsive nanocar riers was evaluated using both hydrophobic and hydrophilic fluorescent probes [67]. Furthermore, changes induced by light to the polymeric vesicles were mod ulated by tuning the functionalization of the periphery. For example, in one series of materials the decoration of the periphery of the dendron was achieved by using a combination of azobenzene moieties and linear aliphatic chains, toward tuning the membrane stability and the payload‐release capabilities of the self‐assemblies. In particular, vesicles with a content of around 50% of azoben zene peripheral units exhibited significant morphological changes when they were exposed to light and an almost immediate release of their cargo [68].
García‐Juan et al. described the preparation of dual responsive LDBCs com bining thermo‐ and light‐response. A thermoresponsive copolymethacrylate of
42513.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release
diethylene and oligoethyleneglycol was coupled to a bis‐MPA dendron contain ing 50% of 4‐alkoxyazobenzene moieties and aliphatic tails. The LDBC self‐ assembled into vesicles were able to encapsulate and release either hydrophobic or hydrophilic payloads under thermal or light stimulation [69]. Recently, Kalva and Ambade described a series of LDBCs equipped with an azobenzene moiety linking the two blocks of the BC. No light‐triggered cargo‐release properties were observed, as the changes before and after irradiation were too subtle to induce the disassembly of the micelle [70]. Nevertheless, the replacement of the azobenzene moiety with an o‐nitrobenzyl linker enabled the preparation of nanocarriers that were capable of encapsulating and releasing cargo in response to pH changes [71]. Although most of the reported examples of photoresponsive LDBCs contain azobenzenes moieties, Goodwin et al. described the preparation of micellar systems based on a PEG‐dendron BC (as in Figure  13.6) having peripheral DNQ moieties. The photoresponse of the DNQ moieties (vide supra) was associated with the release of hydrophobic payloads including fluorescent probes. Furthermore, these systems exhibited low cytotoxicity when compared with linear analogues [72, 73]. Sun et  al. described a PEG‐poly(amidoamine) LDBC having DNQ peripheral moieties. The authors described the cell inter nalization process of the LDBC micelles carrying encapsulated DOX. Triggered DOX release and cytotoxicity under NIR light irradiation using HeLa cells was demonstrated [74]. The regular branched structure of dendrons was also exploited by Sun et  al. to prepare two‐photon‐sensitive (808 nm) and sugar‐ targeting nanocarriers from a poly(amidoamine) dendron having DNQ‐ended linear oligo(ε‐caprolactone) peripheral groups and a hydrophilic sugar moiety at the focal point. Light‐triggered release of encapsulated DOX and specific bind ing with lectins were demonstrated [75]. They also extended this approach to the preparation of photoresponsive nanocarriers based on Janus codendrimers dec orated with DNQ (hydrophobic dendron block) and lactose moieties (hydro philic dendron block) [76]. Sugar‐coated micelles prepared from these codendrimers showed binding with RCA120 lectin and the DOX encapsulated micelles exhibited a NIR‐triggered drug release and cytotoxicity similar to free DOX. Namezi and Gillies also demonstrated the UV‐triggered release of hydro phobic and hydrophilic payloads on Janus amphiphiles having a branched block with PEG linear chains combined with a photodegradable bis(MPA) dendron containing o‐nitrobenzyl esters [77].
Polydispersed hyperbranched polymers share several of the advantageous properties of monodispersed dendrimers but their preparation is significantly less demanding, which has certainly incentivized research in this type of materi als [78]. Hyperbranched polymers can function as unimolecular micelles (vide infra) but also via multimolecular self‐assemblies as amphiphilic BCs [79, 80]. Photocontrolled response can easily be achieved through the appropriate modi fication of end groups. Accordingly, amphiphilic systems were prepared by grafting either DNQ or spiropyran light‐sensitive motifs to the peripheral groups of a polyphosphate‐based hyperbranched polymer. Encap sulation and light‐triggered release were verified using hydrophobic Nile Red and coumarin 102 models [81, 82]. Alternative, hyperbranched polyglycerols with a spiropyran moiety at the focal point also form biocompatible micelles, which under UV
426 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
illumination were able to release pyrene [83]. Mo et al. prepared hybrid struc tures consisting on hydrophilic hyperbranched poly(oligo(ethylene glycol) methyl ether acrylate) with polycaprolactone linear arms grafted at photocleav age o‐nitrobenzyl branching points. Light‐induced degradation of the polymer hybrid was accompanied by the release of Nile Red from aqueous self‐assem blies [84].
Recent advances in polymer chemistry based on combining controlled polymerization methods with click chemistries have opened endless possibili ties to design sophisticated polymers with precisely controlled architectures and tailored functionalities. Thus, BCs have been complemented by new amphiphilic polymer architectures, including star branched polymers. These contain three or more polymer chains emanating from a central core and their globular shape, with multiple chain ends, is attractive for drug delivery applica tions although applicability has been scarcely evaluated in vivo [85–88]. Depending on the length of the arms, star polymers may be seen as unimolecu lar containers or, more frequently, via self‐assembly, as amphiphilic BCs with low micellar concentrations and small morphological changes. Amongst them, miktoarm polymers are asymmetric star polymers including two or more types of arms species with different chemical composition and/or molecular weights. This heteroarm segmented architecture constitutes an excellent platform to combine hydrophobic, hydrophilic and light‐responsive linear blocks for the development of novel polymeric nanocarriers. Several examples of photore sponsive miktoarm azobenzene based polymers have been reported to date, and encapsulation and release of payloads from these systems have been dem onstrated. Amphiphilic photoresponsive miktoarm polymers of A3B type were described by Blasco et  al. consisting of three hydrophilic PEG arms and one azobenzene polymethacrylate arm (Figure  13.7). Polymer with adjusted arm lengths formed vesicles with encapsulating and UV‐triggered releasing proper ties for both hydrophobic and hydrophilic fluorescent probes [89]. Replacing PEG arms by temperature‐sensitive poly(N,N‐diethylacrylamide) ones, dual thermo‐ and photoresponsive micelles were produced where only photoi somerization of azobenzene stimulated the release of encapsulated Nile Red [90]. ABC miktoarm micelles with dual thermo‐ and photoresponse due to the
42713.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release
combination of PEG, poly(N‐isopropylacrylamide) and poly(o‐nitrobenzy lacrylate) where used to encapsulate Nile Red. Cargo molecules were released rapidly upon UV light irradiation [91].

sections.heading: 13.3.3 Polymer Self‐Assemblies from Supramolecular BCs
sections.text:
During last decades, the principles of supramolecular chemistry have been progressively combined with polymer chemistry broadening the scope for new chemically diverse polymers with controlled architectures. Following a “supra molecular synthetic approach,” which in many instances exhibits key features to achieve versatility, can expedite the discovery of novel macromolecular architec tures. Indeed, amphiphilic supramolecular di‐ or tri‐block copolymers can be readily assembled by connecting individual blocks through specific noncovalent interactions (end‐to‐end connection, for example), combining the reversibility and tunability of supramolecular materials with the intrinsic properties of poly mer chains [92]. Indeed, the incorporation of the adequate functionality either at the focal point or at some middle point of one of the individual blocks will result in systems with light responsive properties [93]. For these purposes, a wide vari ety of supramolecular interactions have been developed, which include host– guest interactions, hydrogen bonding, π–π stacking, and electrostatic pairing. The choice of supramolecular binding motif is conditioned by the stability of the noncovalent interaction in aqueous media, which is key requisite if applications in aqueous media are pursued [94]. In spite of this, only a limited number of studies have reported supramolecular micelles with encapsulating and light‐trig gered cargo‐release properties.
Regarding host–guest systems, cyclodextrins (CDs) have been widely used as host molecules due to their wide availability and low toxicity. They are macrocy clic oligosaccharides with a toroidal molecular shape consisting of a hydrophilic exterior and a hydrophobic internal cavity that can form inclusion complexes with different guest molecules in aqueous media [95]. The molecular recogni tion between CDs and azobenzenes has been employed for the construction of photoresponsive amphiphilic BC self‐assemblies. A CD‐azobenzene host–guest complex can serve as a linker to connect two segments, one hydrophobic and one hydrophilic, of a BC [96]. In the vast majority of CD systems, the trans‐ azobenzene is capable of forming stable host–guest complexes, while the cis‐ azobenzene is too bulky and does not fit inside the hydrophobic cavity of CDs. Thus, the reversible coupling of individual segments of a BC can be easily regu lated by alternating UV and visible light irradiation. The preparation of amphi philic linear– linear BCs has been realized by combining azobenzene and α‐CD terminated polymer chains (hydrophilic poly(acrylic acid) and hydrophobic poly(caprolactone)) as described by Yan et al. [97]. In water, this supramolecular copolymer forms tubular structures that exhibit reversible assembly properties on account of the light‐controlled host‐guest “bond,” which connects the two blocks. The photoregulated assembly/disassembly properties imparted con trolled delivery capabilities to the micellar system. Other alternative amphiphilic macromolecular species based on the host–guest recognition properties of azobenzenes and CDs include amphiphilic LDBCs [98, 99] linear‐star [100],
428 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
multiarm dendrimers [101], Janus hyperbranched [102], and hyperbranched– linear‐hyperbranched polymers [103]. Although the self‐assembling properties of these systems and their morphological transformations in response to light have been investigated in depth, clear evidence of light‐controlled cargo‐release properties are limited. Yao et al. have reported the preparation of a series of mik toarm AB2 supramolecular polymers consisting of PEG and poly(N‐ isopropylacrylamide) branches; with either one or two azobenzene‐CD host–guest complexes serving as linking motifs [104]. The miktoarm polymer undergoes micellization in aqueous media and the resulting micelles exhibit dual thermo‐ and light‐responsive properties and enable the controlled delivery of DOX.
CDs have also been used to “mask” specific hydrophobic residues of polymer chains, which can alter the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance of a system in a reversible fashion. Jin et al. have described the preparation of an azobenzene BC consisting of a PEG hydrophilic block and a hydrophobic poly(meth)acrylate car rying side‐chain azobenzene moieties (6 in Figure 13.8) [105]. Such a polymer undergoes micellization in aqueous media on account of the amphiphilic nature of the polymer, which results in the formation of stable vesicles. In the presence of CD the vesicles are disassembled as the macrocycle binds to the trans‐azobenzene moieties rendering the BC more hydrophilic. Upon exposure to UV light, the host–guest complexes fall apart and “unmask” the relatively hydrophobic azobenzene residues of the BC (Figure 13.8). This process partially restores the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance of the system and the vesicles regenerate. Wang et al. followed an analogous strategy by using a double hydrophobic copol ymer [106]. In this case, the micelles were formed in the presence of β‐CD and dissociated upon exposure to UV light. The authors demonstrated reversible self‐assembly by alternating UV and visible light although no encapsulation capabilities were reported.
Supramolecular BCs based on specific hydrogen‐bonding pairs linking two or more blocks have been investigated in the past by using, typically, apolar organic
solvents [53]. Some of these systems can also undergo aqueous self‐assembly forming micelles and vesicles, which are pH‐responsive; although no drug‐ delivery light‐responsive systems have been reported to date. Light‐sensitive moieties may be readily attached to a polymer chain via noncovalent side‐chain functionalization reactions [107]. In one case, light‐sensitive nanospheres were produced by combining a poly(4‐vinylpyridine) polymer chain with a low molec ular weight carboxylic acid terminated azobenzene via hydrogen‐bonding inter actions [108, 109]. Multiple‐point hydrogen bonding motifs can establish much stronger interactions than single‐point hydrogen bonding motifs such as that of pyridine‐carboxylic acid, which are significantly weakened in aqueous media. In this regard, Concellón et al. used a 2,6‐diacylaminopyridine, a nucleobase ana logue, to impart light responsiveness to an amphiphilic BC (7 in Figure 13.9). The BC was composed of a PEG block and a polymethacrylate block with pendant 2,6‐diacylaminopyridine moieties, which were functionalized with thymine‐ terminated azobenzene moieties, via three‐point hydrogen bonding interactions. Depending on the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance of the BC, micelles and vesi cles were obtained in aqueous media. Encapsulation and light‐triggered cargo‐ release of model compounds were also demonstrated [110].

sections.heading: 13.3.4 Photoresponsive Polymer Capsules
sections.text:
In the previous sections, we have covered ways of producing polymeric encapsu lants (micelles and vesicles) from amphiphilic BCs. Alternatively, non‐ amphiphilic structures can also be assembled into colloidal capsules (a compartmentalized pod with a polymer membrane), through appropriate manufacturing methods. In  contrast to polymer vesicles (vide supra), which generally exhibit a bilayer
430 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
membrane formed by amphiphilic macromolecular species, capsules of a much wider range of materials can be fabricated.
The production of large millimeter‐size capsules is most frequently achieved through injection molding, which is a well‐established low‐cost technology [111]. Smaller microcapsules, with diameters ranging from tens of nanometers up to a few hundred microns, are prepared by several methods including pan spray drying, pan coating, centrifugal extrusion, emulsion‐based methods, distil lation–precipitation polymerization, template‐based polymerization, and layer‐ by‐layer approaches [112]. In general, each method has advantages for specific applications, which depend on a variety of characteristics of a capsule including size, shape, shell wall thickness, permeability, and composition and mechanical stability of the shell wall. A number of review articles and books have been focused on the preparation of polymeric capsules, including light‐responsive systems [113–116]. Here, we present a few selected examples of photoresponsive capsules, for their preparation and mechanisms of actuation.
Light‐responsive capsule formation has been achieved by the electrostatic rec ognition of two oppositely charged polymers at the liquid–liquid interface in an emulsified system, or through the use of layer‐by‐layer methodologies. These capsules typically present a thin wall and are thus rather fragile. The stability of the shell wall can be enhanced if the membrane is a covalently cross‐linked net work. Such covalent capsules can be produced, for example, by means of in situ polymerization. Here, the reactive monomers are dissolved in an aqueous phase that is mixed with an immiscible solvent and subsequently emulsified. After emulsification, the monomers are polymerized to create a covalently cross‐linked shell. Cao et  al. reported the synthesis of a photodegradable polymer capsule system through the one‐pot free radical polymerization of N‐ isopropylacrylamide, methacrylic acid, and the photolabile 5‐(methacryloyloxy)‐2‐nitrobenzyl meth acrylate on dimethyldiethoxysilane oil‐in‐water emulsion templates, followed by the removal of the sacrificial core [117]. Upon exposure to UV light, the capsules degraded due to the selective photocleavage of the o‐nitrobenzyl ester linkers in the shell wall. Photocontrolled release of coumarin 102, as a model hydrophobic cargo, was also demonstrated. Alternatively to the free radical polymerization of small monomers and cross‐linkers, photoreactive groups may be directly embed ded in the shell‐forming material via covalent functionalization of a preformed polymer [118]. This is a relatively straightforward approach that enables the preparation of robust systems with a higher level of control over material composition and, more importantly, well‐defined photoresponsive properties. Indeed, such a method has enabled the production of capsules composed of pol yorganosiloxane NPs carrying nitrocinnamate residues [119]. The capsules were assembled through a water/oil/water emulsification process followed by the photocrosslinking of the nitrocinnamate groups. It was shown that the capsule content (CD, as a model guest molecule) can be released upon light irradiation. Layer‐by‐layer approach is another method for capsule preparation, which typi cally involves the use of metal oxide or polymer particles as template, and poly electrolytes as shell‐forming materials [120–123]. Park et al. prepared a series of microcapsules by coating polystyrene particles with alternating layers of nega
43113.3 Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies for Encapsulation and Release
tively charged poly(sodium 4‐styrenesulfonate) and positively charged poly(allylamie hydrochloride) carrying benzophenone moieties [124, 125]. After the coating process, the polymer layers are held together by electrostatic interac tions and the polystyrene core particle was removed by means of selective sol vent extraction, leaving behind a hollow compartmentalized capsule. With the capsules in hand, the kinetics of release of encapsulated rhodamine B were meas ured before and after UV light irradiation, and the photocontrol over release rates (i.e. permeability of rhodamine B through the shell) was demonstrated. It is worth noting that the photocrosslinking of benzophenone is not used as a release trigger but rather as a way to tune the rate of release. Azobenzene switches have also been exploited for light‐controlled permeability purposes. Tao et al. showed that azobenzene moieties, when incorporated into the shell wall of polyelectro lyte layer‐by‐layer capsules, altered the permeability values of the encapsulant exposed to light [126, 127]. In a recent study, Yi and Sukhorukov developed a layer‐by‐layer capsule system by sequential deposition of two polyelectrolytes, i.e. negatively charged azopolymer and positively charged poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride), on silicon dioxide microparticles [128]. Upon light exposure, the multilayer shell of these capsules underwent a structural reorganization driven by the preferential formation of azobenzene J aggregates. Such process, which is accompanied by the disruption of the cap sule wall, was shown to control the release of encapsulated bovine serum albu min. Bédard et al. reported the incorporation of meso‐tetrakis(4‐sulfonatophenyl) porphyrin into the shell wall of layer‐by‐layer capsules [129]. The capsules were disrupted by means of laser light irradiation (λ = 532 nm, at 70 mW cm−2) in the presence of an oxidizing agent, such as H2O2. Under these conditions, it has been suggested that the porphyrin residues have the capacity to generate reactive oxy gen species (ROS) in a process that disturbs the electrostatic interactions between the polymers holding the shell together and increases the permeability of the cap sule [130]. Photoreactive triphenylmethane leucohydroxide (TPML) is another photoreactive group that has been incorporated into the shell wall material of polyelectrolyte complex capsules [131]. In this case, the release rate of p‐toluene sulfonate from layer‐by‐layer capsules increased under UV light irradiation, a phenomenon which was associated with the photoinduced dissociation of the TPML residues. There exist other approaches to exert controlled release includ ing light‐induced changes of ionic strength [132], and the use of specific host– guest interactions [133], diazonium compounds [134], o‐nitrobenzyl derivatives [135], and coumarin‐functionalized polymers [136].
In recent years, the area of light‐regulated substance‐release has witnessed several transformational advances including the use of flow focusing devices for the preparation of hierarchically structured capsules (vide infra) and the devel opment of novel photocontrolled cascade chemical reactions. Gu et  al. have developed a system in which a protein, caspase‐3 in this case, was encapsulated in an enzymaticallydegradable polymeric capsule incorporating peptidic cross‐ linkers [137]. The light‐controlled substance‐release capabilities were associated with specific residues of the cross‐linkers. These residues were caged by photo labile groups, a feature that inhibited the polymer shell from degradation by the
caspase‐3 from within. The utility and robustness of the system was demon strated through the UV light controlled cytoplasmic delivery of caspase‐3 to HeLa cells. Another sophisticated approach has been demonstrated by the Herrmann laboratory where the encapsulation of photolabile 2‐oxoacetates derivatives in core–shell capsules allowed the light‐induced release of fragrances (Figure 13.10) [138]. On exposure to UV light (λ = 340–380 nm, at 3.1 mW cm−2) the encapsulated 2‐oxoacetates derivatives degraded to form the fragrances 2‐phenylacetaldehyde and (E)‐4‐(2,6,6‐trimethylcyclohex‐2‐en‐1‐yl)but‐3‐en‐2‐ one; and the gases CO and CO2 at rates that were sufficiently high to induce the breakup of the capsule.
Finally, the use of flow focusing devices for the preparation of core–shell microcapsules have allowed for a variety of liquids and actives to be encapsu lated, which were incompatible with other emulsification techniques [139]. Also, capsules with multiple release triggers, including light, can be produced in a straightforward manner [140–142]. This approach was followed by the Abell and Scherman laboratories where hydrogel microcapsules were produced by com bining, in the presence of the host molecule cucurbit[8]uril, a guest polymer anthracene‐functionalized hydroxyethyl cellulose, and a fluorinated surfactant [143]. The electrostatic attraction between the charged polymer and the sur factant enabled the formation of a supramolecular hydrogel capsule shell in a single emulsion. Additionally, stimuli‐responsive controlled molecular permea bility was possible on account of the dynamic nature of the interactions holding the hydrogel shell together, which could be selectively transformed into irrevers ible covalent interactions (photochemically dimerized anthracene residues) by UV light irradiation. In summary, significant progress has been made toward understanding the mechanisms underlying the formation of polymer capsules, and this insight is being translated to the modulation of controlled‐release, which shows great promise for the future applicability of this field.

sections.heading: 13.3.5 Photoresponsive Microgels and Nanogels
sections.text:
Microgels and nanogels are swollen cross‐linked polymeric particles that show a unique series of features. They exhibit a combination of the characteristics of colloidal particles (colloidal stability, high surface area, and control over parti cle size) with those associated with macroscopic hydrogels (three‐dimensional branched configuration, structural integrity, and fluid‐like transport proper ties) [144]. Although no clear connection between nomenclature (micro versus nano) and particle size has been established yet (the terms microgels and nano gels are often used interchangeably), particles with a size in the 20–200 nm are typically referred as nanogels. Regarding the preparation of microgels and nanogels, it is possible to distinguish between two main categories depending on whether the gel beads are produced in a single‐phase or multiphase hetero geneous systems (e.g. precipitation polymerization or microemulsion). The production method of choice is dictated by the potential application of the final system, which in many occasions is related to the controlled loading and release of compounds. Light‐controlled release has been proposed in the context of microgels and nanogels [145], and some representative examples are high lighted here. The photoinduced response of microgels and nanogels is predom inantly associated with irreversible transformations. Only a few examples of reversible reactions have been reported to date [146, 147]. Irreversible photoin duced degradation of nanogels has been achieved by exploiting the chemistry of o‐nitrobenzyl [148–150], and 7‐amino coumarin derivatives [151]. Nevertheless, only a few selected studies have demonstrated systems with substance‐release capabilities. Klinger and Landfester have reported the preparation of poly(2‐ hydroxyethyl methacrylate‐co‐ methacrylic acid) microgels with o‐nitrobenzyl‐ type photolabile linkers moieties [152]. The gel beads were successfully loaded with myoglobin, in a process assisted by the establishment of electrostatic interactions between the positively charged protein and the negatively charged polymer. In addition to the pH‐controlled properties of the system (associated with the carboxylic acid residues of the polymer network), light‐induced (UV light in the range of λ = 315–390 nm, at 17–60 mW cm−2) network degradation accompanied by substance‐release was demonstrated by inducing the photol ytic cleavage of the o‐nitrobenzyl cross‐linkers. A similar approach was fol lowed by Azagarsamy et al. for the encapsulation of photocontrolled (λ = 365 nm light, at 10 mW cm−2) release of alkaline phosphatase (as a model protein) from nanogels labeled with cell‐penetrating peptides [153]. These studies clearly demonstrated that biocompatible nanogels are capable of encapsulating pro teins, maintaining their activity and releasing proteins in response to light. The chemistry of o‐nitrobenzyl linkages has also been combined with orthogonal triggers, and nanogels which respond to temperature, pH, and UV light have recently been developed [154].
Zan et  al. have reported the introduction of NIR light dyes into polymeric nanogels, which exhibit controlled‐release based on the photothermal effect [155]. In this case, the nanogels were composed of two complementary poly mers: a side‐chain hydrophilic random terpolymer carrying adamantine residues and a β‐CD‐functionalized poly(amidoamine) dendrimer. The assembly of
434 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
the polymers into nanogels relied on the formation of host–guest interactions between the adamantine and the CD residues. The encapsulation of substances in these systems, which is concomitant to the nanogel formation, can happen directly in aqueous media. The simultaneous loading of indocyanine green (an NIR dye in tumor‐specific imaging [156], and photothermal applications) and the chemotherapy drug DOX were the basis to demonstrate the triggered DOX‐ release capabilities (via photothermal effect and host–guest complex dissocia tion) under NIR light irradiation (λ = 805 nm, at 1.5 W cm−2). Khatun et al. have developed an alternative system based also on the photothermal effect [157]. In this study, DOX‐functionalized graphene was embedded in a polymeric nanogel composed of disulfide‐cross‐linked hyaluronic acid. It was shown that the pho tothermal effect associated with the graphene enhanced the release of DOX from the nanogel at pH = 5.0–7.4 upon NIR light (λ = 670 nm, at 1.0 W cm−2) irradia tion. Additionally, combined thermo‐chemotherapy was investigated both in vitro and in vivo, and the controlled generation of heat leading to photoabla tion of cancer cells was demonstrated.

sections.heading: 13.3.6 Other Miscellaneous Photoresponsive Polymeric Encapsulants
sections.text:
In addition to the classical families of soft polymer encapsulants (capsules, BC micelles, nanogels, and microgels) reviewed in Sections 13.3.1–13.3.5, there exists a large miscellaneous collection of compartmentalized polymeric species that have been explored in the context of light‐controlled substance‐release [13, 158, 159]. These include core‐cross‐linked NPs, knedel‐like shell‐crosslinked NPs, uncrosslinked homopolymer‐based NPs, multiparticle crosslinked species and unimolecular systems, to name just a few. Given the wide variety of NP struc tures and compositions, rather than being exhaustive, we present some selected examples of a few recent and well‐referenced studies and associate them with mechanisms of actuation.
Light‐sensitive degradable polymers that can be triggered to degrade through multiple light‐sensitive groups along the polymer backbone have been broadly explored in NP formulation (see Figure 13.11). Pioneering work by the Almutairi laboratory was based on self‐immolative quinone‐methidine system 10 (Figure 13.11) [24]. The release of Nile Red, as a model cargo, from particles based on polymer 10 was observed upon light exposure (λ = 750 nm with ~100 fs pulse widths and 80 MHz repetition rate, at c. 2.6 W). Control experiments showed that no release occurs when the particles are protected from light expo sure or when the dye is encapsulated in poly(lactic‐co‐glycolic acid). Of those systems developed at the Almutairi laboratory [24, 25, 159–161], it is also worth highlighting 12 (Figure 13.11), which is a random terpolymer with sensitivity toward both UV–vis (λ  =  320–480 nm, at c. 100 mW cm−2) and NIR light (λ  =  800 nm, at c. 82.7 W cm−2), via two‐photon absorption [161]. NPs of 12 encapsulating Nile Red were successfully produced by an emulsification pro cess, and the fluorescence of the encapsulated Nile Red was monitored upon exposure to light. Fast and complete fluorescence quenching was observed when UV–vis light was employed, a phenomenon which was associated with
the  efficient degradation of the particles and release of the payload. The same effect was achieved with NIR light, at the expense of prolonging the irradiation time. Lv et  al. have evaluated the cargo‐release capabilities of polymeric NPs based on photodegradable polyurethane 13 (Figure 13.11) [162]. Additionally, light‐triggered (λ = 365 nm, at 11 mW cm−2) burst release of fluorescein diacetate and Tagalsin G in cells was also demonstrated. While the majority of light‐ triggerable polymeric NPs systems rely on the chemistry of o‐nitrobenzyl esters and their analogues, an alternative system based on benzoin derivatives has recently been reported by Englert et al. [163] (14 in Figure 13.11). Traditionally used as protecting groups [164], benzoins undergo a photochemical rearrange ment to yield 2‐phenylbenzofurans and, in polyester 14, serve as photolabile repeating units. Englert et al. formulated 14 as NPs and, as a proof‐of‐concept, the encapsulation and photoinduced release of Nile Red from the particles was demonstrated. It was shown that exposure times as short as 10 seconds were suf ficient to induce significant release. An additional system has been designed at the Liu laboratory, where photoactive polymer NPs were designed as gene deliv ery vectors [165]. In this case, nucleic acids (and, potentially, therapeutic DNA) can interact electrostatically the photoresponsive polymer in a process that results in the formation of stable NPs in aqueous media. As the polymer carries both photosensitizer moieties, which are capable of generating ROS upon light irradiation, and ROS‐sensitive linkers, the NPs degrade when exposed to light (white light, at 50 mW cm−2) and release the DNA cargo. Lin et al. have recently reported the development of hypoxia‐activated photoresponsive drug‐release system based on a nitroimidazole‐locked coumarin phototrigger [166]. In essence, the drug, etoposide, in this case, was locked by the phototrigger (cou marin), which was again locked by the hypoxia regulator (nitroimidazole resi due); and where the whole system was conceived as a cleavable linker between the drug and the polymer NP. In aerobic environments the nitroimidazole relaxes the photoexcited coumarin and effectively avoids any photoinduced
436 13 Light‐Controlled Encapsulation and Release Enabled by Photoresponsive Polymer Self‐Assemblies
bond cleavage. However, under hypoxic conditions (such as those found in solid tumors), the nitroimidazole residue is reduced to aminoimidazole, which allows the bond cleavage to take place. It is worth highlighting that the drug is not only physically entrapped in the NP (as in the vast majority of previous examples), but also covalently bound to the polymer carrier and the release of the drug is achieved by selectively cleaving the linker between the active and the encapsu lant via light irradiation.
Photoresponsive cinnamic acid residues have been proposed as stimuli‐ responsive cross‐linkers to control the stability and morphology of polymeric NPs. Shi et al. reported that the photoinduced [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of trans‐cinnamic acids, which is associated to reversible changes of NP size, could control cargo‐release too [167]. Tan et al. have recently reported the preparation of porous crosslinked polymeric NPs through a continuous assembly of poly mers strategy [168]. In this study, polymeric macromonomers carrying azoben zene, α‐CD and norbornene groups were embedded into mesoporous silica templates; and subsequently crosslinked by ring‐opening methathesis polymeri zation (irreversible bonds) and CD‐azobenzene host–guest inclusion complex formation (reversible bonds). The etching of the silica templates resulted in porous polymeric NP incorporating reversible crosslinkers, which displayed light‐induced burst‐release capabilities. UV light (λ  =  365 nm) was shown to induce burst release of encapsulated dextran, with c. 50% releases with one sec ond of irradiation. An alternative way of inducing cargo‐release from polymeric NPs is related to a specific photocontrolled switch of the hydrophobic/hydro philic balance of NP. Cui et  al. have prepared polymeric chitosan particles by mixing chitosan hydrochloride and 4‐oxo‐4‐(pyren‐4‐ylmethoxy) butanoic acid, which are capable of interacting through ionic pairing [169]. The attachment of the hydrophobic pyrene residues to chitosan yields a complex with a relatively high hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance, which self‐collapse in the form of NPs. Such species are sensitive to light irradiation on account of the photolabile pyr ene residues. Using Nile Red as a model cargo substance, the controlled‐release capabilities of the NPs were investigated by using UV (λ  =  365 nm, in power range of 50–1200 mW cm−2) and NIR (λ = 808 nm, at 140 mW cm−2). A similar strategy has been followed for the development of swellable NP exhibiting light‐ triggered release capabilities [170, 171].
In the past decade, a significant focus has been placed on unimolecular micelles, which comprise a distinct class of encapsulants. Contrary to cross‐ linked core–shell particles, unimolecular micelles exhibit a distinct core and shell that are covalently bound together [172, 173]. This feature, in the context of encapsulation, provides some potential advantages over multimolecular and crosslinked systems. Unimolecular micelles possess a well‐defined structure and are, therefore, monodisperse. Additionally, they provide many possibilities for specific functionalization to adapt to specific applications. In spite of the recent progress that has been made in the development of unimolecular micelles [174– 176] light‐responsive unimolecular encapsulants remain relatively unexplored. The inclusion of substances within photoresponsive single‐molecule dendritic structures has been reported in the past [177, 178], but no cargo‐release capabili ties were reported. Allcock and coworkers described the synthesis of unimolecular
43713.4 Conclusions
multiarm star amphiphilic BCs of the type star‐poly(methyl methacrylate)‐ poly(ethylene glycol)methyl ether methacrylate) [179]. These polymers were grown from a multivalent initiator with photolabile o‐nitrobenzyl linkers, follow ing an atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) procedure. The study showed that the polymers have the ability to undergo self‐collapse in aqueous media producing unimolecular micelles, which subsequently self‐assemble into large micellar species. The stability of the polymer micelles decreased signifi cantly after UV light irradiation (as shown by the increased critical aggregation concentration values), a phenomenon which was associated to the dissociation of the arms of the polymers from the core. The encapsulation and photoinduced‐ release of pyrene from the star BC micelles were studied in order to demonstrate the potential of the system. Johnson et al. have reported the loading of unimo lecular polymer brushes with drugs such as DOX and camptothecin [180, 181]. The actives were attached to the polymers via photocleavable nitrobenzyloxyl carbonyl linkers. The release of the drugs could be controlled by exposure to UV light. For instance, DOX and camptothecin‐loaded polymer brushes exhibited significantly higher toxicity levels to human cancer cells after photoinduced drug release. Despite these examples, light‐induced release from unimolecular poly meric carriers remains largely unexplored. We believe there are excellent oppor tunities in this area by combining, in a single species, macromolecular building blocks imparting both water‐solubility and high‐loading capacities, with light‐ responsive host–guest complexes [182, 183], which may provide protection to actives and triggered substance‐release capabilities.

sections.heading: 13.4 Conclusions
sections.text:
Light is a convenient “tool” for the isomerization of specific functional groups and the formation and cleavage of covalent bonds and supramolecular interac tions. In addition, it is orthogonal to other reaction conditions and may be applied in a remote fashion, which makes it an attractive trigger for the design of photoresponsive encapsulants, including polymeric vesicles, NPs, and nanogels. The light‐triggered release of actives from polymer carriers can be based, for example, on the photochemical decomposition of a capsule wall containing pho tolabile moieties (o‐nitrobenzyl derivatives), or on photoisomerizable moieties (such as spiropyrans or azobenzenes). A considerable amount of work has been done in the area of light‐responsive polymeric encapsulants, which has been complemented by the advent of powerful polymerization (ATRP, for example) and polymer derivatization techniques (i.e. Huisgen 1,3‐dipolar cycloaddition and thiol‐ene Michael addition). While the vast majority of systems are respon sive to UV light, the latest developments pursue actuation at increasingly longer wavelengths. This trend is driven by the shortcomings exhibited by UV light in the context of biologically relevant applications (limited tissue penetration and potential tissue damage associated with high energy inputs). There is currently a substantial interest to develop red‐shifted chromophores, which could be exploited by combining them with biocompatible polymers; and design visible and NIR‐light‐controlled encapsulants. Other relevant systems are based on

two‐photon excitation methodologies and photothermal effects. Although these techniques have not been discussed here in great detail, the increased pace of research activity is apparent and many exciting developments are expected in this area.

sections.heading: 14.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Proton transfer is one of the most fundamental processes in nature and numerous chemical, material, and biological processes are driven by proton transfer. For example, biological systems use proton gradient as an energy form to synthesize ATP for their biological functions; many organic reactions are catalyzed by Bronsted acids; and many materials have pH‐sensitive properties. Proton transfer is also involved in different aspects of polymer science relative to preparation, property, and processing. For example, cationic polymerizations can be initiated by proton transfer from a strong acid to a monomer. It has been reported that many polymers are sensitive to the pH (proton concentration) of the environment, and their properties including mechanical, geometrical, electric, optical, and magnetic properties, change with pH due to proton transfer between the polymers and the environment. Polymers with acid‐labile bonds have been studied for drug delivery; and photoinduced cationic polymerization using photoacid‐generators (PAGs) has been applied to photolithography.
An important research aims at using photoinduced proton transfer as a general mechanism to develop different types of photoresponsive polymers that reversibly alter their properties or release functional molecules upon irradiation. As described above, PAGs have been utilized to initiate cationic polymerization with great spatial control [1, 2]. Upon irradiation, these PAGs generate strong acids, which induce proton transfer and the consequent events. However, although some PAGs have reversible pathways in their mechanisms, they are generally irreversible. For the development of photoresponsive polymers, reversibility of the photoinduced property change is often required. It is desired that one can not only start (initiate) a process using light, but can also stop and/or reverse the process by turning off the light or applying a light with a different wavelength. The reversibility of the photoinduced property change implies a reversible proton transfer, which requires a reversible photoacid. The well‐ studied excited‐ state photoacids such as naphthol derivatives are reversible [3–5]. However, due
Photoresponsive Soft Materials Based on Reversible Proton Transfer

Our group discovered a new type of reversible photoacid that can be activated by visible light with moderate intensity [6–8]. This type of photoacid possesses a high‐acidic metastable state generated from a reversible photoreaction. Examples of the photoacids as well as their photoreactions are shown in Figure 14.1. The lifetime of the high‐acidic metastable state is long enough for accumulating a large proton concentration. The photoacids revert to the low‐acidic ground state and take back the protons once the irradiation is removed. The reversibility differentiates this type of photoacid from PAG, and the large photoinduced proton concentration differentiates it from the excited‐state photoacid.
Most of the proton transfer processes are driven by a high proton concentration. The lifetime of the photo‐generated acidic state that is needed to generate a practically useful proton concentration can be estimated by a simple model. A sample containing a photoacid is irradiated by a light beam with a photon flux of q. The irradiation area is S and the depth of the sample is L. The fraction of the photon absorbed is f and the quantum yield is ɸ. Under irradiation, the photoacid changes from its ground state G to the acidic state A. At the stationary state, the photoreaction rate is the same as the reverse reaction rate.
