In real conditions, f is often much smaller than 1. So even when a stronger light source is used and a concentration less than 1 mM is required, millisecond is still a reasonable estimate for the lower limit of the half‐ life. For metastable‐state photoacids, the half‐lives are often much longer than milliseconds. Therefore, they can generate a large proton concentration under moderate irradiation.
Since our report of the first metastable‐state photoacid (mPAH) in 2011, photo‐induced proton transfer using this type of photoacid has become a popular approach for the development of various photo‐controlled systems. Applications in energy conversion [9, 10], sensor [11, 12], polymerization [13], micro‐patterning [14, 15], nanomaterial [15–17], molecular machine [18], photochromic material [19–22], and biomedical [23, 24] areas have been reported by our group and other researchers. Regarding photoresponsive polymers, our group previously showed that a hydrogel of poly(acrylamide‐co‐acrylic acid) significantly reduced its volume under irradiation in the presence of a mPAH [6]. Protonation of the carboxylic anions by the photoacid decreased the hydrophilicity of the polymer and diminished the repulsion between carboxylic anions, which consequently lowered the water content in the hydrogel and reduced its volume. The Chumbimuni‐Torres’ group developed an ion‐selective membrane sensor consisting of mPAHs and a calcium ionophore in a plasticized poly(vinyl chloride) [11, 12]. Upon irradiation, the protons of the photoacids in the membrane diffused into the solution. Cations in the solution penetrated into the membrane to balance the charge and thus were detected by the ionophore. The sensor could be repeatedly used due to the reversibility of the photoacids.
In this chapter, the physicochemical properties of mPAHs in polymer matrix are described first, then three photoresponsive materials recently developed by our group will be presented. The photochromic materials are based on optical property change upon protonation; the fragrant‐releasing polymers described in the following section are based on acid‐catalyzed reaction; and the photo‐ controlled nanomaterials are based on noncovalent cross‐linking affected by protonation. These mechanisms together with the ion‐exchange mechanism mentioned above are commonly involved in the photoresponsive materials based on mPAHs.

sections.heading: 14.2 Photoactivity and Physicochemical Properties of Metastable‐State Photoacids in Polymer Films
sections.text:
Photoactivity and physicochemical properties of mPAHs in solutions have been studied before [25]. The mPAH 1 in Figure 14.1 is the most well studied mPAH. It has a protonated merocyanine (MEH) structure with an absorption maximum
452 14 Photoresponsive Soft Materials Based on Reversible Proton Transfer
(λmax) at 424 nm in water. Visible‐light irradiation induces a trans–cis isomerization to form cis‐MEH, which undergoes a nucleophilic reaction to form an acidic spiropyran (SPH) (Figure 14.1). The photoacidity is determined by the acidity of the SPH. The photoacidity of mPAH1 (pKa under irradiation) in methanol was determined to be 3.7 using methyl orange as an indicator, and in water it was estimated to be 3.2–1.7 [20]. The dark acidity (pKa in the dark) of mPAH1 was calculated to be 7.8 based on the pH of an aqueous solution [6]. However, the effective pKa, which includes the effect of the equilibrium between MEH and SPH, must be measured with pH buffers. Experiment showed that the effective dark pKa of mPAH1 is lower than 7.4 [8]. The quantum yield of the photoreaction in DMSO was measured to be as high as 0.37 [25].
The photoreaction is reversible and the metastable SP form reverts back to the MEH form after recombining with the proton it releases. The reverse reaction of mPAH1 in solutions is a second order reaction, which indicates that the rate‐ limiting step involves recombination of SP and proton [25]. The rate constants in water, ethanol, and DMSO are 73, 1.6, and 0.034 M−1 s−1, respectively. The trend can be better explained by the hydrogen‐bond donor acidity, which is related to the ability of the solvents to transfer the proton to SP. The reverse reactions of mPAH1 in organic solvent and polymers are slow. Several mPAHs with faster reverse reaction have been developed. For example, mPAH 2 (Figure 14.2) with a methoxy group on the phenolic moiety showed much faster reverse reaction rate than mPAH1 in solutions [26]. In this work, mPAH2 in polymer films was studied to understand the behaviors of metastable‐state photoacid in polymer matrix [27].
Thin films of mPAH2 were prepared by spin casting solutions of mPAH2 and poly(hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (PHEMA) on glass substrates. PHEMA contains hydroxyl groups on flexible side chains, which mimic the environment of an alcohol and may assist proton transfer in the polymer. The weight ratio of the photoacid to PHEMA was 2.5%. After the solvent was completely removed by baking on a hot plate and then in vacuum, the films were very stable under ambient conditions and showed essentially the same photochemical properties after half a year. The photoreaction of mPAH2 in the polymer was monitored by UV– Vis spectroscopy. To monitor the UV–Vis absorption during the irradiation, polymer film on a glass substrate was kept at a tilted position, and the irradiation was perpendicular to the detecting beam. The light source was a 470 nm LED with a photon flux about 900 μmol m2 s−1 (23 mW cm−2). UV–Vis spectra were collected every six seconds during irradiation (Figure 14.2).
The MEH form of mPAH2 has an absorption maximum (λmax) at 466 nm in the polymer film. As shown in Figure 14.2, upon irradiation, absorbance of MEH rapidly decreased in the first six seconds. Then the reduction of the absorbance quickly slowed down. After two minutes, the absorbance was reduced to about 66% of the original level. Although the photoreaction is formally a unimolecular reaction, the data obtained here cannot be fit to a first order kinetic equation. The rate of the reverse reaction must be comparable to that of the photoreaction. The process is further complicated by the slow proton diffusion in the polymer. Proton diffuses much slower in a polymer than in a protic solution. Upon irradiation, a local concentration of proton was built up around the photoacids. Previous work showed that the rate‐limiting step of the reverse reaction is the recombina-
tion of SP and H+ [25]. In polymer, the concentration of the photoacid is high. In fact, 2.5 wt% is equal to approximately 60 mM as compared to ~0.5 mM commonly used for solution study. A high concentration of the photoacid resulted in a high concentration of SP and H+ at the late stage of the photoreaction, which leads to a fast reverse reaction and slow overall reaction. In addition, the local concentration due to slow diffusion in polymer could be higher or lower than the average value, resulting in complicated kinetics.
The reverse reaction was studied by monitoring the recovery of the absorbance at 466 nm after irradiation. A rapid increase of the absorbance was observed within the first 20 minutes and the rate slowed down with time (Figure  14.3). Unlike the reverse reaction in solutions, the data could not be fitted into either a first order or a second order rate equation. We also tried to fit only the data in the first 20 minutes to first and second order rate equations and did not succeed. Figure 14.3 shows that, 59% of the MEH form recovered after 20 minutes, and it took 180 minutes for 90% recovery. UV irradiation (254 and 300 nm) did not increase the reverse reaction rate.
The reversibility of the photoacid in polymer film was tested by repeated exposure to 470 nm irradiation. For each cycle, the sample was irradiated for five minutes and then kept in the dark for 10 minutes. As shown in Figure 14.4, ~80% of the photoacid reacted after each irradiation, and ~30% recovered after 10 minutes due to the slow reverse reaction. After the tenth irradiation, the sample was kept in the dark for 24 hours, 95% of MEH recovered showing good
photostability. Slow proton diffusion in the polymer film is one of the major reasons for the slow reverse reactions. Recombination with proton is needed for the reverse reaction. Although the initial rate for the reverse reaction could be fast due to high local proton concentration, the overall rate is slow because the protons that have diffused in the polymer cannot move back fast.
For many applications related to photoswitching, a fast reverse process is required. In order to enhance the reverse reaction rate, ammonium trifluoromethanesulfonate (ATFMS) was introduced. ATFMS has been used as a cathode additive in fuel cell systems to improve the proton conductance [28]. Therefore, 5 wt% of ATFMS was added to a polymer film and the film was tested by 100 cycles of three‐minute irradiation and five minutes in the dark per cycle (Figure 14.5). About 60% recovery was observed in 5 minutes compared to ~30% recovery in 10 minutes for the films without ATFMS. After the film was tested for 50 cycles, it was kept in the dark overnight (~16 hours), at which point 92% of MEH was recovered. Then the next 50 cycles were performed. After 100 cycles, the sample was kept in the dark for 16 hours, and 90% of MEH recovered.

sections.heading: 14.3 Photochromic Materials Based on Photoinduced Proton Transfer
sections.text:
Protonation of a molecule can significantly alter its electronic structure and lead to changes in electronic and optical properties. Therefore, photoresponsive electronic and optical materials can be developed using metastable‐state photoacids [19–22, 29]. Photochromic materials that change their colors upon irradiation have been studied for decades. Prior photochromic materials are based on molecules that reversibly change their structures upon irradiation [30, 31]. Common photochromic molecules such as SPHs, diaryethenes, and azobenzenes have colorless or light colored forms that respond to UV light and change to colorful
456 14 Photoresponsive Soft Materials Based on Reversible Proton Transfer
forms [32–36]. Some molecules show negative photochromic property. They change from colorful forms to colorless forms under visible light [37–39]. Our group has developed a new type of photochromic material based on reversible proton transfer using metastable‐state photoacids.
In this work, photochromic materials were prepared by mixing mPAHs with acidochromic dyes in solutions, hydrogels, and polymers [19, 20]. Acidochromic dyes are the molecules that changes colors upon protonation. Under irradiation, the dye is protonated by the mPAH, and consequently changes its color. In the absence of the activating light, the photoacid returns to the low acidity state, takes back the proton from the dye, and the color changes back. Various color changes and the desirable stimulating wavelengths can be achieved by choosing different acidochromic dyes and photoacids.
MPAH1 was mixed with the acidochromic dye AD1, which has a pKa of ~5 and changes from yellow to blue upon protonation (Figure 14.6). Blue and yellow are complementary colors, and have maximum color contrast. The photochromic behavior was first studied in solution. An ethanol solution of MPAH1 and AD1 quickly changed from yellow to blue upon irradiation (470 nm) in about two minutes. Before irradiation, UV–Vis spectrum showed a strong absorption at 440 nm, which is an overlap of the absorptions of both the mPAH and the dye. After irradiation, this absorption decreased and an absorption at 604 nm appeared due to the formation of the protonated dye. Once the light was removed, the blue solution changed back to yellow in about an hour. Thin films of polycaprolactone loaded with MPAH1 and AD1 were prepared by spin casting (Figure 14.7). The loading of MPAH1 and AD are both 5 wt%. In addition, 5 wt% of triethylene glycol was added to improve proton transfer in the polymer. The greenish yellow thin film changed to greenish blue under irradiation. UV–Vis spectra of the thin
film showed the decrease of absorption at 420 nm, and increase of the absorption at 590 nm. After irradiation, the UV–Vis spectrum changed back to the one before irradiation and so was the color of the film in about 10 hours. Multiple acidochromic dyes can be used together to achieve the desirable color change. For example, a hydrogel that changes from green to red upon irradiation was made by loading mPAH1, bromocresol green, and naphthyl red to a polyacrylamide hydrogel [19].
Different mPAHs can be used to tune the color, stimulating wavelength, reverse rate, etc. MPAH3 (Figure 14.8) was developed to increase the stimulating wavelength. The carbazole on the phenol side functions as a strong electron donating group. The resultant push–pull electronic configuration leads to a long‐wavelength absorption with a λmax at 538 nm in ethanol. A solution of mPAH3 and bromocresol green reversibly changed from brown to yellow under 525 nm yellow light. The visual effect is interesting since the color is darker in a darker condition and lighter/warmer in a lighter condition. It may be used for developing novel camouflage materials that change the darkness of their colors according to the environmental lighting condition.
Compared to mPAH1, the TCF‐type mPAH4 (Figure 14.9) possesses a faster reverse reaction rate and a lower dark acidity [20]. The former is desirable for fast recovery of the original color in the dark, and the latter allows the photoacid to pair with the acidochromic dyes with relatively high basicity. PHEMA films loaded with mPAH4 and different indicators including AD1, Congo red [pKa (H2O) = 4.1], Bromocreso green sodium salt [pKa (H2O) = 4.7], and neutral red [pKa (H2O) = 6.7] showed photochromic behavior under irradiation (Figure 14.9). The thin films changed color quickly under sunlight. Even indoor light can slowly change the color. The reverse reaction of mPAH4 is about 104 times faster than
45914.4 Photo‐Controlled Fragrant‐Releasing Polymer Based on Acid‐Catalyzed Hydrolysis
that of mPAH1 in methanol. However, the reverse reaction is relatively slow in a polymer film. A PHEMA film containing 3 wt% of mPAH4 and 1 wt% of AD1 changed from yellow to green under 470 nm irradiation. It took about an hour for the color to change back to yellow in the dark. UV–Vis spectrum showed that ~85% of the absorbance recovered in one hour after irradiation. Heating can accelerate the color change. An irradiated film on a hot plate that was set to 80 °C changed the color back to yellow in one minute.

sections.heading: 14.4 Photo‐Controlled Fragrant‐Releasing Polymer Based on Acid‐Catalyzed Hydrolysis
sections.text:
Photo‐controlled release of functional molecules has many applications in biomedical and material areas. Prior research mainly focused on grafting functional molecules via photo‐labile linkage or caging functional molecules in a photosensitive polymeric or inorganic matrix. Many of these systems required UV irradiation, which could damage the materials or bio‐tissues. Our group developed a new approach to release functional molecules with light, which is based on acid‐ catalyzed hydrolysis using mPAHs [26].
In this work, anisaldehyde, which is a commonly used fragrant molecule, is linked onto a diol‐grafted poly(vinyl phenol) (P1) via an acetal group (P2) (Figure 14.10). The acetal group is thermally stable in neutral conditions, but easily hydrolyzed under mild acidic conditions. P2 and mPAH1 were dissolved in deuterated acetone and water (4 : 1). The concentration of P2 was 6.6 mg ml−1, which was 8.3 mM in terms of the acetal unit. The concentration of mPAH1 was 1.0 mM. The use of deuterated solvents allowed us to study the release of anisaldehyde using NMR spectroscopy. Upon irradiation with 470 nm LED, the NMR showed the emergence of new peaks corresponding to free anisaldehyde, indicating the release of anisaldehyde from the polymer. However, when the light was turned off, the anisaldehyde peaks kept increasing, indicating that the acidity in the solution was still high enough to catalyze the hydrolysis of the acetal group. In fact, NMR also showed that the photoacid was still in the acidic state due to its slow reverse reaction.
As described in the previous sections, mPAH2 possesses a much faster reverse reaction than does mPAH1. In the 4 : 1 mixture of acetone and water, the rate constants of the second order reverse reactions of mPAH1 and mPAH2 are 3.5 and 190 M−1 s−1, respectively. The reverse reaction of mPAH2 is 50 times faster than that of mPAH1. As described above, this type of mPAH reverses faster in water than in organic solvents. Therefore, we increased the amount of water in the solvent mixture. The reverse reaction rate of mPAH2 in a 2 : 1 mixture of acetone and water was measured to be 832 M−1 s−1. Ideally, an aqueous solution would maximize the reverse reaction rate. However, the content of water in the solvent is limited by the solubility of the polymer.
MPAH2 and P2 in 2 : 1 deuterated acetone and water were studied by NMR. NMR spectra were taken after every five minutes of irradiation (Figure 14.11).
Results showed that the percentage of the released anisaldehyde increased linearly with irradiation time (Figure 14.12). After the light was turned off, the peaks of anisaldehyde did not increase with time, indicating that the release stopped immediately. No increase of the anisaldehyde peaks was observed even after the sample was kept overnight in the dark. In addition, peaks of mPAH2 was the same in all of the NMR spectra since the mPAH2 already changed back to the low acidity form before NMR was taken.
These results indicate that the release of the fragrance can be effectively controlled by turning on and off the irradiation. It is worth mentioning that the polymer carrier P1 are re‐obtained after release of all the anisaldehyde, and the photoacids are reversible. They may be recycled to reduce the cost of the material. Although the method described here can only be applied to aldehydes and ketones, other types of functional molecules such as alcohols and amines may also be released by acid‐catalyzed cleavage reactions using similar systems. The application may also be extended to drug delivery, etc.
462 14 Photoresponsive Soft Materials Based on Reversible Proton Transfer

sections.heading: 14.5 Photo‐Controlled Reversible Dissolution/ Formation of Polymer Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Stimulus‐responsive polymer nanoparticles are polymer nanoparticles that respond to external stimuli, for example, light, pH, temperature, ionic strength, and electric field [40]. Among these stimulating methods, photo‐irradiation, especially visible‐light irradiation, is a convenient method to alter the properties of polymers. Polymer nanoparticles are often prepared by polymerization, precipitation, or cross‐linking in a nanoconfined environment. Cross‐linking of preformed polymers is commonly used to prepare stable polymer nanoparticles. Noncovalent cross‐linking could be more sensitive to a stimulus than covalent bonding. In this work, we demonstrated that ionic and hydrogen bond cross‐ linking can be controlled by photoinduced protonation using mPAHs, which led to a polymer nanoparticle that dissolved and reformed under light and in the dark respectively [16].
The polymer nanoparticles used in this study were prepared by cross‐linking poly(methylacrylate‐co‐acrylic acid) (PMA‐co‐PAA) with a small amount of poly(4‐vinylpyridine) (PVPy) in methanol. The molar ratio between MA and AA in PMA‐co‐PAA was 4 : 1. The carboxylic group on PMA‐co‐PAA can form a hydrogen bond and an ionic bond with the pyridyl group on PVPy. Therefore, PVPy acted as a noncovalent cross‐linker and only a small amount of PVPy was needed. The molar ratio of the pyridyl units on PVPy to the carboxylic units on PMA‐co‐PAA was 0.15 : 1. Addition of a higher ratio of PVPy caused quick precipitation of the cross‐linked polymer. The nanoparticle suspension was stable at room temperature over days due to the negative charges of the carboxylic groups on the surface.
The noncovalent cross‐linking between the two polymers can be broken by protonation of the carboxylic or pyridyl group. In either case, the two units cannot form an ionic or a hydrogen bond between one other (Figure 14.13). MPAH1 was added to the nanoparticle suspension to control the cross‐linking with light. Under 470 nm LED, the cloudy suspension became transparent (Figure 14.14). The cross‐linking was broken by the proton generated from mPAH1, and the two non‐cross‐linked polymers were both dissolved in methanol. When the light was turned off, the high‐acidic state of mPAH 1 reversed back to a low‐acidic state and took back the proton. The cross‐linking between the two polymers formed again and so did the nanoparticle.
The size and distribution of the polymer nanoparticle were studied using a dynamic light scattering (DLS) particle size analyzer. The average size of the freshly prepared nanoparticles was 320 nm and the polydispersity index (PDI) was 0.358. After being irradiated for three minutes, the average size of the particles decreased to 20 nm and the PDI was 0.381 (Figure 14.15). The solution looked transparent. Three hours after irradiation, the polymer nanoparticles formed again and the average size was 244 nm with a PDI of 0.329. After irradiation, the nanoparticles dissolved and two polymers were evenly distributed in the solution before the nanoparticles formed again. Therefore, the reformed polymer nanoparticles became more uniform and had lower PDI.
The size of the nanoparticle was further confirmed by AFM (Figure  14.14) and TEM.
The dissolution and formation cycle of the nanoparticles’ suspension were studied by measuring the transmittance of the mixture using UV–Vis spectroscopy. The transmittance of a suspension prepared as described above was collected after the sample was repeatedly irradiated for three minutes and kept in the dark for two hours (Figure 14.16). Transmittance at 580 nm was monitored since mPAH1 does not absorb at this wavelength. The transmittance of the solution after irradiation was about 80%. After the irradiated sample was kept in the dark for two hours, the transmittance reduced to ~22% due to the reformation of the nanoparticles. The cycle could be repeated for many times (Figure 14.16). The material described here could be used for different applications. One
potential application is as an interlayer material that is transparent during daytime and translucent during night for privacy or temperature control. In fact, we found that sunlight is strong enough to induce the photoreaction effectively. Other applications, e.g. reversible patterning and drug delivery could also be explored.

sections.heading: 14.6 Conclusion
sections.text:
Photoinduced protonation is becoming a general approach toward different types of photoresponsive polymers. Reversible protonation of polymers can be controlled by visible light using metastable‐state photoacids. This approach has shown great potential and novel photochromic materials, fragrant‐releasing polymers, photoresponsive nanoparticles, volume change hydrogels, ionic sensors, etc. have been developed in the past years. Other types of photoreponsive materials may also be explored in the future. As described earlier, photoinduced protonation can affect hydrogen bonding and ionic bonding. Polymers with strong hydrogen and/or ionic bonding may show photomechanical behavior in the presence of a metastable‐state photoacid. Protonation can not only affect the optical properties but also the electronic properties. Protonated polyaniline possesses high conductivity while non‐protonated polyaniline is an insulator. Therefore, paring polyaniline with metastable‐state photoacids could lead to photoswitchable conducting materials. However, polyaniline has very high basicity and thus a photoacid with very low dark acidity is needed. Photoacids such as mPAH1 protonate polyaniline without irradiation.
Challenges have emerged during the study of this type of photoresponsive materials in the past years. Proton transfer in polymers is often slow, which affects the photosensitivity and photoswitching rate. Development of novel neutral polymers with relatively fast proton diffusion rate is important for improving the performance of the photoreponsive materials. Covalently grafting mPAHs onto polymers could improve their compatibility with polymers and avoid leakage. More importantly, photoacid polymers could generate a localized proton concentration that is much higher than that of the environment. Given
466 14 Photoresponsive Soft Materials Based on Reversible Proton Transfer
that biological systems are often in pH buffers, the capability of generating a localized pH change could have important implications for many biological applications. An effective method for synthesizing polymers covalently linked with metastable‐state photoacids and demonstration of photogenerated local pH change has not been reported. Such polymeric soft materials are expected to display promising properties that would be interesting for fundamental studies and technological applications and beyond. There remains a lot to understand and more to do in this enabling and emerging frontier.
